headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ALCO STANDARD CORP. Valley Forge, Pa., appointed Robert M. Kearns 2d senior vice president and chief financial officer, and David M. Gadra senior vice president and chief information officer.    BAY NETWORKS INC., Santa Clara, Calif., said it had hired David A. Shrigley from Intel Corp. to lead its sales and marketing program as executive vice president for sales, service and marketing.     MEREDITH CORP., Des Moines, named its president, William T. Kerr, as chief executive, succeeding Jack D. Rehm, who will continue as chairman. Mr. Kerr will continue as president and assume the chief executive post Jan. 1.        UNITED ARTISTS PICTURES, Santa Monica, Calif., a unit of the Tracinda Corp., named Lindsay Doran president, succeeding John Calley, who had resigned to head Sony Corp.'s Sony Pictures Entertainment subsidiary.

headline: A Hint of an Adieu From the U.S. Envoy Has Paris Guessing
abstract: US Amb to France Pamela Harriman, 76, has hinted that she might resign and return to Washington next year (M)

headline: Best Products to Shut 81 Stores and Let 4,500 Workers Go
abstract: Best Products Co announces it will close 81 of its 169 stores and dismiss 4,500 employees, or 45 percent of its work force; in addition, Best will close three of its four distribution centers; Best Products filed for bankruptcy protection in September after Ocean Reef Management Inc withdrew its offer to acquire company, saying Best needs more financial support than it had expected (M)

headline: TIME WARNER REACHES DEAL FOR SET-TOP BOXES
abstract: Time Warner Inc plans to spend $400 million to $450 million in three years for one million set-top television boxes from Scientific-Atlanta Inc and other suppliers; boxes can deliver digital video, Internet access and interactive viewing guides to cable customers (S)

headline: If Bob Dole can promote Air France, why can't Toyota acknowledge the Ford Freeway?
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column asks 20 humorous questions about advertising, marketing and media (M)

headline: Turks Hope U.S. Will Push Cyprus Pact
abstract: New urgency expressed by Pres Clinton on the tensions in Cyprus encourages Turkish officials to hope for a big American push in 1997 to resolve festering the conflict there, or perhaps the larger Greek-Turkish confrontation; Britain also indicates willingness to have world community address Cyprus conflict; European Union might use Greek Cypriot desire for membership as leverage to force it to seek accommodation with its Turkish Cypriot neighbors (M)

headline: French Power In Africa Under Attack On All Sides
abstract: France's long and deep involvement in Africa enters turbulent period, disappointing some African leaders who hoped Pres Jacques Chirac would return to cozy paternalism that marked Gaullist policy; Chirac's speech at summit meeting in Burkina Faso is overshadowed by new army mutiny in Central African Republic, and Chirac has warned his Cabinet that era of unilateral French intervention is over (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP.,  Seal Beach, Calif., said its shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of its aerospace and military businesses to Boeing Co. for approximately $3.2 billion. As part of the transaction, Rockwell is spinning off its $10.4 billion commercial-electronics business to its shareholders.    COASTAL CORP.,  Houston, said its Coastal Field Services subsidiary and Snyder Oil Corp., of Fort Worth would combine their natural gas assets for a stronger presence in the Rocky Mountain region.    L. G. BALFOUR CO.,  Attleboro, Mass., the maker of school rings, has agreed to merge with CJC Holdings, of Austin, Tex., to form a new company, Scholastic Brands Inc. Balfour plans to shut down its operations next year, laying off 430 Massachusetts employees.    TYCO INTERNATIONAL LTD.,  Exeter, N.H., has acquired the fire safety system operations of Zettler G.m.b.H. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Nativity Scenes Become an Issue Even in Mostly Catholic Italy
abstract: Roman Catholic Church in Italy deplores reports that some schools in northern part of country have banned Nativity scenes and even Christmas carols rather than risk offense to non-Catholic pupils and their families; a man is arrested in St Peter's Square after attempting to run over its creche with his car to protest 'the excessive power of Pope John Paul II'; the figure of a tiny black baby in put in a creche in Livorno to encourage greater tolerance (M)

headline: FORMER OFFICIALS CLEARED BY COURT IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Magnus Malan, South Africa's former Minister of Defense and 15- co-defendants are found not guilty of murder charges in the country's first attempt to hold senior apartheid-era officials accountable for atrocities against blacks; Pres Nelson Mandela moves to head off any anger at the ruling, saying that he fully accepts the judgment; Malan was accused of plotting to arm and train the assassination squad that attacked the home in Durban of a African National Congress supporter in 1987; 13 people were, mostly women and children, were killed in the attack; photo (M)

headline: Big Retailer Is Said to Bid For Barney's
abstract: Dickson Concepts Ltd, retail giant based in Hong Kong, has reportedly made initial offer of between $300 million and $400 million to buy Barney's Inc; it is unclear whether price includes Barney's Asian license, which has been valued at $200 million, or the buildings owned by Barney's; left out of loop has been Isetan Inc, Barney's Japanese partner, with which Barney's has been fighting since Barney's filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; Isetan's absence from any role in deal appears to be latest sign of growing gap between Isetan and others on creditors committee; at issue is whether Isetan should be considered an equity partner or a creditor of Barney's (M)

headline: Arbitration Rules Would Give Some, Take Some
abstract: NASD regulatory arm adopts new rules which will limit amount of money investors can get for egregious misbehavior by stockbrokers; regulators say new rules will also help investors by giving them more time to file claims; punitive damages will be capped at twice the amount of compensatory damages, to maximum of $750,000 (S)

headline: Swiss Re to Acquire Italian Reinsurer
abstract: Swiss Reinsurance Co to buy Unione Italiana di Riassicurazione SpA for about 500 million Swiss francs ($380 million) from Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni SpA (S)

headline: Sorkin Leaving Nomura After 19 Months
abstract: Nomura Securities International says Ira Lee Sorkin, who had joined the firm 19 months ago in new position, chief legal officer, as Nomura moved into volatile businesses, is resigning; William T Maitland,, who was hired as general counsel in September, will succeed Sorkin, whose resignation takes effect on Jan 1 (S)

headline: In Peru, U.S. Woman's Parents Lament Prison Conditions
abstract: Interview with Rhoda and Mark Berenson, American parents of Lori Helene Berenson, who is serving life sentence in Peru for her association with Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement; says daughter is living in inhumane conditions; map; photos (M)

headline: Test Run of Pipeline by Iraqis Sends Oil Prices Tumbling
abstract: Crude oil futures prices tumble as test of pipeline to Turkey removes doubts that Iraq will soon begin exports; crude oil for Jan delivery falls 88 cents, to $24.42 a barrel (S)

headline: In the Sierras, Growth and Preservation Are Not at Odds
abstract: Sierra Nevada business leaders are taking lead in calling for policies to protect the environment, on ground that region's grandeur is the key to success of their businesses; Sierra Business Council was formed in 1994 'to secure and enhance the economic and environmental health of the region for future generations'; its first move was to commission an audit of natural, social and financial capital of the region; resulting Sierra Nevada Wealth Index, which was released earlier this year, tracks 42 indicators of region's well-being, from water quality to school test scores to employment; map; tables; graphs (L)

headline: POOR EUROPEAN SALES BRING DROP IN ORACLE SHARES
abstract: Oracle Corp posts disappointing second-quarter sales in Europe, and its shares fall in consequence (S)

headline: TCI May Cut Cable Services, Indicating a Shift in Power
abstract: John C Malone, chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc, one of nation's largest cable television operators, says his company is likely to drop several cable services that are not popular enough and do not generate enough profits for TCI; Malone's hard-line approach to programming reflects swing in leverage from cable programmers to cable operators; many companies are trying to introduce new services at time when some cable systems, including Tele-Communications, have limited channel capacity; Malone also indicates that his company will step up major cost-cutting effort, including salary cuts for executives, request that directors reduce their fees and some layoffs (M)

headline: AMR Said to Be Seeking $10 Billion Order
abstract: American Airlines want to buy at least 100 new jets worth more than $10 billion and is in talks with Boeing Co about an order (S)

headline: Sassy and Teen Will Be Merged
abstract: Petersen Publishing Co will fold Sassy magazine into Teen magazine after Sassy's December issue; Petersen Publishing publishes both publications (S)

headline: Politicized trade law: helping companies avoid market forces.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene article notes Geneva Steel, which seeks Commerce Department protection from alleged 'dumping' of steel from Russia, China and Ukraine on United States market, has piqued curiosity of trade and antitrust specialists by suing importers under 1916 act that provides antitrust protection against predatory pricing by foreigners; notes act is rarely envoked because it requires proof that importer tries to seriously injure or destroy US industry; drawing (M)

headline: Report of a Fall in Production Pushes Heating Oil Prices Up
abstract: Heating oil prices rise on New York Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from six-day slump; coffee prices rise (S)

headline: Property and Currencies Popular : Appetite of Investors Turns to the Exotic
abstract: PARIS—  "For an Asian, if the Asian markets are doing really well, they generally prefer to stay in the markets they know," said Lin Yoke Seetoh, director of Unit Trusts Asia/Pacific, a unit of Baring Asset Management.

headline: Informix's new product is trying to seize market share from its major data base software rival.
abstract: Informix Corp will move to try to take market share from Oracle Corp, its leading rival in data base software, when it begins shipping its Universal Server; Informix's server is new type of data base management software that can process multiple types of data: audio, video, geographic, in additon to traditional numbers, text and dates; Informix profiled (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Pope's Appendix Removed; New Illness Denied
abstract: Doctors remove appendix of Pope John Paul II and report finding no traces of any new or serious ailment (M)

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WORSENS, AND GAP WITH CHINA GROWS
abstract: Commerce Department reports US trade deficit with China rose to record $4.73 billion in September, largest with any nation, and that overall deficit rose to $11.3 billion; widening of deficit with China, for second consecutive month and third time in '96, is seen as further evidence of China supplanting Japan as primary source of trade tension for US; Pres Clinton's upcoming meeting with Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin in Philippines, at which he will press for opening of China's markets to American goods, discussed; charts; graph (M)

headline: Officers Changed At Three Agencies
abstract: Three advertising agencies make changes in top management (S)

headline: Gasoline Surges on Report Of Venezuela Refinery Woes
abstract: Gasoline prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange after refinery in Venezuela, the world's largest, shuts gasoline-making unit for at least two weeks for repairs; Lagoven SA, unit of state-owned company Petroleos de Venezuela SA, says it shut 108,000-barrel-a-day catalytic-cracking unit at its Amuay refinery on Sept 20 because of problem with a compressor (L)

headline: French Truck Drivers Refuse to Lift Blockades Despite Compromise
abstract: Striking French truck drivers refuse to dismantle barricades blocking most main roads for 11th day, rebuffing Government-appointed mediator who had wrung concessions from their employers in 75 hours of talks (M)

headline: Offerings of Equities Expected This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    3-D Geophysical Inc., Englewood, Colo., 4 million shares. Smith Barney.    3DX Technologies Inc., Houston, an initial public offering of 2.9 million shares. Howard, Weil, Labouisse, Friedrichs Inc.    Altos Hornos de Mexico S.A., Monclova, Coahuila, Mexico, $85 million of senior discount convertible notes due 2001, convertible into American depository shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.    Amerco, Reno, N.Y., 2.75 million shares. Salomon Brothers.    APT Satellite Holdings Ltd., Queensway, Hong Kong, an initial public offering of 105 million American depository shares, representing 8 shares of common, 52.5 million in the United States and Canada. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    Asia Pacific Wire & Cable Corp. Ltd., Jurong Town, Singapore, an initial public offering of 3.7 million shares. BT Securities. Inc., Houston, 7 million shares, 5.95 million in the United States and Canada. CS First Boston.    Finish Line Inc., Indianapolis, 3 million class A common. Smith Barney. Paine Webber.    Healthdesk Corp., Berkeley, Calif., an initial public offering of 2 million shares. Whale Securities. Hollywood Entertainment, Wilsonville, Ore., 2 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    International Sports Wagering Inc., Little Falls, N.J., an initial public offering of 1.5 million shares. Barington Capital Group.    Interstate Hotels Co., Pittsburgh, 4 million shares, 3.4 million in the United States and Canada. Merrill Lynch. Multimedia Access Corp., Dallas, an initial public offering of 1.2 million shares and warrants. National Securities.    Netsource Communications Inc., Petaluma, Calif., an initial public offering of 3.5 million shares. Deutsche, Morgan Glenfield.    Pegasystem Inc., Cambridge, Mass., 2.24 million shares. Goldman, Sachs & Co.    Skymall Inc., Phoenix, an initial public offering of 2 million shares. Josephthal Lyon & Ross.    SOS Staffing Services Inc., Salt Lake City, 3.7 million shares. Unterberg Harris.    Sun Hydraulics Inc., Sarasota, Fla., an initial public offering of 2 million shares. Aged.    TMP Worldwide Inc., New York, an initial public offering of 4.8 million shares, 3.84 million in the U.S. and Canada. Morgan Stanley & Co.    Tosco Financing Trust,, 5 million of trust convertible preferred securities. Morgan Stanley & Co.    US Filter Corp., Palm Desert, Calif., 10 million shares, 8 million in the United States and Canada. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    Versatility Inc., Fairfax, Va., an initial public offering of 2.2 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.    Vivid Technologies Inc., Woburn, Mass., an initial public offering of 2 million shares, 1.6 million in the U.S. and Canada. Lehman Brothers.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Jobless Rate Falls in Britain
abstract: British unemployment fell by greater-than-expected number of claims in September, bringing jobless rate to its lowest level in five and a half years; jobless rate falls from 7.5 percent to 7.4 percent; September's fall, by 35,600 claims total of 2.1 million, was largest since December 1994 (S)

headline: He Pledges an 'Extraordinary' Effort : Prodi Says Italy Faces Uphill Battle to Euro
abstract: ROME—  Italy's prime minister conceded for the first time Thursday that Rome would not be able to bring the national budget deficit down on time next year to the level required by the Maastricht treaty on European monetary union.

headline: Nation's Newspapers Report Mixed Results on Circulation
abstract: Audit Bureau of Circulations figures for six months ended Sept 30 show country's two big national newspapers, Wall Street Journal and USA Today, continued to build their circulation leads over metropolitan dailies, whose own figures showed growth in suburban and Sun Belt markets and stagnation elsewhere; Wall Street Journal's sales increased 1 percent, to 1,783,532, and USA Today's daily paper increased 4 percent, to 1,591,629, and its Sunday paper topped two million for first time; New York Times remains country's biggest-circulation all-week paper, although its average weekday circulation declined by 10,000 copies, to 1,071,120, during period that included several price increases (M)

headline: Walt Disney Earnings Soar On Gains in Every Division
abstract: Walt Disney Co reports earnings for fourth quarter ended Sept 30 rose 27 percent, to $336 million, up from year-earlier $265 million; table (M)

headline: Equity Offerings for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Advanced Aerodynamics and Structures Inc., Long Beach, Calif., an initial public offering of 5 million units, consisting of one class A share of common, one class A warrant and one class B redeemable warrant. D. H. Blair & Co.

headline: Executive Promoted At Food Court
abstract: Food Court Entertainment Network says it promoted James N Perkins to president and chief executive succeeding Stephen G Bowen, who resigned to return to advertising (S)

headline: Advice for Diana: Have a Royal Time, but Invest Wisely
abstract: Advice for Diana, Princess of Wales, on investing her $22.5 million divorce settlement; investment advisers Robert C Elliott and Tim Kochis offer alternative investment allocation plans; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: DEAL TO MERGE COPLEY REAL ESTATE AND ALDRICH EASTMAN
abstract: Copley Real Estate Advisers, unit of New England Investment Companies, agrees to buy rival, Aldrich Eastman & Waltch LP, for $67.5 million in cash and securities (S)

headline: Mary Leakey, 83, Dies; Traced Human Dawn
abstract: World-renowned anthropologist Mary Leakey dies in Nairobi, Kenya, at age 83; her contributions to anthropology over past 50 years discussed; photos (M)

headline: Subic Bay, Minus U.S., Becomes Surprise Success
abstract: Conversion of Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base to tax-free port and industrial complex confounds predictions of disaster made four years ago, when US withdrew its forces, and attests to vitality of Philippine economy under Pres Fidel V Ramos; 55,000 people now work at Subic port alone, mostly in foreign-operated factories making a variety of products, from computer motherboards to armored personnel carriers; Richard Gordon, chairman of Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority, which administers port, comments; photos; map (M)

headline: AT&T Will Increase Long-Distance Rates
abstract: AT&T announced that it would raise long-distance phone rates by 5.9 percent, effective on Sunday. The move -- AT&T's largest across-the-board rate increase in nearly three years -- will be felt by a large majority of the company's 85 million residential and small business customers. For the average residential customer, AT&T's monthly bill will go up by 60 cents.

headline: Interbrand Buys Gerstman & Meyers
abstract: Interbrand Group says it has acquired Gerstman & Meyers Inc; Interbrand's 8 employees in United States will join 45 employees of new unit (S)

headline: Boeing Chairman Offers 'Exuberance and Dynamism'
abstract: Philip M Condit, president and chief executive of Boeing Co, is known inside and outside company for his exuberance, energy and willingness to make big decisions; Boeing's $13.3 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp comes just months after its $3.2 billion purchase of Rockwell International Corp's military and space division (M)

headline: GEAC COMPUTER TO BUY DUN & BRADSTREET SOFTWARE UNIT
abstract: Geac Computer Corp agrees to buy Dun & Bradstreet Software for $191 million (S)

headline: A Chronology of an International Corporate Feud
abstract: Chronology of events in General Motors Corp's feud with Volkswagen over Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua; photo (M)

headline: AON TO BUY ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER
abstract: Aon Corp to buy Alexander & Alexander Services Inc for about $1.23 billion (S)

headline: Valujet to Add Flights
abstract: Valujet Inc says it would add flights from Atlanta to Dallas-Fort Worth, West Palm Beach, Fla, and Fort Myers, Fla, on Dec 19 with fare of $49 (S)

headline: Natural Gas Up on Speculation A Gulf Storm Will Limit Output
abstract: Natural gas prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange on speculation that a storm moving through Caribbean could disrupt production in Gulf of Mexico (M)

headline: Why European Computer Makers Flop
abstract: Olivetti SpA is latest European computer maker to drop out in face of strong American competition; most European computer makers failed to gain market share beyond their tight national boundaries, robbing themselves of economies of scale needed to be internationally competitive; in addition, many European companies still run expensive retail stores and failed to speed products to customers in race against obsolescence; American companies have proved superior to their European counterparts at meeting varying local demands; graphs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Summary of major business news in The Times of December 20, including details on drop in United States trade deficit

headline: U.S. ROBOTICS STOCK GAINS ON NEWS OF DELL PACT
abstract: Stock of US Robotics climbs on news, announced on Nov 27, that Dell Computer Corp would offer company's new higher-speed modem technology on its Dimension desktop personal computers; faster modems would increase speed at which people could use the Internet; US Robotics stock gains $5.125, to close at $78.625 a share (S)d

headline: Russians Do Fine On the Big Board
abstract: American depository receipts of Vimpel-Communications AO, first Russian company to trade on New York Stock Exchange, soar in their first day of trading (S)

headline: Pan Am takes to the sky with a familiar approach; Valujet opts for a new tack.
abstract: Valujet Airlines, which resumes service after May crash and safety-related shutdown, adopts more serious image in new advertising drive; new Pan American World Airways, which bought name of bankrupt predecessor, is resurrecting old logo and lingo in advertising, while stressing low fares (M)

headline: Mullahs, Look! Women, Armed and Dangerous
abstract: Iranian women in opposition National Liberation Army are training deep in Iraq as soldiers for struggle against theocracy in Iran; well-armed force of some 30,000 is devoted to Maryam Rajavi and her husband, Massoud; most of officers are women; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Ponders Special Force To Arrest War Suspects
abstract: US reportedly draws up plans for US-led paramilitary force to capture accused war criminals in Bosnia; force would work under authority of UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and NATO troops would provide backup support (S)

headline: McCann-Erickson Has Virginia Office
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide has opened office in Arlington, Va, that will focus on handling retail portion of USAir Inc account (S)

headline: 160 NATIONS MEET TO WEIGH REVISION OF COPYRIGHT LAW
abstract: Copyrights experts from 160 nations will meet in Geneva to write new international treaties protecting intellectual property in digital age; delegates to World Intellectual Property Organization diplomatic conference hope to agree on one or more global pacts to update copyright laws for era in which anything can be digitized and distributed almost instantaneously worldwide (M)

headline: Savings and Loans Win Favorable Ruling
abstract: Federal Claims Court Judge Loren A Smith rules savings and loan associations can recover damages from Federal Government for potential profits they lost as result of 1989 accounting rule change as well as direct losses; ruling involves thrifts that agreed to take over failed savings and loans in return for Government pledge to assume risk of possible regulatory changes (S)

headline: CHARTWELL RE IN TALKS TO ADD ARCHER GROUP
abstract: Chartwell Re Corp says it is in discussions to take over Archer Group Holdings; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Flagstar Cos names John Romandetti pres of its Denny's restaurant subsidiary (S)

headline: Bond Prices Barely Move In Slow Day
abstract: Treasury prices end last full trading session of year little changed in thin trading; price of 30-year Treasury bond slips 2/16, to 99 16/32 (M)

headline: INTERMET TO ACQUIRE SUDBURY FOR $195 MILLION
abstract: Intermet Corp says it has agreed to buy Sudbury Inc for $195 million, expanding its position as nation's largest independent casting foundry (S)

headline: Volkswagen's Italian Prices Spur Antitrust Complaint
abstract: European Commission, in antitrust complaint, holds Volkswagen AG's car-pricing policy in Italy violates trade rules; Volkswagen seeks to bar Germans and Austrians from taking advantage of currency fluctuations to buy cars much more cheaply in Italy (S)

headline: Taxes? Who Cares? Now Some Funds Do
abstract: Investors who are likely to face whopping tax bills next April should consider tax-managed mutual funds, which were created to meet demand for fund investment that would always keep an eye on taxes; such funds use several strategies to minimize taxable income they pay shareholders, including buying low-yielding stocks or municipal bonds to reduce turnover or offset capital gains with losses; chart on some tax-managed funds (M)

headline: Strange, That's Santa in the Seat of the Sultans!
abstract: Istanbul's largely Muslim population has embraced Christmas as secular holiday; celebrates holiday season much as it is marked in West, with Santa Claus, gifts and decorated trees, but without scenes of Jesus in manger; photo (M)

headline: A Leader of '89 China Protest Held on Subversion Charges
abstract: Wang Dan, one of the most prominent student leaders in the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989, is charged with conspiracy to overthrow the Chinese Government, a capital crime; is accused of publishing anti-Government articles abroad, raising money to support needy dissidents and accepting a scholarship from the University of California; he has spent the last 17 months in police detention, barred from contacts with his family; charges present Clinton Administration with a difficult policy challenge during his re-election campaign, forcing it to justify its plans for bring to a permanent end the campaign of sanctions and trade pressure the US has used to win improvement in human rights conditions in China (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   H. Vernon Winters, a manager for Mellon, looks at the Dow after 6,000. By Michael Brush.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6/   J. Mark Mobius's Vietnam fund is marking time. The reason? The country still has no stock market. By Timothy Middleton.    SPENDING IT /Page 8/   Sports collectibles are in growing demand. So where's the baseball from Derek Jeter's controversial home run? By Laura Koss-Feder.    VOICES /Page 12/   The tailor and his family lived hand to mouth in Brooklyn in the 1930's. But they played the stock market with gusto. By Judith Kane.

headline: Bid for Malaysia Unit Of Bank of Nova Scotia
abstract: Kumpulan Fima Bhd says it wants to buy control of Malaysian operations of Bank of Nova Scotia (S)

headline: Wheat Prices Rise as Forecast Of Big Stockpiles Is Reduced
abstract: Wheat prices jump on Chicago Board of Trade after Agriculture Department says higher domestic and international demand will leave US stockpiles leaner than expected (M)

headline: Motorola Posted Income Drop Of 58.5% in Third Quarter
abstract: Motorola Inc reports even sharper earnings decline for third quarter than it reported for second quarter, and warns investors that earnings in current quarter might be hurt by charges to cover restructuring moves aimed at cutting costs; in third quarter, company reports earning $206 million, down 58.5 percent from year earlier quarter; says sales slumped 6 percent, to $6.5 billion (M)

headline: Microsoft and Pointcast in Broadcast Alliance
abstract: Microsoft Corp and Pointcast Inc set broad alliance in fast-growing area of Internet broadcasting, averting protracted battle for new generation of Internet 'viewers;' Pointcast, which automatically sends customized data over Internet to subscribers' computers, will embrace Microsoft technology and distribute data produced by MSNBC news service; will get featured position in next version of Microsoft's computer operating system software; accord is potential blow to Nestcape Communications Corp, whose Internet browser is now used by most Pointcast customers (M)

headline: Albanians, Cash-Poor, Scheming To Get Rich
abstract: Pyramid schemes with links to Government have emerged as major economic engine in Albania, attracting investments from some half of adult population; International Monetary Fund and World Bank, pressing for end to economic excesses, are urging Government to crack down on such schemes; economists fear inevitable collapse of schemes will have major impact on small economy (M)

headline: PACIFIC GAS TO BUY TECO PIPELINE IN TEXAS
abstract: Pacific Gas and Electric Co says it has agreed to buy Teco Pipeline Co for $380 million from TRT Holdings (S)

headline: GENESEE AND WYOMING TO BUY RAIL SERVICES UNIT
abstract: Genesee and Wyoming Inc agrees to buy Rail Link Inc for undisclosed amount of cash (S)

headline: In the Land of the Big Ditch, le Carre's in Hot Water
abstract: John le Carre novel, The Tailor of Panama, has raised ire of Panamanians, who feel they have been maligned; many, who befriended le Carre during his frequent visits over past two years, say le Carre has produced not splendid work of fiction, but particularly malign X-ray of Panamamian society; photo (M)1

headline: Chubb Said To Consider Selling Units
abstract: Stock of Chubb Corp, one of largest insurance companies in country, jumps 12% after analysts say company is considering selling its poorly performing life insurance and real-estate subsidiaries (S)

headline: War at Its Clumsiest, and Now a Necessary Healer
abstract: Afghans are warmly grateful to Alberto Cairo, an Italian lawyer who gave up his practice seven years ago to become a physiotherapist in Afghanistan and now directs Red Cross orthopedic centers that have given renewed mobility to nearly 20,000 Afghans who lost limbs to grenades, mines and other explosives during and after the country's prolonged war; an estimated 50,000 Afghan men, women and children have lost legs, many of them both legs; centers also help 200,000 others with war-related injuries and illnesses; Cairo gives much of his salary away to help widows, orphans and others in special needs; map; photo (M)

headline: Bleak Choices Facing Zaire's Fallen Idol
abstract: Analysis of Pres Mobutu Sese Seko's return to Zaire; return, staged to resemble triumph, fails to overshadow Zaire's humiliation by Rwanda-backed rebels; Mobutu, one of Africa's most ruthless and corrupt dictators, is begging, not ordering, Zaire to unite behind him (M)

headline: Hong Kong Growth Rate Is Slowest in 5 Years
abstract: Preliminary government estimates are that Hong Kong's economy grew at its slowest pace in five years in second quarter of 1996, hurt by slump in exports (S)

headline: Cash Going to Stock Funds Fell Sharply in Latest Week
abstract: Mutual fund investors, who normally view market milestones as signal to increase their buying, sharply slow their new purchases of stock funds in week after Dow Jones industrial average first topped 6,000; as result, cash inflows to equity mutual funds fell 93% in week ended Wednesday; table (M)

headline: For Clinton, a Rest in Hawaii on Way to Economic Talks in East
abstract: Pres Clinton, taking brief respite before first foreign trip since his re-election, arrives in Hawaii, hoping to gird himself with weekend of relaxation for state visits to Australia and Thailand for Asian-Pacific economic conference in Philippines (M)

headline: New Software Speeds Multimedia Distribution
abstract: Narrative Communications Corp to offer software to permit distribution and viewing of feature-length interactive multimedia over Internet using ordinary phone lines; software 'streams' file in real time, eliminating 8 to 16 minutes of waiting time now involved in downloading entire file (M)

headline: For the Mailmen Lost in a Maze, Amazing News
abstract: Nicaraguan Post Office, breaking with tradition that has built up over 25 years, will abandon practice of stating addresses in relation to real or imaginary local landmarks, and will divide capital of Managua into quadrants, in which each street, house and business will have number of its own; it is hoped that this will make it easier to get around in the city; maps; photo (M)

headline: Serbian Leader, Ignoring Protests, Holds a New Election
abstract: Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic, ignoring protesters and flouting warnings from West, presses ahead with new round of voting intended to give his ruling party victory it was denied at polls; photo (M)

headline: A U.N. Exit and Entrance: Words of Regret and Hope
abstract: Excerpts from speeches to General Assembly by United Nations Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali and his successor, Kofi Annan (M)

headline: Sale of 10% of ENI Under Way in Italy
abstract: Sale of up to 10 percent of Italian energy company ENI SpA for as much as 6 trillion lire ($3.9 billion) starts on Oct 21 (S)

headline: CSX Puts Off Making a Higher Offer to Acquire Conrail
abstract: CSX Corp, despite intense pressure to match $10 billion all-cash bid from rival Norfolk Southern Corp, has decided not to raise its offer for Conrail (L)

headline: DEFYING MILOSEVIC, THOUSANDS MARCH IN SERBIAN CAPITAL
abstract: Tens of thousands of Serb opposition demonstrators pour into streets in central Belgrade, defying Pres Slobodan Milosevic's warnings of police intervention; riot police block entrance to main square; photos; US blames Milosevic for violence that injured 38 people; Milosevic appears to be trying to gain control of situation that is spinning further out of his grasp, even as his isolation increases both internationally and at home (M)

headline: Robert J. McCloskey, State Dept. Spokesman, Dies at 74
abstract: Robert J McCloskey, career diplomat who served as State Dept's spokesman during Vietnam War, dies at 74; he rose to become Asst Secretary of State and later was appointed Ambassador to Cyprus (M)

headline: Brazil May Delay Iron Ore Exporter's Sale
abstract: Brazil's planned privatization of Cia Vale do Rio Doce, world's largest exporter of iron ore, may be postponed amid growing political opposition; sale could give Brazil as much as $5 billion to help plug budget deficit; two former presidents and number of leaders in Congress oppose sale (M)

headline: Colombians Winning Quick Redress From Courts With Writs
abstract: Colombian lawyers, judges and plaintiffs say writ known as tutela, which allows any citizen to go before judge and demand protection of his basic rights, has become only effective tool of justice in nation (M)

headline: I.B.M. Sales Unit For New Offering
abstract: International Business Machines Corp says it has formed new unit to sell its stripped-down personal computers (S)

headline: Latest Data May Indicate The Economy Is Cooling Off
abstract: New reports suggest economy is cooling from its overheated pace earlier this year; Commerce Department reports that housing starts fell 6 percent in September, steepest decline in 21 months; drop leaves housing starts running at seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.438 million, its lowest level since last December; only in Northeast did starts edge up by 1.4 percent; Federal Reserve says industrial production grew two-tenths of 1 percent last month, half rate at which it grew in August; production capacity has grown this year at 4 percent; capacity utilization rate fell slightly in September, to 83.3 percent from 83.4 percent, well below level where inflationary bottlenecks start pushing prices up; Commerce Department says business inventories grew five-tenths of 1 percent after revised five-tenths of a percent increase in July, while business sales fell by three-tenths of a percent in August after a 1 percent gain in July; Labor Department reports initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by 18,000 last week, to 340,000; graphs (L)

headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) column on variety of mutual fund topics, including rise in fund management fees (M)

headline: RUSHING AWAY FROM TAXES: The Capital Gains Bypass -- A special report.; Wealthy, Helped by Wall St., New Find Ways to Escape Tax on Profits
abstract: Article in series, Rushing Away From Taxes: The Capital Gains Bypass; Federal tax on profits from sale of stock, land or other assets--known as capital gains tax--is becoming largely academic to nation's wealthiest taxpayers; even as growing number of Americans with more modest incomes are paying capital gains taxes because of their growing mutual-fund profits, wealthy taxpayers can take advantage of growing arsenal of Wall Street techniques to avoid taxes on their investment gains; some wealthy investors and entrepreneurs who have avoided paying capital gains taxes are Eli Broad, William Simon, and Ronald Lauder; graph; photos (M)

headline: Are These Changes Necessary?
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about what happened when their firms hired consultants to fix problems; drawing

headline: Wave of Strongmen Make West Africa Their Oyster
abstract: Diplomats say looming challenge to to Western policy toward West Africa is resurgence of military strongmen who seek to remake themselves into civilian leaders; region, which saw wave of transitions toward democratic rule at start of decade, has suffered series of setbacks as elected governments have been overthrown by soldiers, while incumbents have liberally fiddled with rules governing voting to insure that they win; situation in Gambia and Nigeria discussed (M)

headline: Volatile Day of Market Losses, Led by I.B.M.
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 36.52, to 6,268.35; Nasdaq composite index declines 23.93, to 1,260.98; some active issues noted; chart on stocks held by largest number of accounts at Merrill Lynch (M)

headline: Inflating the Inflation Index
abstract: John Maher letter comments on Consumer Price Index in response to Nov 10 Market Watch column on economic statistics (S)y

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COUNTY SEAT STORES,  Dallas, which has 740 casual clothing stores throughout the United States, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.     KAISER-FRANCIS OIL CO.,  Tulsa, Okla., increased its stake in Petrocorp Inc. of Houston to 48 percent, or 4.09 million shares, after buying 3.72 million shares. The stocks were bought for $8 to $8.25 a share.     SONIC CORP.,  Oklahoma City, which owns drive-in restaurants under the Sonic name, said it planned to open about 100 restaurants a year for the next several years through construction and acquisitions.

headline: Pushing the Envelope on Delivery of Customized Internet Data
abstract: Software that delivers customized news, stock quotes and other data from Internet directly to personal computer is hot topic at Internet World trade show, New York City; several of products offer 'channels' of packaged data regularly updated over Internet; drawings (M)

headline: Kurdish Factions Extend Cease-Fire in Iraq; U.S. Still Cautious
abstract: Two Kurdish factions whose rivalry led US to fire missiles against Iraq in Oct agree to extend their cease-fire and to resume talks in mid-Nov on more permanent political settlement (M)

headline: OCEAN REEF OFFERS $100 MILLION FOR JAN BELL MARKETING
abstract: Ocean Reef Management Inc makes friendly cash offer of about $100 million, or $4 a share, for Jan Bell Marketing Inc (S)

headline: U.S. Seeks NATO Backing
abstract: US Sec of State Warren Christopher says US is urging NATO allies to join in demand that Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic respect results of municipal elections and begin talks with opposition leaders protesting in Belgrade (S)

headline: VIVRA STOCK FALLS ON NEWS OF FEDERAL INVESTIGATION
abstract: Vivra Inc stock falls on announcement of Federal investigation of billing practices in kidney-dialysis business (S)

headline: South African Atrocity Panel Subpoenas 9 Former Officials
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission issues subpoenas to former top military and police officials to testify about the country's past atrocities; people have not been coming forward voluntarily to testify despite amnesty offered to those who ask for it and make total confession; Adriaan Vlok, former Minister of Law and Order, is among those subpoenaed (M)

headline: When It Comes to Trash, Chinese Just Say Throw
abstract: China's rapid economic development is breaking down its traditional sense of thrift, the saving of everything to be used over and over again; having discovered the wonders of plastic containers and the convenience of a throwaway culture, the Chinese face growing mountains of garbage and widespread littering; map; photo (M)

headline: SGS-Thomson Carves Niche Outside the Computer World
abstract: Profile of SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, French-Italian company that is world's most diversified and innovative maker of semiconductors; firm has carved lucrative niche as leading producer of analog chips, which can monitor movement, temperature and sound and convert them into analogous electronic or mechanical patterns that can instruct devices or machines to act; president and chief executive Pasquale Pistorio comments, interview; photo; drawings; graph (L)

headline: Microsoft Proves Even Stronger Than Wall Street Had Expected
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports earnings of $614 million for fiscal first-quarter ended Sept 30, up 23 percent from $499 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 14 percent, to $2.3 billion; graph (M)

headline: Nasdaq Offers Stricter Rules For Listing of Companies
abstract: Nasdaq stock market reacts to embarrassing penny-stock scandals by proposing stricter listing standards that could cause hundreds of companies to be dropped from its listings; dropped companies could still be traded in over-the-counter market, but on what is known as bulletin board; such quotes are not published in newspapers, and companies are subject to penny stock rules making it harder for brokers to sell their shares; Nasdaq also proposes stricter rules for its National Market, where shares in larger companies are traded (M)

headline: Rwandans Confront a Time to Heal
abstract: Rwanda's Butare Province, where mass return of refugees who participated in atrocities two years ago is already generating tensions, is test case of how Rwanda will work out overwhelming difficulties it faces; throughout province many Tutsi, whose homes were destroyed in carnage of 1994, have remained on Hutu property; ethnic hatred lingers, and aid agencies eager to give returning refugees boost may be stirring antagonisms by offering them services unavailable to average Rwandan; maps; photo (M)

headline: New Realities of Life In a One-Paper Town
abstract: Houston, Tex, has had only one daily newspaper since April, when Houston Post was shut down after being bought by competing Houston Chronicle; this is part of nationwide trend: number of two-paper markets has dwindled to fewer than dozen; when Houston became one-paper town, Chronicle raised price of advertising and its circulation jumped; some readers say that Chronicle's local news coverage has been slimmer than before, when it had competition; Tony Pederson, Chronicle's managing editor, defends Chronicle's local news coverage, yet paper's showpiece articles of last year are all about someplace other than Houston; photo; chart (M)

headline: Trading Ebbs as Technology Advances, Costing Jobs
abstract: Lack of volatility in foreign exchange trading is eating into banks' foreign exchange profits, spurring layoffs and forcing institutions to rethink their roles in market; new technology has also taken over much of work traders once did; convergence of forces, so soon after alluring profits of early 1990s attracted new players to market, is shaking up industry; graph; table; photo (M)

headline: Stock Funds' Intake Slows, Then Resumes
abstract: Equity mutual funds' intake in December is at slowest pace since July, as investors seek to avoid taxable payouts that many funds make near year-end; several large mutual fund companies report that buying picked up again toward end of month, making it likely that stock funds would record net inflows for month as whole; early December slowdown in fund sales, combined with rising stock prices, could mean that cash levels, already low, might have fallen even further this month; Investment Company Institute reports average cash reserves in funds that invest in American stocks fell to 5.6 percent of assets in November, from 6.3 percent in October, which itself was lowest level in nearly 20 years; increasing numbers of mutual fund companies have arranged emergency credit lines to meet unexpected redemptions (M)

headline: Russian Dirge: Where Are Snows of Yesteryear?
abstract: Prolonged warm spell in Russian winter season, and absence of snow, has so depressed average Muscovites that many have trouble speaking about it; photo (M)

headline: To Zairians, President Becomes Irrelevant
abstract: Many Zairians are concluding that Pres Mobutu Sese Seko, who is undergoing cancer treatment in France, is virtually irrelevant, six weeks after rebels began siege of cities in eastern Zaire; with no sign that Government has marshaled any effective resistance to advancing rebels, mood in capital of Kinshasa is one of growing uneasiness; instead of Mobutu's return, many are bracing for series of battles to control central Zaire, and expect period of intense intrigue in capital as politicians and generals jockey to fill growing power vacuum; map; photo (M)

headline: 3 MORRISON KNUDSEN EXECUTIVES RESIGN
abstract: Morrison Knudsen Corp announces that its chief financial officer, Denis M Slavich, and two other executives, Thomas F Kealey and Gregg Crockett, have resigned (S)

headline: Investment Adviser Admits $65 Million Fraud Against Her Clients
abstract: Investment adviser Teresa V Fernandez pleads guilty to mail fraud in case involving charges she stole over $65 million from clients over nine years; also settles Securities and Exchange Commission charges, agreeing not to violate Federal securities laws; allegedly defrauded wealthy Filipinos, including relatives and friends (M)

headline: A New Romania: Neither Communist Nor Godless
abstract: Emil Constantinescu is sworn in as new Romanian President; supplements civil inauguration with religious ritual in move sanctioning resurgence of Christianity and signaling that decades of official atheism under Communism is also being set aside; pledges new start for troubled country; map; photo (M)

headline: Wall Street Bears Lose 2 More Voices
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Co's Stephen S Roach and Byron R Wein, two of Wall Street's most visible bears, have changed their opinion in face of economic news that prompted yet another stock market closing high and bond market rally; Wein, who had been predicting 1,000-point decline in Dow Jones industrial average, says his near-term outlook has flipped and he now expects 10 percent upside in market if interest rates go to 6.5 percent; Roach says he expects rates to fall to 6.5 percent this year, but he contends that economy is stronger than current data indicate and eventually interest rates and inflation will move higher; photos (M)

headline: Bates Spinning Off Affiliate in Germany
abstract: Scholz & Friends. Hamburg, Germany, which has operated under the aegis of Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant PLC, says it will be spun off as an independent agency under Cordiant PLC (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Young & Rubicam Selected for Account
abstract: International Home Foods names New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc to handle its consolidated account, with billings of $30 million to $40 million (S)

headline: The Nanny Track
abstract: Sheilah Roth letter on Sept 29 article on nannies (M)

headline: Peso Hits Year's Low In Mexico
abstract: Mexican peso falls to its lowest level of the year, continuing weeklong slide strengthened by investor anxiety concerning Government economic policy after decision on Oct 13 to cancel long-planned privatization of petrochemical industry; peso has fallen 3.3 percent since beginning of last week and reached 12.7 cents on Oct 16, its lowest level since December (L)

headline: Your Lunch Was Yummy. So How Was Mine?
abstract: Peter Hochstein comment on domino effects of corporate downsizing (S)

headline: Carrefour Buys Into GMB To Bolster Market Share
abstract: Carrefour SA buys 33.34 percent stake in Societe GMB (S)

headline: Business Confidence Slips in Germany
abstract: Ifo, economic research institute, reports business confidence in western Germany unexpectedly fell in November, breaking a four-month increase in optimism and creating doubt about the strength of economic expansion in 1997; says its index of business confidence fell to 96.9 in November from revised 97.3 in October (S)

headline: Okinawa Copter Base May Move Out to Sea
abstract: US and Japan announce that American military helicopter base in Okinawa will be transferred onto huge offshore platform as way to reduce noise and danger caused by American military operations on island (S)

headline: East African Countries Keep Burundi Sanctions in Place
abstract: East African leaders decide to continue economic embargo of Burundi despite requests from US that sanctions be eased to bolster credibility of Burundi's military leader Maj Pierre Buyoya; African leaders give Buyoya one month to begin peace talks with main Hutu rebel group; say only then will they reconsider sanctions (M)

headline: Bond Market Closed
abstract: The Treasury market was closed yesterday in observance of Veterans Day.  There was also no trading of related bond contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Government offices and most banks were also closed. The stock and commodities markets were open.

headline: Conscious Consumers
abstract: Comment on question of what exactly is organic food; organic label indicates that ingredients were farmed and processed without chemical additives--no pesticides, no animal-growth hormones, no artificial preservatives (S)

headline: 2 Bell Units Back Away From TV Plan
abstract: Bell Atlantic and Nynex are retreating from key part of their strategy to expand into television; merged companies had intended to offer their programming venture, Tele-TV, to tens of thousands of East Coat telephone customers, using microwave transmission technology called wireless cable; technology has proven to be fatally flawed because signals are obstructed by trees, hills and structures; two companies have decided to shift their focus to direct-broadcast satellite, a fledgling television service that has attracted 4 million subscribers since it became widely available through DirecTV and Prime Star two years ago (M)

headline: Ted (Don't Fence Me In) Turner
abstract: Ted Turner, most recently in news for his company's (Turner Broadcasting) $7.5 billion merger with Time Warner Inc, has poured huge amount of his fortune into acquiring ranch land, about 1.3 million acres on 8 ranches in Montana, New Mexico and Nebraska; vows he will never develop land; says, instead, he will leave it in trust to his children; photos; chart detailing ranch holdings in three states (L)

headline: Networks Are Created and Managers Made Accountable
abstract: Growing number of corporations are trying new approaches to hiring and promotion of women and minorities in face of smoldering resentments of these workers and white males over failed efforts to provide even playing field; are leaning on managers to promote minority workers and making managers accountable for achieving measurable goals; programs focus on changing behavior, rather than trying to create racial harmony; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Clinton to Tell Central European Lands NATO Has Room for Them
abstract: NATO diplomats report Pres Clinton will reassure Central European countries anxious to join alliance that they will soon be welcome; campaign speech in Detroit will reportedly focus on NATO enlargement; under current plans, neither he nor other NATO leaders will identify countries until after alliance summit in summer '97 (M)

headline: Rebels in Peru Release 38 But Still Detain Over 300
abstract: Tupac Amaru guerrillas holding Japanese Ambassador's residence, Lima, Peru, free 38 hostages; continue to hold over 300 diplomats and business executives; five freed hostages express fellow hostages' concerns about lack of progress in talks and about poor conditions at residence; guerrillas threaten to begin killing hostages as Japan presses Pres Alberto K Fujimori to seek negotiated solution; photo (M)

headline: Mexico Drops Its Petrochemical Privatization
abstract: Mexican Government cancels its prolonged and troubled effort to privatize secondary petrochemical industry; privatization of 61 state-owned plants was looked to as a way to raise capital needed for modernization and expansion, but it prompted protests from oil workers and even many businessmen; instead, Pemex will now form series of subsidiaries to manage the plants; they are planned as government-private ventures to be financed initially by Pemex but with shares to be sold during 1997 for as much as 49 percent of their capitalization (M)

headline: Writer's Message to Those Who Trashed His Work
abstract: Pramoedya Ananta Toer, Indonesia's greatest writer, has been imprisoned by Government; his books are banned, and he is barred from leaving Jakarta; Pramoedya, 72, remains thorn in side of authorities, stubbornly critical of Government and magnet for idealistic young people; his photo (M)

headline: Netanyahu Tries to Avert Cabinet Split Over Hebron
abstract: Palestinian and Israeli negotiators and US envoy Dennis Ross continue trying to hammer out agreement on Hebron, as Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu pressures wavering Cabinet ministers to keep deal from splitting his Government; signing would be followed by swift pullback of Israeli troops; tensions remain high in city; firebomb is hurled at building housing Jewish settlers, seventh such attack in week (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Albertsons  Universal Hlth Rlty  Unocal    TUESDAY   Browning-Ferris  Brush Wellman  Burnham Pac Pptys  Dames & Moore  First Indl Rlty  Lennar  Showboat    WEDNESDAY   Chelsea Gca Rlty  Corning  Deere  Helmerich & Payne  Houston Inds  LG & E Energy  LNH Reit  Starrett LS    THURSDAY   Brown Group  Conagra  Rouge Stl  Rowe Furniture  Universal Corp Va    FRIDAY   Fed Home Ln Mtg  Piedmt Nat Gasc  Quick & Reilly  Security-Conn

headline: Time Inc.'s Editor of New Media Plans to Resign
abstract: Paul Sagan, president and editor of new media at Time Inc, announces that he plans to resign from company at end of year; says he wants to spend more time with his family (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Calenergy in $1.23 Billion Offer for British Utility  Calenergy of Omaha offered to acquire Northern Electric of Britain for $1.23 billion. Though Northern rejected the offer only hours later, Calenergy said it planned to bring its offer directly to the shareholders.    The aggressive move by Calenergy shows the eagerness of American power companies and utilities to gain a foothold in the British market. $(Page D7.$)    Copper Trader to Plead Guilty  The former copper trader for the Sumitomo Corporation who has been accused of racking up $2.6 billion in trading losses plans to plead guilty to charges that he forged documents, a lawyer for the former trader said. $(D3.$)    Westerners Rush to Buy Gazprom  Few Russian companies are able to entice Westerners to line up to buy their shares. But investors raced to buy stock in Gazprom, Russia's huge and politically powerful natural gas company, and paid a premium for the shares when trading opened in London. $(D2.$)    Microsoft and Intel Lower Prices  Microsoft and Intel are responding to the emerging ''network computer'' standard by seeking to reduce the cost of computers. $(D3.$)    Stock Exchange Seeks to Grow  The New York Stock Exchange is seeking to alleviate overcrowding on its cramped trading floor with an eight-story, glass-enclosed atrium that would be built over Broad Street in lower Manhattan. The plan, which would drastically alter the look and street life of the financial district, elicited a tentative thumbs up from the city. $(B11.$)    Tandem Computer Names President  Tandem Computers named Enrico Pesatori as president and chief operating officer. $(D5.$)    German Company Seeks Loctite  Henkel, a German household products maker, offered $1.12 billion for Loctite, a specialty chemicals producer. $(D10.$)    U.A.W.-G.M. Talks Continue  The U.A.W. said that it would continue to negotiate with General Motors and keep workers on the job without a contract. $(A14.$)    Campaign Gift May Cost Brokerage  A political contribution by an official of Morgan Stanley may cost the brokerage some municipal bond sales for Massachusetts. $(D9.$)    Merrill Announces Succession  Merrill Lynch said David H. Komansky, its president and chief operating officer, would succeed Daniel P. Tully as chief executive at the end of the year. $(D9.$)    Dow Average Loses 34.29 Points  The Dow Jones industrial average fell 34.29 points, to 5,972.73. Broader measures also slid, with the Nasdaq composite losing 6.71 points, to 1,215.89. $(D10.$)    Treasury prices fell, as the 30-year bond's yield rose to 6.83 percent. $(D17.$)    American Express Profits Rise  American Express said third-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, as its investment services unit outperformed its credit card operations. $(D2.$)    Labor Leader on the Trail  John J. Sweeney, on his first anniversary as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., was delighted by questions of whether labor was showing too much muscle in the election. $(A1.$)    No Yankee Fever For Advertisers  Although today's ticker-tape parade marks the Yankees' return to glory, denizens of Madison Avenue, recalling Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford pitching products, do not see commercial deja vu all over again.  Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D9.$)

headline: Afghan Driven From Kabul Makes Stand in North
abstract: Taliban, Islamic fundamentalists who have seized Kabul, begin battle against Ahmad Shah Massoud in northern enclave of Gulbahar that could prove to be decisive encounter in Afghan war; area comprises most notorious stretch of terrain in Afghanistan, where many armies, including Soviet expeditionary force, have foundered; Gulbahar commands access to Panjshir Gorge, which leads to fertile uplands of Panjshir Valley; photo; map (M)

headline: Et Tu, Cybernetica Machina User?
abstract: Latinists who want Latin language to stay alive are encouraged by number of people who have logged on to Latine loquentium, bulletin board that allows any topic to be discussed as long as discussion is in Latin; what is most striking is that cyber-Latin is a youth movement, with most correspondence carried on by graduate students; problem is to update ancient language for modern world; chart with Latin version of some standard computing terms, as devised by graduate student (M)

headline: Only the Wheeler-Dealers Seem to Win in This Game
abstract: Kurt Eichenwald (Street Smarts) column discusses troubled past of Banyan Management Corp, headed by Leonard G Levine, in light of Banyan's bid to merge with RGI/US Holdings Inc through reverse stock split; says big losers would be Banyan shareholders (M)

headline: Calenergy Offers to Buy British Utility
abstract: Calenergy Co of Omaha offers to acquire Northern Electric PLC of Britain for $1.23 billion, and Northern quickly rejects offer as too low; Calenergy says it plans to bring its offer directly to shareholders of Northern Electric, an aggressive move that shows eagerness of American power companies and utilities to gain foothold in British market, which is attractive because of its low debt and steady growth; there have been four offers for British power companies from American companies this year; British electricity industry was privatized in 1990 and is undergoing deregulation; American utilities are buying British companies in part to learn from experience of losing monopoly control over customers (M)

headline: Barney's Reports A Smaller Loss
abstract: Barney's Inc reports its loss narrowed in year ended Aug 3 to $71.9 million, down from year-earlier $120.8 million (S)

headline: Iraq and U.N. Make Deal on Oil Sales for Aid
abstract: Iraq and United Nations agree on long-delayed deal allowing Iraq to sell $2 billion of oil in renewable six-month period for food and other emergency civilian needs; analysts expect sales to result in only slight drop in world oil prices; United States Amb Madeleine K Albright lauds deal (M)

headline: LIONORE PLANS TO TAKE OVER FORRESTANIA GOLD
abstract: Lionore Mining International Inc of Toronto says it plans to buy Forrestania Gold for about $152 million (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: List of upcoming events in stock market

headline: As Talks Stall, Somalia Strife Kills 300 Over 5 Days
abstract: Rival faction leaders in Somalia continue to wage street battles; at least 300 people are dead; renewed violence comes as Ethiopia convenes all but one of factions for negotiations; talks are boycotted by Habr Gedir clan of Hussein Mohammed Aidid (S)

headline: AMERICA ONLINE SHARES DROP ON EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: America Online Inc shares fall about 10 percent after company says on-line and Internet rivals may cut into its earnings and revenue, filing with Securities and Exchange Commission (S)

headline: Forecast of Severe Cold Snap Sends Gas and Oil Up Sharply
abstract: Forecast of frigid weather sends energy prices surging on New York Mercantile Exchange, with January natural gas contract up 61.6 cents, to $4.467 for thousand cubic feet, record price; Jan heating oil rises 3.11 cents, to 74.82 a gallon (M)

headline: Index of Demand for Chips Soars to High for This Year
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Assn reports book-to-bill ratio of 1.10 in October, in sharp rebound from revised figure of 0.98 in September; ratio compares orders with shipments; analysts hail October number as harbinger of new boom cycle for chip industry (M)

headline: Paramount and Volvo In Cross-Promotion
abstract: Paramount Pictures and Volvo will team up for worldwide cross-promotion for new movie, The Saint, and the 1997 Volvo C70 coupe that appears in the film (S)

headline: Lesbian publications struggle for survival in a market dominated by gay males.
abstract: Media column examines gay and lesbian publications; advertising spending in gay magazines and regional newspapers totals about $74 million a year, and recent survey by Simmons Research found that gay men and lesbians earn median household income of $58,000; although advertisers are increasingly open to gay market, some say this acceptance has come at price, that in trying to appeal to wider audience and win more advertising, gay and lesbian magazines have moved away from more sexually explicit and poltiical subject matter; photos (M)

headline: Bonds Hurt By Strength In Economy
abstract: Bond market is hurt by report showing continued pockets of strength in economy and by Federal Reserve decision to refrain from coming to market to buy Treasury securities for its own account; 30-year bond declines 14/32 to 101 15/32; graph (M)

headline: AMERICAN PRECISION TO BUY A SWISS COMPANY
abstract: American Precision Industries agrees to acquire Portescap SA, a Swiss maker of electromechanical drive systems, for about $60 million in convertible preferred stock, exchangeable note and cash; American Precision is acquiring Portescap from Inter Scan Holding AG (S)

headline: A Scoffer at Albania's Old Regime Scolds the New
abstract: Albanian writer Fatos Lubonja, who served 17 years in prison under Communists, criticizes Pres Sali Berisha; says Albania is only ex-Communist country where Government totally controls airwaves and private radio and television stations are not permitted; map; photo (M)

headline: In China, a Taste Of Buy-Me TV
abstract: Chinese consumers are taking to home shopping with enthusiasm, although their purchases are sometimes hindered by lack of telephone for placing orders; Government is encouraging incursion of Western-style infomercials as chance to learn Western marketing techniques; state-run television stations are helping foreign infomercial makers set up operations to peddle their imported wares, although state-run newspapers urge purchase of domestic goods; Mark Hershshorn of National Medial Corp, which plans to enter Chinese infomercial market, notes that 250 million of world's 809 million television homes are in China; photos (M)

headline: Sports Service Battles N.B.A. In Round Two
abstract: Sports Team Analysis and Tracking Systems Inc, known as Stats Inc, is appealing court order to stop disseminating scores of National Basketball Assn games through its Sports Trax, new gadget the size of personal pager, on which user can punch basketball shaped button to get latest score of game, minute by minute, basket by basket; NBA contends it should be paid for rights to transmit 'virtual game'; because of First Amendment implications of case, various news organizations have filed friend-of-the-court briefs supporting defendants, contending that their devices transmit only 'bare-bones facts' of game; but NBC, which has contract to broadcast NBA games, sides with NBA, contending that line must be drawn to prevent new media like on-line services from taking away the value of live game or television broadcast (M)

headline: The Personal Care Business Has Outpaced the Demand
abstract: Analysts say 'personal care business' is deeply troubled corner of otherwise-healthy cosmetics industry; say too many companies scrambled to get into high-margin business selling fruity shampoos and water-based cosmetics, wreaking havoc by saturating it with new stores; now, many are teetering near financial disaster; Nature's Elements has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and Garden Botanika, which went public in May, has seen its stock price plummet by two-thirds on disappointing sales news; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Advertisements for Winn-Dixie Are Referred for F.T.C. Review
abstract: National Advertising Review Board refers Winn-Dixie Stores Inc's comparative pricing advertisements to Federal Trade Commission for review after deciding they could be misleading; at issue is Winnn-Dixie's practice of making comparisons with prices that other supermarkets charged as much as 90 days before Winn-Dixie ads ran (M)

headline: Rate Cuts Revive Ailing Stock Markets
abstract: SHANGHAI—  Only a few months ago, China's domestic stock markets were languishing. Poor performance and low volume in the country's two stock exchanges combined with an apparent policy-making logjam in Beijing left investors and brokers doubtful of the markets' future.

headline: Treasuries' Prices Move Down Again
abstract: US Treasury prices fall sharply; price of 30-year bond falls 20/32, to 98 12/32; yield rises to 6.88 percent, from 6.83 percent on Sept 9; graph (L)

headline: NORTHERN ELECTRIC REJECTS BID BY CALENERGY
abstract: Joint venture led by Calenergy Inc raises its bid for Northern Electric PLC to equivalent of $1.5 billion in cash and assumed debt; Northern Electric rejects bid as too low (S)

headline: No Accord Soon on Treaty For Data Base Copyrights
abstract: Majority of 160 member countries of World Intellectual Property Organization, who are meeting in Geneva, favor putting aside proposed treaty on copyright protection of computerized data bases, which Clinton Administration supports, in order to concentrate on two other proposed copyright agreements; representatives of 28 countries meeting in Singapore endorse the US-drafted Information Technology Agreement, which will phase out import duties on computers, software, semiconductors and telecommunications equipment by year 2000 (M)

headline: With the Palestinians, Chirac Scores a Hit
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac becomes first head of state to address Palestinian legislative council during visit to Ramallah, where he is welcomed by Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, and thousands of schoolchildren who lined route from heliport; warm welcome contrasts sharply with chilly reception during Israeli part of visit; Chirac publicly lauds American peace efforts, but his tour of Middle East, especially unconcealed overtures to Arabs, are widely viewed as attempt to increase France's role in Middle Eastern politics by presenting himself as active advocate of Arab interests; visit coincides with continuing, marathon efforts by Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, assisted by US mediator Dennis Ross, to complete complex arrangements for withdrawal of Israeli troops from Hebron; map; photos (M)

headline: 4 Indicted in Stock Bribe Case Involving Firm Set Up by F.B.I.
abstract: First indictments are returned against stock promoters who were arrested last month in FBI sting intended to catch people who were willing to bribe stockbrokers; indictments are handed against four of 46 people whose arrests were ordered as result of the operation; fifth defendant, Cary Cimino, is informed that charge against him has been dismissed; those indicted are Roland Acevedo, Richard Cedrone, Joseph Pignatiello and Alexander Ruge (M)

headline: Chilean Utility Sale Nears
abstract: Power Market Developments Corp, unit of Pennsylvania Power and Light Co, has agreed to pay $106 million for 25.6 percent of Empresas Emel SA of Chile (S)

headline: Volvo Operating Profit Off as Truck Sales Fall
abstract: Volvo AB says third-quarter operating profit plunged 98 percent to 43 million kronor, or $6.51 million, from corresponding period last year (S)

headline: French Unemployment At 12.7% in November
abstract: Unemployment in France hits record 12.7 percent in November, resuming its recent steady rise after surprise drop in October (S)

headline: RWANDANS LEAVING TANZANIAN CAMPS, BUT NOT FOR HOME
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Rwandans, facing deadline to return home, abandon camps in western Tanzania and start marching east into bush country, led by Hutu extremists who fear punishment for 1994 massacres in Rwanda; map; emptying of one camp sets off movement, as thousands pack up belongings, cattle, goats and sheep, carrying food and tables on their heads; aid officials say most are in good health and were just given two-week food supply (M)

headline: Q&A / Hans van Mierlo : Preparing the EU for the Future
abstract: The Netherlands takes over the presidency of the European Union for six months on Jan. 1. The Dutch foreign minister, Hans van Mierlo, discussed a range of European and trans-Atlantic policy issues with Robert Kroon of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Icahn Renews Battle With RJR Nabisco
abstract: Carl C Icahn renews his battle to force RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp to immediately spin off its food business from its tobacco operations; Icahn submits names of 10 people he hopes will replace company's current board; Icahn's choice for board chairman is Thomas J Rattigan, who has been instrumental in reviving several companies but has no tobacco experience; this is Icahn's second proxy fight against RJR Nabisco; Icahn has raised his Nabisco share total to 7.3 percent; tobacco analyst says Icahn's chances are not good, because RJR Nabisco's chief executive, Steven F Goldstone, has backing of institutional shareholders; Goldstone opposes immediate spinoff of his company's food unit, citing legal threats and pledges to bondholders and rating agencies; he has said spinoff could not occur before 1997 (M)

headline: Italian Hero of Bribe Inquiry Quits as He Becomes Target
abstract: Antonio di Pietro, former magistrate who became a hero in Italy for role in uncovering corruption scandal, resigns from Cabinet of Prime Min Romano Prodi after being informed that he himself is once again target of investigation (S)

headline: 2 Newspapers Battle for Hearts, Minds and All Those Ad Dollars
abstract: Denver Post and Rocky Mountain News are engaged in one of country's last big-city newspaper wars; Denver and environs is one of richest, trendiest and fastest-growing markets in country, but neither side believes it will support two newspapers forever; competition is so fierce between Post and News that each paper regularly attacks other's circulation claims; newspaper industry is watching Denver story closely, because it is test case of two competing strategies: Post is maintaining broadest possible circulation and home delivery area, despite added expense of distant deliveries, while News is concentrating on its core market, cutting off deliveries to 25,000 readers beyond the Front Range cities; photos; graphs (M)

headline: U.S.-Europe Accord Is Seen On Technology Trade Issues
abstract: United States and European Union, meeting, Singapore, near accord that would pave way for global pact to liberalize trade in computers, chips and other high-technology products; Europe's trade ministers, after viewing draft plan, withhold final approval and order their trade commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, to hold added talks with Charlene Barshefsky, acting US trade representative; photo (M)

headline: Mazda Settles Leasing Suits
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp of America agrees to setttle suits by attorneys general in 21 states over reportedly deceptive lease advertisements (S)

headline: Southern National to Buy United Carolina Bancshares
abstract: Southern National Corp says it will buy United Carolina Bancshares Corp for $985 million in stock; deal will create nation's 30th-largest bank, but will result in dismissal of 10 percent of combined work force, or 1,000 people; Southern National tells analysts it could cut operating costs 45 percent by eliminating 80 of United Carolina's branches for $28 million in savings; says elimination of duplicate administrative support will save another $37 million; in other bank deals, Royal Bank of Scotland says its American subsidiary, Citizens Financial Group Inc, has acquired Grove Bank of Massachusetts for $87 million, and Glendale Federal Bank agreed to acquire Transworld Bancorp for $63 million in cash (M)

headline: Netanyahu Cancels Visit to U.S. to Take Charge of Hebron Talks
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu cancels visit to US to take personal charge of elusive search for agreement on withdrawal of Israeli troops from West Bank city of Hebron; change of plans raises new round of speculation that agreement is imminent (M)

headline: Bond Market Closed
abstract: Treasury market is closed in observance of Columbus Day; stock and commodity markets, however, are open (S)

headline: Losers in Your Portfolio? A Housecleaning Deadline Is Near
abstract: Advice to shareholders on clearing their portfolios of losers, especially as tax aid to profits taken elsewhere (M)

headline: PERU REBELS FREE 225 HOSTAGES, BUT RETAIN MANY OF HIGH RANK
abstract: Tupac Amaru guerrillas occupying Japanese Ambassador's residence, Lima, Peru, free 225 of 365 hostages after day of talks led by Red Cross and Min Domingo Palermo; retain most strategically important captives, including ambassadors of Latin American nations, Peruvian generals and Cabinet members and scores of Japanese and Peruvian businessmen; free all six mid-ranking United States aides; Pres Alberto K Fujimori greets freed hostages at hospital; photos (M)

headline: French Papers Shut by Strike Protesting End Of Tax Break
abstract: Strikers shut down French news organizations to protest Government's budget austerity plan that will phase out special tax breaks for journalists and members of about 100 professions (M)

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM PAYING $45 MILLION FOR TELRAD STAKE
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd to pay $45 million for 20 percent stake in Telrad, unit of Israel's Koor Industries (S)

headline: CULBRO TO SELL $120 MILLION IN GENERAL CIGAR SHARES
abstract: Culbro Corp will sell as much as $120.8 million stock in its General Cigar subsidiary in public offering, probably in February; company says it has bought Villazon & Co and its Honduran affiliate for $89 million, giving General Cigar the Punch and Hoyo de Monterrey cigar brands (S)

headline: Clashes in Seoul as Strike Widens Its Grip
abstract: Riot police clash with protesters on streets of Seoul, South Korea, as nationwide general strike spreads to new areas and sets stage for major confrontation between workers and Government; photo (M)ï

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on Aug. 25 about trading in unlisted stocks overstated the fraction of foreign issues among the ''pink sheets,'' a forum for those stocks. About 6 percent of the pink sheet stocks, not a majority, are from foreign companies, according to the National Quotation Bureau, which compiles a listing of 13,000 such stocks. The article relied on information collected by the National Association of Securities Dealers from its members; its estimate is based on stocks that actually trade.    The article also referred incorrectly to the filing of periodic reports by domestic companies on the pink sheets and the OTC Bulletin Board. Under N.A.S.D. rules, about 30 percent of these companies have to file reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission. An undetermined number of others have to file the reports under S.E.C. rules, once they meet certain conditions.    A letter dated Oct. 15 from Harry K. Eisenberg, chairman of Walker's Manual, publisher of a guide to unlisted stocks, pointed out the errors. The letter was delayed in routing at The Times, and this correction was further delayed for checking with regulators.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau says number of magazine advertising pages in October fell three-tenths of percent from year ago, to 20,702 (S)

headline: Nobody Reads a Good Movie These Days
abstract: Declining popularity of foreign-language films in United States discussed; some 90 percent of those released in New York in past year made under $1 million nationally, cutoff point below which few distributors make money; poor video sales seen key factor; table (M)

headline: Strong Exports Slash British Trade Deficit
abstract: Britain's trade deficit was pared to 454 million pounds ($760.5 million) in October from 1.059 billion pounds in September; Britain exported goods worth 14.62 billion globally in October; in September, total exports were a bit less than 14 billion pounds (S)
