headline: The Death of the Last Emperor's Last Eunuch
abstract: Sun Yaoting, last eunuch of China's last emperor, dies in Beijing on Dec 17; he was 93 (M)

headline: In World Flux, a Constant: U.S. and Iran Still Foes
abstract: Former US Embassy in Teheran sits as little-noticed monument to most radical time in Iran's revolution, time when anti-American fever ran so high that young militants held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days; building now serves as school for Iran's Revolutionary Guards; although revolutionary fervor has waned, Iran still officially regards US as its greatest enemy; both countries are prisoners of oratory that has left them unable to make any conciliatory gesture toward other; photos (M)

headline: Familiar Hero to Warn Bosnian Children About Mines
abstract: US will send to Bosnia more than a half-million comic books to teach children about dangers of land mines; comics, using Superman as teacher, are specifically produced by DC Comics division of Warner Brothers, and printed by American Covernment; will be distributed by NATO-led peacekeeping force and Mine Action Center in Sarajevo; drawings (M)

headline: U.S. Held Likely to Keep Troops in Bosnia
abstract: NATO Sec Gen JavierSolana meets with Vice Pres Al Gore in Washington; is reportedly assured that US will keep some troops in Bosnia as part of international peacekeeping force after current mandate ends on Dec 20 (M)

headline: Is Mexico's Press Free, or Just Taking Liberties?
abstract: ''Monica's Addiction Revealed!'' screamed the headline in an opposition newspaper here this month, reporting that the young Mayor of this border city, Monica Garcia Velazquez, was suffering from cocaine addiction and had been hospitalized for an overdose.    The Mayor denied the accusations and filed criminal libel, defamation and other charges, and last week a state judge here briefly jailed Ninfa Deandar, the publisher of El Manana, and two editors.

headline: China's Economic Growth Eases for the Year to 9.7%
abstract: China's robust economy expands by 9.7 percent in 1997, slowest rate in five years, reflecting Government's efforts to trim growth and push down inflation; industrial production rose 13 percent, compared with 14 percent in 1995; China's success in holding growth at manageable levels while slowing price increases masks other problems; almost half the state-owned companies are losing money, and those losses have nearly doubled while supplies of unwanted goods are increasing (M)

headline: Chase and Citicorp Register Solid Earnings for Third Quarter
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp and Citicorp, nation's two largest bank holding companies, record solid if not spectacular third-quarter earnings results, and analysts say industry remains on track for third consecutive year of record profits; Chase says third-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, to $858 million from $764 million during last year's third quarter; revenues were up nearly 4 percent, to $3.93 billion from $3.78 billion a year earlier; Chase also says that between now and 1998 it intends to buy back up to $2.5 billion of its outstanding shares; Citicorp says net income in third quarter rose 7 percent, to $935 million from $877 million a year earlier; revenues totaled $5.36 billion, up 8 percent from last year's quarter; Nationsbank says net income jumped 18 percent, to $625 million from $530 million during third quarter of 1995; First Chicago NBD says earnings were little changed at $358 million compared with $357 million in year-ago period (L)

headline: BRE-X IS CLOSE TO SELLING GOLD STAKE TO BARRICK
abstract: Bre-X Minerals Ltd says it is close to agreement to sell 75 percent stake in its Indonesian gold property to Barrick Gold Corp; agreement would give Barrick a majority stake in Busang deposit on Borneo, which Bre-X says contains 57 million ounces of gold (S)

headline: Legally, Now, Venezuelans to Mine Fragile Lands
abstract: Venezuela, in effort to end years of disarray in its mining sector, is planning to lift bans on gold and diamond mining without Government permission; government officials contend that large-scale mining is easier to regulate and tax than small scale independent mining and that it will open country's untamed south to development; photo; map (M)

headline: BMW Sales Rise 8.5%, Aided by New Models
abstract: BMW says strong performance by new models lifted revenue 10.6 percent in first nine months of year, to $24.8 billion (S)

headline: Gillette Acquires Czech Razor Maker
abstract: Gillette Co buys Czech razor-blade producer Astra AS (S)

headline: New Technology Helps Keep Inventories Just Lean Enough
abstract: Smaller retail chains such as Bon-Ton Stores are turning to sophisticated technology to control inventories and processing and warehouse costs, as well as to track consumer buying patterns, prevent overshipments and reduce losses from post-Christmas markdowns; photos; graphs on inventory controls; one of most advanced practitioners is Dayton Hudson Corp's huge successful Target chain, which has begun to invade Northeast (M)

headline: ZAIRIAN REBELS ROUT FOES, FREEING REFUGEES IN CAMPS; AID MISSION NOW UNCERTAIN
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees stream homeward from eastern Zaire, breaking military and political deadlock that threatened to cause human catastrophe on grand scale; sudden exodus of refugees begins after Zairian rebels rout ethnic Hutu militias that had prevented refugees from returning home for two years; more than million refugees had been cut off from food and water by the fighting, and US, Canada and other nations had been preparing to send troops to help them; mass exodus of ragged people with bundles on their heads leaves future of proposed military intervention up in the air; rebels deny having timed their attack to force refugees home before international troops arrived; photos; map (L)

headline: Lucas Varity Starts Trimming: 13 Businesses and 3,000 Jobs
abstract: Lucas Varity PLC says it will sell 13 businesses, take a charge of $420 million and cut 3,000 jobs as part of a two-year streamlining (S)ø

headline: Ex-Sumitomo Trader Will Plead Guilty, His Attorney Says
abstract: Attorney for former Sumitomo Corp copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka says his client will plead guilty to forging names of his superiors on documents; refuses to say if Hamanaka would try to implicate others at Sumitomo, or outside, for being involved in his trading activities; Hamanaka was accused by Sumitomo of racking up $2.6 billion in losses through unauthorized trades he conducted by forging signatures of his superiors on documents stating he had company's authority to engage in copper trading and to control related funds; Sumitomo insists that Hamanaka acted alone, and that his superiors were unaware of his unauthorized trades (M)

headline: Leadership Heir Advances As E.D.S. Seeks Visibility
abstract: Electronic Data Systems, in move that positions John R Harris as possible heir to company's leadership, gives Harris responsibility for companywide marketing and strategy with key mission of raising EDS's visability; Harris's further advancement, however, is far from assured because Les M Alberthal Jr, company's president, is only 52, while Harris is 47 (M)

headline: Analysts Are Optimistic About the Proposed Deal
abstract: Wall Street backs proposed merger of Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp; analysts say deal will cement Boeing's leadership in commercial aircraft and military contracting; officials at Pentagon, which will be biggest single customer of combined company, express minor reservations, noting some concern about company getting that big; graph on stock performance of Boeing and McDonnell since Sept 30 (M)

headline: New modem plans by U.S. Robotics entice Wall Street.
abstract: Market Place column on soaring sales of modems, to consumers wanting to connect their personal computers to Internet and World Wide Web and to on-line information services like America Online and Compuserve; US Robotics Corp, modem industry leader, has developed new generation of analog modems capable of downloading information from Internet at nearly twice rate of today's fastest conventional modems; it will be available in February (M)

headline: Creation of Many Channels Sparks Home-Grown Productions
abstract: Television production is booming in Europe, fed by proliferation of channels and by a new viewer preference for locally produced programs over American ones, at least in the prime time; spending on new television shows is expected to double by 2000, to $5.7 billion a year; much of the new European programming remains American-inspired, and American companies are rushing to acquire European partners; Germany is the biggest and most dynamic party, while growth in Italy, Spain and France is more fitful; photos (M)

headline: The Bet Is on High Consumer Demand and Low Inventory
abstract: Retail experts are optimistic about outlook for Christmas holiday season, hoping for gains of 5 percent or more; note thin inventories put less pressure on retailers to discount goods early; luxury and discount stores expect strong sales, while merchants in middle are still struggling; graph; photos (M)

headline: AUDITOR DOUBTS ACCLAIM ENTERTAINMENT'S FUTURE
abstract: Stock of Acclaim Entertainment Inc, maker of video game cartridges, plunges 41 percent after its auditor, KPMG Peat Marwick LLP, is quoted as doubting company's future (S)

headline: 2 Big Retailers Sue Visa, Hoping to Avoid Accepting a Debit Card
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc and Limited Inc file antitrust suit against Visa USA Inc, arguing that they should not be forced to accept Visa Check cards--debit cards that withdraw purchases from cardholders checking account; Visa insists that retailers that accept its credit cards must also accept check cards; suit objects to fact that merchants must pay fee for check card transactions that is almost as high as fee on credit card transactions (M)

headline: AT&T Chief Buys Shares
abstract: AT&T's new president, John R Walter, bought 50,000 shares of AT&T stock at $36.50 each, five days after being named to post (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Performance Food Group Co to buy assets of McLane Food Service, McLane Co unit, for $30 million in cash (S)

headline: Hong Kong's New Chief Sees The Meeting of East and West
abstract: Tung Chee-hwa, chosen by China to be Hong Kong's first Chief Executive, pledges to preserve territory's autonomy and British-inspired legal system and resist effort by China to gain special economic privileges, speech to local and foreign business executives; says individual rights must be subjugated to community needs, elected legislature disbanded and Chinese values embraced; says Hong Kong will remain major Asian base for business and finance (M)

headline: One Commando Still At Large In Korea Submarine Manhunt
abstract: Nearly seven weeks after 26 North Korean commandos slipped ashore on rocky South Korean coast after submarine ran aground, one remains at large after outwitting 40,000 South Korean troops searching for him; South Korean troops shoot and kill two of infiltrators, discovered near heavily fortified border (M)

headline: Bosnian Serb Leaders Boycott Swearing In of Unity Government
abstract: Bosnian Serb leaders, in rocky start for new national Government intended to help unify Bosnia, refuse to take part in ceremony to swear in legislators and three-member Presidency (M)è

headline: Virgin Group Adds A British Rail Network
abstract: Virgin Group, headed by Richard Branson, takes over money losing rail network, Crosscountry; British Government awards Branson a 15-year franchise to operate the network; Branson will get state subsidy of 112.9 million pounds ($188.5 million) in first year to run the network (S)D

headline: Mastercard's 'Smart Card' Builds Support
abstract: Seven financial giants agree to market Mondex electronic-cash product in United States; their backing insures that Mondex will be one of leading systems in country as market for smart cards evolves; but it is unclear who will be willing to bear costs of introducing expensive new technology; merchants have to buy new terminals, and cards themselves cost $10 each wholesale; Mondex USA will charge banks that issue cards 25 cents each time money is transferred to Mondex cards; banks, in turn, are expected to pass this fee and their own costs to customers (M)

headline: Argentines Hunt a Sub: Did It Carry Nazi Booty?
abstract: Agentine Pres Carlos Saul Menem promises his full support to help locate old Nazi submarine that reportedly has been seen near San Matias Gulf; says he wants to determine if submarine exists (M)y

headline: Edith Penrose, 81, Dies; Business Trend Expert
abstract: Edith Tilton Penrose, American-born British economist who was an authority on corporate growth and on oil, dies at age 81; photo (M)

headline: U.S. STANDS ALONE AGAINST U.N. CHIEF
abstract: US stands defiantly alone in its opposition to second term for UN Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali as Security Council begins selection process; chief US delegate Madeleine K Albright says she intends to wield American veto in upcoming vote, even though 14 of 15 Council members back reappointment; has ruled out compromise that would allow Boutros-Ghali to remain for partial term of two or three years; US official says Boutros-Ghali is perceived in Congress as not having pursued reform of UN, and that Congress will not pay its dues while he is office (M)

headline: Bank of France Cuts Intervention Rate
abstract: Bank of France says it is trimming its official intervention rateby five basis points, to 3.20 percent, in 10th of string of small cuts this year (S)

headline: THERMO OPTEC ADDS TWO UNITS FROM PARENT COMPANY
abstract: Thermo Optec Corp says it acquired two business units from its parent company, Thermo Instrument Systems Inc, in transaction valued at $68.7 million; Thermo Optec and Thermo Instrument are both owned by Thermo Electron Corp (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks End Down for Week, As Mutual Fund Flows Fall   The stock market finished a down week with a slight rise yesterday, mainly on the strength of a good earnings report by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.54 points, to 6,007.02, but still below its close of 6,090.97 on Monday.

headline: In November, Fed Held Rates Steady by a Unanimous Vote
abstract: Minutes of Nov 13 meeting of Federal Open Market Committee show that policy makers were unanimous in holding Federal funds rate steady at 5.25 percent in absence of broad evidence of rising price inflation (S)

headline: Caretaker Premier Leads Pakistan Into 90 Days of No Frills
abstract: Pakistan's caretaker Prime Minister, Malik Meraj Khalid, sets himself task of creating new political culture in Pakistan, one he says will emphasize modesty, thrift and concern for poor; has been less than three months to accomplish task before elections, scheduled for February '97 (M)

headline: Underwriting Shrinks, and Thus Do Fees
abstract: Securities Data Corp finds Wall Street firms underwrote $20.6 billion of common stock in quarter ended Sept 30, half the level of equity underwriting they did in preceding quarter; securities industry underwrote $205.3 billion of domestic debt and equity issues, down 13 percent from second quarter; executives attribute decline to uncertainty concerning direction of stock market and interest rates; chart (M)

headline: Fresh Signs of Buoyancy In the German Economy
abstract: German economic research institute reports that business confidence in western Germany rose in October for fourth straight month and to its highest level since July 1995; Bundesbank says M-3 money supply expanded in October at annual rate of 8.4 percent; these figures dim chances for cuts in interest rate (S)

headline: At What Price Advice?
abstract: Letter from Harold R Evensky on Dec 8 column on seeking investment advice (S)

headline: Trump Sells Hyatt Share To Pritzkers
abstract: Donald J Trump sells his half interest in Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York to Pritzker family's Hyatt Corp for $140 million, ending often rancorous 17-year partnership; deal removes obstacle to hotel chain's growth in New York market; partnership agreement with Trump had prohibited Hyatt from opening another property in city (M)

headline: Serbia Vows Not to Crush Protests, U.S. Says
abstract: US State Department says Serbian Government has promised not to use force to repress anti-Government protests (S)

headline: Hungry and Jobless, Elephants Wander the Streets
abstract: Plight of Thailand's elephants and their handlers echoes that of its poor farmers, whose land and livelihood are rapidly disappearing as nation modernizes; their forest habitat has all but disappeared, along with their work for logging operations; handlers have brought them to Bangkok to beg, upsetting middle-class Thais who view them as national symbol; wild elephants, some of them formerly tame animals abandoned by owners, increasingly compete with villagers for food; map; photo (M)

headline: A Bond Trader Will Put Quotes and Trades on Line
abstract: Intervest, which runs small electronic bond trading system, reaches accord to let its quotes and trades be seen by all Bloomberg LP subscribers; says service, being offered to institutional investors, will charge lower commissions than markups charged by brokers and offer rebates to let customers offset cost of Bloomberg machines (M)

headline: In Tokyo, Speculation About Role For Castro
abstract: Japanese officials seeking ways to end hostage crisis at Japanese Ambassador's residence in Peru weigh asking Cuba to let guerrillas and some of their jailed comrades settle in Cuba (M)

headline: Western Resources Ready to Sell Natural Gas Pipelines to Oneok
abstract: Western Resources Inc, a utility based in Topeka, Kansas, that has been looking to expand, says it will sell its natural gas pipelines and plants to Oneok Inc for $660 million in stock, deal that will give it access to Oneok customers across Oklahoma (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Brief listing of corporate and government financings (S)

headline: Germany's Retailers Beckon Warily to Customers
abstract: New German law extending shopping hours takes effect, after years of heated debate; goal is to try to warm up one of most consumer-unfriendly countries in West; stores will now be able to stay open until 8 PM on weekdays and 4 PM on Saturdays; Sundays remain entirely off-limits; many store owners profess misgivings, complaining that new hours will add to their labor costs, and expressing doubt that consumers will buy more; photo of scene in Berlin; map (M)

headline: The Garden and Radio City are squaring off over the market for Christmas musicals.
abstract: Advertising column examines competition between Madison Square Garden and Radio City Music Hall for Christmas musicals; Garden's disadvantage is its cavernous horizontal space in contrast to Music Hall's soaring Art Deco verticals; but Garden theater's advantage is its data base of sports ticket holders and reputation of its building (M)

headline: Japanese Banks Forgive Big Loans
abstract: Twelve Japanese banks say they are forgiving $15.1 billion in loans to housing lenders that went bankrupt on losses from their customers' speculative investing in 1980's (S)

headline: Trade vs. Cultural Identity in Canada
abstract: United States has taken its longstanding grievance about Canadian excise taxes on American magazines to World Trade Organization; US is asking organization to determine whether Canada is using cultural identity to conceal unfair trading practices; at issue is Canada's imposition of excise taxes of 80 percent on Canadian editions of American magazines; Canada's protectionism goes back at least to 1960's, when Canadian editions of US magazines were not allowed across the border at all (M)

headline: Treasury to Sell Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the auction of a 52-week bill on Thursday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent; a six-month bill was at 5.05 percent and the 52-week bill was at 5.16 percent.

headline: U.S. to Revise Its Estimate Of Layoffs
abstract: Labor Department says it will revise upward its tabulation of the number of layoffs in mid-1990's after Princeton University labor economist Henry Farber found a problem with Government's figures; department's Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated in August that 8.4 million people had left their jobs involuntarily from 1993 through 1995, 7 percent less than 9 million people found to have been permanently laid off in bureau's previous analysis covering 1991 through 1993; two surveys, based on responses from 50,000 households questioned by Census Bureau in February 1994 and February 1996, overlap for the year 1993 (L)

headline: Russia to Give U.S. Museum Files Detailing Nazi Crimes
abstract: Russian Govt wil give United States Holocaust Museum 15,000 pages of documents describing Nazi atrocities during World War II that were buried in archives of defunct KGB secret police (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Gary M. Mulloy was named president and chief operating officer at Advo Inc., Windsor, Conn., succeeding Joe Durrett, who left to become chief executive at Broderbund Software Inc., San Francisco. Mr. Mulloy had been president and chief executive at Pilkington Barnes-Hind, Sunnyvale, Calif., a division of Pilkington Vision Care.    * Jackie End was named an executive vice president and managing partner for creative at the consumer products unit of Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York. She joins Beverly Okada, who holds the same position. Ms. End had been executive vice president and creative director at Partners & Shevack, New York, a unit of Mickelberry Communications. Wells Rich is owned by BDDP Group, which is being acquired by GGT Group P.L.C.

headline: CISCO REPORTS STRONG EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc reports its first-quarter net income was $180.9 million compared with net income of $181.4 million in first quarter of last year; revenue rose 79 percent, to $1.43 billion (S)

headline: Status and Salaries Are Both in Decline : Chips Down For Teachers
abstract: PARIS—  Zaira Rodriguez Guijarro, an 11-year-old Mexican schoolgirl, perhaps put it best whenUnesco asked children around the world to say what they expected of their teachers.

headline: For Wealthy Americans, Death Is More Certain Than Taxes
abstract: Article in series Rushing Away From Taxes: Preserving the Legacy; decade after Congress closed some of biggest loopholes in tax on wealth handed down from one generation to next, Federal estate tax has become so easy to avoid that some experts believe that much of it is voluntary, at least for those who start planning early; techniques for circumventing estate tax vary widely; some of them are extraordinarily elaborate and creative; all together, they form broadening pattern of tax avoidance that Congress sought to halt; some strategies noted; tax lawyer Martin M Shenkman and estate lawyer William D Zabel comment; graph; photo (M)

headline: BOOM IN PROFITS FOR CORPORATIONS NOW APPEARS OVER
abstract: Great boom in corporate earnings, which helped propel stock market and buoyed economy for over four years, seems to be over; what analysts are arguing over now is how much more slowly earnings will grow; while not all companies have reported yet, enough have released results to indicate that third quarter should have weakest gains in operating earnings in about four and half years, according to Wall Street estimates; that will mean that for year, earnings growth is likely to be smallest since profits actually fell in 1991; graph (M)

headline: Europe Plans Inquiry On Alliance in Platinum
abstract: European Commission to probe Anglo American Corp's 25.9 percent stake in Lonrho PLC; cites concern that alliance would reduce competition in platinum industry (S)

headline: Hebron Jews Voice Fear Of Attack by the Police
abstract: Jewish settlers in Hebron fear for safety if Israel hands over most of city to Palestinian police; recall that in 1929, during British mandate in Palestine, 67 Jews living in Hebron were killed by Arabs; photo; map (M)

headline: Magazines Learning to Take Not-So-Clueless (and Monied) Teen-Agers More Seriously
abstract: Magazines for teen-agers have not changed much in content, but market is changing: teen-agers are rapidly growing segment of population, and they have more of their own money than ever to spend; this excites advertisers, who are now setting aside funds expressly geared toward teen-age market (M)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     Arizona Public Service Co., Phoenix, is selling $100 million of senior notes due in 2006 through CS First Boston Corp. The notes are priced at 99.639, to yield 6.80 percent. The issue is rated Baa1 by Moody's Investors Service, BBB+ by Standard & Poor's Corp. and BB+ by Duff & Phelps.     CIT Group Holdings Inc., Livingston, N.J., is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2001 through Chase Securities Inc. The notes are noncallable and carry an interest rate of Aa3 by Moody's, A+ by S.& P. and AA- by Duff & Phelps.     Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $100 million of bonds due in 1997 through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. and HSBC Securities. Callable quarterly beginning March 3, 1997, with an interest rate of 5.625 percent.     Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. is selling $500 million of debentures due in 2006 through Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch & Co.The debentures are callable anytime beginning Nov. 24, 1999.

headline: One Partnership And Two Purchases
abstract: WPP Group makes undisclosed investment in Media Technology Ventures; Interbrand Group acquires Zintzmeyer & Lux AG; terms not disclosed; Ha-Lo Industries agrees to acquire Creative Concepts in Advertising Inc (S)

headline: The former Mobil Building, largely vacant in the 90's, gets a new tenant, American Airlines.
abstract: American Airlines has leased 43,000 square feet at former Mobil building at 150 East 42d Street, Manhattan; ZAR Realty, partnership of David Werner and Tom Sapir, has purchased two full blockfront buildings at 260 and 261 Madison Avenue for $75 million; Mitsui Trust and Banking Co Ltd New York banch and Mitsui Trust Bank (USA) have leased 50,000 square feet at 1251 Avenue of the Americas; Francis Greenburger of Time Equities Inc has bought 80-84 Nassau Street for $2.8 million (L)

headline: When You Want a Foundation of Your Very Own
abstract: Fidelity Investments is moving into good works with its Charitable Gift fund, which has attracted $600 million in just four years; for as little as $10,000, a donor can set up a rough approximation of a private foundation and qualify immediately for a tax deduction without having to decide where and when to give the money away; the same option is available through the nation's 500 community foundations through so-called donor-advised funds, which offer identical tax advantages as well as advice on giving; other financial institutions, including Scudder Stevens & Clark and PNC Bank, are also getting into the act; chart of assets of Fidelity Charitable Gift fund (M)

headline: How Much Is That Doggie in the Theater?
abstract: Release of Walt Disney's new live-action film version of 101 Dalamatians is expected to create a great demand for the breed, but prospective owners are warned that Dalmatians do not make ideal family pets and that the lifetime cost of having a Dalmatian can come to about $7,500; photo; cartoon (M)

headline: Granada Sells George V To Saudi Prince
abstract: Granada Group PLC says it sold Hotel George V in Paris to Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia for $171 million, second sale from Exclusive portfolio of 17 hotels that Granada acquired last January (S)

headline: Japanese Economy Grows, but Just Barely
abstract: Japan's Economic Planning Agency reports that gross domestic product expanded by one-tenth of one percent in the third quarter from the previous quarter, an annual rate of four-tenths of one percent (M)y

headline: We Can't Do Business, the Dons Tell a Big Donor
abstract: Oxford University dons have voted to refuse $34 million gift from Wafic Said for new business management school; university is resubmitting offer to wider congregation of dons; opposition centers not so much on business studies, which already exist at Oxford, but on enshrining business management in majestic new school destined to become major research center; photo (M)

headline: U.N. SAYS MILITARY MUST ACT TO SAVE REFUGEES IN ZAIRE
abstract: UN Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali calls for urgent dispatch of international military force to aid about a million refugees, many in danger of dying of hunger or thirst, as colossal refugee crisis in Central Africa intensifies; but calls for immediate foreign intervention are blocked by resistance from United States, which stalls Security Council action on military mission; Americans say they still hold out hope for cease-fire that would allow aid operations to resume without outside military protection; Boutros-Ghali declares 'We are confronted by a new genocide. I will call it genocide by starvation' (M)

headline: MICHAELS STORES FORESEES BIG THIRD-QUARTER LOSS
abstract: Michaels Stores Inc predicts that it will have bigger-than-expected third-quarter loss and says it will close four stores in 1997 (S)

headline: British Airport Operator Says Profits Rose 3.4%
abstract: BAA PLC says its first-half pretax profit rose 3.4 percent, to $502 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Big Business And Kremlin: Togetherness Has Its Pitfalls
abstract: Boris A Berezovsky, one of Russia's richest businessmen and important financial backer of Pres Boris N Yeltsin's re-election campaign, is appointed chief of National Security Council in move that has enraged Kremlin's enemies and bewildered even some close allies (M)

headline: New Teen Queen Reigns in Japan
abstract: TOKYO—  The female idol singer is back in Japan, in a typically big way. After a decade-long drought with no teen queen, Japanese pop culture is awash with images of Namie Amuro, a 19-year-old from Okinawa.

headline: NU SKIN ASIA PACIFIC STOCK SOARS IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
abstract: Nu Skin Asia Pacific Inc stock soars in first day of trading (S)m

headline: HUNTSMAN CHEMICAL BID FOR REXENE IS WITHDRAWN
abstract: Huntsman Chemical Corp says agreement to buy Rexene Corp for $302 million fell apart because of what Huntsman calls Rexene's unreasonable conditions; Rexene had objected to transaction being a one-step merger rather than a tender offer (S)

headline: Touch of Tarnish on Sutton Place Image
abstract: Several of city's most respected brokers say prices for Sutton Place apartments are flat; say neighborhood has lost some of its allure over years (M)

headline: Rome Talks To Examine Aid to Hungry
abstract: Participants at World Food Summit in Rome, Italy, examine problems of hunger plaguing planet that produces more food than ever but distributes it inequitably; participants are expected to adopt declaration pledging to reduce by half number of people suffering from chronic hunger, estimated at 840 million, by year 2015 (M)

headline: Management Shifts At Interpublic Unit
abstract: Anderson & Lembke unit of Interpublic Group of Cos realigns duties among top executives and reorganizes its San Francisco office (S)

headline: Saatchi Shakes Up San Francisco Office
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant PLC announces management changes at its San Francisco office, which recently lost several accounts (S)

headline: 2 Men With Machine Guns Shot at Hussein Son, Iraqi Editor Says
abstract: Leading Iraqi editor Salah Mukhtar says attack last week on Pres Saddam Hussein's son, Uday Hussein, 32, in Baghdad was carried out by two men armed with machine guns, interview; say Hussein was aided by off-duty army officer and was able to drive short distance after being hit; Hussein describes injuries as slight, television interview; seems to link attack to Iran (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Industrial Production Nov.  Capacity Utilization Nov.  TUESDAY   Housing Construction Nov.   WEDNESDAY   None   THURSDAY   Balance of Trade Oct.  Weekly Jobless Claims   FRIDAY   G.D.P. 3d Qtr. Rev.

headline: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, 75, Ruled The Central African Republic
abstract: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former colonel who seized power in Central African Republic and went on to proclaim himself Emperor, dies at age 75 (M)

headline: MOLTEN METAL'S SHARES FALL ON FEDERAL FINANCING CUTS
abstract: Shares of Molten Metal Technology Inc fall 49 percent on news that reduced research financing from Energy Dept will lower its third-quarter and fourth-quarter earnings (S)

headline: Travelers Earnings Increased 23% in Quarter
abstract: Travelers Group Inc reports third-quarter earnings of $591.8 million, up from $481.4 million in same period year ago; all figures reflect 3-for-2 stock split in May; earnings chart (M)

headline: Outcome: 'Please, Please' Give It Time
abstract: Serge Schmemann analysis contends that what little emergency Middle East summit meeting produced was best summed up in Pres Clinton's anxious plea to Israelis and Palestinians to 'please give us a chance to let this thing work in the days ahead'; maintains that it is far from certain that peacemakers will be given this chance; holds that giving formidable differences and tensions in which summit meeting began, it was hardly negligible achievement bringing Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat face to face and drawing from them commitment to immediate and intensive negotiations on Israeli withdrawal from Hebron (M)

headline: With Its Drug Binge Over, Cali Seeks Salvation in Old Values
abstract: Old go-go economy of Cali, Colombia, is struggling to overcome vacuum left by drug-related businesses that have been stopped cold, with most-wanted drug kingpins dead or under arrest and with Government debating bill to seize assets of drug dealers, kidnappers and thieves (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AK Steel Corp, integrated steel producer, announces plans to build $1.1 billion steel finishing plant near Rockport, Indiana, creating about 400 jobs (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Round up of major business news stories in today's newspaper; graphs (M)

headline: Treasury Prices in Retreat As Investors Take Profits
abstract: Treasury prices fall, as investors choose to take profits on this week's market run-up (S)

headline: 30 People Indicted For Stock Promotion
abstract: Federal grand jury indicts 30 people, including former officers of Teletek Inc and United Payphone Services Inc, on charges of money laundering and other improprieties in scheme to run up stocks of three companies by bribing brokers and stock promoters; third company is Enrotek Corp (M)

headline: Channel Tunnel May Reopen Next Week
abstract: French and British officials of company that operates Channel Tunnel ask safety authorities to let them resume high-speed passenger service linking Paris, London and Brussels, despite heavy damage caused by recent fire (S)

headline: Financial Powerhouse Takes Aim at Bad Credit Risks
abstract: Ford Motor Credit Company has become biggest auto financing company in world, earning $299 million in third quarter of this year, compared with paltry $15 million for company's worldwide automotive operations; Ford Credit now plans to extend reach into 'subprime' lending market, borrowers with records of not paying back loans on time; lure is $100 billion that people with flawed credit ratings borrow each year to buy new and used cars, at interest rates of 18 percent and higher; risk is harm to image if Ford is seen as gouging the poor or repossessing cars too aggressively; photo; graph (M)

headline: Rolls-Royce to Sell A Canadian Unit
abstract: Rolls-Royce PLC to sell Bristol Aerospace, Canadian aircraft-maintenance company that employs 960 people (S)

headline: This Scoreboard Is a Research Assistant, Too
abstract: Comment on Value Line Fund Analyzer, computer program for tracking mutual funds (S)

headline: A Scandal Ripples Across the Atlantic
abstract: Morgan Grenfell Investment Services, involved in spreading scandal in Britain involving valuation of some unlisted stocks owned by mutual funds it manages, has gotten unusual clearance from Securities and Exchange Commission and repurchased questionable stocks from two Dean Witter funds it advises that are sold in United States; neither Dean Witter fund has lost any money nor suffered significant redemptions from investors concerned about incident, as three Morgan Grenfell European funds have; Dean Witter, which sought SEC move, declines to say whether it has informed shareholders of its International Small Cap and World Wide Investment Trust funds; table (M)

headline: As microprocessor speeds head skyward, what products will follow?
abstract: John Markoff (Technology) column discusses changes that are in store for users of the network computer; notes original idea of network computer was simply that advent of Internet would make it possible to centralize some basic computing functions and lower cost of desktop machines; says, however, idea has degenerated into fracas over trademarks, pitting Network Computer of Oracle Corp and Sun Microsystems against NetPC of Microsoft Corp and Intel Corp; says far more interesting trend to watch over next few years will be business consequences of exponential growth curve that is driving inexpensive microprocessors to faster speeds; says trend is leading to ever more inexpensive machines that are more accessible to ever growing portion of society (M)

headline: NEXTEL BUYING 81% OF WIRELESS VENTURES OF BRAZIL
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc agrees to buy 81 percent of Wireless Ventures of Brazil Inc for $186 million in stock (S)

headline: Vote of Support On Tobacco Guidelines
abstract: North American members of Worldwide Partners, group of independent agencies, vote to support proposed voluntary guidelines to regulate advertising and marketing of tobacco products to minors (S)

headline: In the spirit of autumn, discount airlines are offering a bounteous crop of low-priced fares.
abstract: Edwin McDowell (Business Travel) column says start of Delta Express, ambitious low-cost carrier arm of Delta Air Lines, along with resumption of flights by Valujet, offer travelers bounty of low-priced air fares; also says American Airlines is adding power ports at all first class and business class seats on selected international flights, which will allow passengers to save batteries on their portable computers; notes Best Western has joined American Express Membership Rewards program (M)

headline: The Texaco Iceberg
abstract: Texaco's settlement of race-discrimination lawsuit noted; photo (S)

headline: Two Clients Move Their Accounts
abstract: Several advertisers change agencies on their accounts (S)

headline: Serbian Town Finds the Cost Of Democracy Is Lost Jobs
abstract: Workers at huge Zastava industrial complex in Serbia turn to second jobs in grim struggle to survive, but express little intention of joining demonstrations that have swept Belgrade and other cities since Government annulled election results (S)

headline: Italy Joins Death Row Appeal In Virginia
abstract: Vatican and Italian Parliament praise US Supreme Court for issuing stay of execution for Joseph Roger O'Dell, inmate on Virginia's death row (M)

headline: Interstate to Acquire Hotel
abstract: Interstate Hotels Co agrees to buy 400-room Washington Vista hotel in Washington for $50.7 million from undisclosed seller; hotel will be converted to Westin brand; after this deal, Interstate will own or have controlling interest in 25 hotels and manage another 161 hotels in 28 states as well as several foreign countries (S)

headline: Bear Stearns Sells Unit
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies sells its pension fund consulting unit, Bear Stearns Fiduciary Services, to unit's management for undisclosed sum; Bear Stearns says it will continue to work with its former unit, renamed Independent Fiduciary Services, in a joint venture (S)

headline: Germany Acquits East-West Go-Between of Extortion Charges
abstract: Wolfgang Vogel, one of most enigmatic figures of cold war, is acquitted on extortion charges by Berlin court, in latest chapter of long-running legal battle over his shadowy role as go-between for former East and West Germany; 71-year-old lawyer acquired reputation for mystery and derring-do as he arranged spy swaps between superpowers in divided Berlin and orchestrated trade in East Germans released to West in return for billions of collars to Communist state and large commissions to himself (M)

headline: Solved! Prof. Plum and Cohorts in the Clear
abstract: Anthony E Pratt, British law clerk who invented classic board game Clue, died in obscurity near Birmingham in 1994; he was 90; his death did not become general knowledge until after Waddington's, company that first published game in 1948, issued public appeal to find its creator; ceremonies were being planned to commemorate impending 150-millionth worldwide sale of game, known in Britain as Cluedo; photos (M)

headline: Peter F. Bronfman, Industrialist, Dies at 67
abstract: Peter F Bronfman, senior chairman and founder of Edper Group Ltd, dies at age 67; his photo (M)

headline: Elmer Berger, 88, A Foe of Zionism As Well as Israel
abstract: Rabbi Elmer Berger, critic of Zionism and of Israel, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Crispin & Porter Advertising, Miami, will be renamed Crispin Porter & Bogusky, effective Nov. 1, to reflect the contributions of Alex Bogusky, partner and creative director.    Publicis Public Relations agreed to acquire Fairchild/Oppel Inc., which specializes in media training and crisis communications consulting. Both are in Dallas.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: General Growth Properties, real estate developer, is negotiating to buy six shopping malls for $250 million; sellers are not identified (S)

headline: FPA MEDICAL AGREES TO BUY AHI HEALTHCARE
abstract: FPA Medical Management Inc reaches agreement to acquire AHI Healthcare Systems Inc for $130 million in stock; companies say they expect to decrease general and administrative expenses by $14 million (S)

headline: How Public Relations Tries to Keep the World Spinning
abstract: History of public relations as outlined in Stuart Ewen's book PR!: A Social History of Spin discussed; photo (M)

headline: British and Irish Premiers Say Ulster Talks Are Still On
abstract: Prime Ministers of Ireland and Britain say efforts to achieve peace in Northern Ireland have been set back, but not extinguished, by bombing of British Army base near Ulster by Irish Republican Army; Prime Mins John Bruton and John Major insist peace talks will go forward without Sinn Fein (M)

headline: QUINTILES COMPLETES PURCHASE OF INNOVEX
abstract: Quintiles Transnational Corp completes its purchase of closely held Innovex Ltd for stock and debt worth about 23 percent less than when sale was disclosed; purchase price is $605 million, about $182.8 million less than price disclosed on Oct 7 (S)

headline: 2 L.I. Makers Of Software Plan to Merge For $1.2 Billion
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc makes $1.2 billion cash bid for Cheyenne Software Inc; deal is subject to both shareholder and regulatory approval; Computer Associates, one of world's largest software companies, will be buying maker of mass storage software for business computers; analysts consider merger a good fit; Charles B Wang, chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, says it will retain all of Cheyenne's 800 employees and maintain Cheyenne's headquarters plant; Cheyenne had $250 million in revenue last year (M)

headline: UNIT THAT LAYS CABLE UNDER OCEANS TO BE SOLD BY AT&T
abstract: AT&T Corp is putting up for sale its AT&T Submarine Systems Inc unit; AT&T does not say how much it hopes to get for the unit (S)

headline: SFX BROADCASTING RAISES OFFER FOR MULTI-MARKET RADIO
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc raises its stock-swap offer again for Multi-Market Radio Inc, to $12.50 a share from $12; offer is valued at about $146 million, including debt (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Loews Hotels names Hill, Holliday/Altschiller to handle its national account (S)

headline: Netscape Taking On Lotus With New Corporate System
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp announces strategy of sidestepping Microsoft Corp's assault on Internet browser software market and competing directly against IBM Corp's Lotus unit in growing market for what is known as groupware; in the future, Netscape's popular browser product, Navigator, will simply be a feature in Communicator, a new desktop program; Communicator is intended to allow users to browse the Internet, send E-mail, update meeting schedules and collaborate with other workers on documents, which is main feature of groupware (L)

headline: USA Network To Fallon McElligott
abstract: USA Network cable channel names Fallon McElligott to handle its account; billings estimated at $15 million (S)

headline: SUNDSTRAND TO TAKE $32 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Sunstrand Corp to take $32 million charge, before taxes, in fourth quarter to restructure its Sullair Europe compressor unit (S)x

headline: In Jockeying to Lead U.N., Ghanaian Is Moving Ahead
abstract: UN Under Sec Gen Kofi Annan, Ghanaian career diplomat, emerges as clear leader in race for new Secretary General; even as his support is solidifying, indications are that France, which has veto power, will deny him job; contest is turning amost entirely into case of big-power politics, with qualifications and personalities of candidates relegated to virtual irrelevance; profiles of Annan and challengers Ivory Coast Foreign Min Amara Essy, former Mauritanian Amb Ahmedou Ould Abdallah, former Niger Prime Min Hamid Algabid and former Ugandan diplomat Olara A Otunnu; photos (M)

headline: Times Co. Raises Dividend to 15 Cents
abstract: New York Times Co announces that its dividend payment will be increased for first time since 1990; quarterly dividend on company's two categories of common stock, class A and class B, will increase from 14 cents to 15 cents, payable on Dec 16 to shareholders of record on Dec 3; chmn Arthur Ochs Sulzberger says that dividend increase reflects company's improved operating performance and board's confidence in company's financial performance in future (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 6/   Why you might consider making after-tax contributions to a 401(k). By Michael Brush.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 7/   Some mutual funds take taxes very seriously. By Carole Gould.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/   Yet more classes of fund shares are cropping up. By Timothy Middleton.     SPENDING IT /Page 9/   For parents, a chance to juggle finances to get the most college aid. By Margaret O. Kirk.    EARNING IT /Page 11/   Getting reimbursed for acupuncture and other alternative treatments. By Barbara Whitaker.

headline: Hostile Bid Is Initiated For ADT Ltd.
abstract: Western Resources initiates hostile $3.5 billion cash and stock bid to buy 73 percent stake in ADT Ltd it does not already own; Western Resources seems to be trying to intimidate ADT board; Western Resources' chairman, John E Hayes Jr, says ADT shareholders should be asked to consider resignation of all current ADT board members, to cut board's membership from 8 to 2, and to elect 2 nominees to board backed by Western Resources (M)

headline: Industrial Output Surges; Rise is Biggest in 9 Months
abstract: Federal Reserve reports industrial production surged in November, rising nine-tenths of percent after falling by revised two-tenths of percent in Oct; private economist says report suggests economic growth could exceed 2 percent in final quarter of year; graphs on capacity utilization and industrial production (M)

headline: Resisting U.S., Africans Back Another Term For U.N. Chief
abstract: African nations stand firm behind second term for United Nations Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali, setting back United States hopes that new candidates might emerge soon to challenge him (M)

headline: Investigation Of Ex-Executives
abstract: New York grand jury probes former executives and brokers at A R Baron & Co, defunct penny stock firm; firm and aides face Securities and Exchange Commission civil charges that they defrauded clients, including New York University and wealthy British families (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Market Timing list of upcoming financial dates

headline: Philips Electronics to Cut Jobs As It Revamps European Units
abstract: Philips Electronics NV to revamp television operations in Western Europe, cutting 1,400 jobs at three plants; cuts are part of plan to cut 6,000 jobs worldwide in consumer electronics division (M)

headline: Bundesbank Holds Steady on Rates
abstract: Germany's central bank Bundesbank leaves its benchmark discount and Lombard rates unchanged; discount rate remains at 2.5 percent and Lombard financing rate at 4.5 percent (S)

headline: Diplomas and Plentiful Jobs For 'Supply Chain Managers'
abstract: Arizona State University already had country's largest undergraduate purchasing program three years ago when it revised its graduate program in purchasing and logistics to take broader look at 'supply chain management'--whole process of establishing a need to getting it filled; about 9 students a year would sign up for old program; 43 enrolled this year, and 60 have applied for next year; graduates should have no trouble getting jobs (M)

headline: Suez Posts Profit For the First Half
abstract: Compagnie de Suez SA posts profit of 772 million francs, or $154 million, in first half of the year (S)

headline: RIGHTIST IS VICTOR OVER SANDINISTAS IN NICARAGUA VOTE
abstract: Nicaraguan voters reject bid by former Sandinista rebel leader Daniel Ortega Saavedra to return to power, electing as president Arnoldo Aleman, rightist former Mayor of Managua who advocates untrameled free enterprise and closer relationship with US; Aleman appears to have enough votes to avoid a runoff with Ortega; proclaims himself winner; says election has consolidated democracy in Nicaragua; says he will pursue policy of national unity; calls on Sandinistas to close ranks and help build Nicaragua; Ortega refuses to concede defeat, alleging anomalies in voting; photos (M)

headline: VACATION BREAK TO ACQUIRE ITS COMPETITOR
abstract: Vacation Break USA to buy Berkley Group for stock worth $225.8 million; Berkley shareholders will control combined firm (S)

headline: WATSCO AGREES TO BUY UNIT FROM INTER-CITY
abstract: Watsco Inc agrees to buy Coastline Distribution Inc unit and four factories from Inter-City Products Corp for less than $50 million in cash (S)

headline: Managers Staying Dry As Corporations Sink
abstract: Second of two articles, Rushing Away from Taxes: the Great Retirement Divide, describes how a bankrupt company's middle managers can lose much of their retirement savings, while company's highest officials keep theirs; at issue are deferred compansation packages offered middle-level managers, which allow postponement of taxes on large amounts of pay; if company suffers financial reverses, it might not honor its promises to pay; growing number of American businesses are offering their executives benefits unavailable to rank and file, while pension options to American workers undergo major changes; workers are increasingly offered only company-sponsored 401(k) plans, which are not protected by Government from investment losses; executives are being offered more generous and inventive compensation plans that can be protected even in worst of times; critics claim executives have diminishing stake in health of whatever plan covers their workers; photos (L)

headline: Infoseek Updates Service
abstract: Infoseek Corp, Internet software maker, plans to announce new version of its popular navigation service and a shift in its corporate strategy to distinguish it from other Internet search services; Infoseek Guide will be replaced by Smartseek service, aimed at letting researchers find specific data quickly; second service, Ultraseek, will offer bare-bones high-speed searching (S)

headline: Gauging the Rubin Effect
abstract: Steven A Ludsin letter on Sept 22 article on Treas Sec Robert E Rubin's influence on Pres Clinton's economic policies in re-election drive (S)

headline: Small Presses Thrive in the Diversity Niche
abstract: Small American publishers flourish in the market for multicultural children's books; some major publishers have been in the field for decades, but it has now become a niche market that few can afford to ignore; photos (M)

headline: J. Walter Thompson gets a one-two punch, but is not knocked out of a review by one client.
abstract: J Walter Thomson Co advertising agency suffers major blows with decisions by Sun Microsystems Inc to place account in review and by Eastman Kodak Co to shift worldwide responsibilities for new Advantix photography system to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide; Sun includes Thompson in review (M)

headline: PETROLITE MOVES TO BLOCK FORCED SALE BY SHAREHOLDER
abstract: Petrolite Corp says that it is considering partnership to block attempts by a major shareholder, William S Barnickel & Co, to force sale of company (S)

headline: Mafia's Tell-All, Forgive-All Mood Is Unsettling Italy
abstract: Italy's Mafia abandons its law of silence forbidding members to give much more than names to police, and the authorities are uncertain what to believe; trickle of Mafia turncoats turns into flood, and problem for police is finding truth in ocean of testimony; letter written by Nitto Santapaola publicly forgiving wife's killer is a case in point (M)

headline: Polish Chief Faces Strains With Vatican
abstract: Polish Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski will visit Italy in Feb; he expects to see Pope John Paul II, but dates of his visit have yet to released, apparently because Vatican is dragging on invitation (M)

headline: Heir to the Throne at Lazard Freres May Not Be Anymore
abstract: Several current and former Lazard Freres partners and employees say Edouard M Stern is not heir to the throne at Lazard, and some contend that he may not even continue to work for their firm; these people in recent days cite furious dispute Stern was said to have in New York last week with Michel A David-Weill, his father-in-law, senior partner and controlling owner of Lazard partnerships in New York, Paris and London (L)

headline: Peru Shrugged Off Warnings Of Rebel Attack, Experts Say
abstract: Terrorism experts say that Peru dismissed several well-executed attacks in last year and ignored warnings that foreshadowed commando-style takeover of Japanese ambassador's house, where guerrillas are holding several hundred hostages; say Government security forces, convinced they had won war against terrorism after years of success, have been devoting their limited resources to other threats; Enrique Obando, considered foremost authority on terrorism and military in Peru, says 'security forces were sloppy and overconfident'; photo (M)

headline: South African Constitution Is Approved By High Court
abstract: South African Constitution approves new Constitution which renounces racism of past and guarantees equal rights; 150-page document contains bill of rights that is one of broadest in world; provisions discussed (M)

headline: Christopher Is Sending Envoy to Spur the Mideast Peace Effort
abstract: Sec of State Warren Christopher, concerned about 'recent drift' in Middle East peace effort, is dispatching his special ambassador to region, Dennis Ross, to talk to parties in effort to 're-energize this effort' (M)

headline: Yeltsin Chides Lebed Over Threat to Quit in Kremlin Squabble
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin says that security adviser Aleksandr Lebed threatened to resign because of his dwindling authority; says he urged Lebed to remain on job, despite most recent irritant, naming of his predecessor, Yuri Baturin, to head commission on military appointments (S)

headline: Returning After 8 Years, Kodak Runs Into White Anger
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co, which had 60 percent of film market when it left South Africa in 1987 in observance of anti-apartheid sanctions, has returned and is trying to reclaim its business; it is vigorously pursuing black consumer market, but it is South Africa's whites who buy most of film, and many of them resent Kodak for leaving and have switched to companies that stayed, like Fuji Photo Film Co, Agfa and Konica; Kodak's experience reflects painful lesson many American corporations that left during sanctions have learned; Mandela Government gives no special breaks to companies that honored sanctions; whites, who still have most of disposable income, are loyal to companies that stayed; blacks, only now getting a piece of economic pie, do not know the brands that left; photos; charts (L)

headline: A Cable Giant Loses Its Way and Finds Recovery Difficult

headline: Afghanistan's New Rulers Soft-Pedal Their Hard Line

headline: Keycorp Plans to Shed 280 Branches and Cut 2,700 Jobs

headline: Archer Daniels Takes Steps To Put an Ally On Its Board

headline: U.S., Defending Efforts on Zaire, Says It Has Sent Relief Experts

abstract: Wheat and corn prices fall in shortened session on Chicago Board of Trade on signs of waning export demand (M)7

abstract: Bombving of commuter train in Paris killing two persons casts pall of gloomover city as Parisians resign themselves to possibility of new wave of terror (S)

headline: Romanians Vote Today, But Change Isn't Likely
abstract: Pres Ion Iliescu is expected to win re-election in Romania; his governing party trails coalition of market reform proponents in polls; Iliescu's hold on power is puzzling in face of sharp drop in living standards (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Texaco Agrees to Settle Discrimination Suit  In the largest settlement ever in a racial discrimination case, Texaco agreed to pay more than $140 million to resolve a suit brought by employees. It also agreed to make changes in the way it does business, including a plan to turn over authority for revamping its personnel operations to a committee chosen largely by outsiders.     The settlement came after two weeks of furor following the disclosure that executives had been taped planning to destroy documents demanded in the suit and disparaging minority groups. The Rev. Jesse Jackson said that the settlement was an important first step but that for now his call for a boycott of Texaco remained in effect. $(Page 1.$)    Time Warner Seeks to Halt Satellite   Time Warner is taking its feud with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to the skies. Time Warner is urging the F.C.C. to withhold approval of MCI's application for a license to operate a satellite in its direct broadcast TV venture with the News Corporation. $(39.$)    Time Warner is also moving into the Times Square skyline. The company's Warner Brothers unit said it would lease One Times Square, the tower that anchors Manhattan's theater district and serves as a national symbol of New Year's Eve revelry for its stroke-of-midnight ball-drop. A retail store is planned for the lower floors. $(25.$)    Industrial Production Drops   The output of the nation's factories fell by half of 1 percent in October, the first drop in seven months, as strikes at General Motors slowed production while some businesses were trimming inventories. $(38.$)     A Fidelity Fund Executive Resigns   Fidelity Investments, which has seen its market share stop growing and has faced investor unrest over the lagging performance of some of its top mutual funds, has lost another senior executive. Neal Litvack, who for four years had charted the rapid growth of Fidelity's retail fund business, has quit. $(39.$)     Near Unanimity by Fed on Rates   At their September meeting, members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making body voted 11 to 1 to hold interest rates steady, saying they were wary about an outbreak of inflation but finding little evidence that it was occurring, the minutes showed. $(38.$)     Bond Traders Take Gains   The Treasury market weakened as investors took profits after the strong gains this week. The 30-year bond's yield rose to 6.46 percent from 6.42 percent on Thursday. A week ago the yield was 6.50 percent. $(41.$)    Copper prices surged as a decline in stockpiles at the London Metal Exchange muted speculation that copper in unregistered Dutch warehouses would flood the market. $(40.$)     The dollar fell against the yen, dropping to 110.88 yen from 111.22 on Thursday, amid doubts that Japan and the United States are committed to a stronger dollar. The drop came despite comments by American, Japanese and German officials in support of the dollar. $(40.$)     Honda Sales and Earnings Surge   Honda said its earnings soared nearly 300 percent in the fiscal first half. Sales in the United States were so strong that Honda ran out of one model, the Civic, and will temporarily import Civics from Japan to augment North American production. Another Japanese auto maker, Mazda, reported improved results, too, although in its case that meant only a slim profit. $(50.$)    California Rule on Strain Injuries   California regulators approved the nation's first law intended to curb repetitive strain injuries, which afflict workers in fields from computer programming to meat packing. The measure requires many employers to provide injured workers with special training, to alter their work routines and to change their work stations or tools, if necessary. $(12.$)    New Airline Fire Rules Sought   The Transportation Department has decided to seek new rules requiring fire safety equipment in all airline cargo compartments, on the eve of hearings into the May crash of a Valujet DC-9 that some investigators say could have been prevented by such equipment. $(13.$)
