abstract: King Hussein of Jordan returns to West Bank for first time since losing territory to Israel in 1967 war; visits self-rule zone of Jericho as guest of Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; promises Arafat full support in peace talks and in his efforts to establish independent state; map (M)

headline: Texaco to Make Record Payout In Bias Lawsuit
abstract: Texaco Inc agrees to pay more than $140 million to resolve Federal lawsuit brought by minority employees; this is largest settlement ever in racial discrimination case; company also agrees to change way it does business, including plan to turn over authority for revamping its personnel operations to new committee largely appointed by outsiders; settlement of two-year-old suit comes weeks after disclosure that senior company executives had been caught on tape planning destruction of documents demanded in suit and making disparaging remarks about minority groups; Rev Jesse Jackson, who had called for boycott of Texaco, says settlement is important step, but he does not cancel boycott; photo (M)

headline: Economy not expanding? Some companies don't mind.
abstract: Because of increased volatility in market and signs of possible slowdown in economy, some Wall Street advisers are telling investors to focus on companies with predictable profits that are not dependent on expanding economy (Market Place) (M)

headline: Ashland to Cut Back on Refining Business
abstract: Ashland Inc, under pressure from dissident stockholders and Wall Street analysts, says it will cut spending on core refining business and focus more on its other businesses; retains CS First Boston to weigh strategic alternatives, including merger or spinoff of exploration unit; Providence Capital Inc, dissident investor, drops planned proxy fight (M)

headline: United Airlines Narrows Review
abstract: United Airlines unit of UAL Corp further narrows review on its account, with billings estimated at $100 million, to four finalists (S)

headline: British Airways to Sell Its Stake in USAir
abstract: British Airways says it plans to sell its stake in its United States partner, USAir; preferred shares are worth as much as $500 million; USAir has option to buy them itself or they can be sold privately or through stock offering; prospect of USAir's disentangling itself from British Airways could simplify any merger talks USAir might hold in future; but restrictions on sale of British Airways' stake could hinder any merger plans anytime soon; USAir filed lawsuit against British Airways last summer, saying it broke its agreement with USAir with its proposed alliance with American Airlines; British Airways says that suit prompted its decision to sell its USAir stake; graph (M)

headline: 'Food Summit' Ends With Usual Earnest Vows
abstract: World Food Summit in Rome, Italy, ends with vague pledge by participants to do better, Vatican opposition to population control and American reservations about internationally recognized right to be fed; photo (S)

headline: Final Peace Near, Guatemala Braces for Complications
abstract: Guatemalan Government of Pres Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen and guerrillas on Dec 29 will sign accord to end 36 years of armed conflict; many Guatemalans are skeptical of peace accord ending civil war, in which at least 100,000 people died; chronology; map; photo (M)

headline: T.W.A. Chief Quits After Report of Loss
abstract: Jeffrey H Erickson resigns as president and chief executive after Trans World Airlines Inc reports $14.3 million third-quarter loss linked to July explosion of Paris-bound jetliner; he is widely credited with reviving airline's financial fortunes and widely rebuked for TWA's response to crash (M)

headline: S.E.C. Acts on Stock Promotion on the Net
abstract: Market Place: Federal regulators have brought what appears to be their first lawsuit to stop securities manipulation over Internet; Federal judge has frozen assets of Charles O Huttoe, chairman of little company called Systems of Excellence, and assets of proprietors of electronic newsletter called SGA Goldstar, which is distributed over Internet; SEC claims SGA's owners touted Systems of Excellence in return for secret, illegal shares in company, which they dumped once stock price skyrocketed; SGA continued to tout Systems of Excellence stock even after SEC questioned adequacy of company's disclosures and possible sale of unregistered stock, and halted trading in stock; regulators have long suspected that Internet serves as cheap and easy vehicle for stock promoters to reach unwary investors; graph (M)

headline: With a Bang, Panama Is Erasing House of Horrors
abstract: Panama's infamous 'Model Prison,' old dumping ground for political prisoners, is emptied after 70 years and will be demolished; photo; closing follows riot last summer in which two prisoners were killed and guards were secretly filmed beating naked inmates (Panama Journal) (S)

headline: UNITED NEWS AND MEDIA TO BUY BLENHEIM
abstract: United News & Media PLC agrees to acquire Blenheim Group, which organizes exhibitions, for 500 pence a share, a total of 592.5 million pounds, or $935.5 million (S)

headline: Zedillo Lectures the Mexicans: Obey the Law
abstract: Converting Mexico into law-abiding nation emerges as central theme of Pres Ernesto Zedillo, self-described workaholic who expels smokers from his office and forgoes three-hour tequila lunches; Zedillo barnstorms countryside exhorting compatriots to help create civilized new culture; he is crusading against culture of 'submissive disobedience,' where citizens ignore traffic and tax laws, police moonlight as kidnappers and nobody trusts the courts; Zedillo outlines anti-guerrilla policy based not on draconian measures but on methodical investigation and prosecutions; interview; photo; Yale-trained economist cites accomplishments of electoral reform agreement and economic recovery (M)

headline: Danone Buys Remainder Of French Food Venture
abstract: Groupe Danone says it bought from Groupe St Louis a 34.5% stake in their jointly held Panzalim prepared foods venture for 2.9 billion French francs ($555.9 million)

headline: European Vote Backs Open Electricity Market
abstract: European Parliament votes to allow biggest corporate users of electricity in European Union to buy from generators anywhere in 15-nation group starting in 1999 as first step to opening electricity market (S)

headline: Layaway Plan Helps Finance a New Generation of P.C.S. Wireless Services
abstract: Makers of equipment for new wireless voice and data networks known as personal communications services (PCS) are finding out what it is like to sell on credit; in few, if any, other industries must small companies make such large capital investments to get started; after spending billions for airwave space, many small PCS operators are spurned by traditional lenders and have nowhere to turn for equipment financing but their suppliers; taking advantage of rivalries among competing vendors, large PCS operators like Sprint Spectrum are demanding generous financing; equipment makers like Lucent, Northern Telecom and Ericsson have financed aggressively; graph on Sprint Spectrum's financing plan (M)

headline: U.S. Shifting Its Payments to Direct Deposit
abstract: United States scrambles to find ways to force all recipients of Government payments, from contractors to pensioners, to accept electronic payment; Treasury plans to stop writing most paper checks by Jan 1999 to save postage and printing costs; US makes 850 million individual payments annually, 53 percent electronically at cost of 2 cents each, compared with 42 cents a check; Treasury presses banks to offer new type of stripped-down direct deposit account and weighs issuing debit cards for Federal benefits to those without accounts (M)

headline: Honors
abstract: Richard Hochhauser is named 1997 chairman of Direct Marketing Assn; Patricia Campbell is named vice chairwoman and chairwoman-elect (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch tries on a new image by promoting a museum's show about Leonardo da Vinci.
abstract: Advertising column describes Merrill Lynch's $300,000 advertising campaign to publicize new celebration of Leonardo da Vinci's Codex Leicester, which will be on display at American Museum of Natural History (M)

headline: A Putnam County project shows the revival of the New York market has extended far north.
abstract: Thylan Associates is building 116 townhouses, Kent, NY, reflecting new-home market recovery in semirural Putnam County (M)

headline: Kurd Rivals In North Iraq Said to Agree To Cease-Fire
abstract: Two Kurdish factions battling for supremacy in northern Iraq to cease-fire after nearly two weeks of attacks and counterattacks, easing, at least temporarily, American fears that renewed fighting could tempt Iraq into intervening in Kurdish enclave again; cease-fire is announced after week of talks in Turkey with leaders of both factions, overseen by Asst Sec of State Robert H Pelletreau; map (M)

headline: Skandia to Review Bid For Mortgage Company
abstract: Skandia Insurance plans review of its $3 billion stock offer for Stadshypotek after Svenska Handelsbanken AB, Scandinavia's largest bank, makes an all-cash offer of 23 billion kronor for Stadshypotek, a mortgage company (S)

headline: Senate Panel Finds Nothing Illegal in Clinton Policy on Iranian Arms Sent to Bosnian Muslims
abstract: Report by Senate Intelligence Committee concludes that Clinton Administration officials may have misled one another, Congress, American allies and American people, but that they broke no laws by standing mute as Iran shipped arms to Bosnian Muslims in 1994 (M)

headline: G.E. Reports 11% Increase In Third-Quarter Earnings
abstract: General Electric Co says third-quarter earnings increased 11 percent over period last year; sales were up more than 15 percent, to $20 billion; actual earnings were $1.788 billion, up 11 percent over corresponding quarter last year; table (L)

headline: Viag and Veba to Make Joint Bid for Utility Stake
abstract: Viag AG and Veba AG plan joint bid for 25.8 percent stake in Berliner Kraft und Licht AG being sold by Berlin state government (S)

headline: Magazine Settles Libel Suit by Scientologist
abstract: Time magazine agrees to settle lawsuit brought by Michael Baybek, member of Church of Scientology, who contended that magazine libeled him in its 1991 article about the church; Time will publish statement in next week's issue stating that it did not mean to suggest that Baybek was 'front' for church or that his actions violated any law or regulation; story on Scientology described church as 'global racket' and included separate box that described Baybek's activities on Vancouver Stock Exchange; article said exchange was source of funds for church (M)

headline: Memorex Marketer Is Reviewing Account
abstract: Advertising column describes new ad and marketing campaigns of several upscale watchmakers; says Patek Philippe, Tourneau Inc and Cartier International campaigns are pushing panache as much as product (M)

headline: BankAmerica to Cut Jobs And Shut Some Branches
abstract: BankAmerica Corp, latest and largest prosperous bank to announce sharp cutbacks, says it will eliminate 3,700 of its 92,700 jobs and close 120 of its 1,017 branches in California; cost of severance, broken leases and other restructuring moves will lead BankAmerica, which is based in San Francisco, to take $260 million pretax charge to earnings, of which $165 million will be in fourth quarter (M)

headline: We Interrupt This Ad for Our Stock Symbol
abstract: Number of companies are putting their stock symbols in ads; photo (S)

headline: In Face of African Crisis, No Plans for World Action
abstract: Officials in relief organizations watch helplessly as four African nations seem to head for precipice, with no concrete international plans to confront looming catastrophe; Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International, meets with Clinton Administration officials to press his view that help is needed immediately to prevent unprecedented disaster in Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi or Uganda; but Pres Clinton is unlikely to want to make public issue of another African crisis just days from Presidential election; diplomats and United Nations officials find that no swift action is likely without commitment and leadership from one or more of world's most powerful nations (M)

headline: Calenergy Bid For Utility Is Victorious
abstract: Calenergy Inc of US claims victory in its 923 million pound, or $1.55 billion, hostile takeover offer for Northern Electric PLC (M)

headline: A Tape Shows Israeli Police Beating Arabs
abstract: Two Israeli border policemen are arrested and denounced by Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu as unfit to serve after amateur videotape shows them beating and kicking Palestinians near checkpoint outside Jerusalem; photo (M)

headline: Making It Right?
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories about what happened when consultants came to your office; notes that from time to time, consultants have been known to save a company, but their arrival also tends to make workers nervous; adds it is not uncommon for employees to start heading for doors soon after experts arrive; drawing (S)

headline: Price Cuts Push Sales of PC's and Consumer Electronics
abstract: Some retailers of consumer electronics and home computers report sales have finally picked up somewhat, spurred on by huge price cuts and special promotions; but it appears that sales continue to be down or flat compared with last year; although certain consumer electronics product categories are selling well, overall sales numbers are being dragged down by slowing sales of home computers and soft market for consumer electronics that has existed all year; major reason for slower retail sales is that nearly half of United States homes already have personal computer; repeat buyers tend to buy through other channels, like mail-order catalogues or directly from manufacturers; photos (M)

headline: Lonrho Chief Sells Stake and Steps Down
abstract: Lonrho PLC says its chief executive Dieter Bock has sold his 18.3 perent stake in the company to Anglo American Corp of South Africa for 257.4 million pounds ($411 million) and will step down from his post; Bock will become deputy chairman and nonexecutive director; he will be replaced as chief executive by Lonrho's deputy managing director, Nicholas Morrell (S)

headline: Ovitz, Hollywood Power Broker, Resigns From No. 2 Job at Disney
abstract: Michael Ovitz resign as president of Walt Disney Company after brief tenure marked by tension with chairman Michael Eisner; 49-year-old Hollywood power broker says he will start his own business, despite recent talks with Sony about job there; Ovitz reportedly will get severance package of $50 million cash and $40 million Disney stock options (S)

headline: So Don't Even Think About Smoking Here
abstract: Many companies are so adamant about excluding smokers from their workforce that they have used measures like forbidding smoking on company property or charging smokers more for health insurance; John Banzhaf of Action on Smoking and Health, non-smokers advocacy group, says overriding concern among employers is recognition of how expensive it is to have smokers as employees; photo (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: Summary of major stories in Business section

headline: British Air Has 24% Rise In Earnings
abstract: British Airways PLC says earnings rose 24 percent in its fiscal second quarter; company earned 275 million pounds, or $430.7 million, after taxes in three months ending Sept 30, up from 222 million pounds, or $347.7 million, in comparable quarter a year earlier; revenue came to 2.29 billion pounds, or $3.59 billion, up from 2.13 billion pounds a year earlier (M)

headline: The Interpublic Group is linking up with an Internet broadcaster in a new media expansion.
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos is forming joint venture with Ifusion Com Corp, which develops so-called Internet broadcasting system; venture, Really Perceptive Interactive Advertings LLC, will develop interactive advertising aimed at specific consumers that is more compelling than current Internet offerings (M)

headline: Indian Officials Gather Evidence on Midair Collision
abstract: Indian officials begin investigation of possible causes of mid-air collision between Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and Kazak Airlines Ilyushin airliner over New Delhi, which killed 349 people; Prime Min H D Deve Gowda visits crash site; maps; photo (M)

headline: Banco Santander Buys 80% of Venezuela Bank
abstract: Banco Santander, Spain's largest commercial bank, buys majority control of state bank Banco de Venezuela; bid $301.1 million for 80 percent stake (S)

headline: Austrian Insurer's Shares Fall as Bid Is Topped
abstract: Last-minute entry of Bank Austria AG as a bidder for Creditanstalt-Bankverein AG may force Austrian insurer EA-Generali AG to raise its bid for Creditanstalt (S)

headline: A Prosperous Securities Industry Is Urged to Accrue Trust
abstract: A B Krongard, outgoing chairman of Securities Industry Assn, urges colleagues to do more to improve industry's standards and practices, particularly to enhance public's trust in securities; notes that organization's second annual survey of investors shows that significant minority of investors still have concerns about securities industry; survey also shows that 38 percent of those polled think 1997 will be either 'very good' or 'good' year for investments; but analysts expect investors to reap significantly lower returns in coming years, and many of those attending Securities Industry Assn conference sound cautious about future prospects for securities business; they worry about regulatory, competitive and technical trends (M)

headline: Prudential Insurance Accused by Florida
abstract: Florida regulators accuse Prudential Insurance Co of deceptive sales practices and begin effort to ban company from selling insurance in state; probe charges Prudential salesmen misled up to 100,000 Florida customers into spending cash value of life insurance policies they already owned to buy other policies they did not necessarily need (S)

headline: Ghanaian Gains Ground In Candidacy To Head U.N.
abstract: Kofi Annan, Ghanaian head of UN peacekeeping operations, strengthens position as top contender for secretary general, prompting speculation that France may withdraw opposition (S)

headline: Russian Army May Prove Unreliable, Official Says
abstract: Russian Defense Min Gen Igor N Rodionov asserts that military is in disarray, and warns that Kremlin may no longer be able to count on it in crisis; presses for more funds, painting bleak picture of ever-shrinking military that is poorly housed, poorly trained and poorly fed (M)

headline: ABN Amro Wants to Sell Investment Banking Unit
abstract: ABN Amro Holding NV says it may sell its Dutch merchant banking unit, Mees Pierson NV; analysts expect unit to attract bids in range of $1.17 billion (S)

headline: Global Trade, High Tech Lift Railroad 'Basket Case'
abstract: Conrail, nearly moribund six years ago, has prospered and become increasingly valuable piece of nation's freight transportation system; railroad deregulation, new technology and shifting patterns of world trade are factors leading to resurgence of business for Conrail and many other American rail companies, after decades-long loss of business to trucking industry; freight shippers say American rail network is best and most efficient in the world; railroads' share of freight traffic rose to 40.6 percent last year; now Conrail is at heart of biggest railroad merger battle ever; CSX has offered more than $8 billion in cash and stock, while Norfolk Southern has offered $9 billion; photos; map; chart (L)

headline: Nancy Macdonald Dies at 86; Aided Spain's Loyalist Exiles
abstract: Nancy Macdonald, well-born anarchist who helped radicalize her husband, Dwight Macdonald, in 1930's, managed his magazine Politics in the 1940's, and then struck out on her own in 1950's to aid refugees of Spanish civil war, dies at age 86 (M)

headline: Argentina's Military Reshuffle Makes It Clear President Is Boss
abstract: Pres Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina forces three top military officers to step down; they have been slow to embrace his military reforms and have embarrassed the government in recent months with authoritarian statements (M)

headline: Pakistan's Bhutto Quandary
abstract: Analysis of political future of Pakistan in light of ouster of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and proclamation issued by Pres Farooq Leghari, who set new elections for Feb 3, 1997; caretaker administration Leghari appointed is led by Prime Minister Malik Meraj Khalid; photo (L)

headline: PEPSICO NAMES OUTSIDER TO HEAD TACO BELL
abstract: Pepsico Inc turns to outsider to help increase sales by naming John Antioco, former chief executive of Circle K Corp, to head its Taco Bell restaurants; Antioco succeeds John Martin, who will become chief executive of Pepsico's casual restaurant chains (S)

headline: U.S. Charges AMR On Sabre System
abstract: Department of Transportation says AMR Corp and Sabre Group Holdings, its affiliated computer reservations system, violated laws prohibiting unfair and deceptive advertising; says some Sabre displays gave American Airlines unfair advantage by listing its flights ahead of other carriers' (S)

headline: Serbia Tries to Buy Social Peace With Back Pay
abstract: Serbia's economy seems headed for new crisis with pledge by Pres Slobodan Milosevic to pay social welfare payments and salaries that have been in arrears in apparent bid to mute public unrest over Government's cancellation of election results; economists say Government has begun to print money for payments without reserves to back it; see threat of hyperinflation (M)

headline: Circus in a Square Angers Moscow's Big Wheels
abstract: Proposed circus festival in Moscow's Red Square has become political three-ring circus; Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin supports project, but Moscow Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov opposes it; he calls decision to allow circus in Red Square insult to Russian national pride; Communist leaders say it is 'cynical desecration' of Lenin's final resting place; Russian Orthodox priests attack event as sacrilegious affront to St Basil's Church; photos (M)

headline: In Turnabout For Workers, Wages Grow More Slowly
abstract: Labor Department reports Employment Cost Index, broadest and probably most accurate compensation gauge, climbed just six-tenths of 1 percent in third quarter, lowest reading in a year, as wage and salaries as well as fringe benefits slackened; slowdown partly undercuts earlier indications that workers were beginning to enjoy increases in pay that outpaced rise in cost of living; graph (L)

headline: CANADA PROPOSES ZAIRE AID FORCE
abstract: Canada volunteers to lead international force into eastern Zaire to bring food and protection to more than one million refugees displaced by fighting between Tutsi rebels anf Government forces; mission would involve 10,000 to 15,000 ground troops from approximately dozen nations, including US, who would protect aid convoys; UN says Canadian-led force could be deployed within week; Clinton Administration officials voice concern; fear foreign venture into chaotic landscape of rival militias and endangered refugees could end in disaster; Pentagon says armed team of 40 American soldiers and other American officials will travel to region within days to assess humanitarian situation (M)

headline: Belgium Holds Suspects in Immigrant Smuggling
abstract: Belgian police report uncovering and partly dismantling criminal network that promised at least 4,000 people from Philippines bright futures in Western Europe, for a price, then took them to Italy where they were pressed into prostitution or manual labor (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.31   5.27   5.74        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.04   4.98   5.22        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.15   5.10   5.33        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.55   6.53   6.07        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.83   6.81   6.39        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.85   7.83   7.42        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.92   5.91   5.92          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Rejection Of 'Star Wars' Not Political, Inquiry Says
abstract: Independent panel of experts rebuts Republican charges that nation's intelligence agencies deliberately played down nuclear threat to US in order to subvert effort to build Star War anti-missile defense system; says 1995 intelligence study, showing no clear and present danger of deliberate nuclear attack on continental US, was not politically skewed (M)

headline: In the Hamptons, Prices Are Soaring, but Not All
abstract: Real estate brokers in Hamptons report that their sales volumes are up from 30 to 60 percent over year ago, but they caution residents not to start raising prices of their houses (M)

headline: Politics Aside, Economy Is Shrugging Off Rise to $4.75
abstract: Increase in minimum wage to $4.75 an hour will affect only 3.3 percent of all workers, and impact on overall economy will be negligible; many economists predict small job losses--200,000 at most over two years in a work force of 126 million; economists agree that inflationary jolt will amount to one-tenth or two-tenths of 1 percent this year, because so few earn the minimum wage; Barry P Bosworth, economist at Brookings Institution, says even second increase, to $5.15 next September, will mean raises for 5.4 million additional workers, but will not change equation much; even in Detroit, Mich, where unemployment is nearly twice the national rate, much of the economy has moved beyond minimum-wage levels; Labor Sec Robert B Reich bristles at notion that higher minimum wage would not make much diference to workers making lowest wages; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Microsoft And Intel Shift PC Strategy to Meet Network Threat
abstract: Microsoft and Intel announce strategy to reduce cost of owning and using personal computers; aim is to blunt potential competition from emerging 'network computer' standard endorsed by several computer companies, referred to as NC; Microsoft-Intel executives say their machines would cost only slightly less than conventional PC's, but would reduce administrative costs for corporate networks; they refer to their new approach as Net PC (M)

headline: British Air Plans Revamping of Unit
abstract: British Airways PLC plans to revamp its struggling German unit, Deutsche BA, focusing on domestic flights at expense of unprofitable international routes; changes will be accompanied by reshuffling of Deutsche BA's management (S)

headline: Zenith Names Bagby To Handle Account
abstract: Zenith Electronics Corp says it named Bagby & Co in Chicago to handle its national account (S)

headline: INTUIT SHARES SOAR ON RUMORS OF BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Shares of Intuit Inc soar 24 percent amid rumor that American Express Co is planning bid; other potential buyers could include Fidelity Investments, First Data Corp and Charles Schwab Corp (S)

headline: To Shop, Perchance Nonstop
abstract: Leading psychologists estimate that five million Americans, or 2 percent of population, are compulsive buyers; during holidays, they tend to be grand champion Christmas givers, showering friends and family with gifts; Janet Damon, psychoanalyst, says compulsive spenders buying gifts are trying to buy love and power; photos (M)

headline: Food and Foreign Tobacco Help RJR Nabisco's Gain
abstract: Dennis Ross, special US mediator in Israeli-Palestinian talks leaves for Washington without deal on Hebron, prompting Israelis and Palestinians to blame other for delay; dispels notion that there is crisis or breakdown in talks; says negotiations have reached level of technicality and specificity that no longer requires his daily attention; senior Israeli officials charge Palestinians with dragging heels in hope Israel will be blamed for impasse and would come under stronger pressure to make concessions; suggest Yasir Arafat wants to delay agreement until after US elections in hope of gaining stronger American support; Palestinian negotiators accuse Israelis of behaving as occupiers toward occupied (M)

headline: Motorola Expects Chip Growth to Resume
abstract: Motorola Inc predicts resumed semiconductor industry growth next year; plans fourth quarter charge related to job cuts and other cost-cutting moves; Semiconductor Industry Association reports book-to-bill ratio rose to 0.99 in Sept from revised 0.93 in Aug as computer makers raised orders 9 percent (M)

headline: Texas Company Sues Lloyd's of London Lloyd's
abstract: Stewart & Stevenson Services Inc sues Lloyd's of London over its refusal to pay judgment in lawsuit that Stewart & Stevenson lost to Serv-Tech Inc in July (S)

headline: Sunbeam to Halve Work Force Of 12,000 and Sell Some Units
abstract: Albert J Dunlap, chairman and chief executive of Sunbeam Corp for nearly four months, announces that half of company's 12,000 employees will be let go, through layoffs or sales of divisions, in biggest restructuring in company's history; one industry expert says that in percentage terms, it is believed to be largest work force reduction of its kind ever to be announced; Sunbeam will take $300 million pretax charge to cover severance and other costs, will sell four major product lines and will reduce to 13 from 43 the number of cities globally where its plants and warehouses are situated; company will introduce more than 70 new products in next six months, open 20 Sunbeam retail stores in 1997 in its first such venture and unleash $12 million television advertising blitz to introduce company's new slogan, 'There's a New Sunbeam Smiling...Now There's a Bright Idea'; Labor Sec Robert B Reich scores downsizing; table; chart; photo (L)

headline: Venture in Japan In Satellite TV
abstract: News Corp of Australia and Softbank Inc of Japan will spend 20 billion yen ($176 million) to start satellite television service in Japan, last big market not part of Rupert Murdoch's global network; venture, Japan Sky Broadcasting Co, will have 150 channels (S)

headline: 2 Big Utilities In California Merge to Fight Competition
abstract: Enova Corp and Pacific Enterprises, two large California electric and gas utilities, announce they will merge, forming the utility with the largest number of customers in the country; combination will be first major merger by utilities in California; companies say they expect they will save about $1.2 billion during next 10 years by cutting duplicate staff and other functions; about 9 percent of combined companies' work force of 11,700 will be cut through attrition and offering incentives to leave; Stephen L Baum, president and chief executive of Enova, will become president and chief operating officer of new company, which will be based in San Diego (M)

headline: Joseph Kovago, 83, Hungarian Freedom Fighter
abstract: Joseph Kovago, political prisoners, Mayor of Budapest during the 1956 uprising, spokesman for Hungarians in exile, and, finally, a champion of Hungarian democracy in post-Soviet era, dies at age 83 (M)

headline: Computer Associates Sees Flat Revenue; Shares Fall 21%
abstract: Shares of Computer Associates International plunge 21 percent after company projects weaker-than-expected quarterly revenue because of sales problems in Europe; graph; flat revenues of about $1 billion are under estimates of $1.2 billion; president Sanjay Kumar says company will still meet average earnings estimates because expenses have been trimmed (S)

headline: More Companies Are Relying On Private Weather Forecasters
abstract: Weather forecasts by Jon B Davis, head of Smith Barney Inc's meteorology department, are watched carefully in grain and energy markets; Davis says Smith Barney's grain futures brokers and their clients are hungry for advice on any weather that can affect crops; Smith Barney is last major brokerage house to have its own weather department; private weather industry has grown up as brokerage firms join farmers and other industries demanding more detailed, frequent and accurate forecasts than National Weather Service provides; map; photos (M)

headline: Job Uncertainty Makes Offers Easier to Refuse
abstract: Executives around the country are saying job uncertainty has made them less willing to transfer to a different city for their current company or to relocate for new employer; survey this summer by New York recruiters Battalia Winston International showed 54 percent of executives polled said job insecurity would encourage them to remain in their current positions instead of moving for a job elsewhere; one byproduct of this insecurity: executives are more willing to move to New York, perceiving that it offers a lot of job opportunities; Paul Cappelli, president of Ad Store, discusses his decision to turn down a job offer in Chicago to stay in New York; photo (L)

headline: British Steel Posts 52% Drop in Profit
abstract: British Steel PLC says its profit slumped 52 percent in six months ending Sept 28, to $432.3 million (S)

headline: Chartwell Re Offers To Buy Archer Group
abstract: Chartwell Re Corp, reinsurance concern based in Stamford, Conn, offers to buy Archer Group Holdings PLC for 35 million pounds, or $55.2 million (US) (S)

headline: Netanyahu Seen as Eager to Complete Hebron Talks Soon
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reportedly advises Yasir Arafat that he is eager to complete negotiations on the West Bank city of Hebron by early November; two sides remain far apart on Israeli demand for tightening of security arrangements for 450 Jewish settlers in the city; photo (M)

headline: Holiday Retail Refrain: Better Than '95 but Not Good Enough
abstract: Retailers and retail experts say Christmas sales appear to be stronger than in last year's dismal Christmas shopping season, but they are expected to fall short of the levels many people in the industry had hoped for; photo (L)

headline: France Names Chief For GAN Insurer
abstract: France ousts Jean-Jacques Bonnaud as chairman of state-owned GAN insurance firm and names Didier Pfeiffer to succeed him (S)

headline: U.S. FILTER TO BUY MAKER OF WATER TREATMENT EQUIPMENT
abstract: United States Filter Corp agrees to acquire United Utilities PLC's processing equipment division for $195 million (S)

headline: Recipe for Corporate Disaster
abstract: Thom W Weisel article opposes California referendum that would remove legal barriers to class-action suits in cases involving stock fraud and would hold corporate directors and officers personally liable when juries award damages; drawing (M)

headline: As Consumer Electronics Evolve, Can Japan Rule?
abstract: Consumer electronics industry undergoes huge shift from analog to digital technology that could threaten Japanese companies' dominance of the industry; as it becomes digital, consumer electronics industry is colliding with personal-computer industry and Internet, areas dominated by American hardware and software companies; personal computer is beginning to usurp role of audio and video products in producing pictures and music, but consumer electronics companies think they have advantage in understanding consumer tastes and making products easy to use; product attracting most attention is digital video disk, a pre-recorded disk, same size as compact disk, that can hold two-hour movie or several gigabytes of computer information, making it potential successor to VCR, laser disk, compact disk and CD-ROM; it will be available in US by Christmas; photos (M)

headline: Leader of AT&T's Small-Business and Consumer Division Resigns
abstract: Joseph P Nacchio resigns as head of AT&T Corp's troubled consumer long-distance unit to become president and chief executive of Qwest Communications Corp; Nacchio's departure has been widely expected since October, when he was passed over for promotion to president; announcement of Nacchio's new post comes after AT&T's president, John R Walter, stripped Nacchio of his duties on Dec 20; AT&T names Gail J McGovern to head consumer and small-business division, making her highest-ranking woman in history of AT&T, based on revenue of her division; Jeffrey Weitzen is named to replace McGovern as head of business markets division (M)

headline: Old Oceanside Spa to Be Razed for Town Houses
abstract: $10 million luxury town house complex to be built on bluff overlooking Atlantic Ocean in Long Branch, NJ; for nearly decade, five-story building has sat empty on site (M)

headline: New Donaldson Fund Raises $3 Billion

abstract: Crude oil prices jump on New York Mercantile Exchange, bolstered by speculation that Tosco Corp encountered new problems making gasoline at its big refinery in New Jersey; in other markets, wheat prices rise on continued concern that frigid temperatures could damage dormant crops (M)

headline: 'Love Therapist' And Sales Therapist
abstract: EMI-Capitol Music Group North America, a unit of EMI Group PLC, will begin television advertising campaign on Nov 11 to sell a 'Luv Collection' of compact disks in musical genres like country, dance and rhythm-and-blues; Deutsch Inc has created $5 million campaign (S)

headline: China Paroles Key Dissident Prior to Visit By U.S. Aide
abstract: Chinese authorities release Chen Ziming from jail, where he has been serving 13-year sentence since 1989 for political crimes; medical parole comes shortly before scheduled visit by Sec of State Warren Christopher to lay groundwork for Presidential summit in 1997 (M)

headline: Turkey Sending Envoy to U.S. to Clear Up 'Misunderstandings'
abstract: Turkish Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan will send high-level envoy, Fehim Adak, to Washington with assurances that Erbakan's pan-Islamic philosophy and visits to Iran and Libya do not threaten relations with US; Erbakan, in interview, proclaims friendship but charges Israel is obstacle to Mideast peace and example of 'double standard' in US policy (S)

headline: Koji Kobayashi, 89; Built NEC of Japan Into an Electronics Leader
abstract: Koji Kobayashi, industrial visionary who built NEC Corp of Japan into leader in electronics industry, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: Skandia Quits Bidding For Mortgage Bank
abstract: Skandia AB, Sweden's leading insurer, says that it withdrew its $3 billion stock offer for Stadshypotek AB, leaving Svenska Handelsbanken A.B. as sole bidder for mortgage bank (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: VALUE HEALTH IS PLANNING SPINOFF OF BENEFIT UNIT  Value Health Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its prescription-drug benefit unit, Valuerx. Valuerx generates 80 percent of Value Health's revenue, but it contributes very little to earnings. Value Health plans to go back to its roots as a managed-care company, retaining its mental health, workers' compensation and disease-management businesses. The company also plans to buy a workers' compensation managed-care company from Beverly Enterprises Inc. for $87.5 million and repurchase as much as $100 million in common stock. In a tax-free spinoff, shareholders will get an as yet undetermined number of shares in Valuerx, which will be publicly traded.   (Bloomberg Business News)    INVESTORS MAKE A NEW OFFER FOR SANTA ANITA   The Koll Company, a real estate concern, and Apollo Real Estate Advisors said yesterday that they had offered to buy the Santa Anita Companies, operator of the Santa Anita race track in California. Apollo is an investment management firm in New York. The bid offers a $14-a-share cash dividend to shareholders in exchange for a 55 percent stake in the company. The partnership put the value of the bid at about $19 a share. Santa Anita had already agreed to sell a 45 percent stake in the company over the next two years to a group led by Colony Capital, a Los Angeles-based real estate investment firm. Santa Anita shares rose $2.25, or 12 percent, to close at $20.50.   (Dow Jones)    JACOR COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY REGENT COMMUNICATIONS  Jacor Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire closely held Regent Communications Inc. of Covington, Ky., which owns or operates 20 radio stations in five markets. Under terms of the deal,  Jacor will issue Regent 3.55 million common shares, which are currently worth about $120 million, and warrants to buy 500,000 Jacor common shares at $40 apiece. It will also assume $64 million of Regent debt. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Jacor slipped 37.5 cents, to $33.75. Regent has radio stations in Kansas City, Kan.; Salt Lake City; Las Vegas, Nev.; Louisville, Ky., and Charleston, S.C. The company had revenue of $32.1 million in 1995. Including pending transactions, Jacor, based in Cincinnati, has 92 radio stations in 20 cities.   (Dow Jones)    COGECO CABLE TO BUY ASSETS OF ROGERS COMMUNICATIONS  Rogers Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would sell several cable systems serving 300,000 subscribers to Cogeco Cable Inc. for the equivalent of about $255 million in cash, shares and notes. Rogers's chief executive, Ted Rogers, said the money, along with the pending sale of the Toronto Sun newspaper chain, would ''substantially improve the financial position of the cable group.'' Rogers, based in Toronto, provides cable service, and cellular and other mobile communications, It also has interests in radio and television broadcasting. Most of the cable systems it is selling to Montreal-based Cogeco were acquired when it bought Maclean Hunter Ltd. in 1994.   (Bloomberg Business News)    AMOCO TO SELL STATIONS IN BULGARIA, POLAND AND ROMANIA  The Amoco Corporation will sell its gasoline retailing business in Poland, Romania and Bulgaria, just four months after opening its first service station in the region. The Chicago-based oil company had said it would invest more than $200 million to get back into Europe, but sales in central Europe fell short of expectations. Now the company's plans focus on growth in the United States, it said. Amoco, the fifth-largest United States oil company by market capitalization, said it would sell four existing sites and 14 under construction in the three countries.   (Bloomberg Business News)    AMR RAISES OFFERING PRICE FOR RESERVATION SYSTEM  The AMR Corporation raised the initial public offering price for its Sabre Group Holdings Inc. unit to as much as $545.4 million in a sign of strong investor demand. The parent of American Airlines raised the  share price for the initial offering of its reservations system to between $25 and $27 each, according to an amended Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The company had expected to sell shares for $20 to $23 each to raise as much as $464.6 million. AMR plans to sell a 15.8 percent stake in Sabre through an offering of 20.2 million class A common shares. AMR would continue to hold 107.3 million class B shares. Under the revised prices, AMR will receive about $495 million after expenses if the shares sell for $26 each.   (Bloomberg Business News)    ZAPATA CANCELS $80 MILLION MERGER WITH HOULIHAN'S  The Zapata Corporation, a Houston company that is trying to get out of the oil and gas industry and into the food business, has ended efforts to complete a $80 million merger with Houlihan's Restaurant Group Inc. Both Zapata and Houlihan's are controlled by Malcolm Glazer. Mr. Glazer's plan to spend $80 million of Zapata's money to buy Houlihan's created a outcry from investors, who promptly sued to block the deal. The investors won an important victory in September when the Delaware Court of Chancery ruled the deal would have to be approved by 80 percent of Zapata's shareholders, rather than a standard majority. Mr. Glazer owns a 73 percent stake in Houlihan's and would have received $29 million in cash from the purchase.   (AP)    KMART TO MERGE MANY CANADIAN BUSINESS FUNCTIONS  The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it would merge many of its Kmart Canada business functions into its United States operations. The move, which the giant retailer said was intended to maximize efficiencies, will result in 150 job cuts at the unit's head office in Brampton, Ontario, by the end of the year. Approximately 200 positions will remain in Canada and a number of new positions will be created in Troy, Mich., where Kmart is based, the company said. It was not specific about the number of new United States jobs.   (Reuters)    SBS TECHNOLOGIES TO ACQUIRE BIT 3 COMPUTER  SBS Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Bit 3 Computer Corporation, a privately held maker of computer networking products, for $24 million. SBS Technologies, a maker of electronic and computer products based in Albuquerque, N.M., said the purchase was contingent on an offering of its common stock, set to close Dec. 20. Bit 3 Computer had 1995 income of about $4.7 million before taxes on sales of about $12.5 million. SBS Technologies said costs associated with the purchase will reduce earnings in its second quarter ending Dec. 31 by $11 million, resulting in a loss for the quarter. In last year's second quarter, the company earned $776,000.   (Dow Jones)    POLISH AIRLINE BUYS TWO NEW BOEING AIRCRAFT  Poland's national airline LOT signed an agreement yesterday to acquire two new-generation planes from the Boeing Company in 1998 in a deal worth $90 million. LOT and Boeing also hope to complete negotiations later this year on the purchase and delivery of eight more Boeing 737-800's until the year 2002, under a long-term contract worth $360 million, officials said. The 737-800 model is Boeing's new jetliner with 162 to 189 seats, which will become available in 1998.   (AP)                     --------------------          BASF CORP., Mount Olive, N.J., a unit of Germany's BASF A.G., said it was exiting the magnetic tape business in North America, which will result in the elimination of 128 jobs and the closing of its BASF Magnetics Corp. operation in Bedford, Mass.      DOLE FOOD CO. Westlake Village, Calif., said it would buy back as much as 5 percent of its 60.1 million common shares outstanding.     JOHNSON CONTROLS INC., Milwaukee, a maker and marketer of energy-use systems, said it would close its valve plant in Milwaukee within two years, cutting 200 jobs and moving most of the production to Mexico.

headline: U.S. Jury Convicts Mexican on Drug Charges
abstract: Federal jury, Houston, Tex, convicts Juan Garcia Abrego of 22 counts of money laundering, drug possession and operating criminal enterprise that allegedly smuggled more than 200,000 pounds of cocaine and 46,000 pounds of marijuana from his native Mexico into US over 16-year period (M)

headline: Cross-Border Satellite Beams Get Mixed Reception
abstract: Otherwise law-abiding consumers in Canada and Mexico are openly buying and installing satellite dishes and subscribing to pirated services that bring them television shows from United States; Mexico and Canada have tried unsuccessfully to use regulations to keep programs out, while United States contends there should be same type of unfettered access for satellite signals as for other products under free trade pact; Mexican Government recently capitulated, but Ottawa, for cultural reasons, insists that at least half the programming on satellite service be Canadian, even though Canada so far has been unable to offer its own satellite service; although there are no legal satellite services in Canada, about 200,000 Canadians have bought dishes and signed up for gray market service that provides programming from United States that Canadian Government has warned is illegal; photo; drawing (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY   Earnings reports are expected from Boise Cascade and Chrysler.     TUESDAY   The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta releases its survey of manufacturing in the Southeast.   Earnings reports are expected from Ameritech, Caterpillar, Honeywell, and Raytheon.    WEDNESDAY   Bill Clinton and Bob Dole debate again, this time in San Diego.    THURSDAY   Archers Daniels Midland shareholders vote on whether to require a majority of its directors to be outsiders.   The Commerce Department reports on business inventories for August. In July they rose four-tenths of 1 percent.   Earnings reports are expected from AT&T, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth and Pacific Telesis.    FRIDAY   The Commerce Department reports on the trade deficit for August. In July it stood at $11.7 billion.

headline: Records Signal Lawyer's Role In Texaco Suit
abstract: Federal grand jury investigating scandal at Texaco Inc is said to have obtained records indicating that a company lawyer gave instructions on how to withhold damaging documents from plaintiffs suing company for racial discrimination; at issue is draft memo from 1994 reporting results of employee survey, including fact that only 37 percent believed criteria for promotions were applied consistently and fairly, and only 38 percent thought they could express such misgivings openly without fear of retribution; handwritten notation from lawyer advises Texaco executives to delay publishing survey results to avoid it becoming part of 'discovery' process in discrimination suit; in another development, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission informs both sides in suit that they cannot settle case without agency's participation (M)

headline: Cheering predictions of increased and sustained growth.
abstract: Robert J Coen (McCann-Erickson USA) and John Perriss (Zenith Media Worldwide) predict sustained growth in advertising spending for 1997 and rest of decade, Paine Webber Media Conference, New York City; Coen predicts advertisers will spend record $182.9 billion in United States in 1997, up 5.6 percent from $173.2 billion he now sees for 1996; graph (M)

headline: American Air Is Said to Plan Big Jet Order
abstract: American Airlines reportedly will order several hundred new Boeing jets, worth almost $6 billion, to be delivered through 2020; order reflects end to airline's long standoff with pilots union; is blow to McDonnell Douglas Corp, longtime American supplier (M)

abstract: USAir Group says it is in talks with the world's three biggest makers of commercial aircraft, Boeing, Airbus Industrie and McDonnell Douglas Corp; airline is in market for about 120 new jets (M)

headline: Refugees Flee Camps as Rebel Forces Drive Zairian Troops Back
abstract: United Nations officials say tens of thousands of Hutu refugees are fleeing Goma, Zaire, and aid agencies are preparing to evacuate workers as Tutsi rebels battle Zairian troops for control of airport (M)

headline: Report Says Colombia Misused U.S. Aid on Rebel War
abstract: Human Rights Watch/Americas report is second recent report charging United States aid to Colombia may have been diverted from fighting drug trafficking to undeclared war on leftist guerrillas; holds Colombian military, acting on US military advice, tightened ties with paramilitary fighers accused of killing civilians; holds military units aided by US protect fighters implicated in killing civilians from prosecutors and promote officers accused of directing killings; Asst Sec Robert S Gelbard holds US does not work with paramilitary groups (M)

headline: Search for Scholarships Can Be a Bitter Lesson
abstract: Scholarship search frauds are growing as families increasingly seek help with high college costs; Federal Trade Commission has charged six companies and two individuals with defrauding families; typical false claims by search firms cited; sampling of sources of information on scholarships and other aid; photo (M)

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group says its third-quarter operating profit fell 7 percent, to $1.82 billion, from year ago (S)

headline: Special Tax Breaks Enrich Savings Of Many in the Ranks of Management
abstract: First of two articles in the series Rushing Away From Taxes focuses on deferred compensation available to executives and other top employees of American companies but not to other employees; the executives let their companies hold on to some of their pay, often with high guaranteed return and matching contribution, and the taxes are not paid until they take the money years later; there are no Government limits on how much can be put away, and many top executives have put away millions; company and its shareholders pay taxes on the money while it remain in the company's hands, thus subsidizing the tax break; some companies buy life insurance policies on their executives to cut their tax liability; even in case of bankruptcy, which theoretically should jeopardize deferred income, top executives end up getting their money even as less powerful managers and rank-and-file workers lose some of their savings; photo; graph (L)

headline: Treasury Prices End Day Mixed
abstract: Treasury securities prices are mixed; 30-year bond falls 7/32, to 100 26/32, to yield 6.44%; graph (M)

headline: Blue Cross of Connecticut Said to Agree to a Merger
abstract: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut agrees to merge with Anthem Inc, big Midwestern insurance company that is rapidly expanding across the country; Connecticut insurer would become part of Anthem East Inc, based in Newark, along with Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in New Jersey and Delaware; with Connecticut, Anthem would have $10 billion in annual revenues; merger, which would require approval of state regulators, is not expected to involve cash payments; both companies are mutual insurers owned by their policyholders; analysts say dozens of other Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies will be making similar moves in next few years (M)

headline: Charles Schwab Widens Mutual Fund Access
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp announces that it will make its Mutual Fund Onesource program available for first time through another financial institution; two banks, Keycorp and First Union Corp, expect to offer their customers access to popular mutual fund supermarket, which includes more than 600 mutual funds available without a sales charge or transaction fee, sometime next year (S)

headline: Apple Is Beaten to a Pact For Use of Operating System
abstract: Power Computing Corp, largest maker of Macintosh clones, agrees to license new computer operating system produced by Be Inc, jumping ahead of Apple Computer Inc, which has been seeking alliance with Be; terms of deal between Be and Power Computing are not disclosed, but company says that by next year, customers will be able to buy operating system from Be's Internet site (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Consolidated Papers Inc says its president and chief executive, Patrick F Brennan, will retire on Dec 31; Gorton M Evans, executive vice president, will succeed him; Republic Industries names Steven R Berrard president and co-chief executive, an office whose duties will he will share with chairman, H Wayne Huizenga; Smith Corona Corp appoints Michael Driscoll president and chief executive, effective upon company's emergence from bankruptcy (S)

headline: Job Shifting Is Big Issue In G.M. Talks
abstract: Striking workers at General Motors Corp say their dispute is not only about corporate downsizing and job security, it is also about whether corporations owe easier jobs to older workers; most workers are effectively guaranteed jobs until retirement, but GM has not been hiring replacements for many retirees; instead, it asks more overtime of remaining workers and hires outside contractors to do less-skilled jobs that in the past were given to its older workers; analysts say presence of UAW workers earning $17 an hour to sweep floors is what is still wrong with GM; UAW wants GM to guarantee that its employment of UAW workers will stay at 95 percent; Ford and Chrysler have agreed to this, but GM is balking; GM uses more labor to produce each car, partly because it makes higher proportion of its parts in-house (M)

headline: In Response to Jewish Protests, Hungary Bans 'Mein Kampf'
abstract: Hungary, responding to protests from Jewish groups, bans Adolph Hitler's Mein Kampf, holding book violates individual rights; book was advertised in far-right newspaper (M)

headline: California Challenges Deal on Nonprofit Hospital
abstract: California Atty Gen Daniel E Lungren, in latest strong objection by a state to a deal between nonprofit and for-profit health-care companies, accuses directors of big San Diego hospital chain of undervaluing their business by $100 million to $200 million in joint venture with Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corp; threatens in letter to Sharp Healthcare to hold Sharp directors 'personally liable' for amount, and says he will open investigation of Sharp-Columbia deal (M)

headline: NORFOLK SOUTHERN ENDS TALKS WITH CSX
abstract: Norfolk Southern Corp terminates discussions with CSX Corp over their competitive bids to buy Conrail Inc; Norfolk Southern reaffirms its all-cash $100-a-share offer for Conrail (S)

headline: Cambodia's 2 Premiers Fight Over Ex-Rebels' Loyalty
abstract: Cambodia's two prime ministers, Hun Sen and Norodom Ranariddh, compete for loyalty of Khmer Rouge defectors, who may number 6,000 in northwest; defecting Khmer Rouge soldiers are issued crisp new Government uniforms and cigarettes by Hun Sen's commanders in remote jungle village of Samlot, historical stronghold for Khmer Rouge; map; Hun Sen appears to fear renewal of battlefield alliance against him by royalists, Khmer Rouge and other groups (S)

headline: United Fights Back With Western Shuttle
abstract: United Airlines has succeeded in retaining business travelers on West Coast in face of competition from low-cost Southwest Airlines by offering shuttle service between Los Angeles and San Francisco that preserves baggage check-in and first-class service; shuttle now commands 41 percent of traffic to Southwest's 43 percent and feeds other United flights (M)

headline: Why the Bull Is a Compulsive Climber
abstract: Possible explanations for continuing rise in stock prices discussed; graphs; drawing (L)

headline: S.&L.'s Post Loss After Insurance Fund Fee
abstract: Office of Thrift Supervision reports that United States savings and loan industry posted loss of $505 million in third quarter after paying one-time, $2.1 billion fee to replenish its deposit insurance fund; office says that savings institutions would have earned $1.6 billion in third quarter if special fee had not been paid; in return for the one-time insurance fund contribution, savings and loans will pay lower premiums to Savings Assn Insurance Fund, which will help earnings in subsequent quarters (M)

headline: Non-Communist Is Elected Romania's Leader
abstract: Romanian voters, after seven years of government rooted in Communist past, make clear break by electing reformer Emil Constantinescu President; incumbent Ion Iliescu. who has governed since overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu, concedes defeat; Constantinescu's victory, coupled with that of his opposition coalition in recent elections, creates totally new political realignment in Romania, which has been only country in Central and Eastern Europe to elect Governments of former Communists since collapse of Communism in 1989; photos (M)

abstract: Treasury market surges amid more signs that economy is slowing and inflation remains low; 30-year bond gains 1 16/32, to 98 29/32, to yield 6.58, down from 6.70 on Wednesday; chart (Credit Markets column) (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Expected During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, a 10-year note being auctioned Wednesday and a one-year bill to be auctioned Thursday.    At the close on Friday, traders said the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.86 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 5.03 percent and the one-year bill was 5.16 percent. In when-issued trading, the 10-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.47 percent.

headline: Dollar Falls Against the Yen After Ex-Official's Remarks
abstract: Dollar falls against yen after former Treasury Sec Lloyd Bentsen says further dollar gains would hurt American trade competitiveness (S)

headline: Swiss Used Nazi Victims' Money For War Payments, Files Reveal
abstract: Documents made public by Swiss historian Dr Peter Hug show unclaimed accounts of presumed Nazi Holocaust victims were used to ease Switzerland's postwar compensation disputes with Poland and Hungary under secret agreements; disclosure, based on research in Swiss National Archives, represents further blow to Switzerland's self-image and fuels assertions by American Jewish groups that despite its reputation for probity and neutrality, Switzerland drew financial benefit in many ways from Holocaust; has added to widening furor among American Jews and Swiss themselves about extensive and still largely secret dealings between Swiss banks and Nazi Germany, and about subsequent fate of untold amounts of money left in Swiss accounts and insurance funds by Holocaust victims; Hug says that on at least three occasions, between 1960 and 1975, Swiss invoked secret agreements with Poland and Hungary to compensate Swiss businesses (M)

headline: New Flat Rate Creates Surge In Use of America Online
abstract: Computer users eager to take advantage of America Online Inc's new flat-rate pricing plan overwhelm system, causing widespread busy signals across nation as subscribers try in vain to dial into on-line service's computers (M)

headline: S.E.C. Sues Wall St. Firm For Fraud
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission sues CS First Boston Corp for securities fraud in connection with 1994 underwriting of $110 million in pension bonds for Orange County, Calif; this is first of series of legal actions SEC is expected to bring against brokerage firms that underwrote bonds and notes for county, which filed for municipal bankruptcy in December 1994; Government contends that deteriorating condition of county investment pool was not disclosed to investors; CS First Boston denies SEC accusation; says Robert L Citron, former Orange County treasurer, was responsible for problems with pension bonds, which were not repaid in time; Citron has been sentenced to jail term and fined in connection with his role in bankruptcy (M)

headline: HUGHES ELECTRONICS WEIGHS SELLOFF
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp wants to sell its military and aerospace business; analysts say Raytheon Co seems most logical buyer (S)þ

MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 7/   Reaching out to Generation X with some financial advice. By Barbara Whitaker. headline: Mystery of Russian Spacecraft: How Did It Fall Back to Earth?
abstract: Mystery emerges about when failed Mars-bound Russian spacecraft re-entered Earth's atmosphere and where it fell, day after it reportedly landed harmlessly in Pacific Ocean; Russian space officials insist unmanned space probe did not land in one piece, as initially announced by US; admit failure has dealt devastating blow space program that had once been source of deep national pride (M)
