abstract: Fortis, the Belgian-Dutch bank and insurer, will pay 2.5 billion guilders ($1.43 billion) in cash for Mees Pierson NV from ABN-Amro Holdings NV (S)

headline: A small thing like a new bump maker might make mountains if understood differently.
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office's gazette of some 2,000 patents issued each week shows vast amount of engineering, mechanics and chemistry it takes to keep modern industry running smoothly; majority of new patents are for complex engineering mechanisms and chemical compounds and many are 'incremental' improvements on existing mechanisms (M)

headline: Iraq Gets U.N. Approval to Sell Oil to Meet Civilian Needs
abstract: UN grants Iraq permission to sell limited amounts of oil to raise money for food, medicine and other urgent civilian needs (M)

headline: Enron Names Trading Chief As President of Company
abstract: Enron Corp names Jeffrey K Skilling president and chief operating officer; he succeeds Richard D Kinder and will remain Enron Capital & Trade Resources unit chairman (M)

headline: Mexican Writers Killed After Underworld Book
abstract: Yolanda Figueroa and her husband, Fernando Balderas, and their three children are murdered in Mexico City, and there are suspicions of involvement of drug traffickers or the police because Figueroa and Balderas collaborated on a book about Juan Garcia Abrego, a cocaine trafficker recently convicted in Texas (S)

headline: Strike Begins as Talks Fail With G.M. of Canada
abstract: Workers walk off job at General Motors Canada assembly plants after GM and Canadian Automobile Workers union break off talks; Basil E Hargrove, union's president, claims GM refuses to address union's concerns about GM's parts purchases from outside vendors; GM Canada spokesman, D Stewart Low, concedes that main sticking point is provision already accepted by Chrysler Corp that would effectively prevent GM from buying more parts from outside vendors; Low says GM could not live with such restrictions on outsourcing; Canadian union had expected its pact with Chrysler to set pattern for industry (M)

headline: Bonus Pay at the Top
abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; mutual fund company chief executives will earn average of $1.02 million in 1996, largely in bonuses, up 6.2% from 1995; table (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: National Home Health Care Corp says it reached agreement to acquire certain assets of C J Home Care Inc; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Tajik Gunmen Seize 23 Hostages, Including 8 U.N. Observers
abstract: Gunmen loyal to rebel warlord Rizvon (Rambo) Sadirov stop convoy of peace negotiators in Tajikistan and seize 23 people, including eight United Nations military observers; threaten to kill hostages and detonate bombs around Dushanbe unless Russian border guards create safe corridor for Sadirov's Afghanistan-based fighters to return to Tajikistan; unrest worsens as Pres Imomali Rakhmanov holds peace talks, Moscow, with opposition leader, Sayed Abdullah Nuri; map (M)

headline: Watching Those Who Watch Fidelity
abstract: Funds Watch column on newsletters advising on Fidelity investments (S)

headline: Zaire Sets Stringent Terms for Effort to Help Refugees
abstract: Governmnent of Zaire, still reeling from loss of several important border cities to Rwanda-backed rebels, sets stringent conditions for any Western-led intervention on its soil, and vows to recapture lands, regardless of cost; France presses efforts to gain international support for military intervention in Zaire that would seek to rescue more than one million refugees from Rwanda and Burundi scattered from camps in Zaire by recent fighting; photos; maps (M)

headline: A Drive to the Mall to Shop on Line (Huh?)
abstract: Virtual Emporium in Santa Monica, Calif, is believed to be the first outlet in a shopping mall that allows people to browse and shop via computer; electronic shopping has been seen as something to do from the home or office, but only 15 percent of households have the requisite link to the World Wide Web; Virtual Emporium makes money by selling Internet vendors advertising space on store's walls and providing some of those companies with customer data; photo (M)

headline: Scaled-Down Aid: Perils Lurk in Plans for Zaire
abstract: Analysis: even scaled-down plan to airdrop relief to Rwandan refugees is fraught with problems and could worsen conflict in eastern Zaire between Zairian rebels of Tutsi ethnic group and Hutu fighters who fled from Rwanda two years ago; relief supplies could fall into militias' hands and help sustain them; photo (M)

headline: OWENS-ILLINOIS IN DEAL FOR ITALIAN GLASS MAKER
abstract: Owens-Illinois Inc to buy Italy's largest maker of glass containers, Avir SpA, for about $580 million in cash, to expand its overseas business (S)

headline: The Sudan's Islamic Leader: Enigmatic Foe for the West
abstract: Hassan al-Turabi, leader of Sudan, assails the United States for providing military aid to his hostile neighbors--Uganda, Ethiopia and Eritrea--and warns that he may strike back at US, indirectly; US, which believes that Sudan serves as a safe house for stateless revolutionaries and may provide training centers for international terrorists, is searching for right combination of political, economic, diplomatic and indirect military pressure to compel Turabi to change his behavior without touching off new fighting in Sudan's long civil war or adding to misery of Sudanese people; photo; map (M)

headline: Valujet Planes Flying Half-Full
abstract: Valujet Inc reports that its planes flew less than half full in November, typically one of the busiest times for air travel, as carrier struggles to regain market in wake of fatal crash and three-month shutdown (S)

headline: Still going after laughs, ESPN decides that it hasn't heard enough of Robert Goulet's baritone.
abstract: Advertising column notes ESPN has signed old-fashioned crooner Robert Goulet for second year to promote its college basketball schedule; Goulet spots are part of overall image ad campaign created for ESPN by Weiden & Kennedy that uses celebrities and Olympic athlets in humorous commercials to promote network's games and programs (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * David Pearson Associates, Coral Gables, Fla., a public relations agency specializing in travel accounts, agreed to merge with another public relations agency, Rubin Barney & Birger, Coral Gables. Terms were not disclosed. Pearson's five employees will join Rubin Barney as the Pearson Group.    * Dennis Rodman, the basketball player for the Chicago Bulls, was signed to appear in a humorous television campaign to promote Advantix cameras and film for the Eastman Kodak Co. Terms were not disclosed. J. Walter Thompson New York, a unit of WPP Group, will create the campaign.    * Millie Olson and Lynda Pearson, former creative executives at Ketchum Advertising San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group, opened Amazon Advertising, San Francisco, where they are partners.    * FCB Health Care, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications, acquired Art for Marketing, Rye, N.Y., which specializes in managed-care accounts. Terms were not disclosed. Art for Marketing will be combined with the New York operations of FCB Health Care.    * Tishman Urban Development Corp., New York, awarded TDI, New York, a unit of the Infinity Broadcasting Corp., a 20-year contract for the ad signage for the E Walk Complex, part of the redevelopment of Times Square. The contract covers 20,000 square feet of billboard space at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.

headline: Administration Proposes Paying U.N. Debt, but Congress Resists
abstract: Clinton Administration, having orchestrated ouster of United Nations Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali, faces increasing diplomatic pressure to pay United States's outstanding UN dues; Congressional Republicans say they will not authorize funds until his successor, Kofi Annan, shows that he will streamline UN budget and bureaucracy (M)

headline: Egypt Adding Corn to Bread: An Explosive Mix?
abstract: Egyptian Government, in move to reduce heavy subsidy it pays to keep price of bread low, decrees that it should be made, beginning December 96, with 20 percent Egyptian corn instead of totally from whole wheat flour, most of which is imported; possible political risks for Government because of past links between bread and domestic discontent discussed; photo (M)

headline: America Online Announces A Newer Transformation
abstract: America Online Inc's chairman Stephen M Case announces new pricing setup, new management organization, a new top manager and new accounting policies; Robert W Pittman will join America Online to run new AOL Networks division; Pittman and Case say that America Online will use its position as largest on-line service to bring the Internet to the masses (L)

headline: Clinton's Chief Economist Accepts Post at World Bank
abstract: Joseph E Stiglitz to resign as Council of Economic Advisers chairman to become World Bank chief economist (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   Looking for an all-weather stock? Consider RPM Inc., maker of the rust preventer Rust-Oleum. By Sana Siwolop.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/   A British scandal has spread to two Dean Witter mutual funds. Shareholders have not lost any money, but they may wonder who is minding the store. By Edward Wyatt.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6/   T. Rowe Price calls the new Simple 401(k) plan for small companies a nonstarter. Employers can do better with other retirement plans, says the big fund company. By Timothy Middleton.    SPENDING IT /Page 7/   Parents of disabled children need to plan not just for their education, but for a lifetime.  By Barbara Whitaker.

headline: NEOSTAR RETAIL GROUP TO AUCTION OFF ITS ASSETS
abstract: Neostar Retail Group, which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, says it has been unable to secure further financing and will auction off its assets (S)

headline: Benetton Profits Rise, But Sales Are Flat
abstract: Benetton SpA says its profit rose 9 percent in first half of year, to $77.3 million, even as its revenue held steady (S)

headline: TV: Evolving Window on the World
abstract: Chronology of slow evolution of television technology, which is now poised to become a revolution as digital television sets go on market and digital broadcasts go on air in about 18 months; photos (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: American General Corp names Robert M Devlin, company president, as chief executive; says Devlin will replace retiring chairman Harold S Hook as chairman next year (S)

headline: MOLTEN METAL TECHNOLOGY PLANS STOCK REPURCHASE
abstract: Molten Metal Technology Inc plans to buy back as much as two million shares, or 8.5 percent of its stock, which plunges 49 percent after Energy Dept says it will give company only $8 million of expected $20 million to research recycling of radioactive scrap metal (S)

headline: Bonn Stake in Lufthansa To Be Sold to Bank
abstract: German Government to sell its Lufthansa shares to state-owned bank, Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau, by end of year to help reduce Germany's budget deficit; sale marks first step in remaining privatization of Lufthansa (S)

headline: New Fighting in Northern Iraq Causes a Jump in Oil Prices
abstract: Crude oil prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange as renewed fighting between Kurdish factions in northern Iraq spark concern that broader military conflict may threaten Persian Gulf exports; crude oil for Nov delivery gains 96 cents, to $25.62 a barrel; activity in other futures markets also discussed (M)

headline: A Shadow Over the Mideast: Arab Youths on a Short Fuse
abstract: New generation of Palestinian youths, virtually uneducated and full of hatred, could be powder keg that sets off even more violence against Israel; incident in which teen-agers in Al Aroub throw burning bottles of gasoline at Israeli soldiers is example; photo; map; youths seem to have little ideology, saying they support anyone willing to kill Jews; Al Aroub refugee camp outside Hebron is squalid warren of concrete-block houses, where Arabs live six and eight to a room, with no trees, gardens or even flower boxes; younger relatives of Palestinians who started intifada in 1980's lack even remittances from relatives who used to work in Persian Gulf, and know only curfews, shootings and grinding poverty (S)

headline: After Busy Weekend, Pope Enters Hospital for Surgery
abstract: Pope John Paul II enters Rome hospital to undergo surgery for what doctors say is inflamed appendix; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: RHONE-POULENC RORER INC. (RPR,N)
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc reports that third-quarter earnings rose 19.5 percent to $97.4 million from year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: Fighters in Afghan Mountains Live for Next Battle
abstract: Afghan fighters loyal to Ahmad Shah Massoud, opponent of Taliban fundamentalists who control Afghanistan, express no fear of death, only general sense that life spent roaming ancient land in pursuit of battle is about all that any Afghan man can expect; photo; map (M)

headline: Japan, in Error, Overstated the Foreign Share of Its Chip Market
abstract: Japan says it unintentionally overstated share of its market held by foreign semiconductor companies in first quarter of 1996, at time when US and Japan were negotiating a new computer chip trade agreement; foreign manufacturers held a 26.9 percent share of market in first quarter, not the initially announced 30.6 percent, a figure cited by Japanese at the time in arguing that no new agreement was necessary (M)

headline: Banner Ads On Internet Attract Users
abstract: Comment on banners--tiny display advertisements that are cyberspace equivalent of billboards; new study from Hotwired, Internet media service of Wired Ventures Inc, concludes that banner advertising influences attitudes of computer users because they make measurable advertising impressions, which can help build the brands being advertised (M)

headline: RENCO GROUP OFFERS TO BUY WCI STEEL STOCK
abstract: WCI Steel Inc says its largest shareholder, Renco Group Inc, has made offer to take steelmaker private for about $69 miliion (S)

headline: Indenet to Merge With Petry Media
abstract: Indenet Inc and Petry Media Corp agree in principle to merge; Petry chairman and chief executive Thomas F Burchill will retain posts in combined firm, not yet named (S)

headline: Is VW's New Plant Lean, Or Just Mean?
abstract: Volkswagen's new truck and bus factory in Resende, Brazil, is expected to revolutionize auto manufacturing by man who designed it, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua; plant transforms Volkswagen from a manufacturer into a contractor, overseeing work of other companies; eight major subcontractors have their own shops along assembly line, where their workers assemble components; only 20 percent of workers in plant are Volkswagen employees, and they are responsible only for overall quality control, marketing, and research and design; Volkswagen says new system will reduce number of defective parts, improve efficiency and cut costs; subcontractors' assembly-line workers are paid a third as much as auto workers; Lopez quit General Motors in 1993 because it would not build his 'dream factory'; GM accused Lopez of stealing its plans for 'Plant X' and building it for Volkswagen; diagram; photo; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Asian Markets Roiled As Bond Market Dives  The bond market went into its steepest dive in more than three months in heavy trading, after a steady climb for much of the last few weeks. Made nervous by a weaker dollar, many investors sold Treasury securities ahead of today's employment report.    The yield of 6.50 percent on the 30-year Treasury bond was up from 6.39 percent on Wednesday and matched the highest yield in nearly a month. $(Page D13.$)    Asian markets reacted strongly to the bond activity in the United States and to the remarks of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. The Nikkei index dropped 3.19  percent and the Hang Seng index was down more than 4 percent in late trading. $(Page D6.$)    Circuit Breaker Shift Sought;  Dow and Nasdaq Make Small Gains   The New York Stock Exchange proposed making the circuit breakers that halt trading when prices plunge less restrictive than they are now -- though still far tighter than when they were introduced in 1988. The Dow industrials gained 14.16 points, closing at 6,437.10, and the Nasdaq composite rose 3.10 points, to 1,300.12; broader averages fell. $(D6.$)    Imported Cars Roaring Back   Japanese and European auto makers have come roaring back to the United States, by cutting prices and increasing rebates, moves made possible by the dollar's surge in the last year. Consequently, Detroit faces its toughest competition since the early 1990's. $(A1.$)    Chrysler Moves Reflect Success   With brisk sales of Jeeps and mini-vans producing a torrent of cash, Chrysler said that it would raise its quarterly dividend, buy back more stock and make management changes to reward executives responsible for its success. Robert A. Lutz, its president, will stay on past the retirement age of 65 as vice chairman. $(D3.$)    Nippon Telephone to Restructure   In a restructuring that would reshape Japanese telecommunications, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone agreed to split into a long-distance service provider and two regional companies for local service. $(D2.$)     N.A.S.D. Expels Stratton Oakmont   The N.A.S.D. expelled Stratton Oakmont, the Lake Success, L.I., brokerage firm, from the securities industry, calling it ''an ongoing risk to the investing public.'' Market Place. $(D6.$)    Bells Retreat on Television Plans   Bell Atlantic and Nynex, which plan to merge, are retreating from a key part of their strategy to expand into television through wireless cable technology, according to people familiar with the companies. $(D4.$)    $1.4 Billion Bid on Mexican Rail   A Mexican-United States joint venture bid $1.4 billion for a 50-year concession to operate Mexico's main railroad line. $(D2.$)    Asset Swap for Redwoods Offered   The Federal Government and the State of California offered oil and gas fields, timberland and other property worth at least $380 million in return for a large grove of Northern California redwoods controlled by Maxxam Inc. of Houston. $(A18.$)    Productivity and Jobless Claims Off   Productivity fell a revised three-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, and first-time jobless claims fell last week, hinting inflationary pressures could lie ahead. $(D2.$)

headline: Industrial Output Down In August in Japan
abstract: Japan's industrial production for August dropped 2.3 percent from previous month, second time in three months key indicator of manufacturing strength has fallen (S)

headline: With Elections Over, The Board Races Begin
abstract: THE 1996 elections are barely over, but another race is already on for many losers, retirees and defectors from the Clinton Administration, and it ends in the corporate board room. A few companies have put out the word that they would like political insiders on their boards -- despite investor questions about such celebrity directors -- executive recruiters say.    And some of the newly unemployed in Washington are actively seeking such positions.

headline: A Web Guide for Election Enthusiasts
abstract: On Election Day, World Wide Web will offer results, projections and exit polls by state, county and even precinct; on some sites, right Web browser will let user watch numbers change (M)

headline: 2 Australian Banks In $2.1 Billion Merger
abstract: St George Bank Ltd and Advance Bank of Australia Ltd announce they will merge in transaction worth $2.65 billion (Australian), or $2.1 billion (US) (S)

headline: How a Stalled Submarine Sank North Korea's Hopes
abstract: Intrusion of North Korean submarine into South Korean waters appears to have scuttled process of engagement intended to bring North Korea out of isolation and help ease its famine; submarine mission could hardly have been more catastrophic for North Korea's interests; political experts say that inter-Korean relations will eventually get back on track, but some fear that tensions could unravel recent progress; photo (M)

headline: Canada Strike Against G.M. Widens as Two Sides Harden
abstract: Canadian Automobile Workers strike against General Motors in Canada widens as GM chairman John F Smith Jr holds firm needs to cut costs, news conference; union, which now has all 26,000 GM workers on strike, demands broad curbs on GM's ability to shrink work force further and buy more parts from outside vendors; analysts warn strike could last several weeks, threatening over 100,000 United States workers with temporary layoffs (M)

headline: Strong 3d-Quarter Results Push Time Warner Stock Up
abstract: Time Warner Inc's president Richard D Parsons says he and president and chief executive of US West Media Group, Charles Lillis, had informal discussions about settlement between the two companies over ownership of Time Warner Entertainment; Time Warner reports that its loss for third quarter widened to 43 cents a share from 41 cents a share in quarter a year earlier; cash flow rose 32 percent in the quarter, to $964 million; stock rises $1, or 2.4 percent, to $41.875 a share; table (L)7

headline: France Is Style, America Is JustBeauty
abstract: PARIS—  As everyone knows, nations are over, just like history. This is the age of the world brand,the international consumer, fashion on the Web hitting every part of the Earth, street style in the global village.

headline: Iraq Hunts Anti-Hussein Gunmen
abstract: Iraqi authorities hunt armed men who wounded Pres Saddam Hussein's son, Uday, in attack on Baghdad street (S)

headline: Microsoft Pushing To Alter Standard For Digital TV
abstract: Microsoft Corp and its computer-industry allies lobby Federal Communications Commission, seeking to block or modify planned technical standards for advanced digital television broadcasting, the next generation of television; equipment makers and broadcasters worked for eight years to develop new standard, but Microsoft and allies argue that it could hinder computer industry's future use of broadcast spectrum; computer coalition has proposed video system technology now used by computer industry, which is not wholly compatible with current broadcasting systems; proposal also abandons superior high-definition picture quality that was original goal of advanced television; FCC urges compromise (M)

headline: Taking the Challenge of Streamlining Credit Suisse
abstract: Interview with Lukas Muhlemann, who will soon become Credit Suisse chief executive and begin sweeping reorganization and streamlining (M)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  None    WEDNESDAY  Producer Prices Oct.    THURSDAY  Consumer Prices Oct.  Retail Sales Oct.  Weekly Jobless Claims     FRIDAY  Industrial Production Oct.  Capacity Utilization Oct.  Inventory-Sales Ratio Sept.

headline: Stocks Climb in Tokyo
abstract: Stocks rise in Tokyo on Nov 1; benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues closes up 166.20 points, at 20,633.06 (S)

headline: As Shouts Die Down, Japan Is Ready for National Vote
abstract: Japanese cast ballots in national elections; first major test of new electoral system may move nation back to traditional domination of Liberal Democratic Party, or usher into power opposition parties that talk of far-reaching changes to open up government, business and society; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto, Liberal Democrat heading coalition Government, speaks at final rally; Ichiro Ozawa of New Frontier Party also appeals for votes (S)

headline: ZURN INDUSTRIES TO BUY ELJER FOR $171.7 MILLION
abstract: Zurn Industries. Erie, Pa, says it will buy Eljer Industries, Dallas, for $24 a share, or $171.7 million (S)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues drops 167.70 points, to 20,870.83 (Wed, 10/9) (S)

headline: Sumitomo Copper Trader Seized on Forgery Count
abstract: Yasuo Hamanaka, former Sumitomo Corp copper trader who exerted enormous influence on world copper markets even as he piled up $2.6 billion in trading losses, is arrested in Japan on forgery charges; arrest had been expected and is first to arise from investigations being carried on in Japan, US and Britain into possible illegal manipulation of copper market; key question for investigators is whether Hamanaka's colleagues and superiors at Sumitomo knew of Hamanaka's activities or cooperated with him; photo (L)

headline: Trader to Be Penalized for Fraud
abstract: Kent A Ahrens, securities trader who made unauthorized bets against the stock market that resulted in losses of $137.6 million for group of college endowment funds, agrees to plead guilty to one count of fraud; he has also agreed to pay $182,000 to settle Federal securities civil actions; Ahrens agrees to be barred permanently from acting as a broker, dealer, investment adviser or municipal securities dealer; Ahrens was trader with First Capital Strategists Inc (M)

headline: A Swift Transformation
abstract: Analysis; Boeing Co's acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp signifies near-completion of one of swiftest and most complete transformations ever of an industry, as matter of explicit Government policy; lesson is that Clinton Administration has largely succeeded in transforming country's military contractors, during span of just four years, into instruments of one of its most important goals, namely, of making economy more competitive globally (M)

headline: Austria's Largest Bank To Bid for Stake in Rival
abstract: Bank Austria AG plans to bid for Austrian Government's 49 percent equity stake in rival Creditanstalt-Bankverein (S)

headline: House Resales Fell by 1.5% In October
abstract: National Assn of Realtors reports that sales of existing houses dropped by 1.5 percent in October, fifth consecutive monthly drop, providing further evidence that housing market is slowing; housing resales declined to annual rate of 3.97 million in October, and figure for September has been revised to 2.7 percent; despite deceline in resales, average of monthly resales will set record of more than four million this year (M)

headline: But What Does It Have to Do With Jeans?
abstract: San Francisco buses carry Joop Jeans Vote! advertising campaign that turns Presidential candidates into carnival figures; Los Angeles refused advertising; photo (S)

headline: Rival Bidders Raise Offers For Conrail
abstract: CSX Corporation and its rival, Norfolk Southern Corp, increase their bids for control of Conrail and rail freight traffic in Northeast; CSX raises its friendly cash-and-stock bid for Conrail by $870 million, to $9.3 billion; Conrail directors agree not to consider takeover proposal from any other company until 1999; Norfolk Southern revises its bid: $10.5 billion cash, or $115 a share; Norfolk Southern also files suit, United States District Court, Philadelphia, seeking to dismantle lockup provision that binds Conrail to CSX for next two years (M)

headline: J. P. Morgan Takes Space For Private Bank Group
abstract: J P Morgan & Co leases office space at Park Ave and 52d St, New York City, for private-client business (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.88 percent and a six-month bill was 5.00 percent.

headline: Corsicans Say They Set Bomb In Bordeaux
abstract: Corsican National Liberation Front, militant Corsican separatist group that broke off secret talks with French Government in August, admits responsibility for bomb that damaged office of Prime Min Alain Juppe in Bordeaux, where he is Mayor (M)

headline: Challenge to Bid for Funeral Home Operator Is Allowed to Proceed
abstract: Loewen Group says that Texas court has dismissed lawsuit filed by Service Corp International that sought to stop antitrust challenge of its $3.2 billion hostile takeover bid for Loewen, second-largest operator of funeral homes in United States (S)

headline: A Tale of Stock Promotion, Regulation and the Internet
abstract: Internet technology is having effects, good and bad, on investors and investing; reams of information are available, but truthfulness and accuracy can be almost impossible to judge; amateur investors find their way to obscure securities and mingle on line with both stock promoters trying to drive prices up and short-sellers trying to drive prices down; securities regulators are becoming more aggressive about on-line stock fraud as on-line investing grows by leaps and bounds; in one high-technology hype, an investor in Omnigene Diagnostics sensed something amiss when he read information on its Web site; he then used Internet to notify SEC and warn other investors; photos; charts (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Keating S.& L. Conviction  Thrown Out by U.S. Judge   Charles H. Keating Jr., whom the Government once called the most notorious swindler in the savings and loan crisis, had his last criminal conviction thrown out by a Federal judge after four and a half years in prison.

headline: Current Account Deficit Soars in South Korea
abstract: South Korea's current account deficit soared tenfold in November as exports tumbled, driving year's shortfall to record high (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: Table shows US petroleum data for weeks ending Dec 6 and 13, 1996, and Dec 16, 1995

headline: Malaysia Readies a Crackdown on Illegal Workers
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  A decade of rapid economic growth has provided abundant jobs and rising living standards in Malaysia, but it has also created for some an unwelcome side-effect: a flood of illegal migrants smuggled in by land and sea, mainly from Bangladesh and Indonesia.

headline: Film Makers Fail to Win Concession in Digital TV Standard
abstract: New standard for digital television, despite aggressive lobbying by film makers, contains no assurances that movies will not be cropped to fit screens of next generation of television sets; film makers plan to continue drive, opposed by broadcasters and large movie studios, to end cropping (M)

headline: Tuition Costs:Colleges Open To Bargaining
abstract: BOSTON—  Sticker price,the parlance of the car dealer's showroom,is a new catchword in American higher education.

headline: Motorola Plans New Global Satellite System
abstract: Motorola Inc to build $6.1 billion satellite network during the next four years that can send voice, video and data to companies anywhere in the world; project, called M-Star, is designed to help speed up communications through private corporate networks; analysts say it will be many years before it can be known whether M-Star will be profitable for Motorola (M)

headline: Microsoft Sees Big Internet Loss
abstract: Microsoft Corp expects to lose over $1 billion over next three years on its Internet and news services before they break even (S)

headline: 15 Years Of Fujimori? Peru Faces Its Future
abstract: Debate in Peru rages over whether President Alberto K Fujimori should run for third term; when Fujimori was first elected President in 1990, Constitution prohibited re-election; after he dismissed Congress and seized near dictorial powers in 1992, Fujimori got new Congress to change Constitution to allow two consecutive five-year terms; he now has persuaded Congress to approve legal interpretation that considers his current term his first under new Constitution and therefore he would be eligible for third term (M)

headline: A tract close to the airport, too noisy for houses, becomes the hot industrial site near Indianapolis.
abstract: Opus North Corp is developing huge warehouse and distribution park outside Indianapolis, Ind; project is third for Opus on land along Interstate 70 (M)

headline: Making Money the Makeshift Way At Small Mail-Order Food Houses
abstract: Dozens of small mail-order food businesses live for December, when most of year's business comes their way; some market themselves, but for many the introduction to broad public comes courtesy of big merchants like Neiman Marcus or Williams-Sonoma, many of whose food items are not made anywhere near headquarters; Direct Marketing Association reports food by mail has become an increasingly popular catalogue item for Christmas; says in 1994, nearly eight million items were delivered by mail, up from about five million in 1990; photos; graph on ordering food from catalogues (M)

headline: Dubliners Outraged At Sellers Of Heroin
abstract: Thousands of residents of Dublin, Ireland, are demonstrating against drug dealers in their neighborhoods; officials say they fear that some of 40 or so anti-drug groups are on verge of vigilante violence (M)

headline: New Attention to Harsh Conditions in Peru's Prisons
abstract: Notoriously harsh prison conditions inside Peru's penitentiary system have emerged as likely bargaining point in negotiations to free remaining hostages held by Tupac Amaru guerrillas in Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima; rebels, who initially demanded freedom for all imprisoned comrades, indicate they may be willing to settle for release of some compatriots and better prison conditions for others (M)

headline: CARTER-WALLACE REJECTS $928 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Carter-Wallace Inc says that its biggest shareholder, CPI Development Corp, has rejected a sweetened $928 million buyout offer from financier Marvin Davis through his closely held Davis Companies (S)

headline: Wired Ventures Withdraws Initial Offering for 2d Time
abstract: Wired Ventures Inc says that it has withdrawn its initial public offering for second time, citing a market unreceptive to Internet-related companies; Internet investment mania has peaked before Wired could do its deal, and 'fanzine' of digital revolution now faces ultimate humiliation, a failed initial public offering (M)

headline: NEW OFFICER NAMED AT PUERTO RICO BOTTLER
abstract: Pepsi-Cola Puerto Rico Bottling Co names John W Beck new chairman and says its former chairman and chief executive, Charles Beach, has given up control of the company; the concern is a bottler for Pepsico, which does not have a stake in the company (S)

headline: People
abstract: David Wheldon, advertising director at the Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, was promoted to the new position of director for marketing for the Greater Europe Group. Ian Rowden, deputy advertising director, succeeds him.    Victoria Lasdon Rose was named publisher at Mademoiselle magazine, New York, owned by Advance Publications, succeeding Catherine Viscardi Johnston, who had been promoted to senior vice president for group sales and marketing at the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance. Ms. Rose was publisher at YM magazine, New York, part of the Gruner & Jahr U.S.A. Publishing unit of Bertelsmann A.G.    Mike Troiano, chief executive of the Ogilvy & Mather Interactive division of Ogilvy & Mather Direct, a unit of WPP Group, left to join the Cunniff Interactive Agency, New York, in a similar capacity.    William Croasdale, president of the national broadcast division of the Western International Media Corp., Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named chairman for media operations, a new post. Also, Dawn Sibley was named president for Western's local broadcast division, succeeding Elaine Kaplan, who resigned. Ms. Sibley had been president at Media Partnership, Norwalk, Conn.    John Amicangelo was named creative director at Pamet River Partners, Boston, succeeding Brad Pruett, who left to join Parish, Wickersham & Partners, Boston, in a similar capacity. Mr. Amicangelo had been vice president and creative director at Duval, Woglom, Brueckner & Partners, Boston.    Kay Allison was named business development director at J. Walter Thompson Chicago, a unit of the WPP Group, succeeding Suzanne Hart, who left. Ms. Allison had served in a similar capacity at Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, a unit of True North Communications.    Richard W. Edelman, president and co-chief executive at the New York office of Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, was named chief executive, assuming responsibilities from his father, Daniel J. Edelman, who continues as chairman, based in Chicago. Pam Talbot, president at Edelman West, Chicago, was named to the new post of president and chief operating officer at Edelman U.S. And Leslie Dach, general manager of the Washington office, was named to the new post of senior executive president and vice chairman at Edelman Worldwide.    Geoff Calnan was named to the new post of president at Electric Ideas, Santa Monica, Calif. He had been executive vice president for advertising and promotions at the Fox Broadcasting Co., Century City, Calif., a unit of the News Corp.    Kraig Kessel, design director at Addison Seefeld & Brew, San Francisco, was promoted to co-creative director, a new post, sharing duties with Paul Daddino. David Takeuchi succeeds Mr. Kessel as design director; he had been an associate at Gensler Associates, Los Angeles.    Jeff Hasen, a vice president at Evans Group Public Relations, Salt Lake City, was named director of a new sports division.    Mary Beth Wright, advertising director at US magazine, New York, a unit of Wenner Media, was promoted to associate publisher, a new post.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: New affiliations and strategic partnerships in advertising field noted (S)

headline: Choosing a Career: Attitudes and Aptitudes
abstract: Letter by Don Hutcheson and Bob D McDonald on how their Highlands Program uses aptitude or ability testing to help people choose careers

headline: Mean Business Is Sad Business
abstract: Article by Brian Fugere, official at Deloitte & Touche Consulting Group, discusses decision by Albert J Dunlap, chairman and chief executive of Sunbeam Corp, to cut more than 50 percent of workforce; notes Dunlap's basic philosophy centers on single-minded focus on short-term interests of shareholders and that mention of his hiring at Sunbeam nearly doubled Sunbeam's stock price; says corporate America has learned hard way that job cuts, unaccompanied by changes in work itself, are in long run often illusory (M)

headline: ECONOMIC GROWTH RETREATS TO 2.2%
abstract: Commerce Department reports slowdown of 2.2 percent in economic growth in third quarter of '96 but says that there is no sign of revival of even modest inflation; economists, many of whom expected slowdown, differ over whether it represents beginning of longer downturn or brief slowing of expansion that can sustained well into '97; Clinton and Dole Presidential campaigns each claim report bolsters sharply conflicting assessments of nation's economic health; Commerce Sec Mickey Kantor says economy is still growing faster than in 'go-go' '80's, but Bob Dole says economy is barely afloat; map; charts (M)

headline: SHARES OF DSP COMMUNICATIONS DECLINE 32%
abstract: DSP Communications Inc agrees to buy rival wireless equipment maker, Proxim Inc, for $400 million in stock, causing plunge in DSP shares on concern that price is too high (S)

headline: GRANITE CONSTRUCTION TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN TIC HOLDINGS
abstract: Granite Construction agrees to acquire 30 percent of TIC Holdings Inc for $21 million (S)

headline: Apple Software Leader Quits; New Questions for Company
abstract: Isaac Nassi resigns as head of Apple Computer's troubled operating systems division, raising new questions about Apple's ability to differentiate its Macintosh operating system from Microsoft Corp's Window 95 program (S)

headline: Unicef Head Says Thousands of Children Are Dying in Iraq
abstract: Carol Bellamy, executive director of Unicef, says approximately 4,500 childrenm under age of 5 are dying every months in Iraq of hunger and disease; appeals for donations from governments (M)

headline: Deadline on Conrail Unfair, Witness Says
abstract: Expert witness for Norfolk Southern Corp in its effort to block acquisition of Conrail by CSX Corp says Conrail shareholders will tender their shares to avoid missing cash portion of two-tiered CSX offer unless CSX's deadline of Nov 20 is lifted; Norfolk Southern charges Conrail violated Federal securities laws by making misleading statements to coerce shareholders into tendering shares to CSX (S)

headline: British Asset Manager To Sell Its Swiss Bank
abstract: British investment manager Mercury Asset Management says that it will sell its Swiss private bank Mercury Bank AG to Luxembourg-based Safra Republic Holdings SA for about $192 million (S)

headline: Tickets on Sale! But Is the Show a Dud?
abstract: Ticketmaster's plan to sell shares of its own stock assessed; photo (S)

headline: Indonesia Sells Shares In Telephone Monopoly
abstract: Indonesian Government sells 388 million shares of its domestic phone monopoly, PT Telkom, 4.15 percent of its stake, for 1.41 trillion rupiah (about $600 million); sale is third-largest sale of Indonesian shares ever (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.63   5.68        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.01   5.00   5.23        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.08   5.06   5.29        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.37   6.33   6.03        30-YR. TREAS.
