headline: Retail Growth Proves Slowest In Northeast
abstract: Retail sales in Northeast appear to be lagging behind those in rest of country in 1996; Tactical Retail Solutions, retail consulting firm, says sales in Pacific region gained 9.5 percent, and in South Atlantic region they rose 8.5 percent, while in mid-Atlantic region they rose mere 1 percent; for first 10 months of year, sales at malls in Northeast gained 3.3 percent, lower than 3.7 percent gains posted by malls nationwide, according to International Council of Shopping Centers; disappointing retail sales in Northeast underscore region's generally poor economic performance (M)

headline: MCI Wins Right to Begin Broadcast Satellite Services
abstract: Federal Communications Commission grants MCI Telecommunications Corp license to begin direct broadcast satellite services; ruling is blow to Time Warner Inc and other broadcasters, who sought delay because of British Telecommunications PLC's plan to acquire MCI; MCI says it will broadcast video programming to American customers nationwide through American Sky Broadcasting, joint venture with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp; ruling does not settle whether MCI can transfer license to British Telecommunications (M)

headline: Kimberly-Clark Mill Sale
abstract: Alliance Forest Products says it intends to buy paper mill near Birmingham, Alabama, from Kimberly-Clark Corp for about $600 million (S)

headline: How to Leap Before You Look: Lessons for a Digital World
abstract: Comment by John R Walter, R R Donnelley chairman who is moving to AT&T;, on adapting to digital technology; notes that customers who used to pay more than $2,000 for printed encyclopedia can now buy CD-ROM version for $40 or less (S)

headline: Loan Debtor Liquidated By Japanese Court
abstract: Osaka District Court announces that it has liquidated real estate development company that borrowed more than $235 million from Japan's insolvent housing lenders (S)

headline: COMSAT TO SELL 80% STAKE IN ASCENT ENTERTAINMENT
abstract: Comsat Corp plans to divest itself of its 80 percent stake in Ascent Entertainment Group Inc (S)

headline: Tougher Tax Assessment on Restaurant Tips Is Rejected
abstract: Judge Marian Blank Horn of US Court of Federal Claims, in major victory for owners of nation's 375,000 restaurants, strikes down technique by Internal Revenue Service for assessing taxes that service says has contributed to sharp jump in reporting tips; decision means that any restaurant owner assessed taxes based on technique can file for refund (M)

headline: SYLVAN LEARNING ACQUIRES MINORITY STAKE IN JOSTENS
abstract: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc says it acquired 19 percent interest in Jostens Learning Corp from Bain Capital Inc; price not disclosed (S)

headline: TECO TO BUY LYKES ENERGY FOR $300 MILLION
abstract: Teco Energy Inc to buy Lykes Energy Inc for $300 million in stock from Lykes Brothers Inc (S)

headline: Unit Being Formed Against Tobacco
abstract: David Milenthal, chairman and chief executive at HMS Partners, is continuing his efforts to persuade advertising and marketing industries to help stop sale of tobacco products to minors by forming task force called Initiative on Tobacco Marketing and Children (S)

headline: Isle Furor Stirs Chinese Nationalism in Hong Kong
abstract: Wave of emotional Chinese nationalism is washing over Hong Kong, finding focus in Japanese claims to islands off Taiwan and the drowning of local man trying to reclaim them for China; has brought tens of thousands of people onto streets and launched flotilla of boats toward disputed islands, known as Senkakus to Japanese and Diaoyus to Chinese; photo; map (M)

headline: Valvoline in Sears Accord
abstract: Ashland Inc says its Valvoline Instant Oil Change division has agreed to provide oil changes in 20 Sears Auto Centers in three markets next year; financial terms not disclosed; companies expect eventually to open oil change operations in more than 150 Sears Auto Centers nationwide (S)

headline: COINMACH TO ACQUIRE KWIK WASH FOR $140 MILLION
abstract: Coinmach Laundry Corp says it has agreed to buy Kwik Wash Laundries LP for $140 million in cash and notes (S)

headline: That's the Ticket
abstract: Letter by James M Davin on Nov 10 article on plans by Ticketmaster for initial public offering (S)

headline: U.S. to Spur Beijing on Trade Group Entry
abstract: Clinton Administration plans to tell Chinese leaders, in high level-meetings starting in 10 days, that it is ready to speed up talks on China's entry into World Trade Organization, although it will not drop demands for series of market openings that China has so far resisted; Clinton plans to raise China's entry into trade organization when he meets Chinese President Jiang Zemin in two weeks (L)

headline: TI of Britain Bids For Forsheda of Sweden
abstract: TI Group of Britain says it offered $298 million for Forsheda AB of Sweden (S)

headline: Thomson's Bidder Is Stunned; Daewoo Registers 'Outrage' : France Backs Out Of Deal to Rescue Electronics Giant
abstract: PARIS—  In a stunning about-face, France abruptly canceled on Wednesday the planned sale of Thomson SA, the state-owned electronics company, whose privatization has been the centerpiece of President Jacques Chirac's ambitious plan to restructure the French defense industry.

headline: Ex-Colleague Accuses Aides In Argentina Of Corruption
abstract: Former Argentine Finance Min Domingo Cavallo, in bitter rebuke of Government of Pres Carlos Saul Menem, accuses members of Cabinet in which he served for six years of concealing corruption and manipulating judges; was dismissed by Menem in July after disagreements over Argentina's economic revisions; singles out Interior Min Carlos Corach and Justice Min Elias Jassan (M)

headline: Airbus Sets Timetable for New 500-Seat Jet
abstract: Officials at Airbus Industrie say their design for plane with 500 or more seats will be ready by end of year; Airbus plane is intended to compete with Boeing's planned stretch-747 jumbo jet; Airbus and Boeing had once considered joint venture to produce stretched double-deck, long-range aircraft with 500 or 800 seats (S)

headline: Sense of Unity Is Showing Strain As Europe's New Currency Nears
abstract: As pressure mounts on European Union members to qualify for monetary union in 1999, hopes for a happy family of nations sitting down together to share a common currency have dimmed this week amid another outburst of nasty infighting; several European leaders are finding fault with one another's plans to bring 1997 budgets in line with strict fiscal criteria set forth in treaty on European unity that was agreed on in Dutch city of Maastricht nearly five years ago (M)

headline: With Boatmen's Deal, Nationsbank Returns to Its Roots
abstract: Nationsbank, which emerged from $2 billion weakling in 1970's when it was named North Carolina National Bank, has muscled its way to become a heavyweight with $200 billion in assets as well as being a challenge to huge money-center banks and brokerage firms at their own games of global finance, options trading and investment banking; with investors believing Nationsbank, under its chairman Hugh L McColl Jr, was focused on high-technology ventures, bank recently agreed to spend $9.5 billion to acquire Boatmen's Bancshares, healthy but otherwise unremarkable agglomeration of Midwestern banks; basis for McColl's change of heart is discovery that there is lot more money to be made than otherwise realized in old-fashioned branch banking with consumers and smaller business; profile of Nationsbank and McColl; photos; charts on Nationsbank's position in several states (L)

headline: NO PROGRESS SEEN IN PERUVIAN TALKS ON 140 HOSTAGES
abstract: Negotiations between Peruvian Government and Marxist guerrillas fail to win release of 140 hostages who remain in Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima; Pres Clinton welcomes the release of 225 hostages released on Dec 22, including seven US Embassy officials, but calls for immediate release of the remaining hostages; US has encouraged Pres Alberto K Fujimori not to give in to guerrillas' demands and has reportedly sent force of advisers and military commandoes to help the Peruvians; Fujimori, whose younger brothers is among the remaining hostages, stands firm in his refusal to negotiate; photo (M)

headline: Most Improved French Wine? Try Montmartre '95
abstract: Montmartre section of Paris, famous for winegrowing in Roman times, is trying to make comeback; Francis Gourdin has been hired by City of Paris and local municipality to make something potable out of grapes grown on urban lot, which until recently produced vintage that was difficult to drink and had diuretic rather than dietetic qualities; photo (M)

headline: Burmese Champion of Democracy Calls Crackdown Her Victory
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader, says military crackdown over last few days is victory for her movement (M)

headline: 2 Major Marketers In Consolidations
abstract: Gillette Co names Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide to handle its consolidated Right Guard anti-perspirant account in North America and Britain; billings estimated at $15 million (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Oct. 11   Oct. 4   Oct. 13          1996   1996   1995       Gasoline production, daily   7.6   7.4   7.3       Distillate production, daily   3.6   3.4   3.2       Gasoline stocks   195.8   196.3   196.5       Distillate stocks   114.3   113.6   132.0       Crude imports, daily   7.3   7.9   7.6       Product imports, daily   1.6   1.8   1.9       Crude stocks   301.9   302.3   300.2       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.5   6.7       Refinery utilization (%)   92.7   94.9   87.7          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: EUROPEAN MONITOR TELLS SERB LEADER TO HONOR ELECTION
abstract: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe tells Serbia to reinstate rightful winners of elections, whose results were annulled by Government following opposition victories, or face further international isolation; says opposition candidates won elections in 13 Serbian cities in November; warning elicits conciliatory response from Foreign Min Milan Milutinovic; protests continue on streets of Belgrade; photo (M)

headline: Union Bank Official Is Charged with Fraud
abstract: Union Bank of Switzerland says its private banking unit, Cantrade Private Bank Switzerland (CL) Ltd, and one of its officers has been charged with fraud by police on Channel Island of Jersey; bank identifies officer as Peter Stoneman and says he has been suspended pending resolution of charges against him; charges relate to series of currency trades between 1988 and 1993 by independent currency trader, Robert Young, that caused investors to lose $27 million (S)

headline: Multinational Producers Stumble Over Bureaucratic Roadblocks : The Long March to Chinese Stores
abstract: BEIJING—  Su Zhen, a computer science student, seemed an unlikely person to be promoting Mars chocolate products in a Beijing department store. "Some classmates told me about this job," she said, arranging the chocolate bars and candies on her special display stand. "It's an easy way to earn extra money."

headline: For Retailers, Weather Is Wild Card in Holiday Sales
abstract: Retailers, as final week of holiday selling season begins, are finding their sales stuck between mediocre and decent, meaning that these last few days could be crucial to their success; there are five fewer shopping days this year because Thanksgiving weekend was later than usual; weather may also be turning against retailers; graphs (L)

headline: U.N. Reports 3 Million New H.I.V. Cases Worldwide for '96
abstract: Over three million people, mostly under age 25, have become newly infected with AIDS virus this year, officials of United Nations and World Health Organization say; they stress need for more vigorous programs to prevent further spread of virus because it is being transmitted in all countries (M)

headline: Who's Beating Swords Into Plowshares in Balkans: A Score Card
abstract: European diplomats and military officials say Yugoslavia has destroyed 240 of its tanks in wake of arms control treaty that was signed in June; say Clinton Administration, which promised Yugoslavia $2 million to help with demolition program, is delaying payments (M)

headline: Excerpt From the Speech by Greenspan
abstract: Excerpt from speech by Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan (S)

headline: Maidenform Unit Picks Blum/Herbstreith
abstract: Maidenform Inc names Blum/Herbstreith as first agency to handle advertising for its Self Expressions brand of lingerie (S)

headline: General Motors Output Lags Behind Demand for New Models
abstract: Dealers complain General Motors Corp delivers popular new models too slowly, hurting sales; GM aides hold slow introduction was planned to insure quality (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: First of America Bank Corp to reorganize operations, put more workers into incentive pay plans and drop some jobs (S)

headline: MICRO WAREHOUSE SHARES FALL 18% ON ACCOUNTING NEWS
abstract: Shares of Micro Warehouse Inc fall 18 percent after company says accounting errors might force it to restate earnings for 1994 and 1995 and possibly take charge of $18 million (S)

headline: Giving, And Getting In Return
abstract: Charitable remainder trusts, which allow donors to generate a steady stream of income by making a charitable donation, are growing in popularity (M)

headline: ELTRON INTERNATIONAL AND ZEBRA TECHNOLOGIES TO MERGE
abstract: Eltron International Inc and Zebra Technologies Corp agree to merge; companies say each Zebra common share will be exchanged for 0.84 Eltron common share; Zebra has almost 16.9 million shares outstanding, meaning its shareholders stand to receive almost 14.2 million Eltron shares, worth about $475.3 million at Oct 16 closing price of $33.50 a share (S)

headline: Bond Prices In Mild Rally On New Data
abstract: Prices of Treasury securiies rise on weak housing report and strong dollar; 30-year bonds are up 7/32, to 101 1/32 (M)

headline: Armor All Buying Car-Rex
abstract: Armor All Products Corp agrees to buy Car-Rex, a German maker of automotive chemicals, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Magazine Guides That Help the Surfers
abstract: At least 10 magazines have been started to cover the content of the World Wide Web and serve as a guide to surfing the Internet; Net Guide and Internet World look like the healthiest in terms of advertising, but it is still too early to predict which will survive the fierce competition; the winners stand to outperform magazines devoted to the computer itself, since net surfers will one day outnumber computer buffs; editors acknowledge the irony of publishing Web magazines on paper; photos; tables (M)

headline: Prep Schools and the Middle Class
abstract: Letter by Susan D James on Sept 15 article on prep schools that are wooing the middle class (S)

headline: Peru's Premier Foresees Peaceful End to the Hostage Crisis
abstract: Peruvian Prime Min Alberto Pandolfi, in first prediction by Government official of bloodless end to captivity of 83 hostages being held by Tupac Amaru guerillas in residence of Japanese Ambassador in Lima, says he expects solution that protects physical well-being and lives of all hostages (M)

headline: Wyndham Hotel Purchase
abstract: Wyndham Hotel Co says it will buy Doubletree Hotel in Salt Lake City from City Hotels SA for $44 million, and change hotel's name to Wyndham brand name (S)

headline: British Petroleum In China Venture
abstract: British Petroleum Co and Shanghai Petrochemical Co agree to form $2.5 billion joint venture to build ethylene plant in Shanghai (S)

headline: China Economy's Class Act: High Growth, Low Inflation
abstract: Dai Xianglong, China's chief banker, reports that China has achieved favorable balance of high growth and low inflation; private economists say problems remain in China's economy and that fall in inflation is cyclical and inflation could pick up again with a poor harvest (M)

headline: Concern on Fungus Infection Pushes Wheat Prices Higher
abstract: Wheat prices rise on Chicago Board of Trade amid concern that fungus infections are reducing amount of good quality wheat in United States; in other markets, heating oil and natural gas prices fall (M)

headline: Genital Ritual Is Unyielding in Africa
abstract: Tradition of female genital cutting remains strong in much of Africa despite rising chorus of international condemnation, but some seeds of change are noted as the debate over the practice slowly moves into public arena; organizations have sprung up to combat the practice, but they are small, ill financed and must struggle within societies where men rule women's lives, and old people, including old women, rule the young; purpose of the cutting, which diminishes a woman's ability to experience sex ual pleasure, is to help insure a woman's fidelity to her husband and her family, and the practice knows no class or religious boundaries; photos; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. and Europe Agree On Technology Trade Deal  The United States and the European Union reached agreement on a deal to liberalize trade in information technology, paving the way for a broader pact incorporating most of the world's big trading nations.    After several days of intense negotiations at a meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore, the United States and Europe resolved a host of differences over a proposal to eliminate tariffs within three years on computers, software, telecommunications equipment and other products. $(Page A1.$)    VW Executive Charged in Germany  German prosecutors have indicted Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the former General Motors executive who switched to Volkswagen, on charges of embezzlement and theft of confidential documents from G.M., the auto makers said. $(D9.$)    Bond Market in Big Slump  The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday amid concern that interest rates could rise if foreign investors slowed their buying. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which rises when the price falls, increased to 6.62 percent from 6.49 percent, despite favorable reports on inflation and a drop in oil prices. $(D20.$)    The Producer Price Index was up only four-tenths of 1 percent last month, even less when volatile energy costs were excluded. $(D2.$)    The price of crude oil fell sharply for a third consecutive session on signs that supplies appeared to be more ample just as Iraq was beginning to export oil. $(D17.$)    Microsoft's Latest Deal  Microsoft and Pointcast have become allies in the fast-growing area known as Internet broadcasting. In return for a featured position in Microsoft's operating system software, Pointcast, a customized information provider, will embrace Microsoft technology and distribute the MSNBC news service. $(D4.$)    More Women Hold Directorships  Women passed a milestone in the board room in 1996, for the first time holding more than 10 percent of the directors' seats at the nation's 500 largest companies, a survey showed. $(D4.$)     Du Pont Farms Out Its Computing  Du Pont joined a growing list of companies that have contracted out their computing operations to giant technology-service specialists. $(D4.$)     Answering a Rage to Spend  Fueled in part by sharply rising incomes of the wealthiest Americans and a rise in the number of people in their peak earning years, luxury goods are selling at a growth rate faster than that for goods and services as a whole. $(A1.$)     A Live Big Board Ticker for TV  The New York Stock Exchange has made a deal with CNNFN to transmit its ticker live instead of on a delayed basis; the service will be offered to other television channels as well, exchange officials said. $(D8.$)     Panel Supports Diabetes Drug  An advisory panel recommended that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new type of diabetes drug that could help some diabetics reduce or stop their daily insulin injections. The drug, Rezulin, is being produced and tested by the Parke-Davis division of Warner-Lambert. $(A25.$)    Fight Over Tobacco Ads in Canada  The Canadian Parliament is on the brink of endorsing stringent curbs on cigarette marketing, but tobacco companies are sure to fight back. Advertising. $(D8.$)

headline: Anchor Ousts Chief, Agrees to Sell Assets
abstract: Anchor Glass Container Corp removes its chief executive, Alfonso G Palacio, and announces that it is being sold by its parent, Vitro SA, to Ball-Foster Glass Container Co for $365 million in cash; Anchor names its chairman, James R Malone, acting president (S)

headline: Malaysia:Caning for Illegals' Bosses
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Malaysia will soon amend its laws to include caning and imprisonment for anyone employing illegal immigrants or helping to arrange their entry into the country.

headline: China Announces Trade Penalty as Reply to Similar U.S. Move
abstract: China announces ban on imports of selected goods from US, stepping up trade dispute with Clinton Administration and sending blunt signal that it will not easily succumb to pressure; says decision is in response to unilateral cut by US in import quotas for Chinese textiles (M)

headline: CAMDEN PROPERTY TRUST TO ACQUIRE PARAGON GROUP
abstract: Camden Property Trust, real estate investment trust, to buy Paragon Group, which owns apartments in the South and the Midwest, for $338 million in stock (S)

headline: Have you heard 'Living Single' is back on Fox? (By the way, who's on first?)
abstract: Networks like to acquire major sports properties partly to use the highly rated, season-ending events as promotional kickoffs for new or returning series; following in that tradition, Fox Network's telecasts of World Series included huge, coordinated promotional assault devised by Fox to garner attention for its prime time television schedule; photo (M)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD EXPANDS BUYBACK BY UP TO $1 BILLION
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co plans to buy back up to $1 billion in common stock plus $230 million remaining under earlier buyback plan (S)

headline: Magazine Executives Are Appointed
abstract: Lou Fabrizio leaves New York Times, where he was managing director in advertising and marketing strategy department, to become publisher of Out magazine; Kenneth Watson is named to new position of vice president and consumer marketing director at New York Times Co Magazine Group; Mark A Furlong is named advertising director of Snow Country (M)

headline: Foes Take Steps To Cut Tension In West Bank
abstract: Palestinian policemen and Muslim clerics join efforts to prevent any disturbances in West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the Israeli Army moves tanks out of sight to reduce tensions; Israelis say they will soon reopen one of the crossings at Gaza for limited transport of goods; most Palestinians appear disappointed by the outcome of the Washington meeting at which they failed to win concessions from Israel; Sec of State Warren J Christopher plans to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat and attend opening of their talks on Israeli withdrawal from Hebron (M)

headline: Sprint and Ameritech Report Profit Increases
abstract: Sprint Corp and Ameritech Corp report higher third-quarter earnings on revenue increases of about 10 percent; Sprint had profit from operations of $316.2 million compared with profit from continuing operations of $263.6 million in third quarter last year; revenue rose to record $3.54 billion, from $3.21 billion; operating profit in its long-distance business rose 32 percent, to $242 million; revenue rose 14 percent, to $2.08 billion; Ameritech says net income for quarter rose to $519 million from $464 million in same quarter last year; revenue increased to $3.72 billion from $3.38 billion (M)

headline: Narciso Jubany, 83, Cardinal in Barcelona
abstract: Cardinal Narciso Jubany Arnau of Barcelona dies at age 83 (S)

headline: Hollywood's obsession with the opening weekend makes or breaks a film.
abstract: Bernard Weinraub column on Hollywood's obsession with the opening weekend box office receipts of new films; Monday tallies sometimes determine a studio's commitment to promote a film; studios have been known to stretch the truth a bit to emerge from the weekend as No. 1; cartoon (M)

headline: Short on Cash? Try Parting With Stock, a Computer or an '85 Buick
abstract: Article on tax deductions for charitable contributions of stocks and personal belongings; drawings (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Ingram Book Co, La Vergne, Tenn, promotes Lavona Russell to president; Motorola Inc names Carlos Genardini general manager of its Asia-Pacific semiconductor business; he succeeds C D Tam, who becomes general manager of Motorola's microcontroller technologies group; Salomon Brothers names Stanley H Hartt to new post of chairman of Salomon Brothers Canada Inc; Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corp names Jay Fishman president and chief operating officer for commercial lines; he also continues as vice chairman (S)

headline: Slower Trading to Cut Earnings for Yamaichi
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co says it has cut its earnings forecast because of declining brokerage commissions and lower profits from trading (S)

headline: KCS ENERGY TO BUY OIL AND GAS UNIT OF MIDAMERICAN
abstract: KCS Energy Inc says that it agreed to buy Intercoast Oil and Gas Company, oil and natural gas unit of Mid-American Energy Co, for $210 million in cash and 435,000 common stock warrants (S)

headline: Downtown Retailing Trend Again Favors a Car Culture
abstract: Pedestrian malls, built in towns across the country in 1960's and 1970's in effort to revitalize their central shopping districts, have not lived up to their potential; at least half of the 200 pedestrian malls in US are in some form of transformation; such car-free strips have not met demands of American shoppers, who are time-pressed and spoiled by one-stop convenience that enclosed malls offer; photos; map (M)

headline: Designers Wake Up to Dressing Down
abstract: NEW YORK—  Almost imperceptibly, the American fashion industry has awakened from the deeply satisfying success it enjoyed in the early 1980s—when women willingly paid dearly for imposingly designed clothes —to find itself facing a tough new customer whois no longer enamoured with fashion.

headline: Netscape Stock Sale Planned
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp and four of its shareholders will sell five million shares, raising as much as $235 million (S)

headline: Serbs' Answer to Oppression: Their Web Site
abstract: Radio B92, independent radio station recently forced off the air by Serbian authorities, has begun digital broadcasts on anti-Government protests over audio Internet links; tens of thousands of students, journalists and others are believed to be connected on line to this technological revolt; photos (M)

headline: United Airlines and NatWest to Issue Corporate Charge Card
abstract: United Airlines and National Westminster Bank PLC to introduce corporate charge card in United States for use at merchants who accept American Express cards; card is first be be issued by bank on American Express network and will compete with American Express's own corporate card; NatWest also plans to issue separate personal credit cards in Britain that operate on American Express network (M)

headline: 2 Chicago Agencies Plan to Merge
abstract: Grant/Jacoby Inc and Pitzel & Pollack Advertising to merge and operate under Grant/Jacoby name; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: High-Flying Quintiles to Buy Innovex in $747.5 Million Deal
abstract: Quintiles Transnational Corp says it plans to buy Innovex Ltd of Britain for $747.5 million in stock; Quintiles says deal will make it world's biggest outside supplier of research and development to pharmaceutical, medical device and biotechnology companies (M)

headline: Marines Polish Command Skills, Switching Places With Traders
abstract: Two dozen Marine officers take part in unconventional training exercise, participating in mock commodities trading session at New York Mercantile Exchange; corps seeks to learn about communications and decision making from commodity markets; Col James A Lasswell of Marines' Warfighting Laboratory notes that commodities traders, like military officers in time of war, must absorb certain amount of information, figure out what should be right decision and make it, in short order; photo (M)

headline: Holiday gifts may someday include pants to sled in and a play mat to keep a child in one place.
abstract: Patents column lists new gadgets and toys that inventors hope will top shopping lists (M)

headline: Don't Trust I.R.A. Leaders, Turncoat Says
abstract: Sean O'Callaghan, former IRA terrorist, convicted murderer and informer for British intelligence, recounts bombings and robberies he carried out in 1970's, and decision to turn against IRA because of its bigotry against Protestants; interview; photo; O'Callaghan describes being sent to London to carry out bombing that would assassinate Prince Charles and Princess Diana at theater in 1983, and arranging with British authorities to have to flee so plot could not be carried out; he strongly warns British Government not to be 'conned' into making peace with IRA and attacks Gerry Adams' effort to gain respectability and role in peace process for IRA; O'Callaghan provides insider's endorsement of Prime Min John Major's view that IRA's 18-month cease-fire was ruse to gain respectability while retooling terrorist apparatus; 42-year-old Callaghan was freed December 8 after serving eight years of life sentence, under rarely-used procedure that requires Queen's approval; he expresses shame for his past and says he does not fear for personal safety in the short term; he tells of joining IRA as teenager to get British out of Ireland, and becoming disillusioned by bigotry (M)

headline: Downsizing Prevails as Customers Resist Paying More
abstract: Food industry is resorting to new rounds of reorganization, cost-cutting and downsizing to increase shareholder value without increasing prices; food companies used to increase prices regularly, but consumers are resisting such increases, shopping for bargains among less expensive private-label and store brands, buying in bulk from warehouse clubs, and benefiting from price wars among profusion of grocery chains, discounters and convenience stores; result is that at least 100,000 jobs have been lost in food industry, about 10 percent to 15 percent of all employees in packaged-food industry, in last 18 months, and there have been wave of mergers and acquisitions as companies seek to shed mediocre performers and acquire new category leaders; graph; photos (L)

headline: Car Companies In United States Hurt by Imports
abstract: Japanese and European car companies roar back into US market this fall by cutting prices and increasing rebates, posing greatest challenge for US companies in several years; dollar has increased 15.3 percent against German mark and 41 percent against Japanese yen, allowing for lower prices; graphs; Japanese are also introducing new models designed to be assembled at lower cost, while luxury European makers are offering less expensive models that compete with Cadillac and Lincoln; Toyota, Honda, Volkswagen and BMW had sales gains of 13-29 percent in November from year earlier, while sales rose only 1.4 percent for Chrysler and fell 2.2 percent for Ford and 11.8 percent for General Motors; Ford Taurus is now only barely ahead of Honda Accord and redesigned Toyota Camry; Japanese companies have 23.8 percent of car-light truck market for this model year, and European makers have 3.6 percent; three-fifths of Japanese models are now made in US, but have foreign parts that account for ten to seventy percent of manufacturing costs; Big Three companies, which acknowledge fierce competition, have tended to discount market research, embraced by Japanese companies, indicating Americans feel prices are too high and prefer to spend money on vacations and computers (M)

headline: WCI STEEL PLANS TO RETURN TO PRIVATE OWNERSHIP
abstract: WCI Steel Inc's board approves proposal to revert to private ownership in transaction that could be worth as much as $55 million (S)

headline: What Do You Call Iraqis? Mostly Abu
abstract: Iraqi names and the mode of addressing Iraqis follow an elaborate and confusing system known as kunia (M)

headline: A Deal That Brings Together 2 Players in Electric Power
abstract: Assessment of Southern Company of Atlanta's acquisition of Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd for $2.1 billion this week; Southern's chmn, A W Dahlberg, expresses confidence that places like Keti Bandar, Pakistan, and Sual, in Philippines, will become some of company's most profitable operations; takeover is Dahlberg's largest and most daring so far, and it has linked his fortunes with one of boldest entrepreneurs in Asia, Gordon Wu, and his company, Hopewell Holdings Ltd, which controlled Consolidated Electric; acquisition enables Southern to tap into one of world's fastest-growing markets, place where demand for electricity exceeds supply and where profits for power generators have been substantial, but Southern is also opening itself up to substantial risk (M)

headline: COMPUTERS HINDER EUROPEAN FIDELITY INVESTMENTS
abstract: European brokerage arm of Fidelity Investments agrees with British regulator not to accept new clients for three months; has problems with new computer system (S)

headline: Mutual Benefit Settlement Is Reached in New Jersey
abstract: Successor to Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co, which collapsed in biggest insurance company failure in United States history, announces settlement with creditors and policyholders; agreement awards 70 percent of revived company's stock to creditors and balance to policyholders; creditors include Bank of America unit of BankAmerica Corp; key factor in reaching settlement was desire of both sides to end protracted litigation that threatened to leave loser with greatly reduced benefits; MBL Life Assurance Corp was designated to take charge of recovery by regulators two years ago (M)

headline: UNION CARBIDE SEES DISAPPOINTING 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT
abstract: Union Carbide Corp warns fourth-quarter profit will be well below expectations because of surging raw materials prices (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported that magazine advertising pages in September fell 2 percent from September 1995, to 21,120. For the first nine months of 1996, total ad pages fell 1.1 percent, to 150,251, from the corresponding period a year earlier.    The Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. affiliated with the China Advertising Corporation for Machinery and Electronics, Beijing, a unit of the Ministry of Machinery Industry of the Chinese Government. Terms were not disclosed.    Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, will acquire Blank, Knispel & Partners, Amstelveen, the Netherlands, which will be renamed Bozell BK& P. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Winning Formula: Location, Location, Connections
abstract: Riady family's investment in enormous $700-million power plant in Fujian Province, China, is example of how overseas Chinese families do business when they come back to China; keys are locations where they know local officials, familiar partners and willingness to take financial risks that Western banks might avoid; partner in Fujian plant is Mission Energy, California-based giant that also cooperated with Riadys' Lippo Group on power plant in Indonesia (S)

headline: South Korea Cuts 1997 Growth Forecast
abstract: Bank of Korea says South Korea's economic growth rate will slump to four-year low of 6.4 percent in 1997 because of crumbling exports and slowing capital investment; economy grew 9 percent in 1995 and is expected to grow 6.9 percent this year (S)ì

headline: I.R.A. Says It Set Bomb That Wounded 31 at Barracks in Ulster
abstract: Irish Republican Army admits detonating two bombs at British Army base in Lisburn, Northern Ireland; bombs wounded 21 soldiers and 10 civilians (M)

headline: Kansas Utility Extends Bid
abstract: Western Resources Inc extends its $1.9 billion tender offer for Kansas City Power and Light Co, move that may lead to first hostile takeover of an electric company in at least 36 years (S)

headline: A Mongolian Moment: No Gas and the Camel's Lost
abstract: Severe shortage of gasoline, caused by falling deliveries from Russia, has become chief topic of conversation in small Mongolian town of Bulgan, where small filling station has become main hangout; map; photo (M)

headline: Italian Monopoly Fined For Abuse of Advantage
abstract: Italian appeals court orders Telecom Italia to pay $2.6 million in damages to rival, Telsystem, for abusing monopoly position (S)

headline: Spaniard Pregnant With 7
abstract: Spanish woman who has had fertility treatment is pregnant with seven fetuses and wants to give birth to all of them; she is in 27th week; doctors in Madrid say they know of no other case in which pregnancy of this kind reached such advanced stage in which fetuses were viable (S)

headline: Small Agency Is Said to Win Acura Review
abstract: Acura, luxury division of American Honda Motor Co, reportedly ends one of the biggest and most closely watched advertising reviews of the year by dismissing Los Angeles office of Ketchum Advertising, agency that handled brand since its introduction in 1984; reportedly awards account to Suissa Miller, Santa Monica, Calif, smallest of four finalists and regarded as long-shot contender (M)

headline: Sales License Is Extended
abstract: Sonus Pharmaceuticals Inc says it has extended Abbott Laboratories' sales license for Echogen, agent used to improve quality of ultrasonic images; Abbott agrees to pay $34.6 million for expanded license (S)

headline: Amid the Cheers forAPEC, Critics Assail 'Globalization'
abstract: QUEZON CITY, Philippines—  Proud claims ofeconomic successes by the Philippines are expected Sundayas 18 leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation open a conference in Manila.

headline: Value Names Gray Kirk/VanSant
abstract: Value Rent-a-Car names Gray Kirk/VanSant Advertising to handle its account (S)

headline: Spurred by U.S., Two Sides Open New Talks to Save Mideast Peace
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians begin urgent negotiations agreed on at recent Washington summit to salvage peace efforts; central focus will be to reach agreement on turning over control of most of Hebron to Palestinians, which has evolved into litmus test of Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's intentions toward Palestinian peace; presence of Sec of State Warren Christopher and aides at talks, as well as Christopher's meetings with Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, underscore US determination to press for quick and tangible results; map (M)

headline: Group to Study On-Line Users
abstract: NFO Research Inc has formed panel of more than 50,000 households to provide data aobut consumers who use interactive and on-line media and to conduct interactive market research (S)

headline: Chechen Separatists in Istanbul Set Up Shadow State
abstract: Advocates of Chechne independence from Russia are operating what amounts to government in exile in Istanbul, Turkey, while Russian-installed government of Chechnya has faded into irrelevance; are taking advantage of current cease-fire to try to cement commercial and political ties between Chechnya and outside world (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Post Slight Drop
abstract: Treasury prices end slightly lower, as lack of economic data and prospect of auctions discourage active buying; price of 30-year Treasury bond slips 2/32, to 100 12/32 (M)

headline: 2 Japan Airlines See Shares Plummet
abstract: Shares in Japan's top airlines plummet amid news that Japan Airlines Co and All Nippon Airways Co will report lower-than-expected earnings for half year that ended in Sept (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M. and Auto Workers Struggle to Resolve Pact  Top officials of General Motors and the United Automobile Workers struggled to resolve their differences before the expiration of their labor contract.

headline: Netanyahu Ousts a Negotiator Who Met With the Opposition
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu suspends Maj Gen Oren Shahor as negotiator in talks over army pullback from Hebron because he meet with former Prime Min Shimon Peres and other opposition leaders without Government's knowledge; ouster highlights Government suspicion that generals named as negotiators by previous Labor Party administration undercut current policies (S)

headline: AES CORPORATION TO BUY AFFILIATED AES CHINA GENERATING
abstract: AES Corp agrees to acquire its affiliated company, the AES China Generating Co, in stock swap valued at $107 million to $120 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Boehringer Mannheim Corp., Indianapolis, to Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, to handle advertising and public relations for its diabetes care division, previously at Medicus Communications, New York, owned by MacManus Group. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

headline: Lufthansa Says Its Profit Has Declined
abstract: Lufthansa reports third-quarter pretax profit fell to 315 million marks ($206 million) from 317 million marks in 1995 period; expects earnings for year to be at least 10 percent below 1995 level (M)

headline: Abductions Rock Mexico, Scaring Not Just the Rich
abstract: Kidnapping epidemic in Mexico is alarming foreign investors and adding to sense that parts of country are sliding into chaos; Francisco Resendiz of Cuernavaca reported abduction of his teen-age son to authorities last year; like hundreds of other Mexicans whose loved ones have been kidnapped, he believes that police are collaborating with abductors; Resendiz has paid two ransoms totaling $41,000, but his son has not been released; he has channeled his grief by taking part in street demonstrations protesting Mexico's rising insecurity; map; photo (M)

headline: When the Experts Check In
abstract: Accounts solicited for column on wise and foolish suggestions of workplace consultants

headline: Clintons Down Under: Sweet and Sour
abstract: Pres Clinton continues visit to Australia, saying he feels 'on top of the world'; tours of Great Barrier Reef and Sydney Opera House described, as well as golf game with Greg Norman; photo; map; Hillary Clinton offers Sydney audience some reflections on public's complicated expectations for First Ladies (S)

headline: The Bride Wore Fatigues?
abstract: Photos of Hummer off-road stretch limousine (S)

headline: Merrill's Debt Is Upgraded
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raises its rating on Merrill Lynch & Co debt above that of any other securities firm (S)

headline: New Data Standard May Help Speed Up Video on Internet
abstract: Coalition of 38 computer makers and software publishers led by Netscape Communications Corp and Progressive Networks Inc is set to announce a new audio and video data standard that will permit companies using the Internet to compete more directly with radio and television broadcasters; single standard, known as Real Time Streaming Protocol, will allow Internet publishers to broadcast streams of digital information to users of personal computers; Microsoft Corp, a Netscape rival, does not belong to the group (M)

headline: VALUE LINE TO PAY A $15 DIVIDEND
abstract: Value Line Inc says it will pay extraordinary dividend of $15 a share as part of settlement of legal dispute between company's majority owners; company also reports that net income in quarter that ended Oct 31 was $7.8 million (S)

headline: F-16 Fighter on Patrol Over Iraq Fires on a Radar Site, U.S. Says
abstract: United States says US jet fighter fired on radar installation in southern Iraq that seemed to be trying to target plane (M)

headline: Journey to Cyberspace for Latest Guides to New York City
abstract: World Wide Web features at least six guides to current happenings in New York City; this is natural application for Internet, given its ability to store unlimited amounts of live information; chart (M)

headline: Disney Reaction Calm To Ovitz's Resignation
abstract: News of Michael S Ovitz's resignation from Walt Disney Co causes little stir at Disney; people at company say they were aware for several months that Ovitz was chafing under Disney's powerful chmn, Michael D Eisner; analysts say his departure will have little affect on day-to-day business of Disney; one analyst notes there are number of 'really talented people' running things at Disney; photo (M)

headline: Canadian Arrest Is Tied To U.S. Child-Porn Ring
abstract: Canadian authorities investigating international child pornography ring on Internet have confiscated 30,000 pornographic computer files and arrested Trevor Davis, Ontario man believed to be connected with group of pornographers in US known as Orchid Club (S)

headline: Prudential Unit Agrees to Settlement
abstract: Prudential Securities Inc says that it agreed to pay $18 million to settle charges related to bankruptcy of Foundation for New Era Philanthropy; trustee in case had sued Prudential Securities, demanding return of tens of millions of dollars that passed through firm as part of what Federal officials call Ponzi scheme run by New Era (S)

headline: Trade Deficit Declined Sharply in October
abstract: Commerce Department reports nation's trade deficit declined sharply in October, down 30.2 percent, to $7.99 billion--lowest figure since March--from $11.44 billion in September; says exports rose to new monthly record of $71.73 billion, up 4 percent for month; also notes widening gaps with Japan and China, two nations that have been focus of American trade policy; October figures bring deficit for first 10 months of 1996 to $94.47 billion, about $2 billion more than amount at same time last year, making it all but certain that total for 1996 will surpass last year's deficit of $105.1 billion; graph (M)

headline: Some Humbling Times For a High-Tech Giant
abstract: Recent reverses at Motorola Inc, rapidly growing electronics and communications firm, discussed; setbacks have shattered firm's aura of invincibility and underscored increasing challenges Motorola faces in identifying and mastering most valuable new technologies; graphs; table; photos (L)

headline: People
abstract: Recent promotions in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: INVESTCORP AGREES TO BUY 51% OF CSK AUTO
abstract: Investcorp SA to buy 51 percent controlling interest in CSK Auto Inc (S)

headline: Late Shoppers Taking a Risk On Catalogues
abstract: Apparel catalogue companies that typically do large share of their business during holiday season are short on some goods, putting pressure on shoppers to order early; low inventory levels, cold weather and new demand for clothing have contributed to early shortage (M)

headline: A big tax cut to lift the economy. Not here, in Ukraine.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says Ukraine's Government is trying to convince Western bankers at International Monetary Fund to countenance huge tax cuts to turn around republic's post-Communist economy; old apparachiks have saddled country with reputation of being most corrupt of former Soviet republics; one economist estimates that unofficial economy, out of reach of regulators or tax collectors, is larger than official economy; Pres Leonid Kuchma is pushing for bold reforms suggested by Western advisers, including sweeping tax cuts and deregulation designed to lure underground economy to the surface; but IMF continues to insist that Ukraine balance its budget first; drawing (M)

headline: Goldman, Sachs Promotes Official
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co says E Gerald Corrigan would become a partner and managing director on Nov 30 (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: List of upcoming key dates for business and financial investment

headline: Slower Revenue Growth In Quarter at WPP
abstract: WPP Group PLC says its third quarter revenue rose 8.1 percent to 407.2 million pounds ($651 million) from year earlier (S)

headline: Fidelity's Exit Door Swings Once More
abstract: fidelity's exit door swings once more**Article profiles Fidelity Investments in wake of wave of fund manager and executive departures, including most recent leave taking by Brian S Posner, manager of the Fidelity Equity-Income II fund; over all, more than half of the $225 billion in Fidelity's general equity funds has been put under new management this year, as the company has rotated portfolio responsibilities to account for the departures; chart (M)

headline: Deal for Zeolite Maker
abstract: Corsaire Snowboard will buy 90 percent stake in Zeolite Mira for $10.8 million in cash and stock (S)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   5.21   5.97        3-MO.
