headline: Growing Pains at Micron Technology
abstract: Lawrence Zuckerman analysis of recent resignations of three of Micron Technology's top managers from board, move that clears way for new directors who can bring outside expertise and experience to company; says outside directors will be culture shock for Micron, whose board has been dominated by group of local agribusiness magnates who financed Micron through its lean years in 1980's (M)

headline: Thanksgiving, for Odd Sort of Harvard Expatriate
abstract: Victor Grossman, US Army private who defected to Eastern bloc in 1952, is living in Berlin with his German wife; photo (M)ü

headline: DEVELOPER OF DIABETES DRUG PLANS TO SELL STAKES
abstract: Amylin Pharmaceuticals Inc says it will sell up to $15 million in stock, or about 1.2 million common shares, to Johnson & Johnson; Amylin also files with Securities and Exchange Commission for public offering of 1.5 million shares; proceeds from sales will be used to finance Amylin's clinical trials of experimental diabetes drug, pramlintide, which is supposed to improve glucose control in patients using insulin; Johnson & Johnson has teamed with Amylin to develop the drug (S)

headline: Prince Philip Angers Britons on Gun Control
abstract: Prince Philip speaks out in broadcast against pending handgun legislation, using offhand analogy to cricket, and promptly finds himself at center of latest round of dismay over conduct of British royal family; photo (M)

headline: Swedish Insurer Bids for Top Mortgage Bank
abstract: Skandia Insurance AB offers $3.5 billion in stock to acquire Stadshypotek, move that would form one of largest financial institutions in Nordic region (S)

headline: A Payoff for Lives Twisted by Gulf War
abstract: More than 860,000 men and women in 78 countries will begin receiving checks for $2,500 eachfrom UN under program to extract reparations from Iraq for damages resulting from Persian Gulf War in 1991; UN Compensation Commission, until recently, had little money to settle claims it approved; payments have begun as Iraq has resumed international oil sales under UN agreement that reserves 30 percent of proceeds for payment of reparations (M)

headline: Prices of Heating Fuels Soar As Forecasters See Cold Snap
abstract: Prices for heating oil and natural gas surge on New York Mercantile Exchange as forecasts for colder weather raise concerns about increased demand at time of low supplies; coffee prices rise, while corn and soybeans fall (M)

headline: Elf in British Linkup With 2 U.S. Companies
abstract: Elf Aquitane of France says it is merging its British refining and retail operations with units of Gulf Oil Ltd of Chevron Corp and Murco Petroleum Ltd, unit of Murphy Oil Corp; move expected to cost 400 to 500 jobs (S)

headline: NATO Close To Popping Big Question In East Europe
abstract: NATO foreign ministers will end years of debate on Dec 10, setting date for July '97 summit to invite first formerly Communist countries of Central Europe to join alliance; are expected to approve military operations plan for new, 30,000-member peacekeeping force in Bosnia that will replace, for next 18 months, 50,000-plus NATO soldiers who have been in Balkans in last year (M)

headline: A Market-Moving Guru Plans to Run Funds
abstract: Influential stock market analyst Elaine Garzarelli plans to start two mutual funds, Garzarelli Balanced Fund and Garzarelli Affinity Equity Fund, to be based on her proprietary method of sector analysis; her dual roles as analyst and fund manager raise conflict-of-interest issues likely to limit her propensity for talking about market's direction; graph; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Mitchell Energy and Development Corp announces sale of portfolio of retail properties and other real estate assets for around $38 million (S)

headline: Executives Back Dole Despite Clinton Record
abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll shows if any class of Americans has reason to be content on eve of Presidential election, it is probably nation's top executives; nearly 9 of 10 say condition of the economy 'is good,' up from nearly half who said so four years ago; solid majority believes that inflation has been tamed, and many of the companies that the executives run have bullish plans to invest and hire new employees in the coming year; nearly half of the executives believe next recession will not be before 1999, and another 27 percent do not see downturn coming until 1998; at time when polls show Pres Clinton ahead by double digits, 65 percent of executives surveyed say they preferred Bob Dole; twenty-five percent say they will vote for Clinton--just about same level of support he got in 1992; 26 percent of top managers rank cutting Federal budget deficit as nation's chief economic problem, versus 9 percent who say high taxes tops the list; 41 percent of executives say Dole's centerpiece plan to cut Federal income taxes by 15 percent is wrong for country; fifty-two percent favor the plan, but figure falls to 19 percent if tax cut would increase deficit; 71 percent of executives still say Dole would do better job reducing deficit, versus 18 percent for Clinton; 63 percent say Dole's economic program would result in more growth, versus 26 percent who favor Clinton's plan; executives appear to see no reason to vote for Clinton, despite economy's strength; only 39 percent of executives approve the way Clinton has handled his job as President, while 54 percent disapprove; among general public, 58 percent approve and 32 percent disapprove; tables; charts; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Prices of Treasury Bonds Rise On a Weakness in Home Sales
abstract: Treasury prices end higher, erasing an early loss, as a slump in sales of existing homes helps ease concerns over inflation (S)

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Buys Marketing Agency
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt acquires McCracken Brooks promotional marketing agency (S)

headline: Hans W. Kosterlitz, 93; Found Clues in Brain on Pain Control
abstract: Hans W Kosterlitz, neuropharmacologist who won international race to find first opiate-like substances in brain, dies in Aberdeen, Scotland, at age 93; photo (M)

headline: A Drug and Sports Scandal Swirls Near Argentine Chief
abstract: World-renowned soccer player Diego Maradona and associates are enmeshed in drug scandal in Argentina that threatens to taint Government of Pres Carlos Saul Menem; while neither Menem nor any member of his administration has been directly linked to scandal, his close association with those involved has prompted new questions about his integrity among populace that had grown accustomed to his socializing with international celebrities and Buenos Aires jet set; at center of scandal is Maradona's manager, Guillermo Coppola, close friend of Menem's private secretary, who was arrested after police found 500 grams of cocaine in his apartment (M)

headline: 6,000 Could Be Sent by Weekend; Pressure Off, U.S. Weighs Its Role : Canada Agrees to Lead Military Force in Zaire
abstract: PARIS—  Canada has agreed to head a multinational military force to protect humanitarian relief operations for refugees in eastern Zaire that could be on the ground as early as this weekend, Western diplomats said Monday.

headline: Mingo Is Renamed; Texaco to Uniworld
abstract: Mingo Group in New York is renamed Chisholm-Mingo Group to reflect restructuring and contributions of Samuel J Chisholm, chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: UNITED DOMINION TO BUY SOUTH WEST PROPERTY
abstract: United Dominion Realty Trust Inc to acquire South West Property Trust Inc for $312 million in United Dominion common stock (S)

headline: In Japan, Old Problem Undermines New Leader
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's new Government is under attack because of two corruption scandals; Deputy Health Min Nobuharu Okamitsu resigned on Nov 20 after admitting he had received benefits from Hiroshi Koyama, businessman accused of bribing Japanese officials; at least 17 politicians reportedly accepted donations from Junichi Izui, oil trader charged with evading nearly $5.4 million in taxes (M)

headline: Police Won't Open Fire, Arafat Promises Israel President
abstract: Yasir Arafat pays his first public visit to Israel, meeting with Pres Ezer Weizman; says he has given permanent orders to his police force not to open fire on Israeli soldiers; both leaders say warm meeting has strengthened peace efforts, which were shaken by recent violence in West Bank and Gaza Strip; photo (M)

headline: Taiwan Concern Seeks To Buy Mother's Cake
abstract: President Enterprises Corp of Taiwan is negotiating to buy Mother's Cake and Cookie Co, US baker, for as much as $200 million from Specialty Foods Corp (S)

headline: Lawmakers Assail Clearing Of Officers in Saudi Bombing
abstract: Several leading Democratic and Republican lawmakers criticize Air Force decision to exonerate officers responsible for protecting US military housing complex in Saudi Arabia where 19 Americans were killed by truck bomb in June; Sens Arlen Specter, Bob Kerrey and Richard H Bryan and Repr Floyd D Spence charge whitewash amid calls for Congressional probe; Air Force decision contradicts major finding of separate Pentagon inquiry, which singled out Brig Gen Terry J Schwalier for failing to protect complex despite repeated warnings about terrorism; Air Force says report exaggerated those warnings and that Schwalier was responsible only for security inside fenced compound (M)

headline: Acquisition in Vision Care
abstract: TLC The Laser Center Inc says it will buy 20/20 Laser Centers Inc for about $33 million (S)

headline: AMERICAN BRANDS TAKES CHARGE TO CLOSE FACTORY
abstract: American Brands Inc to take $55 million charge when it closes cigarette factory in England as it prepares to spin off its Gallaher Tobacco unit; about 950 Gallagher workers to be dismissed (S)

headline: NOVELL STOCK SURGES AMID TAKEOVER SPECULATION
abstract: Shares of Novell Inc, provider of networking software products, soar 26% amid speculation that company could be takeover candidate (S)

headline: DIAMETRICS MEDICAL IS NEGOTIATING FOR PFIZER UNIT
abstract: Diametrics Medical Inc says it is negotiating with Pfizer Inc for purchase of its Biomedical Sensors Ltd unit for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Once Burned, The First Wife Is Twice Shy
abstract: Interview with Olivia Goldsmith on her conservative strategy for investing proceeds of her popular novels, including The First Wives Club; photos; graph (L)ï

headline: Siemens Shares Plunge On 1997 Forecast
abstract: Stock of Siemens AG falls after company says its profit for 1997 fiscal year would not exceed 1996 earnings (S)

headline: Protesters Take to Streets to Defend Canada's Safety Net
abstract: Thousands of angry Canadians demonstrate in streets of major cities to protest cuts in social service spending; transit system in Toronto is shut down, highway traffic is snarled and police are called in to keep protesters from disrupting stock exchange; photos; direct target is Ontario's new leader, Mike Harris, who has slashed almost $1 billion from province's budget, dropped more than 180,000 people from welfare rolls and promised 30 percent income tax cut; other provinces and national Government are also working on theme of cutting Canada's generous social benefits (S)

headline: Chief of a WPP Unit Joins Y. & R. Office
abstract: Austin McGhie to head San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Inc as president and chief executive (S)

headline: TDK Moves an Account To Ryan Drossman
abstract: TDK Electronics Corp has moved its integrated advertising and sales promotion account to Ryan Drossman & Partners from Merkley Newman Harty, a unit of Omnicom Group; billings estimated at $8 million (S)

headline: U.S. Agencies Lead Health Care Awards
abstract: United States agencies win 12 of 24 awards at Grand Global Awards competition for health care communications, sponsored by New York Festivals (S)

headline: In Australia, Clinton Takes a Dip by the Great Barrier Reef
abstract: Pres Clinton snorkels off Australia's Great Barrier Reef after pleading earlier for greater protection of endangered reefs worldwide; Australia takes occasion of Clinton's visit to rename a section of the reef in honor of Rachel Carson, the pioneering American environmentalist (S)

headline: Stocks Higher in Japan
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues is 6.29 points higher, at 20,877.12, at midday, Friday, Oct 11 (S)

headline: HICKS, MUSE ACQUIRES DEL MONTE UNIT IN MEXICO
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc says it acquired Del Monte Foods Co's food processing unit in Mexico for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Ocean Spray Shifts Work to Arnold
abstract: Ocean Spray Cranberries shifts several advertising assignments to Arnold Communications from North Castle Partners; sixteen North Castle employees, including chairman, president and chief executive Lynn Rotando, will join Arnold; Rotando will oversee Ocean Spray work as managing partner; Clifton McFeely will succeed him as North Castle president and chief executive (S) y y

headline: They're Like Nasdaq, and Coming to Europe
abstract: New stock exchanges, or bourses, are being organized in Europe, to channel money from risk-embracing investors to enterprises that do not yet meet stringent standards of big markets in London and other cities; Easdaq, modeled on Nasdaq, began Sept 30 and now has 30 registered traders (S)

headline: S&T BANCORP TO ACQUIRE PEOPLES BANK
abstract: S&T Bancorp Inc to acquire Peoples Bank of Unity for $94 million in stock (S)

headline: African Countries Name Four U.N. Candidates
abstract: African nations put forward new candidates for United Nations Secretary General: Hamid Algabid of Niger, Kofi Annan of Ghana, Amara Essy of Ivory Coast and Ahmedou Ould Abdallah of Mauritania (S)

headline: A dashboard-generated device that strews sand in your path without venturing out onto icy roads.
abstract: Joel H Dulberg and Stephen E Immomen receive patent for system they say will allow drivers to dump sand underneath spinning tires merely by pressing button on dashboards of their cars; Jack R Levien receives patent for his idea to keep sports fans from ignoring television during commercial breaks; idea is for advertisers to announce time-sensitive passwords during their commercials that will enable viewers to download useful or entertaining information from their computers; Dr Tom Cane receives patent for Christmas stocking that lights up, to prove to young children that Santa visited their home overnight (M)

headline: New Software Seeks End To Long Waits on Internet
abstract: Users of World Wide Web are often frustrated by interminable delays in retrieving software and graphics; Marimba Inc will introduce new software, called Castanet, for distributing information much more quickly over Internet; analysts say Castanet may have even bigger impact on way software is managed on private corporate networks, automating process by providing efficient way for computers on network to retrieve and distribute new versions of software (M)

headline: Pipeline Set To Expedite Kazakstan Oil
abstract: Major oil companies and Governments of Russia, Kazakhstan and Oman have agreed to build $1.5 billion pipeline, clearing a bottleneck that has prevented large amounts of Central Asian republic's oil from reaching Western markets; pipeline will connect huge oilfields in Tengiz in Kazakhstan with new port to be built on Black Sea near Russian city of Novorossiysk; new pipeline will enable Chevron Corp to capitalize on its $1 billion investment in developing fields in Tengiz (M)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Gold Rush Town Gives Past a Second Thought
abstract: Like Tombstone, Arizona, and Deadwood, Colorado, the California Gold Rush town of Placerville has its roots in a rough-and-tumble era of hard men, simple values and summary justice.

headline: Newmont in $2 Billion Bid for Santa Fe Gold
abstract: Newmont Mining Corp announces unsolicited bid of $2 billion in stock for Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corp; move could set off bidding war in rapidly consolidating mining industry; some industry analysts expect Newmont to have to sweeten its bid by as much as $500 million before it can expect to acquire Santa Fe Gold in potential auction that is sure to attract rival bids; graph (M)

headline: The Tortoise Catches Up
abstract: Growth mutual funds, which invest in companies with rapidly growing earnings, and value funds, which invest in out-of-favor stocks with low valuations, have similar performances so far in 1996; value funds have gained 13.4 percent and growth funds 12.7 percent; graphs (M)

headline: Broderbund Software Picks Chief Executive
abstract: Broderbund Software says it has hired Joseph Durrett as its chief executive, ending five-month search; he replaces Douglas G Carlston, who will remain chairman (S)

headline: Canadians' Failure: Indians and Eskimos
abstract: Report indicting Canadian policies towards indigenous peoples noted

headline: A Legislature Made in China Is Presented To Hong Kong
abstract: China establishes new legislature for Hong Kong, ignoring protests from Britain that proceedings are stage-managed and violate agreements on colony's coming transition to Chinese rule (M)

headline: Dutch Considering Sale Of State's Stake in KLM
abstract: Dutch Government and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines NV say they are discussing possible sale of state's stake in carrier (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Integrated Health to Buy Coram in $280 Million Deal   Integrated Health Services, a home health care and specialized nursing home company, agreed to buy Coram Healthcare, a troubled, debt-laden home care company, for about $280 million in stock.    The deal, which includes the assumption of $375 million in Coram debt, would create one of the largest companies that provide care for patients whom hospitals no longer find profitable. $(Page D2.$)    Stronger Profits at Oil Companies   Several major oil companies reported higher earnings as surging prices for crude oil and natural gas more than offset rising refining costs. Oil company stocks, which have rallied recently, were flat.    Texaco said net earnings jumped nearly 50 percent, compared with the third quarter of 1995; Chevron reported a 29 percent increase, excluding special items, and Exxon said profits rose 4 percent. The results met or slightly exceeded Wall Street expectations. $(Page D4.$)    Stocks Seesaw, Ending Down   Stocks seesawed, ending slightly lower after a morning rally following I.B.M.'s earnings report gave way to heavy profit-taking. The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 3.36 points, at 6,090.87, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 6.07 points, to 1,236.41. $(D14.$)    Treasury prices fell slightly, weighed down by more than $30 billion of notes to be auctioned today and tomorrow. The yield on the 30-year bond edged up to 6.80 percent. $(D21.$)    Election Disappoints Japan Inc.   Corporate executives in Japan have been looking to the Government for two things -- strong leadership, and economic deregulation that would lay the groundwork for Japan Inc. to roar again. But last weekend's national elections will probably fall short of either of these outcomes. $(D9.$)     Few Issues Remain in G.M. Strike   Representatives of G.M. and the Canadian Automobile Workers union struggled with a few remaining issues in a 19-day strike, as G.M. temporarily laid off nearly 11,000 more American workers. $(D4.$)    Betting on the Internet's Future   The Frontier Corporation and Qwest Communications announced plans for a $2 billion national network to carry telephone conversations and data. $(D4.$)     United Airlines' Choice Questioned   United Airlines' surprising selection of Fallon McElligott and Young & Rubicam to share its $120 million account is raising questions about how well those two fiercely independent agencies can cooperate. But they voice optimism. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D13.$)    RJR Reports Stronger Profits   RJR Nabisco Holdings announced that profits were increasing in its Nabisco food unit and its international tobacco business. But the company's results were marred by erosion in its domestic cigarette business. Net income in the third quarter rose 4 percent to $225 million, or 66 cents a share. Revenue increased 7 percent to $4.35 billion. $(D2.$)     Corporate Credit Ratings Improve   The rising stock market is having a very positive effect on American companies: corporate credit quality, as measured by changes in bond ratings, appears to be better than ever. So far this year, Moody's has upgraded the ratings of 221 companies, compared with 146 companies downgraded. Floyd Norris: Market Place. $(D14.$)     USAir Earnings Rise 57%   USAir said earnings rose an unexpectedly strong 57 percent, to $67.7 million on robust demand for international flights. $(D4.$)

headline: A shot at getting the big spenders to invest in the commercial potential of the Internet.
abstract: Advertising column describes concept devised by two advertising industry veterans, John L Mezzina and Jordan Stanley, to get big consumer products companies to begin advertising seriously on Internet; their new loyalty program, called Free Ride, would offer computer users points for buying brand-name products, or by looking at on-line advertisments; computer users who amass 1,000 points get free month of Internet access from participating access providers (M)

headline: Compassion and Peril in Africa
abstract: Analysis: any international military force that would wade into conflict in Zaire between Tutsi rebels, Zairian Army and Rwandan Hutu guerrillas would face quandry not unlike that which faced American soldiers in Somalia in 1992, namely, how to avoid fueling war; even if UN soldiers could disarm guerrilals and separate them from rest of refugees, aid organizations would find it difficult to avoid setting up permanent camps like those that became bases for guerrillas and helped create current crisis; map; photo (M)

headline: GLOBAL AGREEMENT REACHED TO WIDEN LAW ON COPYRIGHT
abstract: Negotiators from 160 nations agree at World Intellectual Property Organization meeting, Geneva, on two treaties to extend international copyright law to works that can be easily copied and distributed over computer networks; treaties cover literary and artistic works and music; supporters say treaties will encourage record companies, computer programmers and eventually even television and movie studios to distribute wares over Internet; negotiators drop proposal to extend protection to computerized data bases; delete wording that would treat even temporary computer copies automatically created to view data from Internet as possible violations; drawing (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY    Ft Dearborn Inc Secs   Jefferson-Pilot   Picadlly Cafe   Telefex      TUESDAY    Cinn Milacron   Cooper Inds   Liberty Corp   Monarch Mach Tool   Paragon Group   Piper Jaffray   Unifirst Corp      WEDNESDAY    Chemed   General Amern Invs   Hanna M A   Hilb Rogal & Hamlton   IES Inds   Macerich   Nrthwst Pub Svc   Penn Energy & Mfg   Phelps Dodge   Talbots      THURSDAY    Ashland   Conseco   Coop Tire & Rub    CPI   Current Income Shs   Dover   Dyersburg   Fin Sec Assur Hldgs   First Miss   Fremont Gen   Geon   Greenbrier   GTE   Maritrans   Marriott Intl   Motorola   St Paul Cos   Stepan      FRIDAY    Deluxe   Gaylord Entmt   Meridian Indl Tr

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: European Currency System To Readmit the Italian Lira   Finance ministers and central bank governors from European Union nations, meeting in a special session, agreed to readmit the Italian lira to the European exchange rate mechanism. Officials said the ministers agreed to let the lira return to the currency grid at 990 lira to the German mark.    The lira had been dropped from the system in 1992 during a currency crisis in Italy, and re-entry was seen as crucial for Italy's hopes of being in the first wave of nations to adopt a single European currency in 1999. $(Page D2.$)    U.S. and China Agree on Visits   President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed to exchange state visits in the next two years, the first such meetings since the 1989 massacre at Tiananmen Square. White House officials also said that Mr. Jiang had signaled a willingness to move ahead on opening markets to pave the way for China to join the World Trade Organization. $(A1.$)    Settlement Reached in TLC Case   The singing trio TLC, their recording label and managers settled a yearlong battle over how the fruits of the group's success should be divided. The trio had filed for bankruptcy at least in part to void their contracts; the case was important to the industry, because the royalty restrictions that TLC could have shed are common in the business. $(D2.$)    Endless, Unattainable Love   Shiori Fujisaki is a 17-year-old high school junior, Shingo Hagiwara a 21-year-old college sophomore who idolizes her. One problem: Ms. Fujisaki, left, is only a character in a video game, the goal of which is to get her or a friend to date you and fall in love. ''Love simulation'' games have become a hot category in Japan's home video game industry, and Mr. Hagiwara, who is quite real, is one of a legion of young Japanese men who have lost their hearts to a virtual girl. $(D5.$)    Tighter Clean-Air Provisions Sought   The E.P.A. is recommending tighter national standards for emissions of the chemicals and particles that form smog and soot. Business groups are lobbying hard against the proposal to redefine how clean the air must be, saying it would cost billions of dollars to meet standards they contend offer no important benefit. $(A1.$)    Departing Editors Are Sued   When the publisher and 2 editors quit Orchard Books to start an imprint at another publisher, it seemed just one more industry realignment. But in Orchard's case, nothing has happened in the usual way since. $(D7.$)    Big Shift in Health Care Billing   After signing large numbers of New York doctors, the nation's health maintenance organizations are radically changing the way they pay physicians there and have begun to reduce reimbursements. $(A1.$)    Paper Guides to Internet Sites   At least 10 ink-and-paper publications are fighting to become, in effect, the TV Guide of the World Wide Web. And, as bigger and better-financed magazines jump in, the competition is turning into a demolition derby. $(D10.$)    Chat as a Marketing Opportunity   Advertisers for the most part have either ignored on-line ''chat'' or poked fun at the phenomenon. But a study suggests marketers ought to take those cybercommunities seriously. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D6.$)    Michael Jackson's Global Reach   Though Michael Jackson's two-year-old album ''HIStory'' has failed to meet expectations in the United States, it remains a hit in dozens of other nations, selling 11 million copies worldwide. Sony Music ships as many as 100,000 overseas each week. Entertainment. $(D7.$)

headline: APPLIED MATERIALS OFFERS TO BUY 2 COMPANIES
abstract: Applied Materials Inc says it will make tender offer of $175 million for Opal Inc, and pay $110 million in cash for Orbot Instruments Inc (S)

headline: ANDREWS OFFERS $171 MILLION FOR TOY BIZ SHARES
abstract: Andrews Group Inc, investment company owned by Ronald O Perelman, says it has offered to buy outstanding shares of Toy Biz Inc for $19 a share, or $171 million (S)

headline: Mama Tish's, a firm's latest public offering, falters.
abstract: Landmark International Equities, which brought initial offering of Mama Tish's Italian Specialties stock to market, has been unable to close offering and issue shares; delay spurs drop in price of what had been hot new stock, but all trades will be canceled if offering does not close (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Judd Harner was named to the new post of client services director at Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York. He had been an account director at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising.    * Marcel Moens was named managing director at Leo Burnett/Brussels, a unit of the Leo Burnett Co., succeeding William Golding, who is leaving the agency business to become a franchisee of the McDonald's Corp. in Italy. Mr. Moens had been executive director of the Belgian Association of Advertising Agencies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Surge in Number Of Mutual Fund Investors  Encouraged by continued growth in financial markets, the number of American households investing in mutual funds has risen by more than 20 percent in the last two years, recent research shows.    But many investors in the largest segment of funds, those that buy stocks, have never experienced a significant market downturn. That raises questions among analysts about how such investors would react if a significant drop occurred. Market Place. $(Page A1.$)    Dow Average Rises 23.83 Points   Stocks advanced in a sedate session. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 23.83 points, at 6,546.68, just 1.11 points shy of its all-time closing high of 6,547.79. One analyst called the rise ''the traditional folkloric Santa Claus rally.'' Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by nearly 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 6.94 points, to 1,294.57. $(D5.$)    Treasury Securities Unchanged   Treasury securities finished unchanged in a quiet session, with traders reluctant to take positions in the absence of significant economic news. The 30-year bond yield remained at 6.58 percent. $(D4.$)    Gas and Heating Oil Futures Slump   Natural gas and heating oil futures prices slumped, as forecasts for mild weather across much of the country contributed to lackluster demand. Natural gas for February delivery tumbled 32.1 cents, to $3.384 per 1,000 cubic feet, and January heating oil sank 1.34 cents, to 70.06 cents a gallon. $(D11.$)    Dollar Advances Against the Yen   The dollar hit 115.08 yen, its highest level in more than three and a half years, before profit taking in a thin market trimmed the gain, sending the dollar to 114.66 yen. It was barely changed against the German mark. $(D11.$)    Workers Protest South Korean Law   South Korea's auto industry came to a standstill as 150,000 workers walked out to protest the Parliament's secret passage of a law that curtails labor's power. An umbrella group of unions called the strike hours after 155 legislators of the governing New Korea Party passed the law during a session at which no opposition members were present. If it escalates, the strike could be devastating to the country's economy. $(A4.$)    Japanese Banks to Forgive Loans   Major Japanese banks said that they would forgive billions of dollars in loans to the country's failed mortgage lenders, known as jusen. The banks said the decision would have little effect on their earnings in the current fiscal year because they had already set aside special reserves for writing off loans. The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi and the Industrial Bank of Japan are forgiving the highest amounts. $(D4.$)    Strikers to Be Compensated   The Government has told Caterpillar, the nation's leading maker of earthmoving machinery, to compensate thousands of workers who participated in strikes against the company and missed out on the free meals, flu shots, ice cream and popcorn the company gave employees who did not strike or who crossed picket lines. The United Automobile Workers union has engaged in two bitter strikes against Caterpillar in the 1990's. $(A18.$)    Short-Sellers Drop Intel Stock   Intel shares have surged 13 percent in the last six weeks, causing short-sellers to cut their positions. But over all, Nasdaq reported, short interest on that market rose 4 percent in the most recent period, reflecting trades from Nov. 18 to Dec. 10. $(D2.$)

headline: Utility Seeks Partner to Aid Power Needs
abstract: Oglethorpe Power Corp, big Georgia utility, agrees to buy half of its electricity from LG & E Energy Corp for 15 years to cut costs; LG & E will run Oglethorpe's plants, buying electricity from outside sources if cheaper than producing it and selling power from plants if that is more lucrative; Oglethorpe is negotating with other big power marketers to manage rest of its electricity needs (M)

headline: Offerings of Equities Expected for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    American Medserve Corp., Naperville, Ill., an initial public offering of 5.4 million shares. William Blair & Co.

headline: British Parties Vie for Votes of the Upwardly Mobile
abstract: Britain's Labor Party and Conservative Party are both out to win votes of swing voters, members of the aspiring class, people with good jobs who want better ones, who believe there is social mobility in British life that will give them chance to get further ahead and who will vote for party they trust to protect their security; Labor Party is working hard to cast aside its trade union ways and develop regard for individual entrepreneurship (M)

headline: Net Income Unchanged At Pharmacia & Upjohn
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc says its third-quarter net income before charges was $231 million, unchanged from last year; operating profit dropped 9 percent, to $285 million (S)

headline: German Utility Spurns One Venture for Another
abstract: RWE AG abandons partnership with Viag AG and British Telecommunications PLC in split over mobile-telephone strategy and instead joins alliance with Veba AG and Cable & Wireless PLC; shift reshuffles German telecommunications landscape barely year before full competition is set to begin (S)

headline: People
abstract: Appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Business Groups Try to Forge a Unified Political Front
abstract: Broad coalition of business groups organized by United States Chamber of Commerce is paying for television ads supporting vulnerable Republican Congressional candidates; effort is seen as critical test of private sector's ability to forge from its diverse, fractious constituencies a unified political front with impact commensurate to its role as dominant provider of campaign contributions; so far, business coalition has generated only $5 million in contributions from 33 business organizations and trade groups; this is small relative to amount AFL-CIO is spending--$20 million to $25 million; coalition's problem is that small-business members tend to be ideologically driven, supporting Republicans across the board, while big business takes more pragmatic approach, spreading contributions almost evenly among Republicans and Democrats; photos; chart (L)

headline: A Vacation Not Taken May Be 401(k) Fodder
abstract: Obscure ruling last month by Internal Revenue Service has drawn attention to an intriguing option for unused vacation time: adding its value to tax-deferred profit-sharing plans; IRS ruling seems to allow such a transfer, even when an employee has already reached $9,500 annual limit for tax-deferred contributions into 401(k) retirement plans (L)

headline: Silicon Graphics to Unveil A New Supercomputer Line
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc and Cray Research, which merged in February, will announce first of new line of supercomputers intended to blend two companies' technologies; new system, to be marketed jointly by two companies, will be known as Silicon Graphics Cray Origin 2000; it will eventually replace Silicon Grahpics's high-end Challenger line and Cray Research's T3 series (M)

headline: CS Holding to Sell Elektrowatt Unit Stake
abstract: CS Holding says Siemens AG would buy its 44.5 percent stake in Elektrowatt AG's building services division for $822 million (S)

headline: Energizer Bunny Returns to Roots
abstract: EB, drum-beating pink bunny that is featured in advertising campaign for Energizer batteries, is returning to its roots in television advertising spots that began running this week; Energizer batteries are made by Ralston Purina Co (S)

headline: Dow Keeps On Ascending at Record Pace
abstract: Stocks rise to records amid prospects for growing profits and low inflation, giving Dow Jones industrial average its best weekly gain in more than three months; index rises 13.78, to 6,219.82; tables (M)

headline: RADISYS STOCK TUMBLES ON NEWS OF SUIT BY EX-EMPLOYEE
abstract: Stock of Radisys Corp falls 15 percent on news that former executive, Bruce Taylor, has sued company, charging that it overstated its earnings; report in Barron's says Taylor charged company misreported inventory before and after public offering to maintain value of its stock; Taylor, who is suing Radisys, claims he was dismissed when he brought matter to attention of company (S)

headline: French Said to Know That Official, Now Dead, Spied for Soviets
abstract: Jacques Fournet, top French counterintelligence official, says former Defense Min Charles Hernu, who served from 1981 to 1985 and was considered strong supporter of strong defense, was reported by Eastern European intelligence services to have worked as paid political informant for them years before he held defense post; says authorities decided at time that information provided by Romanian intelligence in 1992 was not verifiable and was locked away in Government files; Hernu died in 1990, after Communist rule in Eastern Europe crumbled (S)

headline: Mood on Hebron Is Upbeat At Netanyahu-Arafat Talks
abstract: Progress is reported in meeting between Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat toward agreement on an Israeli pullback from West Bank city of Hebron; map (M)

headline: Eurotunnel Divides Management's Roles
abstract: Eurotunnel PLC says it split its top management into two teams, one dedicated to increasing car-shuttle traffic and the other to drawing more rail passengers to use the English Channel tunnel (S)

headline: Dollar Slumps Against Yen After Tokyo Aide's Remark
abstract: Dollar has appreciated by roughly 40 percent against yen in last 18 months, but it falls sharply on Nov 7 after key architect of its rise strongly suggests that yen has fallen far enough; Eisuke Sakakibara of Japanese Finance Ministry tells Japanese newspaper that yen will not be lead any lower; dollar falls to 111.60 yen, down 2.33 yen (M)

headline: Doctor, What's the Prognosis? A Crisis for Canada
abstract: Canada's state-funded universal health-care system is in crisis; cuts in Federal funding have led to service cuts and increase in already long waiting times for nonemergency procedures; doctors are refusing to see new patients and taking other drastic steps to call attention to their problems; photo (M)

headline: Motorola Names Founder's Heir as Chief
abstract: Motorola Inc says Christopher B Galvin, president and chief operating officer, will succeed Gary L Tooker as chief executive on Jan 1; Galvin's grandfather founded company in 1928, but his ascension to top comes sooner than Wall Street had expected; Motorola says move was touched off by company policy requiring that William J Weisz step down as chairman in January when he turns 70; Tooker will then become chairman; Galvin's current job will go to Robert L Growney (M)

headline: 2 Theorists of Real-Life Problems Get Nobel
abstract: James A Mirrlees and William Vickrey win Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for contributions to economic theory of incentives; real-life applications of their theories cited; photos; drawings (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: AT&T Names President And Market Cries Sell  AT&T selected John R. Walter, chairman of R. R. Donnelley & Sons, as its new president, and the stock market had a quick and strong reaction. The company's shares dropped by $1.875, to $37.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The broader stock market recovered from early losses, helped by a rally in computer stocks. But blue chips ended lower for the third consecutive session.    The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 25.34 points, at 6,036.46, after paring an intraday loss of more than 60 points. Other indexes were mixed. The Nasdaq composite ended up 7.88, at 1,227.88, after technology stocks recovered from their poor performance on Tuesday. $(Pages A1 and D12.$)     Treasury prices rose for this first time this week, after the bond market absorbed another large issue of new debt. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.83 percent. $(D19.$)    St. Jude Medical in Acquisition  St. Jude Medical said that its Pacesetter subsidiary would acquire Ventritex in a stock swap valued at $505 million. The deal would give St. Jude, a major maker of pacemakers, an entry in the defibrillator market, which is growing much more rapidly. Separately, St. Jude said it would acquire the cardiac-rhythm-management assets of Telectronics Pacing Systems from the Australian consumer and industrial product concern Pacific Dunlop for $135 million. $(D2.$)    E.D.S. Sees Slower Growth  Electronic Data Systems said that its earnings and sales increased in the third quarter, but Wall Street hammered its stock in response to a warning of slower growth in the fourth quarter. The company said it had earned $266.4 million, or 55 cents a share, in the third quarter, up from $245.7 million, or 51 cents a share. $(D4.$)    New Head for a Disney TV Unit  Walter C. Liss Jr., who has managed ABC's flagship television station in New York for the past 10 years, was promoted to be chairman of Buena Vista Television, the television syndication arm of ABC's parent corporation, Walt Disney. $(D5.$)    Court Strikes Down I.R.S. Effort  A court with nationwide jurisdiction handed owners of the nation's 375,000 restaurants a big victory, striking down a new I.R.S. technique for assessing taxes on workers' tips. The agency says its effort has brought a 44 percent jump in reported tip income. $(D4.$)    German Labor Dispute Grows  IG Metall said that big rallies were planned nationwide to protest possible cuts in sick pay, after the collapse of talks with employers aimed at resolving the matter. $(D9.$)    Dollar Falls Against Mark  The dollar fell to the lowest level in a month against the rallying German mark, but briefly climbed to more than 113 Japanese yen for the first time since January 1994. $(D10.$)    New Nissan Ads Promote Fun Image  Nissan's new ad campaign seeks to promote the company's image as one of fun and enjoyment. One spot -- featuring a macho action-figure racing through a house in a toy car -- is among the most popular on television. The ads feature Nissan's new icon ''Mr. K,'' who is supposed to embody the company's zesty founder and former president, Yutaka Katayama, who loved sports cars and flying kites. The ads use the tag line ''Life is a Journey. Enjoy the Ride.'' Advertising. $(D11.$)    Cable Feud in the Courts  Continuing a bitter fight over whether the News Corporation's Fox News Channel will be seen in New York City, the Giuliani Administration and Time Warner issued dueling legal briefs to bolster their stances on the legality of the Mayor's plan to show the channel on a cable station run by the city. $(B3.$)

headline: National Journal Editor
abstract: Stephen G Smith is named editor of National Journal, succeeding Richard S Frank, who is retiring after 20 years (S)

headline: Sprint Spectrum Shrinks Wireless Rollout
abstract: Sprint Spectrum, which owns more Federal licenses for advanced wireless networks than any of its competitors, again lowers its estimate for the number of cities in which it will provide personal communications services by January, saying it will be in five to 10 markets (S)

headline: Intel's Profits Rise Greater Than Forecasts
abstract: Intel Corporation, aided by strong demand from personal computer manufacturers for its microprocessor chips, reports third-quarter earnings of $1.31 billion, compared with $931 million in same period year ago; earnings greatly exceed Wall Street's expectations; although much of Intel's financial strength stems from improved profit margins based on internal factors, improved financial gains speak well for broader industry, such as personal computer makers of other types of chips for personal computers; earnings chart (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: POMEROY COMPUTER RESOURCES INC., Hebron, Ky., a professional computer service company, said it had received two contracts valued at more than $43 million over the next 18 months to provide computer networking products and services to two unidentified companies.    REGENCY REALTY CORP., Jacksonville, Fla., which develops grocery-anchored shopping centers, said it had bought three shopping centers in Florida and one in North Carolina for more than $37 million.    CARIBINER INTERNATIONAL INC., said it had acquired all the outstanding stock of Rome Networks Inc. for cash and Caribiner stock.      OSBORN COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Greenwich, Conn., said it would sell three radio stations in Florida to Clear Channel Communications Inc. for about $11 million, and take a pretax gain of $3 million on the sale.

headline: A notable trend toward the upgrading of corporate credit.
abstract: Floyd Norris, in Market Place column, contends that rising stock market is having very positive effect on American companies; maintains that corporate credit quality, as measured by changes in bond ratings, appears to be better than ever; notes that Moody's Investors Service has upgraded ratings of 221 companies so far this year, compared with 146 companies downgraded (M)

headline: Aloha to the GTE Party Line
abstract: GTE Hawaiian Telephone fights state's Public Utilities Commission order to sell its networks in the Ka'u District of the big island to Telhawaii, a unit of Telalaska; Telhawaii promises to upgrade phone service in the rural district, where there are now only party lines that preclude use of Internet, fax machines or telephone answering machines; photo of Dan Gordon, Telhawaii executive, and Barry Neal, a resident who was instrumental in bringing the company to Hawaii (M)

headline: French Military Supplier Plans 2,700 Job Cuts
abstract: Thomson-CSF, state-controlled military electronics company in France, says it would cut 2,700 more jobs next year because of weak outlook for military-related orders (S)

headline: A Strange Twist in Christmas Gifts
abstract: Some unusual gift items are surprisingly strong sellers this holiday season; include furry doll that squeals when tickled; stores comment on top sellers; photos (M)ú

headline: Allied Domecq Says Earnings Fell 10.8%
abstract: Allied Domecq PLC reports pretax profit dropped 10.8 percent in year ended Aug 31; before one-time charge, it fell to 575 million pounds ($949.7 million), from restated 645 million pounds a year ago (S)

headline: Rising Star in the Kremlin: An Ardent Pro-Capitalist
abstract: Article profiles Anatoly B Chubais, Pres Boris Yeltsin's chief of staff, who has risen from political oblivion to become one of most powerful behind-the-scenes figures in Russian Government; ardent pro-capitalist says he is striving to turn sometimes rudderless Government into disciplined state; photo (M)

headline: Diverse Diana Corp. to Split Into Two Separate Companies
abstract: Diana Corp says that it will split into two separately traded companies: Sattel Communications, telecommunications maker, and a distributing company to be called Newco until another name is chosen (S)

headline: For Dogs Pursued Pitilessly, Sanctuary
abstract: Interview with Lu Di, 69, of Beijing, who runs animal rescue shelter; she lives with 51 cats and 6 dogs; comments on Govt's persecution of dogs; Communists regard urban dogs as competitors for scarce foods; she says three times in her career police have killed some of her dogs; photo (M)

headline: The Fed Tries To Deflate A Bubble
abstract: Commenet on Federal Reserve's reaction to unprecedented run-up in stock prices (Market Watch) (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Business is Top Campaign Donor
abstract: Graph of findings in campaign finance study; this year's Presidential race will cost three times more than in 1992, and business is by far the largest source of money for all candidates

headline: Some Worries About the Rush Into Mutual Funds
abstract: Stock analysts express concern that millions of Americans who have entered mutual fund market in recent boom years may not be prepared for downturn; survey by Investment Company Institute finds that 37 percent of respondents own shares in mutual fund, up from 31 percent two years ago; figure translates to 37 million households and 63 million Americans, about one-fifth of whom made initial investments within last two years; economists John Rea and Byron R Wien comment; nearly 24 percent of households that own mutual funds have them only in 401(k) or similar fund; greatest increase is among Americans aged 45-54; graphs (M)

headline: Bristol-Myers Stock Split
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co will split its stock 2 for 1 and raise quarterly dividend by one cent a share on presplit basis (S)

headline: Blunt Message Sets Scene for Singapore's Election
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Residents of the Bukit Gombak public housing estate in the central part of the main island of Singapore have a powerful inducement to end their support for the opposition and vote for the candidate of the governing party in general elections Thursday.

headline: American Brands Ends Tobacco Role
abstract: American Brands Inc to spin off its British-based Gallaher Tobacco business to shareholders, ending its role as tobacco producer; sets name change to Fortune Brands; chairman Thomas C Hays comments (M)

headline: DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO. (DWD,N)
abstract: Dean Witter, Discover & Co says third-quarter earnings rose 9 percent to $239 million from corresponding 1995 quarter (S)

headline: Japan Proposes Agency To Oversee Its Banks
abstract: Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka says Japan is planning to establish agency in April 1998 to supervise and inspect nation's banks; move would take away part of Finance Ministry's role (S)

headline: Big Auto Insurers Go on the Offensive As Big Time Fraud Gains Sophistication
abstract: Size and cynicism of large-scale fraud rackets in automobile insurance industry has persuaded insurers to abandon path of least resistance--paying claims and passing cost on to consumers in form of higher premiums--and to be tough on fraud; insurers, in effort to trace tangled but extensive paper trails left by these rings, are hiring armies of investigators and adapting computer tracking systems designed for military and intelligence agencies; and they are deploying new legal tactics to bring to court cases that both insurers and prosecutors long viewed as too time-consuming and expensive to pursue; Allstate Insurance has 600 investigators, up from about 100 four years ago; State Farm has nearly doubled its anti-fraud force to 1,000 agencies; diagram; photo (L)

headline: Mental Health Ventures May Gain From New Law
abstract: Investors in firms specializing in mental health care are hopeful that new law barring employers who offer mental health benefits from setting more restrictive limits on such benefits than on physical health benefits will bolster industry stocks; law will let companies drop mental health benefits and raise co-payments or deductibles; offers exemption if provision leads to premium rise of over 1 percent; table (M)

headline: Oil Price Rise Stirs Concerns Of Forecasters
abstract: Forecasters are concerned about $4-a-barrel increase in oil prices since June; although price now is not alarmingly high, what is disturbing is that prices are not retreating as many analysts thought they would; and while gasoline prices at pump are falling, prices in futures market are rising again; Frederick P Leuffer, energy analyst, says it is unlikely prices will fall anytime soon, given further delay in resumption of Iraqi oil sales, political problems in Mideast and very low inventories of home heating oil; rise in oil prices has two impacts on economy: it works like a tax that can quickly cut into spending and slow growth, and it is quickly passed on to consumer, pushing up Consumer Price Index; graphs (M)

headline: MERCK AND RHONE-POULENC IN JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Merck & Co and Rhone-Poulenc SA says they are combining their animal health businesses in joint venture, creating the world's largest maker of medicines for pets and livestock; joint venture will be called Merial Animal Health (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Busy Body Fitness Warehouse, Dallas, to Kalis & Savage Advertising, Pacific Palisades, Calif., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

headline: European Aides Accused of Stifling Data on Illness Tied to Cows
abstract: Investigative committee of European Parliament accuses senior European officials of stifling scientific findings that might have led to earlier restrictions on British beef, which is suspected of causing human deaths from mad cow disease (M)

headline: GTE Raising A Latin Stake
abstract: GTE Corp says it will buy as much as $200 million in shares of Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela (CanTV), in company's planned stock offering; purchase would increase GTE's stake in CanTV to 26 percent; Venezuelan Government plans to sell 41.3 million American depository receipts in CanTV on Nov 21 (S)

headline: Dollar Slips After Elections And Pessimistic Euro Report
abstract: Dollar slips as currency traders shift their focus from elections in United States to a report suggesting that only handful of countries would qualify to join single European currency; dollar dips against yen (M)

headline: Resolving to Sweat, At Least Until February
abstract: Advice on how to evaluate worth of health club before making long-term financial commitment; photo (M)

headline: Interest Rates Drop Sharply In Bond Rally
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities reach their highest levels in six months; 30-year bond surges 1 30/32 to price of 100 29/32 to yield 6.68 percent, down from 6.83 percent on Oct 28 and lowest since April 4, when it was 6.67 percent; graph (L)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Review of economic, business and financial news of the week; photos; graphs; drawings (L)

headline: Japan Urged to End Fixed Stock-Trade Fees
abstract: Japanese government panel has called for scrapping fixed stock-trading commissions, even though group's chairman, Shoichi Royama, acknowledges that many smaller brokerage firms could be driven out of business (S)

headline: Henri Nannen, Editor, 82, Hurt In Hitler Hoax
abstract: Henri Nannen, founder and longtime publisher of German magazine Stern, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: 2 Agencies Name Chief Executives
abstract: BBDO North America names Larry Tolpin as president and chief executive of BBDO South in Atlanta; Richard C Sandler is named president and chief executive at Pagano Schenck & Kay; Robert Pagano, who was president, is promoted to co-chairman (S)

headline: Agriculture Prices Spiral Lower After Forecast of Bumper Crops
abstract: Futures Markets column; soybeans lead plunge in agriculture commodity prices after Govt crop forecasts for everything from grains to cotton to oranges exceed expectations; tables (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Some advertising account changes noted; Transitions Optical of Tampa, Florida, assigns Media That Works to handle national and spot media buying (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Westinghouse to Spin Off Industrial Businesses  After months of prodding from Wall Street, Westinghouse said that it would spin off its remaining industrial businesses to shareholders and focus on its radio and television operations.    But investors, who had bid up the price of Westinghouse shares by about 20 percent over the course of the last week on reports that a sweeping reorganization was in the offing, chose to sell on the news. Market Place. $(D8.$)     Stocks Rise on Fed Inaction  Stocks rose after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged and investors looked to corporate earnings for their cues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.20 points, to 6,274.24, its sixth consecutive record close, on higher than average volume. $(Page D8.$)    But retail stocks endured a second day of pounding, with some companies paying for the weak earnings of their peers. Dillard Department Stores announced disappointing earnings and Federated Department Stores had healthy profits, yet both stocks fell. The Standard & Poor's retail index fell 1.7 percent, to 382.75. $(D3.$)    Bond traders were relieved by the Fed's decision, but prices barely budged. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.45 percent from 6.44. $(D15.$)    Stock Funds Draw Less Cash  Cash flows into equity mutual funds fell by 25 percent in October, to $13 billion, a trade group said, as uncertainty over the strength of the economy and over the outcome of the November elections tempered investors' long-running love affair with stocks. $(D24.$)    Another British-U.S. Utility Deal  Dominion Resources, continuing an American invasion of the British utility industry, agreed to acquire East Midlands Electricity for about $2.15 billion. $(D4.$)    Drug Helps Prevent Heart Attacks  A study has found that a blood thinner called clopidogrel is more effective than aspirin in warding off heart attacks and strokes in people who have clogged arteries. Clopidogrel is being jointly developed by Sanofi and Bristol-Myers Squibb. $(A18.$)    Tougher Nasdaq Standard Proposed  The Nasdaq stock market, after being embarrassed by scandals that involved penny stocks, is proposing stricter listing standards that it said could cause hundreds of companies to be dropped from its listings. $(D2.$)    I.B.M. in Educational Software Deal  I.B.M. took its first big step toward becoming a major seller of educational software to schools and homes, saying it would buy Edmark for about $110 million. $(D3.$)    Pepsi Returning To Venezuela  Pepsi is coming back to Venezuela, five months after its bottler and distributor switched to Coke. Pepsico formed a venture with a brewer to bottle and distribute Pepsi, which had been the dominant soft drink in Venezuela before Coke's coup. $(D5.$)    Growth, Not Inflation, Is Up in China  China's chief banker said that the Government had achieved what few economists thought it could: high growth and low inflation. $(D4.$)    Limit on Workweek Is Rejected  Prime Minister John Major has plunged Britain into another clash with its 14 European Union partners by rejecting a court ruling that mandates a maximum workweek of 48 hours, including overtime. $(A7.$)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Expands Stock Offering
abstract: Deutsche Telekom expands its stock offering; offering will put about 23 percent of total equity in investors' hands, with German Government retaining 77 percent (S)

headline: Orange County Jail Term Set
abstract: Judge Stephen Czuleger sentences former Orange County, Calif, treasurer Robert Citron to year in jail, 1,000 hours of community service and $100,000 fine for his role in county's bankruptcy (S)

headline: Stocks Recover A Bit in Japan
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock index is up 387.70 points, or 2.02 percent, at 19,549.41 on Wednesday, Dec 25 (S)

headline: More Scholarly and Luxurious, Art Gallery Catalogues Move Upmarket
abstract: NEW YORK—  In growing numbers, art gallery catalogues are undergoing a transformation that has in effect spawned anew literary genre.

headline: People
abstract: Promotions in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: A Final Settlement for 7 Tons of Nazi Gold
abstract: PARIS—  The United States, Britain and France are about to close a chapter in history by distributing the last seven tons of bullion in their postwar pool of Nazi gold, worth about $86 million

headline: Natural Gas Prices Surge Again On Cold's Threat to Production
abstract: Natural gas prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange on persistent concern that frigid weather will cut production in Texas and Louisiana while bolstering demand across US; wheat prices fall (M)

headline: A General on His Own
abstract: News analysis reports that Aleksandr Lebed is cocky and unbowed as he announces presidential ambitions, only three hours after Pres Boris Yeltsin's angry dismissal of him as Russian security adviser; photos; Lebed charges chief of staff Anatoly B Chubais with masterminding fall from grace, calling Yeltsin an 'aged and sick man'; dramatic dismissal could allow Lebed, already highly popular, to rally public discontent, but he may find rivals just as determined to chase him off political stage; Lebed also needs money, which comes from banking and industrial oligarchies that are much more fond of Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin and Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov; chronology of Lebed's four months in Kremlin (M)

headline: Germany's Phone Giant Is Bracing for Invaders
abstract: Deutsche Telekom, Germany's giant state-owned telephone company, is going public in one of largest stock offerings ever; twenty percent of shares will trade in New York, Tokyo and Frankfurt, and are expected to be wildly oversubscribed in Germany itself; offering should raise about $10 billion, with perhaps another $10 billion worth of stock to be sold in two years; overriding question is how company can shift to more competitive environment, now that all 15 members of European Union have agreed to open up their telephone markets by January 1998; profile of company; charts of European rivals (L)

headline: Bond Prices Turn Mixed After Rally
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities end mixed; 30-year bond rises 1/32, to price of 98 29/32, to yield of 6.84 percent, unchanged Oct 11; graphs (L)

headline: SUN AMERICA IS BUYING ANNUITY RESERVES FROM JOHN ALDEN
abstract: Sun America Inc says it will buy $5 billion worth of annuity reserves from John Alden Financial Corp for undisclosed terms; acquisition will include substantially all of John Alden's annuity business (S)

headline: Eileen Donovan, 81, Former Ambassador
abstract: Eileen R Donovan, former US Ambassador to Barbados, dies at age 81 (S)

headline: France Nears the End Of Elf Aquitaine Sale
abstract: French Government sells 9.1 percent stake in Elf Aquitaine for $2 billion, nearly ending its interest in the oil company (S)

headline: Fearing a Rate Rise, Shippers Await 2d Front In Rail Merger
abstract: Shippers along East Coast are awaiting outcome of bidding war between CSX Corp and Norfolk Southern Corp for Conrail, hoping to win some concessions when winner seeks Federal Surface Transportation Board approval; fear big rate rises on routes with no competition and possible deterioration of service as merged railroad struggles to cut costs; merger opponents face uphill battle; graph (M)/

headline: This Fur Advertisement Was Not Exactly as Advertised
abstract: New Yorker magazine publishes ad in its Oct 14 issue purporting to be from 'Paul's Furs,' offering free fur video; the Paul of Paul's Furs is Paul McCartney, former Beatle, and advertiser is not a furrier, but the animal-rights group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals; video offered in ad graphically depicts how animals are slaughtered in the name of fashion; Maurie Perl, New Yorker vice president, says magazine is not pleased about being duped and would not knowingly have run a misleading ad; drawing (M)

headline: Judge Rejects Move to Block CSX-Conrail Merger Deal
abstract: Federal Judge Donald VanArtsdalen rejects Norfolk Southern Corp bid for preliminary injunction to block CSX Corp-Conrail merger; Norfolk Southern appeals ruling (M)

headline: Magazines Increasingly Lend Titles to Other Products
abstract: Publishers are increasingly generating new revenue by marketing products branded with their magazines' name; ventures can also make magazine more visible and attractive to readers and advertisers; now produce almost 10 percent of most magazines' total earnings and are expected to rise to 20 percent in five years; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Times Company Names 2 Senior Vice Presidents
abstract: New York Times Co announces appointment of John M O'Brien and Solomon B Watson 4th as senior vice presidents; O'Brien, 54, will be senior vice president for operations for Times Co; Watson, 52, retains additional title of general counsel; David L Gorham, senior vice pres and deputy chief operating officer of company, announces that he plans to retire early next year; photos (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Earthlink Network Inc., Pasadena, Calif., an initial public offering of 2 million shares. Invemed Associates.    Energy Search Inc., Knoxville, Tenn., an initial public offering of 1 million units, each consisting of 1 common share and 1 class A redeemable warrant. National Securities Corp.    Flanders Corp., Washington, N.C., 1.6 million shares. Gilford Securities Inc.    Fundex Games Ltd., Indianapolis, an initial public offering of 1 million shares and 1 million warrants. National Securities Corp.    NAL Financial Group Inc., Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., 2.5 million shares. Prudential Securities.    Multimedia Access Corp., Dallas, an initial public offering of 1.2 million shares and 1.2 million warrants. National Securities Corp.    Vital Food Products Inc., Chicago, an initial public offering of 750,000 shares and 750,000 warrants. National Securities Corp.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: YELTSIN ANGRILY ANNOUNCES DISMISSAL OF AIDE HE HAILED AS A LIKELY POLITICAL HEIR
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin angrily appears on Russian television to dismiss Aleksandr Lebed, aggressive national security chief he embraced as his political heir only four months ago; photos; Yeltsin, appearing frail but determined, signs dismissal with exaggerated flourish, saying he can no longer tolerate Lebed's brazen, insubordinate behavior; risky decision to oust former general, who almost singlehandedly halted ruinous war in Chechnya and is highly popular, follows weeks of Lebed's public clashes with Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin and chief of staff Anatoly Chubais; three have been running country while Yeltsin awaits heart bypass surgery; fragile peace in Chechnya could now unravel; Yeltsin accuses Lebed of having 'Napoleon complex,' although he belittles suggestions of coup plot; Lebed vows to begin political activities at once, but only by 'constitutional means,' although he drops dark warning about demoralized army; calls Yeltsin 'aged and sick man' who has failed to pass on his duties to anyone (M)

headline: The Summer Olympics failed to vault any gold medal winners into major endorsement deals.
abstract: Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Ga, failed to vault any American gold medal winners into major advertising endorsement deals; many sports marketers say the reason is that companies are spending their endorsement money before the Games, seeking to pick winners so their products can be seen by the millions of people watching the Games (L)

headline: Robert Bourassa, 63, Dies; Led a Turbulent Quebec
abstract: Robert Bourassa, former Premier of Quebec who led Canada's most turbulent province through some of its deepest crises and greatest triumphs, dies at age of 63; photo (M)

headline: Big Fund Manager Acquired in Italy
abstract: Assicurazioni Generali SpA of Italy says it paid 325 billion lire ($213 million) to acquire Prime Gestioni SpA, a fund management company controlled by Fiat SpA, and to increase its stake in Prime Augusta Vita SpA, life insurance subsidiary of Prime Gestioni, to 40 percent from 18 percent (S)

headline: Occupation of a Nuclear Plant Signals Russian Labor's Anger
abstract: Russia's inability to pay workers prompts more than a dozen employees at St Petersburg's nuclear power plant to take over control room and threaten to shut the plant down unless they receive months' worth of back pay; Government flies in $200 for each worker and promises to deliver the rest within a week; problem arises because tax revenues have been worse than anemic this year; social safety net, always shabby for the majority of the people, has rarely been thinner (M)

headline: From Dayton to Sarajevo: Spirit of Giving and Eye for Deals
abstract: Delegation from Dayton, Ohio, where treaty ending Balkan conflict was negotiated, arrive in Sarajevo, Bosnia, to see how peace process is faring; bring gifts and offers of help; speak of sponsoring cultural and educational exchanges, while keeping eye out for commercial opportunities (M)

headline: Yeltsin Orders Withdrawal Of Troops In Chechnya
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin orders withdrawal of virtually all of remaining Russian forces in Chechnya, in move that will deprive Moscow of even face-saving military presence in breakaway region in southern Russia (M)

headline: Hong Kong Putting on a Brave 'Face'
abstract: HONG KONG—  There is a lot of "face" being practiced in Hong Kong seven months ahead of the 1997 transition. Not just the ancient Chinese custom relating to respect, but a very brave face on the populace masking nerves over the transition.

headline: Two Airliners Collide in Midair, Killing All 351 Aboard in India
abstract: Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and Kazak Airlines Ilyushin 76 collide in midair over New Delhi, India, killing all 351 passengers and crew members; collision occurs shortly after takeoff of Saudi airliner, and during approach of Kazak plane to New Delhi airport; is third-deadliest air disaster and worst mid-air collision in aviation history; wreckage is spread over six-mile-wide area, but police report no casualties on ground; rescuers recover 275 bodies; eyewitness describes crash; Indian civil aviation officials comment; map; diagram; photo (M)

headline: Cadwell Davis Loses Three J.& J. Brands
abstract: Personal products division of Johnson & Johnson moves North American advertising account of three brands from Cadwell Davis Partners to McCann-Erickson Worldwide and Ammirati Puris Lintas (S)

headline: Canadian Tribe, Shedding Ashes of an 'Evil Place,' Gets a Chance at Rebirth
abstract: Article on Indians of Davis Inlet, Newfoundland, who have become notorious symbol of Canada's misguided paternalism toward indigenous people; Innu Indians were forced by government and Roman Catholic missionaries to give up nomadic culture in 1967 and move to bleak island, where they lived in total dependency and near-total drunkenness and gasoline sniffing; tragic culmination was fire that killed six young children whose parents were out drinking; photos; map; 500 Innus will move to traditional campsite on mainland which they have selected themselves; $62-million relocation will involve tribe in all decision-making and construction, as national Government shifts to approach of self-determination and economic development (M)

headline: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL TO CUT 800 JOBS IN REVAMPING
abstract: Great Western Financial Corp plans to cut 800 jobs, or nearly 6% of its work force, by end of next year; some 400 people have already been told they will lose their jobs (S)

headline: ABC Official to Head Disney Syndication Unit
abstract: Walter C Liss Jr, who has managed WABC-TV for 10 years, is named chairman of Buena Vista Television, television syndication arm of ABC's parent company, Walt Disney Co (M)
