headline: Treating the Excesses of Sick Pay
abstract: Number of American companies are combining sick days, vacation time, personal days and floating hoidays into one category called paid days off; aim is to take days away from sick-leave abusers and give it back to good employees (S)

headline: The Fed Holds Rates Steady; Housing Gains
abstract: Federal Reserve votes to leave interest rates unchanged, concluding that inflation remains dormant despite sporadic surges in economic activity; Fed's decision was widely anticipated among economists and in financial markets; Commerce Dept reports that construction of housing jumped sharply higher last month, suggesting that economic growth could be picking up again in fourth quarter after cooling down substantially over summer; graph (M)

headline: Ex-Soviet Spy Free as C.I.A. Chief Calls Arrest by F.B.I. a Mistake
abstract: John M Deutch, Director of Central Intelligence, helps free a former Soviet spy, Vladimir Galkin, convincing Justice Department that arrest on entry into US on October 29 was a mistake that could provoke Moscow to seize retired US spies doing business in Moscow; was unaware Justice Department planned to imprison Galkin, who was charged with trying to steal secrets from 'Star Wars' antimissile program; decision to release Galkin enrages some FBI officials and revives old tensions between bureau's spycatchers and CIA; senior State Department officials agree arrest of Galkin was blunder; arrest led Russia to accuse US of breaking unwritten rules of espionage, which call for both to deport the other side's spies and to leave retirees alone; photo (M)

headline: A retrospective of Britain's best television ads from the last 20 years traces their evolution.
abstract: Advertising column describes new retrospective of Britain's best television ads from last 20 years, brought to New York by Museum of Modern Art and now traveling to other museums; says British television advertising has evolved from small, charming vignettes with tongue-in-cheek humor to sleekly photographed campaigns, many with references to United States and its culture (M)

headline: Rwandan Road Is Lined With Lost Children
abstract: More than 2,000 children have been found alone, abandoned or lost since half million Rwandan refugees began trek home from Zaire; are straining capacity of aid agencies, clogging emergency compounds set up for them; some say they began journey alone, with parents lost or dead when fighting broke out in vast Mugunga refugee camp on Zairian side of border; photo (M)

headline: 2 Blasts on British Army Base in Ulster Hurt 23 and Cloud Talks
abstract: Two explosions on British Army base in Lisburn, Northern Ireland, wound 20 soldiers and 3 civilians and further damage already floundering peace effort in British province; attack, believed work of Irish Republican Army, is deplored by Prime Min John Major and other officials (M)

headline: No Progress As Guerrillas In Peru Free A Captive
abstract: Guerrillas release an ailing Japanese diplomat from Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru; the 103 hostages left in compound share some Christmas cheer in the form of carols, food and a mass celebrated by Bishop Jose Luis Cipriani; there are no signs of breakthrough in talks aimed at ending siege; photos (M)

headline: Baby May Make 3, but in Japan That's Not Enough
abstract: Officials in Kyokushi are concerned about Japan's low birth rate; they are offering any mother in town almost $5,000 upon birth of fourth or subsequent child; many other Japanese towns also offer cash for births, but Kyokushi's rewards are among highest; since Kyokushi introduced reward in April, no woman with three or more children has become pregnant; they say reward is too small; photo (M)

headline: Degussa to Buy A Drug Maker, Muro
abstract: Degussa AG says it will buy 80 percent outstanding of Muro Pharmaceutical Inc for cash and stock; says total purchase price, including 20 percent it already owns, is $350 million (S)

headline: TENNESSEE GAS TO PAY $60 MILLION TO END CONTRACT
abstract: Tesoro Petroleum Corp says Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co agreed to pay it about $60 million to end contract that requires Tennessee Gas to buy gas at above-market prices; this ends long-running litigation between two companies; Tennessee Gas lost court decision over disputed contract (S)

headline: The Marriott Prospers as Three Separate Companies
abstract: Profile of Marriott empire, which has thrived since it split up into Marriott International and Host Marriott three years ago; independence has bestowed new nimbleness on firms in pursuing separate interests without weakening their ability to pool resources to pursue common goals; firms share headquarters building, some staff members and Marriott family guidance; Host Marriott has also successfully spun off its Host Marriott Services Corp; graph; table; photos (M)

headline: Ford Joins Move to Used Car Warranties as New Rivals Grow
abstract: Ford Motor Co is latest auto maker to offer warranty program for used cars from its dealers; first 'quality certified' used Fords will be sold next week from dealerships in Southeast, and at dealers nationwide by next spring; General Motors Corp and Chrsyler Corp are setting up similar programs, as is Honda; aim is to draw used car buyers to their dealers' lots and away from used car superstores that are cropping up around the country (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M. Dispute in Canada Hinges on Issue of Control   The dispute between General Motors and the Canadian Automobile Workers union is a struggle over who really runs the company, which is making it difficult to resolve a four-day-old strike. After decades of seeking higher wages or better benefits, the Canadian union seeks a labor contract that will restrict many management prerogatives, like the ability to sell factories and shift production to low-wage, outside companies.    G.M. Canada's top labor negotiator said that it could not accept limits on corporate decision-making. But the union's president said that anything less would be inadequate, even if a long strike resulted. $(Page A14.$)      A Cross-Border Magazine War   In charging excise taxes of 80 percent on Canadian editions of American magazines, authorities in Ottawa say they are only protecting Canada's national identity and supporting its own magazine industry. The United States contends that the real goal is to stifle competition. After years of no resolution, the United States has taken its grievance to the World Trade Organization. $(D9.$)     Revising an Evergreen   The redesign at Time Warner's Sunset magazine -- a new cover logo, new typeface for text, bolder use of photos and graphics -- stands out in an industry in which redesigns are routine. For decades, the monthly hewed to postage-stamp-sized photographs and practical articles about food, travel, home improvement and gardening. $(D9.$)     Preaching to the Converted on Line   Evangelists are using the Internet to convert lapsed Christians and newcomers, with smaller, computer-savvy churches drawing a more active response than sites of huge operations like the Christian Broadcasting Network. $(D5.$)  Frail European Computer Makers   When Olivetti put its personal computer unit on the block last week, it joined a long line of European companies that had left the business. Unlike rivals in the United States and the Far East, the Europeans held on to costly retail stores too long and failed to speed products to market. $(D2.$)     Software to Speed Up Downloads   Marimba, an Internet startup, introduces software today for distributing data over the Internet, called Castanet, that tries to cut the delays in retrieving software and graphics that can make the experience of using the World Wide Web a frustrating one. $(D5.$)     What's Cool on Line?   Members of the emerging World Wide Web design industry wore their synthetic finery last Thursday to toast the best in their field at the Cool Site of the Year Awards in Manhattan. Taking In the Sites. $(D8.$)    A Visionary's Latest Mission   In the 1950's and 1960's, Douglas Engelbart invented many seminal products and concepts taken for granted in the computer industry today -- the mouse, hypertext, groupware and many others. Now he is assembling a group of ''thought leaders'' from industry, government and universities to help change the use of information technologies, because how people work together is as critical as the technologies that connect them. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. $(D5.$)

headline: ALLEGIANCE TO TAKE $550 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
abstract: Allegiance Corp to take $550-million charge in fourth quarter, its first quarter as independent company, because of accounting change; Allegiance was spun off by Baxter International (S)

headline: Ready to Go In Vietnam: Alas, There's No Market
abstract: Article on Templeton Vietnam Opportunities fund despite lack of stock market in Vietnam; says earlier this month Securities and Exchange Commission and shareholders approved changes in the policies of $100 million closed-end fund; holds Templeton fund has been marking time; about half its assets are in US Treasury bills, with most of rest in Asian companies doing some business in Vietnam (L)

headline: Compromise Is Offered on Computer Security Codes
abstract: Clinton Administration offers compromise to the computer industry by holding out the possibility of removing all export restrictions on data-scrambling technology for companies that accept new approach to allow law enforcement officials to unscramble codes; new approach, accepted by Central Intelligence Agency, calls for law enforcement officials to unscramble computer communications--provided they have warrant--without having to obtain mathematical key to code; agents instead could use warrant to obtain cooperation of outside parties to help unscramble portions of code accompanying a message; two-step process is intended to address main criticisms against data-scrambling systems; is being recommended by an alliance led by International Business Machines Corp (M)

headline: Natural Gas Prices Increase For Second Consecutive Day
abstract: Natural gas prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange for second consecutive session amid expectations that report will show inventories fell last week; in other markets, lumber prices surge (M)

headline: Treasures Trickle Back to a Plundered Cambodia
abstract: Cambodian Government is seeking return of treasures that have been stolen from hundreds of temples and archeological sites; with cooperation from curators and customs agents abroad, this has been significant year for recovery of artifacts; map; photo (M)

headline: When Lawyers Switch Firms
abstract: Robert J Lipton letter on Aug 25 article on lawyers switching law firms (S)y

headline: Tandy Plans To Close 17 Superstores
abstract: Tandy Corp will shut down its Incredible Universe chain of superstores and close 19 of its 108 Computer City stores, resulting in after-tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $170 million; will sell assets in six Incredible Universe stores to Fry's Electronics, and sell those six stores to real estate partnerships that will lease stores to Fry's; seeks to sell remaining 11 Incredible Universe stores (M)

headline: S.E.C. Filing by Bottler
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc files with Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $2.5 billion in securities (S)

headline: Mexican Drug Wars Creep Near U.S. Border
abstract: Rival drug gangs in Tijuana, Mex, are fighting turf war that threatens to spill over into US; Mexican and US officials say bloodshed is being driven by conflict in which rival gangs are muscling in Arellano Felix family, whose drug organization has long controlled Tijuana border, and parallel conflict raging among corrupt factions within Mexico's Federal Judicial Police; some recent incidents of violence discussed; maps; photos (M)

headline: UNITED COMPANIES AGREES TO BUY EMPIRE FUNDING
abstract: United Companies Financial Corp agrees to acquire privately held Empire Funding Corp for about $89 million in stock (S)

headline: Shell to Revamp European Refineries
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group to revamp its refinery business in Europe, selling at least one plant in bid to raise margins in crowded market (S)

headline: After Nintendo's victory, more Japanese companies may say they'd rather fight than pay.
abstract: Japanese companies are expected to be less willing to sign licensing agreements with American patent holders in wake of Federal appeals court ruling reversing a $250 million jury award to Alpex Computer Corp against Nintendo Co, which refused to pay Alpex a licensing fee for technology that enables video game characters to move and interact; Terry L Butler and Ricky J Bishop patent a plastic turkey call that they say is capable of emitting authentic turkey sounds (M)

headline: Lousiana-Pacific Sets Income Charge
abstract: Louisiana-Pacific Corp says it will take $215 million charge against third-quarter earnings to cover expected costs for shutting some of its plants and settling lawsuits; charge will result in loss for quarter (S)

headline: Israel to Expand Jewish Settlement in West Bank
abstract: Israeli Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai approves plans for major expansion of Jewish settlement on West Bank near Nablus; move is condemned by Palestinian Authority; map (M)

headline: TELEPORT COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE EASTERN TELELOGIC
abstract: Teleport Communications Group agrees to buy Eastern Telelogic Corp for $233 million (S)

headline: 9 More Brokers Barred in License Scandal
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers permanently bars nine New York area securities brokers from industry and fines them, some up to $50,000, for paying impostors to take their licensing exams (S)

headline: Decoding What 'Screen-Agers' Think About TV
abstract: Profile of Douglas Rushkoff, 35-year-old consultant who tells television producers and network executives how to reach people under 30, the market's future; that he is highly paid and in great demand by networks is a sign of the high anxiety among many companies today; some critics have dismissed him as the Faith Popcorn of his generation, promoting youth trends with pop slogans of dubious validity; photo (M)

headline: Research firms say they can tell companies if sponsoring an event is worth the money.
abstract: Bonham Group is one of handful of research firms that have emerged in recent years to track exposure companies get from sponsoring events; such firms are attracting business as more corporations come under pressure to justify costly sponsorships; critics score research methods (M)

headline: Microsoft Is Detailing Plans For Its Assault on Internet
abstract: Bill Gates is expected to detail Microsoft Corp's latest plan for dominating Internet; key to strategy is redesign of Microsoft Network, which has quickly become third-largest Internet access and on-line information service; MSN reportedly will offer unlimited use for competitive, flat monthly fee of $19.95; firm is also expected to show new version of its World Wide Web browser software and step up push to create information and entertainment products (M)

headline: U.S. Archives Describe Contents of Nazi Hoard
abstract: Recently declassified US Government document shows that in waning days of World War II, American soldiers found large cache of art and gold hidden in German salt mines; indicates cache, which included ceremonial cups used for Jewish religious observances, may have been part of money-laundering scheme devised by SS leader Heinrich Himmler (S)

headline: Foote, Cone Wins Work for Sara Lee
abstract: Sara Lee Bakery, Sara Lee Corp unit, names Foote, Cone & Belding to handle integrated advertising and promotions for its grocery division; account had been at Ammirati Puris Lintas (S)

headline: Q&A /Jean-Philippe Beja : China Patriotism Cuts Both Ways
abstract: Recent efforts by Japanese rightists to assert Tokyo's sovereignty over the uninhabited Senkaku Islands, also claimed by China and Taiwan as the Diaoyus, have unleashed a wave of protests against the Japanese in Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan and China itself. Jean-Philippe Beja, head of the French Center for the Study of Contemporary China in Hong Kong, spoke with Kevin Murphy of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Taking Hold of the Purse Strings, and Holding Their Own
abstract: Article on some of main points in lead article by Diane Harris in November issue of Money magazine on how women are taking more control of their financial future; photo (L)

headline: Prices Lower On Treasury Securities
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities turn lower for second consecutive session, mostly on strength of housing report that surprised market and raised investors' concerns about inflation and higher interest rates; 30-year bond slips 3/32, to 97 28/32; graph (M)

headline: Debt Agreement For Eurotunnel
abstract: British-French Eurotunnel group reaches an agreement with 225 mostly British and French banks to restructure its estimated $14 billion debt (S)

headline: Pentagon Defends 2 Jet Missile Firings in Iraq
abstract: Defense Dept says pilots of two US jet fighters were justified in firing missiles in southern Iraq, even though it is still unclear that either plane had actually been in danger; says in both cases, cockpit equipment suggested to pilots that they had been targeted by Iraqi radar installations in preparation for attack (M)

headline: Bleak Serbian Mining Region May Decide Milosevic's Fate
abstract: Fate of Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic, whose Government has faced almost two weeks of street protests in major cities, may ultimately hinge on whether miners strike in bleak southeastern mining region of Bor; opposition coalition says support of workers in mining communities in south is crucial to drive to force Milosevic from power; miners, who are plagued with poor working conditions and subsequent health problems caused by toxic emissions and dangerous production procedures, have been warned they face dismissals if they join protests; opposition has campaigned on pledge to curb industrial contamination; protests have followed Government decision to nullify results of recent elections; photo; map (M)

headline: Times Co. Sees '96 Profit Gain
abstract: New York Times Co says it expects to report higher earnings for 1996 compared with previous year; Diane P Baker, Times Company's chief financial officer, tells gathering of security analysts that company expects to earn $1.78 to $1.88 a share for 1996 (S)

headline: Gauging the Rubin Effect
abstract: Jesse H Oppenheimer letter on Sept 22 article on Treas Sec Robert E Rubin's influence on Pres Clinton's economic policies in re-election drive (S)

headline: New Small-Town Mayor Is a Man for All Serbs
abstract: Vojislav Seselj, new mayor of Zemun, Serbia, is being investigated by International War Crimes Tribunal; he is respected member of Pres Slobodan Milosevic's political establishment; map (M)

headline: Relief-Plan Politics Discussed at U.N.
abstract: Officials from countries planning international force to assist relief efforts in Rwanda and eastern Zaire meet at UN to discuss political situation in which force will have to operate (S)ï

headline: French Strike Slows Planes, Trains and Mail in Protesting Cuts
abstract: Nationwide public employees' strike in France hobbles air and rail service; schools and post offices operate with reduced staff; walkout widens union rifts on how firmly to resist spending cuts and hiring freezes that Government says are necessary to prepare for common European currency in 1999; militants in Paris boo moderate union leader who supports part of plan to cut deficits (S)

headline: Refugees Flee War in Western Afghan City
abstract: Thousands of refugees flee for makeshift camps on outskirts of Herat, in western Afghanistan, after jets belonging to opponents of fundamentalist Taliban militia bomb airport there (S)

headline: 2 Executives Quit Chiat/Day Office
abstract: Two top executives at St Louis office of TBWA Chiat/Day, Lloyd Wolfe and Bill Freeman, resign over what they describe as philosophical differences; Mary Tetlow will assume Feeman's duties, an Duncan Milner will temporarily lead creative department (S)

headline: An Additional Title For Wren at Omnicom
abstract: John Wren, president of Omnicom Group, is named to additional position of chief executive (S)

headline: U.S. Radio Aiming At China 'Tyranny,' But Few Can Hear It
abstract: Radio Free Asia, authorized by Congress to 'confront tyranny' in East Asia, is reaching very few people in China because few know about shortwave broadcasts and signal is too weak to reach most of intended audience; network is forced to use transmitters as far away as Armenia and Tajikistan, near vast western Chinese region where few people understand Mandarin Chinese broadcasts; US diplomat in Beijing says nobody there has heard anything yet; most Chinese who listen to foreign broadcasts are devoted to BBC, Voice of America and Radio France International; Radio Free Asia vice president Daniel Southerland insists signal is getting through and blames local jamming, which American officials doubt; prominent intellectual Dai Qing cancels her broadcasting arrangement, charging network jeopardizes her with confrontational approach (M)

headline: Stock Option Trading High
abstract: Options Industry Council reports that trading in stock options this year hit record high, at 180,693,189 traded through November with month left (S)

headline: Linotype to Cut 1,200 German Jobs
abstract: Linotype-Hell AG, German graphic equipment maker, will cut 1,200 jobs, or about one-third of its work force; expects to lose more than 70 million marks, or about $45 million, for second straight year in 1996 (S)

headline: Unforgiving Spain Pursues Argentine Killers
abstract: Spanish judge opens criminal investigation into torture, disappearance and killing of 320 Spanish citizens in Argentina during military rule, between 1976 and 1983; charges 97 former and active Argentine military and police officers in case and wants to interrogate them in Spain or Argentina; among them are members of three successive military juntas, intelligence chiefs, commanders of clandestine jails, and even doctors who reportedly attended torture sessions; parallel investigation focuses on abduction of 54 children of Spanish victims who remain missing; legal scholars describe investigations as largest peacetime human rights abuses in which court in one nation has claimed jurisdiction over events in another; Judge Baltasar Garzon has invoked international law in arguing that such crimes against humanity can be tried anywhere and are not subject to any time limit; Esperanza Labrador, resident of Madrid who lost husband and two sons in Argentina 20 years ago, comments; photo (M)

headline: Chief Executive Puts Stock-Only Pay to Ultimate Test
abstract: Jerre L Stead, chief executive of Ingram Micro Inc, agreed to daring package when he joined company in August; he will get nothing but stock options; his deal allows him to purchase 3.6 million shares of Ingram Micro's stock over period of years, some of it tied to goals for stock price and company earnings; in theory, he could own 2.8 percent of company in five years; Stead's package has one highly desirable byproduct: Ingram Micro will go public this month, at expected $14 to $16 a share; for years, shareholders and analysts have said corporate chieftains should put more of their pay at risk; there have been some precedents for what Stead has agreed to, but his deal will be the ultimate test; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None     TUESDAY   None     WEDNESDAY   None     THURSDAY   Weekly Jobless Claims     FRIDAY   Durable-Goods Orders Sept.  Existing-Home Sales Sept.

headline: Look, Ma, No Gas!
abstract: General Motors' new electric car noted; photo (S)

headline: Assignments Added For Two Agencies
abstract: Two marketers are expanding relationships with roster agencies.    The Kellogg Company in Battle Creek, Mich., named J. Walter Thompson New York, a unit of WPP Group, to handle advertising for its newly acquired Lender's Bagels brand. Thompson New York handled Lender's while Kraft Foods owned the brand and is also a Kellogg roster agency. Though billings have not been determined, Kraft, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, spent about $12 million to $15 million annually to advertise Lender's.

headline: CARGILL FINANCIAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR EAPCO
abstract: Cargill Financial Services Corp says it will buy Eapco Commercial Properties Inc for $45.7 million in stock (S)

headline: TOM BROWN INCREASES BID FOR PRESIDIO OIL
abstract: Independent oil and gas company Tom Brown Inc says that it increased its bid for Presidio Oil Co by $10 million, to $193 million, in return for support from Presidio's creditors (S)

headline: Japanese Liquor Tax Is Declared Unfair
abstract: World Trade Orgn panel decides that Japan's taxes on domestic liquor breach its rules; European Union complained that Japan taxes imported liquor at rates six times those imposed on domestic products (S)

headline: HEARTPORT SHARES SURGE ON NEWS OF F.D.A. APPROVAL
abstract: Heartport Inc says Food and Drug Administration will allow it to market its minimally invasive heart surgery systems in United States; systems allow doctors to perform heart surgery wihtout having to crack open chest (S)

headline: Europeans to Fight U.S. Sanctions Against Cuba in Trade Court
abstract: European Union, in rebuff to Clinton Administration five weeks before election, says it will challenge in new court of world trade the American law that has imposed sanctions on foreign companies doing business with Cuba (M)

headline: Judge Prefers a Long Sentence In Muni Sales Kickback Case
abstract: Federal Judge William Young says he wants to give long prison sentence to Mark Ferber, former partner of Lazard Freres & Co, who was convicted of swindling public agencies around country of influence-peddling scheme in sale of municipal bonds; says Ferber made 'knowing false staements' when he recommended that clients award lucrative underwriting work to Merrill Lynch & Co; Merrill was paying Ferber and his firm a secret annual retainer of $1 million; Judge Young also sharply criticizes Merrill Lynch and Lazard for 'corporate criminal culture' (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BASF CORP., Mount Olive, N.J., a unit of Germany's BASF A.G., said it was exiting the magnetic tape business in North America, which will result in the elimination of 128 jobs and the closing of its BASF Magnetics Corp. operation in Bedford, Mass.      DOLE FOOD CO. Westlake Village, Calif., said it would buy back as much as 5 percent of its 60.1 million common shares outstanding.     JOHNSON CONTROLS INC., Milwaukee, a maker and marketer of energy-use systems, said it would close its valve plant in Milwaukee within two years, cutting 200 jobs and moving most of the production to Mexico.

headline: The Hunt for the Creature That Ebola Calls Home
abstract: International team of scientists in Tai Forest, Ivory Coast, is trying to uncover elusive pathogen responsible for deadly Ebola virus; Dr Pierre Formenty, French veterinary specialist, is head of World Health Organization-financed project; map; photo (M)

headline: REVCO'S BID FOR BIG B SAID TO DRAW COMPETITION
abstract: Big B Inc says several unidentified parties have shown interest in topping unwanted takeover offer from Revco DS Inc (S)

headline: RATIONAL SOFTWARE TO ACQUIRE SQA IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Rational Software Corp agrees to acquire SQA Inc for stock valued at $313 million (S)

headline: Europeans Dubious on British Air Alliance
abstract: European Commission says it has doubts about proposed British Airways-American Airways alliance, holding it would dominate trans-Atlantic air travel; holds it has authority to block deal, stand disputed by British Airways (S)

headline: Primark Seen Announcing Baseline Purchase
abstract: Primark Corp is expected to acquire Baseline Financial Services for $40 million cash from Bowne & Co and Robert Patterson (S)

headline: I.B.M. TO EXPAND DISK-DRIVE MANUFACTURING CAPACITY
abstract: International Business Machines Corp says it plans to spend $440 million to expand its worldwide manufacturing capacity for disk drives and other components (S)p

headline: One Dispute Settled While Another Begins
abstract: Hubert H Humphrey 3d, Attorney General in Minnesota, announces settlement resolving claims made by 19 states against advertisements for drugs marketed by McNeil Consumer Products Co that carried name of Arthritis Foundation; Humphrey charged that campaign, with actress Julie Andrews, misled consumers into believing that line of drugs--which were discontinued last month--were medications newly created by foundation; McNeil admits no wrongdoing; company agrees to pay $1.96 million; $250,000 will go to an agency of National Institutes of Health for arthritis research and rest to states for costs and consumer education; Gillette Co files suit in Federal District Court in Massachusetts against Norelco Consumer Products Co charging that Norelco campaign for electric shavers is false and disparaging (M)

headline: APPLE COMPUTER REDUCES THE PRICE ON SOME SERVERS
abstract: Apple Computer Inc has lowered by 12 percent to 23 percent the price it charges resellers in US for its servers based on its Macintosh operating system; Compaq Computer Corp also cuts server prices, reducing price on selected Compaq Prosignia 300 servers by up to 12 percent (S)

headline: Canada Tries to Shake Off Economic Doldrums
abstract: Canada is trying to shake off economic doldrums; central bank reduces rates for for 20th time in 18 months, dropping prime rate to 4.75%, lowest it has been since 1956; even such invitingly low rates have not been enough to get Canada's consumers spending again; nor have lowest rates in 40 years stimulated enough growth to reduce country's high unemployment; Statistics Canada reports that unemployment rose to 10% in October (M)

headline: British Governor of Hong Kong Takes a Parting Shot at Beijing
abstract: Chris Patten, last governor in 157 years of British rule of Hong Kong, delivers his final policy address to colonial legislature, defending Britain's record and denouncing China's intentions toward territory when it takes control next July (M)

headline: Rising Above Politics
abstract: Stock market performance in Presidential campaign seasons noted; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has gained ground in fourth quarter of all election years except 1948; photo; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Marine Corps Retains Thompson
abstract: United States Marine Corps ends mandated review on its account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, by retaining J Walter Thompson Atlanta unit of WPP Group, which has handled account since 1946 (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   5.21   5.66        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.98   5.01   5.25        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.12   5.12   5.29        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.56   6.50   5.93        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.85   6.80   6.28        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.88   7.84   7.31        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.90   5.87   5.88          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: The Predictions: Will the Real 1997 Please Stand Up?
abstract: January issues of personal-finance magazines are loaded with prognostications and lists of stock picks for 1997; magazines are nervously bullish on stocks for 1997; most predict correction in first half, followed by a rebound; some analysts see Dow Jones industrial average hitting 9,000 or 10,000 in coming years; photos (L)/

headline: U.S. Sets Conditions for Using Troops to Aid Refugees in Zaire
abstract: Canadian and American officials haggle over details of international military mission to rescue million Rwandan refugees stranded in fighting in Zaire; US reportedly wants to wait for cease-fire between Hutu militias and Zairian Tutsi rebels before sending troops, but other countries say situation is too dire to wait (M)

headline: NCR stock is trading high, and some analysts wonder why.
abstract: Market Place column notes that AT&T is spinning off NCR Corp just five years after its hostile takeover; NCR is now valued at about half the amount that AT&T paid in 1991; NRC has lost nearly $4 billion over last five years; Lars Nyberg, NCR's chairman and chief executive, has cut 8,500 jobs and $600 million in expenses in effort to turn around he company (M)

headline: Pope's Talk With Anglican Leader Appears to Stall
abstract: Pope John Paul II and Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, try hard to cast harmonious glow over their encounter in Rome, but interfaith dialogue appears to have stalled over unreconcilable issue of ordination of women as priests; photo; English church broke away four centuries ago over another issue involving women: King Henry VIII's wish to divorce and remarry; women have been ordained as priests in American Episcopal Church since 1976 and in Church of England since 1994, but Roman Catholic Church and Pope have refused to even consider change (S)

headline: Oil Flows From Iraq
abstract: Iraq began pumping oil abroad for the first time in six years, reopening a 616-mile pipeline to terminals on the Turkish coast under a deal with the United Nations. But experts said that it could be weeks before the oil reached delivery points.     Article, page A3.

headline: Palestinians Dismayed, Israelis Delighted
abstract: Palestinian leaders voice dismay at results of Middle East summit meeting in Washington, pronouncing it failure and warning that it leaves their relations with Israel in critical state (M)

headline: COMMERCE SECURITY TO ACQUIRE ELDORADO BANCORP
abstract: Commerce Security Bancorp Inc says it agreed to acquire Eldorado Bancorp for $90 million (S) y

headline: Placer Dome Seeks to Buy 2 Mining Concerns for $600 Million
abstract: Placer Dome Inc, which has already acquired 20 percent of Highlands Gold Ltd, seeks to buy firm; Highland directors reject bid as too low; Placer also seeks to buy 24.6 percent of Placer Pacific Ltd it does not already own; two deals would have total value of about $600 million (US) (M)

headline: 'Charity' That Helps Givers Attracts I.R.S. Auditors
abstract: Internal Revenue Service is examining returns of 120 wealthy people in New York City and Los Angeles to see whether they used charitable trust in abusive way to improperly avoid capital gains tax (M)

headline: Omnicom Forms European Media Unit
abstract: Omnicom Group has joined European media service operations of BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide under umbrella operation named Optimum Media Direction; new unit will help handle media services for accounts of 20 countries with billings estimated at $7.1 billion (S)

headline: Japanese Voters, Too, Get a Big Tax-Cut Promise
abstract: Japanese opposition leader Ichiro Ozawa, trying to win support in Oct 20 general elections, calls for big tax cuts (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: Summary of major news stories on inside pages

headline: A German-Czech Pact on Wartime Abuses
abstract: More than 50 years after end of World War II, Germany will apologize for Hitler's invasion of former Czechoslovakia, and Prague will express regrets for postwar expulsion of millions of Germans; German Foreign Min Klaus Kinkel and Czech counterpart, Josef Zieleniec, reportedly will meet in Prague on December 20 to initial long-negotiated document and end corrosive dispute between two countries; maps (M)

headline: OLSTEN SHARES FALL ON REPORT OF STRONG COMPETITION
abstract: Shares of Olsten Corp fall 27% after company says fourth-quarter profit would be hurt by competition for its staffing and health care business (S)

headline: A special vest can take the place of hand-held pumps for breast-feeding mothers.
abstract: William Palmer gets patent for breast pump in form of adjustable vest that contains microprocessor-controlled vacuum pump; chip allows woman to program pumping to accommodate her body and imitate her baby; milk flows through tube into collection cup for later use; Penny Stillman, Minnesota, gets patent to make feeding baby easier whether bottle is filled with milk, juice or water; patent is for shoulder cloth for holding bottle at an angle for nursing; Sidney and Gayle Steib get patent for invention that insures that every bit of bar of soap is used (M)

headline: New Rivals and Pending Merger Force a Company to Focus on Service
abstract: Nynex Telecommunications, which services New York State and much of New England, faces pressure to improve its services; Federal Communications Commission claims Nynex currently ranks last among seven regional Bell phone companies in terms of customer satisfaction; New York Public Service Commission has imposed $62.3 million in fines on Nynex for missing customer service benchmarks in first year of seven-year regulatory agreement it has with state; experts agree that New York City's five boroughs in particular pose unique set of problems in operating a telephone network; but Nynex chairman Ivan G Seidenberg says company is determined to improve customer service before its planned merger with Bell Atlantic; photo; graphs; chart (M)

headline: Magda Trocme, 94, Is Dead; Sheltered Victims of Nazis
abstract: Magda Trocme, French parson's wife who inspired movement that saved thousand of Jews and others from Nazis in World War II, dies at age 94 (M)

headline: REYNOLDS METALS PLANS TO CUT 1,060 WORKERS
abstract: Reynolds Metals Co will cut 1,060 jobs under plan to increase profits amid slumping aluminum prices; Reynolds will reduce its 30,000-member work force by 3.5 percent through layoffs and attrition (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest for December 28

headline: K-III Appoints Three Publishers
abstract: K-III Consumer Magazines division of K-III Communications Corp names new publishers at three magazines; at Modern Bride, Nina Lawrence succeeds Cara David, who left in June; at Automobile magazine, Doug Fierro succeeds Terry Russell, who left; Fierro has been publisher of another K-III magazine, Chicago, where he is being succeeded by John Carroll (S)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: COOKSON GROUP P.L.C., London, a specialist materials manufacturer, agreed to buy GRP Inc., a U.S.-based unit of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, a French ceramic and glass manufacturer. Terms were not disclosed.     SNYDER OIL CORP., Fort Worth, increased its stake in two Gulf of Mexico oilfields for $35 million. The company now owns a 44 percent interest in the Pabst and Busch fields off the Louisiana coast.     KATZ DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES, a printing and pre-press services company, announced that it had ended talks to buy Boris Image Group Inc., Boston, a provider of large-scale photographic and digital printing services.

headline: Excite's Stock Soars on Deal With America Online
abstract: Excite Inc agrees to make its directory the exclusive tool used to search Internet on America Online Inc; Excite will buy America Online's Webcrawler Internet directory for two million shares, valued at $19.8 million, and replace it by moving its own directory onto No.1 on-line service; Excite's exclusive agreement provides exposure to America Online's seven million customers; in exchange, America Online will sell advertising and get majority of revenue from ads that appear on Excite's service on America Online (M)

headline: Dues Blues: Nonpaying Workers Irk Federal Unions
abstract: About 100 unions represent 1.2 million Federal workers, but they are unlike other unions in any other industry; except for unions that represent postal workers, they cannot negotiate salaries nor can they require dues from workers they represent; of 1.2 million Federal workers, it is estimated that only 25 percent pay dues; unions maintain that if all eligible Government employees paid dues, unions would be able to offer more services and bargaining power (M)

headline: Major, Feeling Political Heat, Plans to Step Up Slaughter of Cows
abstract: British Government cedes to European Union demands and says it will increase number of cattle to be slaughtered in effort to eradicate mad cow disease; there will be selective slaughter up to 100,000 cattle most at risk of contracting disease (M)

headline: Why the Wheels Stopped Turning
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews book No Hands. The Rise and Fall of the Schwinn Bicycle Company, by Judith Crown and Glenn Coleman; jacket cover; book blames arrogance and complacency of younger generation of Schwinn family managers for downfall of quintessential American bicycle maker; Schwinn name was bought by Zell-Chilmark investment group (S)

headline: Japan's Output Drops 1.9 Percent in November
abstract: Ministry of International Trade and Industry reports that Japan's industrial production declined 1.9 percent in November from October, third time in six months that output has fallen; output is expected to rise 0.8 percent in December and 5.1 percent in January before Government imposes 2-percentage-point increase in consumption tax (S)

headline: Tower's Chief Calls His Airline A Valujet Victim
abstract: Tower Air says domestic bookings are down 25 percent since May crash of jet owned by Valujet, rival low-fare airline, and that it expects to lose money this year for first time since 1986; Tower chairman Morris K Nachtomi holds low-cost airlines have been unfairly tainted by Valujet disaster, interview; low-cost airlines are also suffering from narrowing of spread between their unrestricted fares and discount fares offered by larger competitors (M)

headline: Sunset's New Face on the Tried and True
abstract: Sunset, 98-year-old magazine, is undergoing major redesign in attempt to attract younger readers; Rosalie Muller Wright, Sunset's new editor-in-chief, says Sunset's core strength will continue to be service to readers; photos (M)

headline: A Fugitive Lawman Speaks: How Mexico Mixes Narcotics and Politics
abstract: Guillermo Gonzalez Calderoni, former Mexican police commander in exile in Texas, discusses political espionage by Mexico's governing party and corrosive effects of drug profits, interviews; says he told former Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari in 1992 and later told American officials that major Mexican drug trafficker told him of making large cash payments to Salinas's brother, Raul, during his presidency; says Mexico invented charges against him after he began reporting high-level corruption to US aides; photos (M)

headline: Tone Is Edgy as Mideast Economic Conference Opens in Cairo
abstract: Absence of Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and subdued mood among business and political leaders at Arab Economic Summit in Cairo underscores changes in Arab-Israeli relations since last meeting year ago; more 4,000 participants make gathering largest of its kind ever held in Middle East; host, Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, praises those in attendance, but warns opportunities for peace in region are being squandered (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Dip Below 6,000 In Biggest Loss in 7 Weeks  Blue-chip stocks recorded their biggest loss in seven weeks as lower worldwide sales from Procter & Gamble confirmed for some investors that companies would have a hard time matching profit expectations next year. The Dow Jones industrial average declined for a fourth day, losing 43.98, or 0.73 percent, to 5,992.48. Other indexes gave up less ground.    It was the Dow's first close below 6,000 since Oct. 11. The Dow has now fallen more than 140 points from its all-time high of 6,133.70 reached during trading on Monday. $(Page D8.$)     Prices of Treasury securities fell, and the yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.85 percent. $(D15.$)     Boeing Earnings Rise 13 Percent   Boeing reported a 13 percent gain in third-quarter earnings, meeting most analysts' expectations, but its shares fell on concerns about profit margins as the company seeks to bolster production. Boeing reported earnings of $254 million, or 74 cents a share, up from $225 million, or 66 cents a share. Revenue rose 28 percent, to $5.60 billion from $4.38 billion. $(D4.$)     Airlines Report Strong Profit   Delta Air Lines reported a 32 percent earnings gain, in line with other big carriers. $(D5.$)    USAir Ends British Airways Alliance   USAir said it would end its alliance with British Airways in March 1997 because of the carrier's proposed code-sharing deal with American Airlines. $(D4.$)    At Compaq, New Faces Near the Top   Compaq Computer, long known for stability in a volatile industry, announced a series of executive shifts. $(D2.$)    Quaker Oats Profits Rise   Quaker Oats said its profit more than doubled in the third quarter as proceeds from the sale of its frozen-food business offset lower cereal prices and disappointing Snapple sales. $(D2.$)    Investors Can Seek Damages   New rulings in New York State courts appear to allow investors who think they have been robbed by their brokers to seek punitive damages in arbitration, something the industry has bitterly fought. $(D8.$)     Podiatrists to Form Labor Union   A group of podiatrists are forming the first nationwide labor union for doctors. $(A1.$)     Hemophiliacs Accepting Drug Offer   A $640 million offer to hemophiliacs to settle claims that blood-clotting products they used were infected with H.I.V. was accepted by more than 90 percent of those eligible. $(D7.$)    I.M.F. May Suspend Loan to Russia   Worried by Russia's failure to collect taxes, the I.M.F. is expected to suspend further disbursement of a $10 billion loan. $(A6.$)    Huge Oil Windfall  For Venezuela   Venezuela is grappling with an enviable problem: what to do with $2.5 billion in unexpected oil revenue. Oil prices have surged more than 20 percent since July, with much of the increase following the American bombing of Iraq in early September. $(D5.$)    HBO Pictures Names President   John A. Matoian, recently a Fox Entertainment executive, was named president of the H.B.O. Pictures division of Home Box Office. $(D2.$)

headline: Dutch Drug Tolerance Is Under EU Pressure
abstract: BRUSSELS—  The Netherlands is facing mounting pressure to abandon its liberal drug laws, as most of its European Union partners have lined up behind a French-led plan to wage a Europe-wide war against drugs.

headline: Former Oppenheimer Trader Is Censured
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says that Sanjoy Hazarika, former trader at Oppenheimer & Co, has been barred from securities industry for one year for concealing trading losses that cost firm $878,000; he incurred losses trading mortgage-backed bonds for Oppenheimer in late 1994; losses were discovered by another Oppenheimer trader (S)

headline: VIACOM BUYS 50 PERCENT STAKE IN UPN NETWORK
abstract: Viacom Inc says it has exercised its option to buy 50 percent stake in United Paramount Network (UPN) from BHC Communications Inc for $160 million; UPN says its 152 affiliate stations reach 92 percent of United States households, which will give Viacom another outlet for its programs (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY    Johnson & Johnson   Phillips Pet      TUESDAY    Augat    Camco Intl   Cavalier Homes   CMAC Invt   Hawaiian Elec Inds   Salomon Bros Fd   Sigcorp   Weyerhaeuser      WEDNESDAY    Briggs & Stratton   Heilig-Meyers   Pacific Gas & Elec   Sherwin-Williams   Sonoco Prods   V F Corp   Washington Energy      THURSDAY    Arch Danls Mid    Arvin Inds   Black & Decker   Brlngton Nth Sant Fe   Carter Wallace   Coca-Cola   FAC Realty    Firstar Corp   Gillette   Interstate Power   Legg Mason   Oneck   Rohm & Haas   Standard Mtr Prods   Student Ln   Union Planters      FRIDAY    Amcast Indl   Delta & Pine Ld   Lyondell Petrochem   Ntnwde Hlth Pptys

headline: In northern New Jersey, more retirement communities are being built to meet demand.
abstract: Work begins this week in West Caldwell, NJ, to turn 35 acres into retirement community that will provide pople age 62 and older with housing, services and health care; $67 million project, called Crane's Mill, will offer 264 studio to three-bedroom residences as well as 60 nursing beds (M)

headline: BMW Picks Two Publicis Offices
abstract: BMW of North America names New York and Dallas offices of Publicis/Bloom to handle two of four new regional advertising accounts (S)

headline: Fonar Settlement With Siemens
abstract: Fonar Corp reaches settlement with Siemens Medical Systems Inc on patent litigation related to magnetic resonance imaging technology; dollar amounts undisclosed; Fonar says it will receive one-time payment for past royalties and receive future royalties; adds each company will issue licenses to the other allowing use of various components of the technology (S)

headline: After War and Blockade, Crime Frays Life in Iraq
abstract: Iraqi social fabric is severely strained after years of war and international sanctions; wave of killing and theft prompts state-run television to expand 'most wanted' program to help catch criminals; photo; Iraqi Chief Justice Abd al-Majid al-Janabi says most of those convicted are trying to get money for daily needs; he and ordinary Iraqis say killing and robbery soar when currency rate falls, making food more expensive; murder of 72-year-old man by neighbors who needed money for visas cited (M)

headline: A Paper Goes Afar For a Look At Itself
abstract: St Louis Post-Dispatch, facing charges of bias in forthcoming mayoral election between two black candidates, has hired Chuck Stone, black journalism professor, as ombudsman to monitor its election coverage from North Carolina; long distance reader advocacy breaks new ground in history of newspaper ombudsmen; editor Cole C Campbell discusses move, interview; Mayor Freeman Bosley Jr's backers hold paper favors likely challenger, Clarence Harmon Jr; photo (M)

headline: New Urban Art Form, Old Copyright Problem
abstract: Mix tapes are new urban art form, but those making and selling mix tapes rarely pay copyright; they are also called deejay compilations or street tapes, and can be purchased almost anywhere; police in South River, NJ, recently confiscated 12,000 mix tapes and arrested five people on charges related to illegal manufacture and sale of mix tapes; many record companies overlook illegality of mix tapes, considering them good promotion for their artists; photos (M)

headline: Simon DeBartolo Picks Evans Group
abstract: Simon DeBartolo Group Inc has retained Evans Group to handle its advertising account, which has been at that agency for five years; billings are estimated at $25 million (S)

headline: SINTER TO ACQUIRE PRESSED POWDER UNITS
abstract: Sinter Metals Inc agrees to buy Maag Holding AG's Powder Metal Holding Inc for about $215 million (S)

headline: 2 French Rappers Get Jail for Insults to Police
abstract: PARIS—  Two singers from the French rap group NTM received prison sentences, fines and a ban on performing Friday for insulting the police during a concert in the Mediterranean port of Toulon, a stronghold of the far-right National Front.

headline: Kabul's Museum: The Past Ruined by the Present
abstract: Afghanistan's National Museum in Kabul lies in ruins, like country itself, after 18 years of war; war, and looting for illegal sales on international antiquities market, have destroyed museum that was repository of Afghanistan's history and culture, most comprehensive record anywhere of civilizations that thrived along ancient Silk Road that crossed Afghanistan on its way from Europe to China; now, galleries lighted by shafts of daylight penetrating shell holes in roof, are littered with rubble of ancient ceramics, statues and friezes; broken display cabinets stand emptied of of their ivories and paintings and frescoes, and of their kings' treasures of silver and gold; some rooms are filled with bearded young fighters from Taliban religious movement; interview with Najibullah Popal, who served as curator of museum; photo (L)

headline: Renting the Workers, but Buying the Stock
abstract: Investments in stock of temporary-staffing companies discussed; table (S)

headline: Credit Offerings During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and two-  and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.99 percent and the rate on the six-month issue, 5.04 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.66 percent, and the five-year note, 5.95 percent.

headline: Tentative Debt Accord Rescues Eurotunnel
abstract: Eurotunnel, operator of tunnel under English Channel, narrowly avoids bankruptcy with agreement on 'basic principles' of an accord to revamp $12.5 billion in debt (S)

headline: Cathay Pacific and Swissair plan to test an airborne A.T.M. that will exchange currencies.
abstract: Cabins on international flights may soon have inflight ATM-type machines that dispense foreign currencies at exchange rates comparable to those in airports; next spring, Cathay Pacific and Swissair will try out small 150-pound model, developed by Aero-Design Technology and stocked with currencies by yet unnamed banking partner; Europe's expanding network of high-speed trains is making intercity commutes a lot easier for business travelers, particularly with so many flight delays and traffic jams plaguing European cities; two-year Eurostar expresses, heavily used by corporate travelers, have already captured about 40 percent of London-Paris air shuttle market; on new Thalys line to the north, high-speed TGV trains are cutting travel time between Paris and Brussels to two hours from three (L)

headline: Johnson Buys Company
abstract: Johnson & Johnson buys Indigo Medical Inc (S)

headline: Axime Makes Offer For Rival Sligos
abstract: Axime SA offers to buy Sligos SA in friendly takeover valued at $700 million that would create France's biggest computer services company (S)

headline: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES BENEFITS COSTLIER THAN EXPECTED
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is 44 percent owned by Coca-Cola Co, says costs of its employee stock and benefit plan would be $19 million more in its third quarter than in corresponding period year earlier, because of 70 percent rise in its stock price this year (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the releases of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None   TUESDAY   None   WEDNESDAY   Producer Prices Nov.   THURSDAY   Consumer Price Index Nov.  Retail Sales Nov.  Weekly Jobless Claims   FRIDAY   Inventory-Sales Ratio Oct.

headline: A U.S. Split With France Is Seen in Poll On U.N. Chief
abstract: Potential battle between France and US over who will be next Secretary General of UN looms in Security Council after informal voting on new African nominees who entered race since incumbent Boutros Boutros-Ghali recently put candidacy on hold; diplomats speculate that French objections to Kofi Annan of Ghana, who is clear favorite, has less to do with qualifications and more with perception that he is American candidate (M)

headline: WET SEAL OFFERS TO BUY 508 COUNTY SEAT STORES
abstract: County Seat Inc says it received proposal from Wet Seal Inc to buy 508 of its casual clothing stores but that offer is 'grossly inadequate' (S)

headline: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Advanced Radio Telecom Corp., Bellevue, Wa., an initial public offering of 2.75 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: Earnings of BankAmerica Fell By 3% in the Third Quarter
abstract: BankAmerica Corp reports that third-quarter earnings fell 3 percent; net income fell to $683 million from $704 million a year earlier; table (M)è

headline: Weakness Overseas Is Drag on Ford's Results
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports third-quarter profits that barely meet analysts' expectations, while disclosing heavy losses in its European and South American operations and an unexpected drop in profits from car loans and leases; Ford earned $686 million, up from $357 million a year earlier; sales rose 8 percent, to $33.96 billion from $31.42 billion; table (L)

headline: Nazi's Case Forces Italy To Revisit Sore Subject
abstract: Case of Erich Priebke, major participant in Nazi execution of 335 Italian civilians in 1944, reviewed; Priebke tells Italian legislator that his mistake was 'to be the last'; his comments from cell in same Rome prison where he randomly rounded up victims maintain his defense that he merely followed SS orders; Priebke also notes that he lived openly in Argentina for years under his real name with German passport, traveling freely until he was finally extradited; Italian court has nullified military court's finding that statute of limitations has expired, and ordered new trial for war crimes (M)

headline: Film Studio Gets A New President
abstract: Columbia Pictures says it named Amy Pascal, president of production at Turner Pictures, as its new president; she replaces Lisa Henson, who left this fall (S)

headline: U.S. Productivity Declined in 3d Quarter
abstract: Labor Dept reports that productivity fell revised three-tenths of 1 percent in third quarter, first decline since late last year; in separate report, department says first-time jobless claims fell last week by 8,000 to 336,000, in line with expectations (M)

headline: Retail Spending Off a Bit; Price Index Up 0.3%
abstract: Govt reports that shoppers kept wary eye on spending in November as this year's late holiday shopping season got under way; report seems to confirm indications of only modest improvement from last year's poor sales; retail spending, dragged down by weak automotive business, slumped 0.4 per cent in November, as spending on goods other than cars and trucks rose only enough to keep pace with inflation; Labor Dept reports that Consumer Price Index rose only 0.3 per cent for third straight month; chart (M)

headline: ANCHOR GAMING SHARES FALL ON POSSIBLE CHANGE IN PLANS
abstract: Shares of Anchor Gaming fall 22 percent as investors are concerned that company's reconsideration of an addition to a Colorado casino will hurt its earnings; stock falls $8.875 a share, to $30.125 (S)

headline: Poppe Tyson Pulls Stock Offering
abstract: Poppe Tyson unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt postpones initial public offering of stock because of 'unfavorable market conditions' (S)

headline: CHECK POINT SOFTWARE STOCK DECLINES ON NEWS
abstract: Stock of Check Point Software Technologies Ltd falls after company discloses that revenue from Sun Microsystems Inc, big distributor of its software, has fallen in latest quarter; shares of Israeli company fall $4.75, to $25.625; analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, Rakesh Sood, says revenue from Sun fell to $2.7 million in third quarter from $3.8 million in second quarter; separately, company also says it is named in lawsuit by Checkpoint Systems Inc, which contends trademark infringement and unfair competition because of Check Point name; Check Point says it believes charges are without merit (S)

headline: SARA LEE TO BUY BACK UP TO 20 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Sara Lee Corp says it will buy back up to 20 million shares in addition to the 12 million shares remaining from previous buyback programs (S)

headline: The Young and Their Options
abstract: Catherine Cartwright letter on young lawyers and their 100-hour work weeks; says these grueling hours tend to devalue her own work as magazine editor, because she does not want to hand over her life to career

headline: Viacom Termed Close to Deal For Control of USA Network
abstract: Viacom Inc is close to agreement to pay MCA Inc $1.45 billion and exchange its 50 percent interest in Sci-Fi Channel for 50 percent of USA Network it does not already own, executives close to negotiations say; transaction will come as part of settlement of lawsuit filed against Viacom by Seagram Co, which bought MCA last year (M)

headline: Dean Witter To Purchase A Discounter
abstract: Dean Witter, Discover & Co says it has agreed to buy Lombard Institutional Brokerage Inc; terms not disclosed (M)y

headline: Accounts
abstract: Account changes noted (S)

headline: Shares of UAP Surge On News of AXA Merger
abstract: Shares of UAP surge and AXA fall on first day of trading since two French companies agreed to merge; AXA would take over UAP in $9 billion stock swap (S)

headline: F.C.C. APPROVES CABLE DEAL BY U S WEST
abstract: Federal Communications Commission approves U S West Inc's $11.8 billion purchase of Continental Cablevision Inc; gives U S West 10 months to sell all Continental cable systems in its phone service region (S)

headline: Clinton, Golf in Mind, Visits An Understanding Australia
abstract: Pres Clinton begins four-and-half-day Australian trip; receives warm reception; opens friendly round of talks on trade, environment and military cooperation (M)

headline: WABAN PLANS TO SPIN OFF B J's WHOLESALE CLUB
abstract: Waban Inc plans to spin off B J's Wholesale Club, separating the profitable warehouse stores from lagging Home Base home-improvement chain; spinoff to shareholders will create publicly traded company called B J's Wholesale Club Inc; Waban plans to change its name to Home Base Inc (S)

headline: Goldman to Elevate 115, but Not All to Coveted Partnerships
abstract: Jon S Corzine and Henry M Paulson Jr, continuing their make-over of Goldman, Sachs & Co, are expected to name the firm's first managing directors today; while the 115 people who get new title will receive a promotion, only 35 to 40 of them will simultaneously be named Goldman Sachs partners, one of most coveted titles on Wall Street (M)

headline: Tense Zaire Is Primped For Return Of Mobutu
abstract: Zairian Government rushes preparations for return of ailing Pres Mobutu Sese Seko, absent for four months for cancer treatment in Europe; new rebel government has swept much of country's eastern region during absence with virtually no challenge from largely unpaid national army (M)

headline: Seeing Special Needs
abstract: Jeffrey H Minde-L Jerry Cohn letter on special-needs estate planning (S)

headline: Interval Research Is Planning To Spin Off 3 Software Units
abstract: Interval Research Corp, secretive computer organization created four years ago by Microsoft Corp co-founder Paul Allen, plans to announce three spinoffs; start-up companies would be first attempts at market payoff from Allen's $100 million investment in Interval; spinoffs, all of which will be based in Palo Alto, Calif, are Carnelian Inc, an Internet publisher, Ogopogo Studios, designer of role-playing software games for children, and Purple Moon, creator of interactive media programs aimed at girls aged 7 to 12 (L)

headline: Routing Makes Cisco Systems A Powerhouse Of Computing
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc emerges as dominant provider of routers, specialized computers that control movement of data from one network to another, whether within a corporation or across the global Internet; more than 80 percent of routers connected to Internet are Cisco machines; John Chambers, Cisco's president and chief executive, says Cisco means to shape future of network industry by focusing next on Internet-working, providing connections so many computers on multiple networks within an organization can all share files and data (M)

headline: Copper Prices Are Up Sharply As Tight Supply Spurs Buying
abstract: Copper futures prices surge on drop in inventories; copper for Dec delivery rises 2.30 cents, to $1.082 a pound (S)

headline: SHARES OF VANGUARD AIRLINES DROP ON NEWS OF A LOSS
abstract: Stock of Vanguard Airlines Inc declines 41 percent after the low-price carrier says it will post a third-quarter loss and cut services to some cities; attributes loss in part to adverse publicity surrounding crash of TWA Flight 800 in July; also cites other factors (S)

headline: Sierra Health Stock Falls on Acquisition Announcement
abstract: Sierra Health Services Inc says it has agreed to buy Physician Corp of America in all-stock deal valued at $509.4 million; Sierra shares fall $5 and analysts say Sierra will be paying too much for troubled company and that turnaround could take up to two years (M)

headline: Kiwi Declares Bankruptcy and Trims Routes
abstract: Kiwi International Air Lines, low-cost carrier started by former pilots of Eastern Airlines in 1992, files for bankruptcy protection; says it will shrink its route structure to serve three cities--Newark, Atlanta and Chicago, and drop service to Tampa and Orlando, Las Vegas and Bermuda; Kiwi has been plagued with problems since its inception; Jerry Murphy, Kiwi's chief executive, says debt accumulated in its first three years of business proved insurmountable, even though airline posted three recent consecutive quarters of profit (M)

headline: Confidence Is Real Victim of Fire Under the English Channel
abstract: Fire that ripped through freight train in 32-mile Eurotunnel linking Britain and France has badly shaken confidence of European officials who hailed tunnel during opening in '94 as ultimate in technology, comfort and safety; limited freight service has resumed in one of two tunnels undamaged in fire, but Eurotunnel officials remain unable to give date for resumption of even reduced passenger service (M)

headline: HEINZ AND QUESTOR END THEIR TALKS TO BUY BUMBLE BEE
abstract: H J Heinz Co and Questor Partners Fund LP drop talks on buying Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc from Unicord Co (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.00   4.77   5.44        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.08   4.95   4.88        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.05   5.03        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.29   6.28   5.70        30-YR. TREAS. headline: 2 Financiers Cross Swords Over Marvel
abstract: Marvel Entertainment Group, comic book publisher, files for protection in bankruptcy court, victim of overexpansion and of a bitter fight between two Wall Street takeover titans; Marvel says filing is necessary for proposed $525 million plan to bring company back to financial health; Marvel is controlled by Ronald O Perelman; although Perelman owns 80% of Marvel's stock, all those shares are pledged to support loans he took out by issuing junk bonds; most prominent owner of those bonds is Carl C Icahn (M)

headline: Agency Seeks A Role in Texaco Case
abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission asks to be allowed to intervene in discrimination suit settled by Texaco Inc; this raises possibility that agreement may have to be renegotiated; agency officials say they were brought into case long ago, when Federal Judge Charles L Brieant, who is hearing the case, asked for an investigation; that investigation found systemic discrimination at Texaco, but EEOC proposal to conciliate resolution with Texaco met with opposition from company until day after The New York Times disclosed that Texaco executives were recorded planning destruction of documents demanded in lawsuit and denigrating minority groups; immediately after that, Texaco settled the suit; it must still be approved by Federal judge (M)

headline: For the Farming Life Now, Who'll Give Tuppence?
abstract: Mad cow disease takes toll on livestock trade in Bridgewater, England, where farmers find themselves losing money, land and livelihoods; they are victims of dispute between Britain and Europe that they do not comprehend, and they are angry without quite knowing whom to be angry at; are required to destroy large numbers of animals they bred and are barred from exporting them; map; photo (M)

headline: Britain May Forbid Private Ownership Of Most Handguns
abstract: British Government proposes ban on almost all privately owned handguns; action follows outrage over massacre by Thomas Hamilton, who opened fire with four handguns at primary school in Dunblane, Scotland, in March '96, killing 16 students and teacher; seeks ban on all handguns of more than 22 caliber, including high-caliber semiautomatic pistols of kind used in Dunblane; smaller caliber guns, including 22's, would be allowed, but could be used only for competitions and sporting purposes and would have to be kept under lock and key at licensed gun clubs (M)

headline: Amata Kabua, 68, President Of Marshall Islands, Is Dead
abstract: Amata Kabua, first and only President of Marshall Islands since 1979, dies at age 68; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Plans 300% Increase in Spending for Basic Research in 1997
abstract: Microsoft Corp plans to raise spending for basic research by 300 percent in 1997; plans to create world's largest computer science laboratory, spending up to $330 million over next five years; chief technology officer Nathan Myhrvold scores national trend away from research, interview (M)

headline: Russia's Mars Craft Fails and Crashes in Southern Pacific
abstract: Russian Mars space probe that failed to break out of Earth orbit re-enters Earth's atmosphere above southern Pacific Ocean west of South America and apparently crashes into sea; failure, which apparently occurred when booster rocket failed to ignite, deals devastating blow to Russia's shrunken and badly underfinanced space program (M)

headline: Shareholders Press Shoney's On Bias Issue
abstract: Shoney's restaurant chain seeks to exclude from its proxy proposal by some institutional investors that firm account publicly for its efforts to reverse discriminatory employment and purchasing practices; bid tests whether Securities and Exchange Commission retains policy against shareholder resolutions on matters of ordinary business operations (M)

headline: Zaire Rebel Approves Food Drop But Rejects Western Military Role
abstract: Lieut Gen Maurice Baril, Canadian commander of United Nations intervention force for eastern Zaire, meets with Laurant Desire Kabila, rebel commander holding region, and wins tentative approval for airdrop of food to thousands of refugees; Kabila says he will not accept foreign force in rebel-held territory under any circumstances; UN officials have said that military support would be needed to carry out large-scale aid program; map; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Closes Its Investigation of Denver Airport
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says it has closed its two-year investigation into Denver's sale of $3.9 billion in airport bonds without making any charges; at issue was whether Denver officials failed to inform bond investors fully of construction delays at Denver International Airport, which opened 16 months behind schedule and $2 billion over budget; city spent $1.6 million defending itself in SEC inquiry (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Scheduled for the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.96 percent,  and the rate on the six-month issue was at 5.08 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.86 percent, and the five-year note at 6.23 percent.

headline: Reebok is paying $13.5 million for a prime site in Canton, Mass., for a new headquarters.
abstract: Susan Diesenhouse (Real Estate) column on agreement by Reebok International to acquire 42 acres of land in Canton, Mass, for its new headquarters complex that is expected to go into construction in early 1988; says Reebok is buying land for $13.5 million and that first phase of new headquarters will cost about $90 million; since 1989, Reebok has been based in town of Stoughton, about six miles from Canton (M)

headline: Dismissal of Slovak Editor Called Setback for Press Freedom
abstract: Prime Min Vladimir Meciar of Slovakia dismisses Tatiana Repkova as editor in chief and publisher of independent daily newspaper (M)

headline: Kmart Profits Top Estimates As Revenues Decline 1.6%
abstract: Kmart Corp reports its second straight profitable quarter; says net income in third quarter was $9 million, compared with year-earlier loss from continuing operations of $118 million and net loss of $69 million; Kmart's total revenues for latest quarter fell 1.6 percent, to $7.85 billion, while companywide same-store sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent from year earlier (M)

headline: All Walks of Life Protesting in Belgrade
abstract: Anti-Government protestors who swarm to streets of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, on daily basis to protest Government's annulment of results of local elections in which Opposition won come from every walk of life, age group and entire political spectrum; some cite economic reasons, and others political, for joining protests, but almost all say they are motivated by need for shift from dictatorship to democracy; photo (M)

headline: British Prudential Fund to Invest in Troubled U.S. Companies
abstract: Prudential Corp of Britain's PPM America unit is raising $300 million to invest in financially troubled companies (M)

headline: Hogs and Pork Bellies Surge; Corn and Soybeans Decline
abstract: Hogs and pork bellies leap their daily trading limits on Chicago Mercantile Exchange after Agriculture Department says nation's hog and pig herd is smaller than expected; on other markets, corn, soybeans and natural gas prices fall (M)

headline: How the Butterfly Rule Clips Directors' Wings
abstract: Joseph Hinsey 4th Viewpoint column questions merit of corporate governance precept now in vogue that calls for outside directors to offer to resign if they change (or lose) their jobs (M)

headline: Viacom and Hubbard Swap TV Stations
abstract: Viacom Inc's Paramount Stations Group unit and Hubbard Broadcasting Inc conclude deal to swap Paramount's WTOG television station in Tampa, Fla, for two Hubbard stations in upstate New York, WNYT in Albany and WHEC in Rochester; transaction was approved by Federal Communications Commission (S) y

headline: Unification Church Gains Respect in Latin America
abstract: Unification Church has gained new respect in Latin America, where it has established strong foothold, access to rich and powerful and investments in real estate, hotels, banks, newspapers and other businesses valued at hundreds of millions of dollars; church officials say they have three million followers in region; just how far Unification Church has come in Latin America in last 20 years is evident when former Pres George Bush and dozens of current and former heads of state from region attend party in Buenos Aires on Nov 23 to inaugurate Spanish-language newspaper being published by media company with close ties to Rev Sun Myung Moon, church's spiritual leader (M)

headline: Despite Crisis, Fujimori Maintains His Iron Image
abstract: Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru projects an iron will in face of Marxist guerrilla takeover of Japanese Ambassador's residence and shows no signs of abandoning his authoritarian ways; many of his critics fear that his rigidity is jeopardizing lives of hostages, but officials and foreign diplomats believe Fujimori is a sensible leader who will compromise, but only if absolutely necessary; rumors circulate that several unofficial deals are being negotiated to free hostages, including one with Japanese Government; photo (M)

headline: When Your C.D. Is in Francs or Pounds
abstract: Laura Pedersen article answers reader's question on buying certificates of deposit at United States banks denominated in foreign currencies; table (M)

headline: McGraw-Hill to Sell Plant
abstract: McGraw-Hill Companies to sell its William C Brown printing operation in Dubuque, Iowa, to Quebecor of Montreal for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Sydney M. Pozer, Left Behind In 'Great Escape,' Dies at 78
abstract: Sydney M Pozer, Canadian gunner who survived the crash landing of a British bomber in World War II to become one of the prisoners who conspired against their German captors to organize the mass breakout known as the Great Escape, died on Nov 29 at age 78; photo (M)

headline: Monsanto Chooses a Spinoff Of Its Chemical Operations
abstract: Monsanto Co to spinoff its chemicals business to shareholders and cut up to 2,500 jobs, 9 percent of work force; will take after-tax charge of $400 million to $600 million; says Robert G Potter will be chairman and chief executive of chemicals unit; has not decided which firm will keep Monsanto name; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Leaves Its Mark On Politics In Britain
abstract: Campaign for British general election is following many of trends and using many of techniques of United States Presidential race; Conservative Prime Min John Major and Labor Party head Tony Blair are debating many of same issues raised in US; Major is expected to delay vote until May to gain time to overtake Blair, who leads in polls (M)/

headline: Nike Profit Up 81%, Delighting Analysts
abstract: Nike Inc reports net income for second-quarter ended Nov 30 rose 81 percent, to $176.9 million, up from $97.8 million a year ago; table (S)

headline: American Topics : Short Takes
abstract: Karla Chapman, an eighth-grade student in Pikeville, Kentucky, has been suspended from school for wearing black lipstick, which the principal said was a distraction. Karla's parents, Michael and Connie Chapman, protested angrily outside the school, and Michael now faces charges of terroristic threatening and abuse of a teacher, to which he pleaded not guilty. "What would your child's cosmetics have to do with her education?" he asked. Principal Rosa Wolfe said Karla, 13, could return if she gives up the lipstick. Karla says she will do so if the charges against her parents are dropped. There the matter stands.

headline: U.S. ROBOTICS SHOWS A NEW, FASTER MODEM
