headline: DIARY
abstract: THE AIR-BAG DEBATE 1,600 Saved, 51 Dead On the safety front, people tend to fixate on the heart-rending anecdote and ignore the statistic. A plane crashes, and the media go crazy, seeming to forget how vastly safer it is to fly than to drive to the corner for milk. A child dies from a fast-expanding air bag, and people forget the positive. ''What's getting lost,'' one safety advocate said, is that air bags ''have already shown their incredible payoff'' -- an estimated 1,600 lives saved, compared with 51 deaths traced to them. The goal now: save the 1,600 and the 51, too. The Transportation Department weighed in last week, moving to allow drivers to have air bags disconnected and let car makers come up with bags that inflate more slowly. Those both have their own risks, though, so other ideas are emerging, like ''two-speed'' air bags and even ''smart seats'' that sense the size of the passenger. Smart drivers might help, too.   COLD-WAR DEBRIS Plutonium Everywhere The cold war lasted a mere half-century, but its deadly debris will be around for millennia. Perhaps the deadliest is the plutonium from dismantled bombs, and the debate rages about what to do with the nasty stuff. It could be used for nuclear power, of course, but American leaders have long opposed that, fearing loss or theft or deadly mishaps. But now the Administration is on the verge of changing its mind, saying it's the only way to secure Russian cooperation on weapons disposal. The risk is negligible, the Administration says, but critics see a very high risk indeed. And some anti-nuclear activists were outraged, too, that that Mars-bound Russian spacecraft that fell to earth last week was carrying 200 grams of plutonium. There was no risk, officials said, but others asked, how could there not be?   CELEBRITY 'I'm Bob. Fly Me.' After years of toiling in near anonymity in Washington, a fellow named Bob Dole is starting to make a name for himself. He's appeared with David Letterman and on ''Saturday Night Live'' -- clearly, a man to watch. And last week he leapt even closer to the fickle, white-hot light of the big time, making his debut as a celebrity endorser. Under the line ''Not doing anything?'' in an Air France ad, there he is, smiling and waving -- the very image of a man with time on his hands. No, this doesn't mean he's cashing in on his fame as a politician; he's donating his fee to a center for the elderly. But who knows? Maybe soon he'll be enough of a celebrity that he could, say, run for President.  TOYS Mattel? Or Perhaps Mattel? If that toy you just tripped over wasn't made by Mattel, don't worry: it probably will be soon. Mattel, already the world's largest toy maker, agreed last week to buy Tyco, America's No. 3 toy company. But it's no doubt best to put that in terms that children will understand: one company will now turn out Barbie and Cabbage Patch dolls, Matchbox cars and Fisher-Price and Sesame Street products. There will be everything from the literary, like Scrabble, to the less intellectually taxing, like Baby Wiggles 'N Giggles. The giant new Mattel, a rival executive said, will now be able to tell retailers: ''I know this toy isn't selling, but you have to buy it anyway.''   GENERAL MOTORS So Where Are the Cars? Well, consumers seem ready to whirl General Motors back onto the dance floor, but the newer, prettier G.M. suddenly has a headache. After years of watching buyers turn to popular imports, G.M. finally has some models that people want -- like the Pontiac Grand Prix and some new mini-vans. But there is one tiny problem standing between the auto maker and its former glory: it can't build the cars fast enough. So the cruel twist now is that when buyers turn to imports, they might be settling for their second choice. G.M.'s excuse: it wants quality, not speed. But as G.M. goes, so goes the nation. Must be a parallel there. Life is great, and we can't get enough of it? Sounds good.  SAUDI ARABIA A Job? What's a Job? For a while there, it was often a nice soft life in those Arab countries that were drenched in oil money. In Saudi Arabia, say, sitting on a quarter of the world's oil reserves, natives got comfortable Government jobs and other handouts, and Indians or Pakistanis were brought in to do the messier work. But all soft things, alas, must come to an end. The oil's still there; the trouble is that the population's soaring, leaving economic growth in the dust. So this generation of Saudis are waking up to a harsh reality -- they must learn, as one Saudi official put it, ''to lower their noses'' and learn how to get jobs. One aspiring member of the work force referred to one possibility -- becoming a Mercedes salesman -- as a ''second-class job.'' What would he call selling Ford Escorts?  THE TREASURY The Check Is in the Air There's something deeply satisfying about getting a check from the Government, whether a tax refund or whatever, a sense that after all the income tax you feed to the Washington beast, here's a piece of paper showing that -- yes! -- it can flow the other way, too. But the Government, that perennial killjoy, wants to wrest this small pleasure from us. That beast, you see, makes 850 million payments a year. If by check, they cost 42 cents each; if by direct deposit, 2 cents. Small wonder that it's moving to force all recipients to take direct deposit, hoping to wipe out most checks by January 1999. It's a bit tough, though, on those who lack bank accounts. A possible solution is being tried in Texas: plastic cards are being issued to Social Security recipients, who can use them in stores and at A.T.M.'s. But there's a $3 monthly fee, plus any A.T.M. fees -- totaling a lot more than 42 cents.  TOBACCO WARS 'Smokeout' on TV For the annual Great American Smokeout on Thursday, HBO contributed ''Smoke Alarm,'' a half-hour show, mixing interviews and choking cartoon lungs, aimed at getting teen-agers not to smoke. The show featured a spoof of tobacco executives plotting how to hook ''pre-smokers'' (read ''teen-agers'') with cigarettes named for cartoon animals. ''Seinfeld'' also got into the act, as Kramer invited hordes of street smokers into his apartment, but was then horrified at how, within days, this intense exposure disfigured his face and teeth.  NEW YORK SCHOOLS The 42% Education The New York City school system is a big business, with an $8.2 billion annual budget, but it's a business under constant fire for the quality of its education. One question people have been asking for years is how much of that money goes to the system's equivalent of the factory floor: the classroom. And last week Chancellor Rudy Crew gave the answer: 42 percent. If that seems low, though, it is apparently in line with other large urban districts.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wall Street in Cyberspace: Power and Peril on the Net  Despite the millions of dollars that Wall Street spends on computers and high-technology gadgetry, in many ways its business has not changed much since the 18th century. But the Internet, which brings buyers and sellers together, is also bringing profound changes that hold promise -- and peril -- for individual investors and powerful securities firms. $(Page A1.$)    China Bans Some U.S. Goods  China announced a ban on imports of selected goods from the United States, stepping up a trade dispute with the Clinton Administration and sending a blunt signal that it will not easily succumb to threats of sanctions. $(A9.$)    Texaco Reports on Investigation  Outside investigators hired by Texaco have concluded from an analysis of a tape recording that a senior company executive did not use a racial epithet at a 1994 meeting, even though a transcript of the recording, filed in court papers, said he did. $(A1.$)    Whimsical Ads for Net Searcher  As Internet navigators proliferate, they are turning to Madison Avenue to distinguish themselves. The $2 million campaign for Lycos by Mullen Advertising shows users on fanciful searches for information. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D12.$)    Some Web site developers are going to great lengths to try to get their site to appear first on lists compiled by search requests. $(D5.$)     Securities Industry SurveyA survey by the securities industry said 94 percent of investors with a broker were either ''somewhat'' or ''very satisfied'' with their service. But a significant minority of investors criticized industry fraud. $(D2.$)    F.A.A. Chief Sees Improvements  David R. Hinson, who resigned as head of the Federal Aviation Administration, coped with a string of crashes that raised embarrassing questions. But he is unapologetic about his agency's performance. $(A11.$)    Comedy Central's Next Iteration  ''Politically Incorrect,'' a show with Bill Maher, left, was a signature tune for Comedy Central until it was snapped up by ABC. Now the cable network, drawing on the same talent pool of New York comedians, is finding new programming to help keep its edgy image. $(D9.$)    E-Mail Links and Isolates Students  Visitors to colleges might be in for a jolt, as computer networks cinch even tighter the already inward-looking communities. $(A12.$)    Organic Evolution in Cyberspace  Support on the Internet for theories in Michael Rothschild's book ''Bionomics: Economy as Ecosystem,'' has set off a flurry of mutations of his theories. Edward Rothstein: Technology. $(D5.$)    Newspaper Industry Savings  The page these words are printed on cost about a quarter of a cent. A few months ago, the equivalent page cost about a third of a penny. That drop in price has amounted to a torrent of savings for the industry, which raises the question of who will benefit. Iver Peterson: Publishing. $(D9.$)

headline: Under U.S. Pressure, Bosnia Dismisses Official Linked to Iran
abstract: Bosnian Government, bowing to American pressure, dismisses Hasan Cengic, top civilian defense official who allegedly is fervent Muslim nationalist with ties to Iran; decision clears way for delivery of $100 million of American military hardware to Muslim and Bosnian Croat armies, which is part of effort to bring them to equal strength with Bosnian Serbs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: New York City Enters Fray In Rancorous Cable Feud  New York City has thrust itself into the middle of a rancorous dispute between Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch by asking for permission to carry Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on a public-access cable station the city controls. Time Warner immediately rejected the request, raising the prospect of a showdown between City Hall and New York's dominant cable television provider, whose franchise agreement with the city is up for renewal in 1998. City officials said they were supporting Mr. Murdoch's efforts because it would mean jobs for the city. $(Page B1.$)     Little Progress In G.M. Strike  Negotiations between General Motors and the Canadian Automobile Workers union showed little progress after 15,000 assembly workers began walking picket lines. Jane Armstrong, a union spokeswoman, said  negotiators met twice during the day, but were accomplishing very little. ''Talks are continuing, but absolutely no progress,'' she said. $(D2.$)     Markets Pause Before Jobs Data  The stock market's record-setting advance paused, pulling most indexes lower as investors waited to see if today's employment report justifies an optimistic outlook on inflation and interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at new highs on Tuesday and Wednesday, slipped 1.12 points, to 5,932.85. $(D6.$)     The bond market also waited for today's employment data and few investors seemed  willing to make large commitments. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.83 percent, from 6.84 percent on Wednesday. $(D16.$)     Factory Orders Down Sharply   New orders to factories tumbled 1.9 percent in August, the sharpest fall in three and a half years, the Commerce Department said. $(D4.$)    Kohlberg Kravis to Buy Kindercare   Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. agreed to buy Kindercare Learning Centers, the nation's largest child care company, for $467 million, or $20.25 a share. Kohlberg Kravis will also assume $130 million of Kindercare debt. $(D3.$)    Kodak in Talks to Buy Wang Unit   Eastman Kodak is in negotiations to buy Wang's document imaging software business. Analysts said Kodak would pay between $300 and $400 million for the Wang unit. $(D3.$)     Authentic Fitness Takes Charges   Authentic Fitness, owner of the Speedo trademark in North America, said it was abandoning the skiwear business, closing its outlet stores and restating second-  and third-quarter results to add $18.8 million in reserves to cover potential losses. $(D3.$)    U.S. to Rescue Pension Plan   The Government announced a rescue plan for the battered pension fund covering 70,000 unionized workers in the men's suit industry. The plan, the first of its type involving an entire industry, is supported by the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees and by the Clothing Manufacturers Association. $(D6.$)    Ratings Pressure at WCBS   The abrupt dismissal of seven anchors and reporters from WCBS-TV illuminated the intense pressure for ratings among television stations competing in the enormously lucrative local news market. $(B4.$)

headline: When the Best Policy May Be No Policy at All
abstract: Advice on growing range of special-purchase insurance policies offered to individuals; such insurance, as whole, offers consumers little value for their money; table; drawings (M)

headline: SHARES OF CYBERMEDIA RISE 30% IN FIRST TRADING
abstract: Shares of Cybermedia Inc close almost 30 percent above their offering price on Oct 23 in their first day of trading (S)

headline: Calor Reports Offer By Biggest Shareholder
abstract: SHV Holdings NV offers to buy 48.4 percent of Calor Group PLC it does not already own for 245 million pounds ($383 million); Calor directors recommend shareholders accept offer (S)

headline: CERNER STOCK JUMPS AS COMPANY REJECTS BUYOUT OFFERS
abstract: Cerner Corp stock jumps 24 percent on news that firm got and rejected unsolicited buyout offers in recent months (S)Ø

headline: Rose Is Leaving Calvin Klein
abstract: Martin J Rose is leaving Calvin Klein Inc after 17 years as exec vice pres and head of company's in-house agency, CRK Advertising (S)

headline: Visiting Washington, China's Defense Chief Calls for Peace
abstract: China's defense Min Chi Haotian meets with Pres Clinton and Defense Sec William J Perry in Washington; says his country only desires peace and stability; will spend two weeks in US discussing wide range of issues; visit is seen as more than telling indication that Washington and Beijing have repaired much of damage to relationship that marked Clinton's first term (M)

headline: Will Fund Investors Prove to Be Faithful or Fickle?
abstract: Mutual Funds Quarterly Report; photo; graph (M)

headline: Bosnia Serb Leaders Refuse To Join United Government
abstract: Bosnian Serb leaders refuse to take part in a new national government of Bosnia, a position that reflects abiding influence of the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic; national government will have few powers but is considered an essential link between the Serb-ruled half of Bosnia and the half under the Muslim-Croat Federation (M)

headline: Inchcape Testing Unit Sold for $585 Million
abstract: Inchcape PLC sells its industrial testing business to Charterhouse Development Capital Ltd for 380 million pounds (about $585 million US) (S)

headline: Global Pact on Computers May Be Nearing
abstract: Clinton Administration aides expect meetings of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and of World Trade Organization trade representatives to set stage for global accord abolishing tariffs on computer and software products; some experts see accord as key to breaking three-year logjam on multilateral trade agreements (M)

headline: Kidnapping Is Snagging Guatemalan Peace Talks
abstract: Peace talks aimed at ending Guatemala's 35-year-old civil war--expected to culminate in signing of final agreement in December '96--have hit unexpected snag as result of admission by leftist guerrillas that top commander, Rafael Valdizon Nunez, carried out recent kidnapping of handicapped, elderly woman, who is matriarch of prominent family; involvement of Nunez has generated public outcry that has led Government to suspend negotiations indefinitely (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Classic Sports Network, New York, cable television network account goes to McCabe & Co, New York; account had been handled in-house; billings are estimated at $5 million to $10 million; listing of other account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: STOCK OF THE GENSYM COMPANY FALLS SHARPLY
abstract: Stock of Gensym Corp plunges more than 40 percent after company says it expects third-quarter earnings to fall below Wall Street forecasts (S)

headline: Channel Tunnel, Hit by Fire, May Stay Closed for a Week
abstract: English Channel tunnel may remain closed for week following fire aboard freight train (S)

headline: Insurers Returning To Poor City Areas
abstract: Insurance companies, which virtually wrote off the inner city in favor of the suburbs and wealthy pockets of cities, are now rediscovering poor and working-class urban neighborhoods.    Insurers like State Farm and Allstate have opened offices in the urban core, and some are doing a brisk business writing policies.

headline: California Journal: A Name to Reckon With
abstract: Sacramento, Calif, court on Sept 27 restrained Wall Street Journal from using title California Journal, part of main newspaper, because name is used by Thomas R Hoeber, publisher and co-founder of California Journal, a Sacramento monthly magazine devoted to politics and public affairs; Wall Street Journal published anyway on Oct 2, reasoning that its California Journal was part of main newspaper and not a free-standing section; last week the local California court tightened restrictions by forbidding Wall Street Journal to use title in any part of its paper until issue has been settled in a trial; ruling threw temporary wrench in Wall Street Journal's plans to extend its regional marketing strategy, built around weekly state sections; on Oct 15, Third District Court of Appeals refused to overturn Judge Earl Warren Jr's order; Journal says it will publish section under name 'California' and appeal case to California Supreme Court (L)

headline: Chrysler Sets Sales Pace While G.M. Lags
abstract: Chrysler Corp reports sales of its cars and trucks rose 22 percent in September, while sales at General Motors fell 2.1 percent from period year ago; among 10 auto makers reporting September results, sales rose an average 4.9 percent over period year ago; Robert J Eaton, chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, comments (M)

headline: Tensions Rise in Rwanda as Refugees Seek to Reclaim Homes
abstract: Tensions rise between Hutu refugees returning to Rwanda from Zaire and seeking to recflaim old homes, and Tutsis who currently occupy them; compounding tensions is strong suspicion that among hordes of returning Hutu are thousands of killers who took part in 1994 massacres and who conducted terror campaigns against Tutsi in Zaire; maps (M)

headline: Indonesia to Contest Auto Trade Complaints
abstract: Indonesia says it will defend its national car policy against complaints to be filed with World Trade Organization by both Japan and United States, and possibly European Union; Indonesian policy exempts company controlled by Pres Suharto's son from taxes and tariffs that other auto producers must pay (S)

headline: Tokyo Stocks Off Sharply
abstract: Stocks prices declined on Tokyo Stock Exchange on December 24; Nikkei average lost 528.75 points, to close at 19,161.71 (S)

headline: Luxury-Brand Connoisseur Behind a Bid for DFS Group
abstract: Analysts say current attempts of LVMH Moet Hennessey-Louis Vuitton of France to buy DFS Group Ltd for $2.47 billion is prompted by LVMH's desire to find more storefronts to sell and promote its luxury-brand products; deal is being contested by Robert W Miller, who holds 38.75 percent stake in DFS (M)

headline: A BRITISH COMPANY WEIGHS BUYING MCI IN $22 BILLION DEAL
abstract: British Telecommunications could announce as early as tomorrow that it has agreed to buy MCI, nation's second-largest long distance company, in deal worth more than $22 bilion; it would be most dramatic foray ever by foreign company into American telecommunications business; if acquisition is approved by boards of both companies, it would be first time a foreign company has taken control of major American telephone company; it would be largest foreign takeover of any United States corporation; charts (L)

headline: Delivery Isn't Guaranteed, but Stamps Are Turning Profits
abstract: Advice on collecting and investing in stamps; stamps are risky investments but collectors recently have seen steadily rising prices; Wade Saadi comments on six-figure profit when he sold collection of rare 1869 American stamps; photo; graph of prices (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HUGHES NETWORK SYSTEMS INC., a unit of General Motors Corp., has received a six-year contract to supply up to $1 billion of wireless equipment to Nextwave Telecom Inc.'s personal communication network.     UNITED ASSET MANAGEMENT CORP., Boston, agreed to acquire J. R. Senecal & Associates Investment Counsel Inc. of Richmond Hill, Ontario, an institutional investment management firm, for undisclosed terms.     HEALTHSOUTH CORP., Birmingham, Ala., a provider of rehabilitation and outpatient surgery services, expanded into its 50th state with the purchase of an outpatient surgery center in Grand Forks, N.D.

headline: Swiss Bank Reports Gain in 9-Month Profit
abstract: Union Bank of Switzerland says its operating earnings for first nine months of 1996 exceeded last year's profits, but third-quarter earnings were below those in previous quarters (S)

headline: Consumer Borrowing Pace Declined During September
abstract: Federal Reserve report shows that for first time in more than three years, borrowers in September paid off more credit card and other nonmortgage debt than they newly borrowed and installment loans declined 2.7 percent at an annual rate; report helps explain why household spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, slowed, braking economy's growth sharply this summer; economists expect consumers to reopen their pocketbooks during holiday shopping season; graph (M)

headline: 20 More Hostages Released By Group of Rebels in Peru
abstract: Tupac Amaru rebels release Dominican Republic Amb Jose Diaz Valdepares and Malaysia Amb Ahmad Mokhtar and 18 other hostages after Peruvian Education Min Domingo Palermo enters residence of Japanese Ambassador in what appears to be first direct contact between rebels and Government; say release of 20 of remaining 103 hostages is 'gesture of good will'; it is largest hostage release since rebels freed 225 people on Dec 22; photo (M)

headline: BASF to Sell Tape Unit To Kohap of Korea
abstract: BASF AG signs agreement to sell its 1.2 billion mark ($795 million) magnetic tape business to South Korean textile maker Kohap Ltd instead of Raks Electronics of Turkey; details undisclosed (S)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.16   5.74        3-MO. headline: THIRD-QUARTER REVENUE EXPECTED TO BE UNCHANGED
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co says that it expects its third-quarter revenue to be unchanged from year ago because of weak North American new-car sales (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Existing-Home Sales Nov.  Leading Indicators Nov.   TUESDAY   New-Home Sales Nov.  Prices of New Homes Nov.  Consumer Confidence Dec.   WEDNESDAY   None   THURSDAY   Weekly Jobless Claims   FRIDAY   Construction Spending Nov.

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK TO ACQUIRE WELLS FARGO BOND BUSINESS
abstract: Bank of New York Co and its BNY Western Trust Co affiliate to acquire corporate and municipal bond administration business of Wells Fargo & Co (S)

headline: A Tutorial for Young Saudis On Ways to Toil for Money
abstract: Young Saudis born during oil boom of 1970's and reared in world of nearly unrivaled wealth are coming of age in time of diminished oil revenues, and are steeling themselves for lifetime of once unexpected work; burning question is how they will confront present less flush than past; for Saudi monarchy and its Western allies, most pressing concern is that increasing complexity, and dashed expectations it will inevitably engender, may breed resentment like that already being expressed by country's religious militants; population, both native and foreign-born, is growing faster than economy, resulting in shortage of especially desirable jobs in Government ministries that Saudis have been willing to accept; after more than two decades of hiring out, and with half of Saudi citizens under age of 16, country faces challenge of finding way to take back jobs that have long been disdained; chart; graph (M)

headline: Compaq Computer's Net Income Rises by 43%, But Stock Dips
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp reports strong gains in revenues, earnings and profit margins, which it attributes to successful new products, cost-cutting efforts and an increase in its share of personal computer market; for third quarter, Compaq reports earnings of $350 million, a 43 percent gain from $245 million in comparable period last year; revenues grew 25 percent, to $4.5 billion, compared with $3.6 billion reported in third quarter of 1995; table (L)

headline: Peronists Shun a Rally Honoring Their Founder
abstract: Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires, where masses of Argentines have gathered in past to honor Juan de Peron, is empty of Peronists on anniversary of night in 1945 when Government freed popular young colonel; photo; few Peronists are in mood to cheer at time of record unemployment, when their leader, Pres Carlos Saul Menem, has erased decades-old laws guaranteeing jobs (S)

headline: The Sober Man in the Gray Suit
abstract: John Birt, director general of British Broadcasting Corp, has made BBC a more efficient noncommercial broadcaster, but has alienated many employees in the process; his rescue plan has been similar to that adopted by some American networks, including the dismissal of thousands of staff members; Birt sees his primary task as that of turning BBC into efficient noncommercial domestic broadcaster capable of withstanding competition from private British terrestrial channels and satellite-delivered programs; photo; graphs (L)

headline: Boston Beer: The Sad Fall Of an I.P.O. Open to All
abstract: Profile of Boston Beer, maker of Samuel Adams beer, which went public year ago; founder, C James Koch, offered buyers one unit of 33 shares for $495, or $15 a share, in effort to give small investors chance to participate in the offering; share price went to $30 after Boston Beer went public but dropped to $11.75 last Friday; even at $15 a share, stock was priced at more than 50 times earnings and company is facing increased competition from specialty beer makers and big brewers; photo; stock price graph (M)

headline: With Goats and Gunfire, Pakistanis Cheer Bhutto's Fall
abstract: Much of Pakistan celebrates dismissal of Prime Min Benazir Bhutto and dissolution of her Government; she remains under house arrest; husband, Asif Ali Zardari, is arrested in Lahore; Presidential proclamation accuses Bhutto and ministers of long list of abuses, some of which seem potential grounds for prosecution; cites, among others, failure of Government to halt killings of political opponents in Karachi, country's largest city; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft has failed to apply its own success formula to interactive media.
abstract: Technology column on recent personnel changes within Microsoft Corp that highlight strategic importance company is now placing on interactive media market; industry watchers estimate Microsoft's media investments are now between $800 million and $1.5 billion, embracing everything from giant reference works on CD-ROM to television's MSNBC cable channel; company has settled more than 2,000 workers in new campus in Redmond, Wash, for its interactive media division; drawing (M)

headline: Q & A / General Khin Nyunt : Burma:An Inside View Of the Military's Control
abstract: For two decades Burma was shut off from the rest of the world under the military dictatorship of General Ne Win. In 1988, after he announced his retirement, the doors burst open and riots raged throughout the country. Within months, the military quelled the protests by forming the State Law and Order Restoration Council. In 1990, the council, under Lieutenant General Khin Nyunt, allowed elections, resulting in an overwhelming majority for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her National League for Democracy. Six years later, Burma is still under military rule, languishing in poverty and accused of numerous abuses of human rights. In Rangoon, General Khin Nyunt was interviewed by Barbara Victor, an author and journalist.

headline: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES ENDS NORA BEVERAGES BID
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc says it is unable to complete purchase of Nora Beverages because its $117 million offer has not gained support of all of Nora's shareholders (S)

headline: Sale of Truck Stake Aids Profit at Investor A.B.
abstract: Investor AB says its nine-month pretax profit more than quintupled, to $1.76 billion, after it sold half of truck and bus maker Scania AB (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of business events for week ending Oct 27; graphs; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Paris Blames U.S. Position For Setback Over NATO
abstract: France's Defense Minister, Charles Millon, says French re-entry into NATO's military command is set back by US refusal to consider putting a European officer in charge of the alliance's southern command, which is based in Naples and includes the US Sixth Fleet; Defense Sec William J Perry has said it is essential to maintain current arrangement (M)

headline: Pfizer Posts 22.7% Rise In Earnings In Quarter
abstract: Pfizer Inc reports third-quarter earnings of $514 million, up 22.7 percent from $425 million in period year earlier (M)

headline: In Modern War, Emblem Is No Shield
abstract: Murder of International Red Cross Committee workers in Chechnya calls attention to new risks faced by Red Cross in ethnic conflicts; 18 Red Cross workers have been killed in six years since end of cold war, compared with 15 killed between 1942 and 1990; director general Peter Fuchs notes no one is in control in conflicts that often involve many warring factions and many of armed groups lack understanding of group's historical neutrality (M)

headline: Sears's Earnings Rise 22% On Strong Sales in 3 Areas
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co says third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent; net income was $279 million, up from $228 million in third quarter last year; revenue rose 7.5 percent, to $9.07 billion, from $8.44 billion in third quarter of last year; table (M)

headline: With Surprising Cooperation, New Russian Budget Is Approved
abstract: Russia's Communist-dominated Parliament and Pres Boris N Yeltsin's Government, in unusual display of cooperation, have worked together to adopt budget for 1997; 530-trillion-ruble budget (about $96 billion) is approved by Parliament by vote of 243 to 117 on Dec 28 (M)

headline: Aetna to Cut 4,400 More Jobs As It Shifts to Managed Care
abstract: Aetna Inc, in one of largest job cutbacks in health care and insurance industries, says that it will reduce its work force by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent of its 33,700 employees; says it will lay off 8,200, but some of those people will be retrained for 3,800 new positions that it will create; decision brings number of overall layoffs planned by Aetna this year to over 10,800; about 1,000 jobs will be cut in Connecticut; Aetna's downsizing reflects company's struggle to transform itself from provider of traditional insurance and financial services into leader in managed health care; Aetna announced in April that it would spend $8.18 billion to acquire US Healthcare (M)

headline: NORTHWEST AIRLINES TO BUY BACK UP TO 5 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp board approves repurchase of up to five million common shares (S)

headline: Investor Guilty In Fraud Case
abstract: Wayne T Drinkwine, principal owner of Mutual Financial Services Inc, pleads guilty to charges that he plotted to defraud group of teachers of more than $500,000 in retirement savings; he admits that instead of investing funds, he diverted them to his personal accounts and lied under oath to Securities and Exchange Commission (S)

headline: 8 High Ex-U.S. Aides Ask Netanyahu to Shun Pre-emptive Acts
abstract: Eight former high-ranking American officials, concerned that Israeli Government's settlement policies are harming chances for peace in Middle East, write to Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu urging him not to take unilateral actions that would preclude meaningful settlement and comprehensive and lasting peace; identified as Zbigniew Brzezinski, James A Baker 3d, Cyrus R Vance, Lawrence S Eagleburger, Frank C Carlucci, Brent Scowcroft, Robert S Strauss and Richard Fairbanks; photo (M)

headline: Texas Sues To Halt Move By Blue Cross
abstract: Atty Gen Dan Morales of Texas files suit seeking to block merger of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois; suit contends that Texas Blue Cross, a nonprofit corporation, is charitable asset that cannot be removed from the state; Illinois Blue Cross says it is a nonprofit mutual insurance company, which means it is owned by its policyholders, but Morales maintains that it is a for-profit entity as defined by Texas law; merger is subject to approval of insurance regulators in two states (M)

headline: USG OFFERS $50 MILLION FOR REST OF CGC
abstract: USG Corp to offer $66 million (Canadian) (US $50 million) to acquire 24 percent of CGC Inc it does not already own (S)

headline: Rio Pursues Olympic Bid With Charm
abstract: Rain dampens Rio de Janeiro's welcome for International Olympic Committee members rating possible sites for 2004 Olympics; city's problems spur skepticism about bid (M)

headline: Cutbacks at Lehman
abstract: Lehman Brothers Inc is shutting its precious metals trading business, dismissing eight people; lays off three workers from its natural gas derivatives team (S)

headline: Scandal Spurs Bell Atlantic Shift in Mexico
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp, yielding to Mexican Government pressure, to assume management control of Grupo Iusacell SA de CV; will remove Carlos Peralta Quintero from day-to-day operations because of scandal involving his $50 million payment to Raul Salinas de Gortari, jailed brother of former President; Peralta will remain on board, but be replaced as vice chairman by Bell aide Lawrence T Babbio Jr; Bell, through stock swap, will acquire majority of voting shares and take majority of board seats; Peralta family will continue to own 48 percent and Bell Atlantic 42 percent of firm (M)

headline: Rates Increased 5.9% by AT&T, Its Biggest Rise in Nearly 3 Years
abstract: AT&T Corp to raise long-distance phone rates by 5.9 percent, its largest across-the-board hike in nearly three years; sets 5 percent hike for calling card calls and 2.6 percent rise for operated-assisted calls; rise will not affect customers enrolled in One Rate calling plan or rates for overseas calls; consumer advocates score move; graph (M)

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Gets $28 Million Billings
abstract: Two offices in Latin American network of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide have been awarded accounts with combined billings estimated at $28 million, from Toyota Argentina SA and Carvejaria Brahma (S)

headline: On Ukraine's Capitalist Path, Clique Mans Roadblocks
abstract: Ukraine's new ruling elite, led by Pres Leonid Kuchma and Prime Min Pavlo Lazarenko, are all former Soviet-era officials from Dnepropetrovsk; once-closed industrial center, where nuclear missiles were made, is now beneficiary of economic spoils, including completion of subway project; photo; map; Ukraine has also become third largest recipient of American foreign aid, and US delegation recently warned of concern that corruption connected to Dnepropetrovsk clan is impeding country's slow transition to market economy; former Deputy Asst Sec Sherman Garnett describes clan influence as 'bloodsucking,' choking off benefits to ordinary people (S)

headline: CONRAIL ACCEPTS $8.4 BILLION OFFER BY EASTERN RIVAL
abstract: Conrail Inc, freight railroad that dominates Northeast, will be acquired by CSX Corp in $8.4 billion deal, biggest in industry since deregulation in 1980's; merger would leave most of nation east of Mississippi with only two large railroads that carry freight; combined company would have more than 50,000 employees and revenues of $14 billion; both have routes extending nearly 30,000 miles, with approximately 54,000 miles of track; only major rival would be Norfolk Southern Corp, which has expressed interest in merging with Conrail and could try to top CSX's bid; map; chart (M)

headline: Bell-Casting Is Booming As a Craft In Europe
abstract: Manuel Quintana is owner of company that makes church bells in Saldana, Spain; his company and other major European bell foundries are backlogged with orders, because they are world's principal suppliers of Western church bells and carillons; by contrast, bell-making in US has virtually disappeared (M)

headline: More Flagstar Work For Foote, Cone
abstract: Flagstar Companies says it has expanded its relationship with Santa Ana, Calif, office of Foote, Cone & Belding by naming agency to handle advertising for Coco's Bakery Restaurants chain; account, with billings estimated at $10 million, had been at Evans, Hardy & Young Inc, for eight years (S)

headline: I.B.M. Allots $3.5 Billion More to Buy Back Stock
abstract: International Business Machines Corp, which has already spent nearly $10 billion since Jan 1995 buying back its stock, authorizes added $3.5 billion buyback; graph (M)

headline: Norway's Third-Largest Conglomerate Formed
abstract: Aker ASA and Resource Group International to merge, forming the third-largest industrial company in Norway, with $3 billion in annual sales (S)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: INVESTCORP, Bahrain, an investment company, has sold 26 percent, or 7.25 million shares, of Prime Service Inc. , a rental equipment company, Houston, at $23.50 a share in an initial public offering.    TAMOR PLASTICS CORP., Leominster, Mass., a privately held manufacturer of plastic home and office organization products, has been sold to Selfix Inc. of Chicago, for undisclosed terms.    ALLIED SIGNAL CORP., Morristown, N.J., a specialty chemical maker, formed a joint venture with Knorr-Bremse A.G. of Munich, Germany, and Fenghua Automotive Air Compressor Factor of China, to make and sell air brake compressors and related products in China.

headline: HORIZON/CMS TO SELL 15 REHABILITATION CENTERS
abstract: Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corp says it has agreed to sell its interest in 15 rehabilitation centers in California to Regency Health Services Inc for $42.3 million (S)

headline: Will U.S. Accounting Rules Be Irrelevant?
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission will allow foreign companies to sell securities in US if their accounting conforms to international rules, whether or not it meets generally accepted accounting principles now required in US; if that happens, American companies will think it unfair to force them to comply with more stringent rules; graph (M)

headline: Editor in Chief to Leave Buzz Magazine
abstract: Allan Mayer, editor in chief of Buzz, a Los Angeles city magazine, says he will leave at end of month because of disputes with parent company, Buzz Inc (S)

headline: Some Changes In Stock Rules To Be Delayed
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission agrees to delay for few months some parts of new order-handling rules aimed at revamping Nasdaq stock market to make it easier for investors to get better prices on trades; does not change any major parts of rules (M)

headline: A Nation Ponders Its Growing Digital Divide
abstract: Eight-member board of Federal regulators and state officials will issue recommendations in November on how to give libraries and elementary and secondary schools access to modern telecommunications services at discount prices, as mandated in amendment to Telecommunications Act of 1996; Pres Clinton has called on board to give every school and library basic Internet service for free; Reed E Hundt, Federal Communications Commission chairman and member of special board, is leading proponent of generous support for schools and libraries; but other members of board say their role is to devise plan of balanced economic regulation rather than to champion social change, which could be quite costly; photo (M)

headline: Montgomery Ward Selects New Leader; Creditors Wary
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp names Roger Goddu as chairman and chief executive of its retail operations; he replaces Bernard F Brennan, who will remain chairman of holding company; company's earnings declined 91 percent in 1995 from previous year, and in latest quarter, which ended in September, company lost $38 million on revenues of $1.5 billion; company has continued to focus on durable goods at time when consumers have shifted their focus to apparel; also, company is saddled with many locations in poorly performing malls; creditors say they are eager to see what Goddu could do to change merchandise mix at Wards (M)

headline: United Overseas Bank Merges Malaysian Units
abstract: United Overseas Bank Ltd of Singapore says it will merge its two subsidiaries in Malaysia to create Malaysia's 11th-largest bank, with assets of $4.1 billion and combined network of 25 branches (S)

headline: U.S. Approved Equipment Sale to China Despite Hint of Misuse
abstract: GAO inquiry finds that Commerce Department approved sale of American machine equipment to China in 1994 despite advance warning that it might be used for military purposes; China did divert sensitive equipment, for civilian aircraft production, to military factory in 1995; report also questions whether McDonnell Douglas Corp failed to inform department fully about sale; Federal grand jury is now investigating; China is making increasingly loud demands for technology in return for billions of dollars in commercial contracts (S)

headline: The Bonus Isn't Reserved for Big Shots Anymore
abstract: Large companies are increasingly offering bonus plans for hourly workers; over a third of hourly workers will get some bonus pay in 1997, sometimes disguised as incentive or variable play; graph (M)

headline: Lagardere Shares Surge On Thomson Purchase
abstract: Shares in Lagardere Groupe surge to six-year high after French Government approves Lagardere's bid to acquire Thomson SA (S)

headline: U. S. BANCORP TO BUY CALIFORNIA BANK FOR $35 MILLION
abstract: US Bancorp agrees to buy Business and Professional Bank for $35 million in cash as bank continues to expand in California (S)

headline: U.S. Agrees With Norway To Aid Russia In Atom Plan
abstract: US and Norway agree to provide technical aid and financing to help Russia dispose of nuclear submarine reactors and other radioactive waste that was dumped into Barents and Kara Seas by Soviet Union (M)

headline: N.T.T. Agrees to Split Into 3 Separate Units
abstract: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp, world's largest telephone company, will be broken into three separate units under plan that would redraw future of telecommunications in Japan; NTT will split itself into long-distance service provider and two regional companies handling local service; all three companies to be owned by holding company; this compromise resolves dispute nearly 15 years old between NTT and Japanese Government (M)

headline: Deals Looming To Establish U.S. Ventures In Cash Cards
abstract: Three groups of banks and credit card companies are racing to complete deals in next few weeks involving so-called smart cards--cards embedded with microchips that can store electronic cash and other data; next week, Mastercard International is expected to invest about $160 million to buy 51% interest in Mondex, electronic cash system developed in Britain; in another deal, group of banks including First Union Corp and Bank of America is negotiating with Visa International Inc to establish rival American smart card system; American Express is negotiating joint venture with Proton, electronic cash system in Belgium; some prospective deals noted (M)

headline: Why Silence Isn't Golden During Your Evaluation
abstract: Advice to employees on handling annual performance appraisal; consultants warn against passivity, urging involvement in planning and evaluation as career booster (S)

headline: Pope Bolsters Church's Support For Scientific View of Evolution
abstract: Pope John Paul II, nearly century and half after Darwin's Origin of Species, has put teaching authority of Roman Catholic Church firmly behind view that human body may not have been immediate creation of God, but is product of gradual process of evolution; Pope, in formal statement sent to Pontifical Academy of Sciences, says 'fresh knowledge leads to recognition of the theory of evolution as more than just a hypothesis'; church has never formally condemned theory of evolution, but its strongest statement of concern came in encyclical letter issued by Pope Pius XII in 1950 (M)

headline: Two inventors contend that the V-chip is an idea they've seen before -- in their own patent.
abstract: Brett West and John P Gardner received patent that they believe might entitle them to royalty on virtually every V-chip installed in a television set; their patent describes technology similar to V-chip system mandated in Feb 8 telecommunications law; but one communications expert has identified 23 television filtering products already on market; Kimeragen Inc receives patent for chimeric molecules that it hopes will be powerful new form of gene therapy, to repair gene damage or to deactivate malfunctioning gene altogether; Jeffrey A Chapman receives patent for 'carvable artificial pumpkin' made from acrylic-coated polyurethane foam (M)

headline: LITTON TO BUY ELECTRONICS BUSINESSES FROM RACAL
abstract: Litton Industries says it will buy Racal Electronics PLC's marine electronics businesses for $49 million in cash (S)

headline: Genentech Chooses A New Chairman
abstract: Genentech Inc names J Richard Munro, former head of Time Warner, to become chairman, succeeding Robert Swanson, a co-founder (S)

headline: Municipal Bond Dealers Face Scrutiny
abstract: Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority, in detailed report for Internal Revenue Service, contends that Wall Street firms frequently charge artifically high and potentially illegal prices for municipal securities that are sold to local governments; experts in municipal finance say extra markups in special municipal escrow accounts accounted for half or more of firms' profits in municipal bond market in early 1990's; transportation authority is invoking Justice Department's powers under False Claims Act and enforcement powers of Securities and Exchange Commission; authority also charges markups have come at expense of Treasury Department and municipal borrowers; Public Securities Association, in letter to Internal Revenue Service, defends Wall Street's pricing practices for selling securities to municipal escrow accounts (M)

headline: One Airline's Shift to a One-Maker Fleet
abstract: News analysis of American Airlines' deal with Boeing Co, in which American will buy 103 jets and perhaps hundreds more over next 20 years as carrier moves toward all-Boeing fleet; chart; photo (M)

headline: Potential for 400 Jets And $18 Billion Sale : Airbus Gets Huge Order From USAir
abstract: PARIS—  USAir Group Inc. said Wednesday it planned to buy up to 400 narrow-bodied aircraft from Airbus Industrie in what could be the European consortium's biggest sale.

headline: Behind Japan's Furor Over Tiny Isles, Gangland Fingerprints
abstract: Interview with Toyohisa Etoh, head of mob-affiliated rightist organization in Japan that has built lighthouse on remote cluster of uninhabited Diaoyu Islands, claiming them for Japan and setting off major dispute with China and Taiwan (M)

headline: Ups and Downs? All an Illusion
abstract: Photo of painting by master trompe l'oeil artist Otis Kaye, which depicts stock market's ups and downs between 1929 and 1937 and which recently sold at Sotheby's for record $442,500

headline: BANYAN SYSTEMS TO SCALE BACK AND SEEK NEW EXECUTIVE
abstract: Banyan Systems Inc says it will cut 100 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, close some units and seek chief executive to replace its chairman and chief executive, David C Mohoney, who is now vice chairman; Jeffrey D Glidden is named acting president and chief operating officer in place of Mohoney (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Jose Manuel Cubas, president and chief executive at Foote, Cone & Belding Latin America, Miami, a unit of True North Communications, was promoted to the new post of chairman. Scott Hollingsworth, senior vice president for the Andean Pact markets and Puerto Rico, was promoted to succeed Mr. Cubas.  * Deborah Zdobinski was named vice president and corporate communications director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, a unit of MacManus Group. She assumes responsibilities from Bill Haney, senior vice president and corporate communications director, who was promoted to executive vice president and executive director for corporate and public affairs at MacManus Group. Ms. Zdobinski had held similar posts at DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Stocks Slip in Japan
abstract: Nikkei stock index closes down 78.66 points to 21,003.49 on Oct 24 (S)

headline: Cease-Fire At Last in GM's Duel With VW?
abstract: FRANKFURT—  After more than three years of legal and public-relations clashes between two of the world's leading automakers, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the embattled production chief of Volkswagen AG, will resign Friday, company sources told German media Thursday.

headline: Loewen's Board Rejects a Hostile Offer as Stingy
abstract: Loewen Group Inc's board unanimously dismisses hostile $3.2 billion offer from Service Corporation International (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Nextwave Telecom Inc says it will buy $200 million in wireless telephone equipment from Lucent Technologies Inc (S)

headline: KMART SHARES RISE 17% ON RUMOR OF A TAKEOVER
abstract: Kmart Corp stock surges 17 percent in heavy trading, partly on rumor that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co weighs bid (S)

headline: Stocks Climb in Japan
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stocks rises 327.01 points, to 20,603.71 (Mon, 12/9) (S)

headline: VW Official Is Expected To Resign
abstract: Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua is expected to resign as Volkswagen Ag president after three years of fighting charges he stole secret documents when he left as General Motors Corp purchasing director; GM's Opel division says it will continue to seek financial compensation from Volkswagen (M)

headline: Selling Shares, Russian Gas Monopoly Generates Its Own Fuel
abstract: Gazprom, Russia's natural gas company, has one-third of world's proven gas reserves, and unrivaled influence in Russia; it is one of few Russian companies able to entice Westerners to buy its shares, given unstable political and economic situation in country; it has connections at highest levels of Government; it has secured investment capital from abroad on large scale as $229 million in stock was offered, slightly more than 1 percent of its total shares; ultimate goal is to sell 9 percent of company's stock to foreign investors; American investment banker says enthusiastic response to Gazprom's stock offering indicates that marketplace is beginning to accept Russia as serious place to invest its money and has put aside criticism of instability in government, lack of proper laws and crime (M)

headline: Single-Family Homes in a Mix, All Maintenance-Free
abstract: Sterling Woods condominium project in Danbury, Conn, is being revived after being stalled by savings and loan debacle and by real estate recession that shut down construction and sales in 1990 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: IMC Mortgage Inc, Tampa, Fla, to buy Mortgage America Inc, Bay City, Mich, for an initial payment of about $26.6 million in stock; Service International, Lufkin, Tex, says it will sell its 41.6 percent stake in Equity Corp International; Reynolds Metals Co, Richmond, to sell its North American home building operations to Amerimark Inc, Raleigh, NC, for undisclosed terms (M)

headline: Big Drug Companies Announce 3d-Quarter Earnings Gains
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co says earnings rose 9.3 percent in third quarter; net income rose to $753 million from $689 million in year-earlier quarter; revenues rose 10 percent, to $3.75 billion from $3.41 billion; American Home Products Corp says profits jumped 77.6 percent; net income increased to $491.1 million from $276.5 million; revenues increased 6.4 percent, to $3.47 billion, from $3.26 billion; Smithkline Beecham PLC reports 15.6 percent gain in third quarter; net income rose 15.6 percent, to $386 million from $334 million last year; sales increased 15.3 percent, to $3.09 billion from $2.68 billion; Eli Lilly & Co's earnings surged 33.8 percent in third quarter; net income rose to $415.6 million; revenues increased 10.4 percent, to $1.8 billion from $1.63 billion (L)

headline: On-Line Advertising Standards Proposed
abstract: Interactive-media coalition formed by trade associations for agencies and advertisers has proposed standardizing advertisements for on-line media (S)

headline: 2 Health Care Companies Report Profit Rise as Humana Slips
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp reports third quarter net income rose to $311 million, from profit from operations of $274 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 12 percent, to $4.88 billion; Oxford Health Plans says its net income in quarter increased 77 percent, to $26.7 million, from year ago, and revenue surged 69 percent, to $811.3 million; Humana Inc says its net income for quarter fell to $32 million from $43 million, while revenue rose 63 percent, to $1.75 billion (M)

headline: Seoul Court Overturns Ex-Leader's Death Sentence
abstract: South Korean appeals court overturns death sentence imposed on former Pres Chun Doo Hwan for staging military coup in 1979 and for ordering military crackdown in 1980 that left hundreds of anti-Government protestors dead; sentence is reduced to life imprisonment (S)

headline: Weak Reports Bolster Bonds in Thin Trading
abstract: Treasury prices end higher; 30-year bond yields 6.53 percent

headline: Quaker Oats may bring back the Snapple Lady.
abstract: Glenn Collins (Advertising) column discusses possible return of Wendy Kaufman as Snapple Lady in television ads for Quaker Oats Co's Snapple soft drinks; she comments; photo (M)

headline: South African English (With Home-Grown Spice)
abstract: Oxford University Press publishes new Dictionary of South African English, product of 25 years of work by team at Rhodes University; book, modeled on Oxford English Dictionary, examines peculiar expressions, infused by 350 years of white rule (M)

headline: Canadian Air Scrambles To Avoid Bankruptcy Filing
abstract: Canadian Airlines International, Government and unions are scrambling to keep carrier out of bankruptcy; only four of six unions have agreed to 10 percent salary cut, part of chief executive Kevin Benson's restructuring plan (M)

headline: German Industry Agrees To Discuss Sick-Pay Cuts
abstract: Germany's biggest manufacturing firms, in embarrassing retreat, agree to talks with metal workers' union on plans to cut sick pay by 20 percent; respond to firestorm of union protests and walkouts and to plea from Chancellor Helmut Kohl to respect existing contracts; emboldened labor leaders announce wage-increase demands (M)

headline: Radisson Picks Ingalls for Hotels
abstract: Radisson Hospitality Worldwide names Ingalls Advertising to handle advertising for its Radisson hotel division (S)

headline: Hoping to Bolster Its Hold on School Computers, Apple Introduces a Cheaper Model
abstract: Apple Computer Inc will introduce new kind of computer for elementary and high schools that will sell for about half the price of current multimedia systems; Apple is hoping to strengthen its foothold in $4 billion educational computing market; its new computer, Emate 300, is not based on Macintosh, but borrows technology from Apple's Newton line of hand-held computing devices to create sleek notebook-sized device for Internet browsing, word processing and other basic computing tasks; it is not intended to compete with or replace multimedia Macintoshes, but to give schools a supplementary device; Emate, costing under $800, will be available initially only to schools, but Apple eventually will market it to families as well; graph (M)

headline: BAHRAIN INVESTMENT COMPANY ACQUIRES CARTER
abstract: Investcorp International, investment group based in Bahrain, says it has bought William Carter Co, maker of baby and children's apparel products; purchase price is not disclosed (S)

headline: SFX BROADCASTING TO ACQUIRE 9 RADIO STATIONS
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc agrees to buy closely held Secret Communications LP for $300 million, adding nine radio stations in three new markets; under the deal, SFX will get WDVE-FM, WXDX-FM, WDSY-FM and WJJJ-FM, all in Pittsburgh, Pa, company will also get WLTF-FM and WTAM-AM in Cleveland and WFBQ-FM, WRZX-FM and WNDE-AM in Indianapolis (S)

headline: The Hand-Held Computer Is Introduced Once Again
abstract: Seven firms introduce hand-held computers that run on Microsoft Corp's new operating system software, computer industry trade show, Las Vegas; bill products as mobile extensions of personal computer (M)

headline: Ovitz Is Said To Be in Talks To Quit Disney
abstract: Walt Disney Co president Michael Ovitz reportedly is discussing taking top job at Sony; reportedly is very unhappy at Disney; Sony denies planning to hire him (M)

headline: A Yellow Light Is Blinking For a Sizzling I.P.O. Market
abstract: Caution is advised on sizzling initial public offering market; many companies offering stock have little to show in sales or profits, but carry big price tags; new offerings have already raised over $39 billion in 1996, exceeding $34 billion record set for all of 1993; table; photo (M)

headline: A Slow Recovery Is Seen in Japan
abstract: Japan's most-watched economic indicator, Bank of Japan's survey of business sentiment, known as tankan, confirms full recovery is still not in sight; quarterly survey's main manufacturing index improves to -3, meaning more companies are pessimistic than optimistic about economy (S)

headline: NATIONWIDE FILES TO SELL SHARES IN LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: Nationwide Corp files to sell to public as much as 20 percent of its life insurance unit; according to registration statement, sale would raise as much as $500 million (S)

headline: Salomon Stock for Buffett
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc will convert $140 million of its preferred stock in Salomon Inc into common stock rather than cash (S)

headline: Takeover Decision Declined by Investors
abstract: Shareholders of Wallace Computer Services Inc dismiss challenge to company's 'just say no' takeover defense; shareholders vote against proposal that would have forced company to put its takeover defense strategy to shareholder vote if it received offer that met certain criteria; company lobbied vigorously against the proposal, which had been drafted by arbitrager Guy P Wyser-Pratte after Wallace rejected bid last year from Moore Corp (M)

headline: Bias Suits Against Wall St. Firms
abstract: Three female employees of Smith Barney sued company in Federal court last May, charging discrimination and sexual harassment, and 22 more current and former employees from across country joined that action last month; women claim that their complaints about being sexually harassed were ignored, and that when firm did investigate, it disclosed their identities prematurely, exposing them to retaliation; Smith Barney denies charges; on Wall Street, discrimination cases are heard in closed-door proceedings of security-industry arbitration panels; but 80 percent of arbitrators are white men, and most cases are settled before they are submitted for arbitration; securities industry records show cases have been filed against nearly every major brokerage firm; photo (M)

headline: 46 Charged in Stock Fraud Sting by F.B.I.
abstract: Market Place column discusses FBI's arrest of 46 stock promoters, brokers and executives on charges of securities fraud and conspiracy to commit securities fraud; says FBI set up phony brokerage firm to catch stock promoters who bribe brokers to buy stock in small companies; says operation was in effect for a year; US Attorney Mary Jo White says arrests represent the 'largest single set of securities arrests ever made' (L)

headline: LILLY PAYING FOR OBESITY AND ALZHEIMER STUDY
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co reaches five-year deal to pay Neurocrine Biosciences Inc $74 milion in cash to develop new drugs for obesity and Alzheimer's disease (S)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN TO ADD LUXURY RESORTS IN WEST
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc to buy all or half of four luxury resorts from Resorts LP and affiliates for $210 million in cash, stock and debt; will buy all of Boulders, near Scottsdale, Ariz, and Lodge at Ventana Canyon, near Tucson, and 50 percent of Peaks Resort and Spa, Telluride, Colo, and Carmel Valley Ranch, Carmel, Calif (S)

headline: Re-engineering Firm Tries Some of Its Own Medicine
abstract: CSC Index, management consulting firm that originated concept of re-engineering and tripled in size in just three years during re-engineering craze, has seen its fortunes decline as term re-engineering falls from grace in corporate board rooms; CUC Index is trying now to re-engineer its own limage; company is barely beating industry averages in its rate of growth, which dropped below 15 percent this year from 52 percent in 1993; David A Lord, consultant, says this reflects danger of company attaching itself too heavily to one particular concept; J Douglas Gray was brought in to replace James Champy as chief executive; photo (M)

headline: World Is Less Crowded Than Expected, the U.N. Reports
abstract: New United Nations survey finds that world's population is growing almost everywhere more slowly than expected even a few years ago; study also finds that number of people being added to world each year has begun to fall sooner than anticipated; analysts say family planning and other aid programs of 1960's and 1970's that gave couples around the world more control over number of children they had, augmented by more recent programs to give women more economic power and social status, have paid off in steady, continuous fertility declines in every region; new UN figures, covering 1990 to 1995, show population growth rate worldwide of 1.48 per cent a year, significantly lower than 1.57 per cent projected by previous report in 1994; in same period, fertility also declined, to average of 2.96 children per woman; projected figure had been 3.1; UN analysts say that by 2050, world's population could be 9.4 billion, nearly half billion lower than 1994 projections; UN says there are now 5.77 billion people on earth; table (M)

headline: BOSTON INVESTMENT FIRM TO ACQUIRE CENTRAL TRACTOR
abstract: J W Childs Equity Partners LP to buy Central Tractor Farm & Country Inc for about $156 million (S)

headline: The Day of the Ghouls vs. the Day of the Dead
abstract: Distinctly American form of Halloween, with jack-o-lanterns, candy corn, Batman and Morticia, is rapidly catching on in Mexico, country with its own powerful traditions for celebrating Day of the Dead; American Halloween and colorful rituals taking place in cemeteries throughout Mexico today, All Saints' Day, and tomorrow, All Souls' Day, have same roots, at least in part; modern Mexicans observe Day of the Dead by decorating graves and communing with deceased loved ones; photos (M)

headline: Mall Company Picks North Castle
abstract: Wells Park Group names North Castle Partners to handle its account; billings at $6 million to $7 million (S)

headline: 2 Timorese Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
abstract: Carlos Ximenes Belo and Jose Ramos-Horta -- a Roman Catholic bishop and an exiled independence campaigner -- were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday for their work to end years of violent oppression in East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in the 1970's.    Article, page 6.

headline: U.S. Energy Chief Rejects Action To Push Heating Oil Price Down
abstract: Energy Sec Hazel R O'Leary, after meeting with oil company aides and industry experts, says United States will not intervene to ease sharp rise in heating oil prices; heating oil futures prices jump (M)

headline: I'll Bring It Back, Promise
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about their use of company time or property for personal benefit; drawing

headline: Irish Protestants Feeling More Irish
abstract: Abp Walton Empey, who heads Church of Ireland in Irish Republic, says Protestant church has undergone transformation in 74 years since predominantly Roman Catholic Ireland won independence from Britain, interview; holds it has emerged as confident minority, unafraid to speak out; says church has joined with Catholic hierarchy on some issues and is allowing change in some of its austere rituals; photo (M)6

headline: A broad patent is spurring the shares of Protein Design Lab.
abstract: Lawrence M Fisher (Market Place) column discusses outlook for investing in Protein Design Labs Inc following company's recent disclosure that it was awarded broad patent covering production of so-called humanized antibodies in mice; notes that despite nearly 25 percent rise in share price, some analysts say stock is still compelling buy (M)

headline: Birger Lunde, Norway Seaman; Survivor of Nazi U-Boats Was 82
abstract: Birger Lunde, who served in Norwegian merchant marine during World War II and was awarded medal for bravery by King Haakon VII, dies at age 82 (M)

headline: On clear-cutting, economists can't see the forest or the trees.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on initiatives in Maine to ban or limit clear-cutting, the practice of harvesting acres of timber at a time rather than selectively culling mature trees; proponents of limited clear-cutting say their solution would save jobs, but economist at Wilderness Society disputes this, saying Maine will lose about 750 forest jobs a year to labor-saving technological change, regardless of what is decided about clear-cutting; real problem is how to weigh interests of those living today against interests of future generations; drawing (M)

headline: Veba Earnings Soar On Strong Oil Sales
abstract: Veba AG says its profit jumped 25 percent in first nine months of year, to $814 million, as oil and telecommunications sales increased (S)

headline: Taking Stock, but No Guff, Mandela Talks of Democracy
abstract: Pres Nelson Mandelahails South Africa's success in building nation based on democratic principles and array of checks and balances, interview; holds carping by disenchanted blacks and whites is unfair; defends contributions of whites; photos (L)ï

headline: Group Sues I.R.S. In I.B.M. Buyout
abstract: Group of 2,139 former employees of International Business Machines Corp (IBM) sues Internal Revenue Service seeking $46 million of income tax refunds; contend severance packages they received when their jobs were eliminated should not be taxed; IRS replies (S)

headline: Fiat to Lay Off Workers Temporarily
abstract: Fiat SpA plans 25,900 temporary layoffs of workers in January as new car sales falter (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Industrials Slip 1.12 As Profit Taking Halts Rally  The Dow industrials fell 1.12 to 6,346.91, ending a string of 10 winning sessions and falling just shy of a ninth straight record.    Broader measures also slipped, as investors secured profits made in the the stunning post-election rally that lifted the Dow 325 points, or 5.4 percent. The S.& P. 500-stock index fell 0.60 to 737.02, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 7.23 to 1,254.57. $(Page D10.$)    Treasury prices eroded slightly, as a lack of economic data and auctions scheduled this week discouraged active buying. $(D21.$)    Deutsche Telekom Comes to Market  Buoyed by a six-month ad campaign, shares in Deutsche Telekom's initial stock offering surged in Frankfurt to 33.90 marks, up nearly 19 percent from the opening price in the first day of trading. The offering raised 20 billion German marks, or $13.3 billion. In New York, the company's American depository receipts were the day's most active issue and opened at $22, up from the offering price of $18.89. But they eased during the day, closing at $21.50. $(D5.$)    Hewlett-Packard Earnings Off 4.4%  Hewlett-Packard reported a 4.4 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings to $648 million after the market closed. The company also announced a new Government-approved encryption technology for secure data transmission over the Internet. $(D4.$)    Lockheed Martin to Close 8 Plants  Lockheed Martin plans to close eight plants in California, Connecticut, New York and Pennsylvania to cut operating costs following its $9.1 billion Loral acquisition. $(D2.$)     For Gambling, a Possible Peak  With seven of eight states voting down gambling proposals, critics and boosters alike agree that the gambling industry's great period of expansion appears to be over. $(A22.$)    Kellogg to Buy Lender's Bagels  Kellogg said it would buy Lender's Bagels from Kraft Foods for $455 million, expanding its presence in breakfast foods. $(D4.$)    $1.5 Billion Pipeline Is Planned  Chevron announced that it and other big Western oil companies had agreed with the Governments of Russia, Kazakstan and Oman to build a $1.5 billion pipeline to send oil from Kazakstan to the West. $(D8.$)    U.S. Decision a Setback to RCN  RCN Corporation, a fledgling media company that is challenging Time Warner and Nynex in the cable and telephone businesses, faces a murky future; the Government rejected a bid by MFS Communications, a sister company, to transmit video over telephone wires. $(D4.$)    Europeans Avoiding Child Labor  In Europe, the use of child labor, particularly in the making of Oriental rugs, has galvanized public attention -- Ikea was pilloried in Sweden. After consulting with child-labor experts, Veillon, one of Switzerland's largest mail order houses, has adopted a code of conduct to insure that it offers rugs made only by adults. $(D9.$)    Big Bankruptcy in Japan  One of Japan's flashiest real estate companies, Sueno Kosan, was forced into bankruptcy, with more than $6 billion in bad debts. $(D8.$)    Canada-Chile Trade Pact  Bypassing a deadlock in Washington over whether to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to include Chile, Canada signed its own Chilean trade agreement. $(D8.$)

headline: MICROSEMI TO ACQUIRE PRODUCT LINES FROM 2 COMPANIES
abstract: Microsemi Corp says it will acquire certain product lines from National Semiconductor Corp and SGS Thomson Microelectronics Inc. for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Blue Chips Set Records, But Nasdaq Retreats 9.03  Blue-chip stocks set their third record of the week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.39 points, to 6,059.20, and the S.& P. 500 stock index rose 2.58 points, to 706.99, as investors focused on consumer-product companies like Merck, P.& G. and Philip Morris.    In contrast, the Nasdaq composite retreated 9.03 points to 1,241.96, as traders took profits in computer and technology stocks. $(Page D8.$)    Buyers bid up Treasury prices, as a host of economic data showed growth slowing with little chance that inflation will pick up. The 30-year bond yield slipped to 6.80 percent. $(D18.$)    Silicon Graphics Reports Loss   Silicon Graphics reported a loss for its first quarter, surprising analysts who had expected a profit even after the company warned last month that its results would not meet their estimates. The loss marked the fifth consecutive quarter in which Silicon Graphics has underperformed expectations. $(D4.$)     Stronger Profits at Baby Bells   Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, Pacific Telesis and SBC Communications each posted stronger profits, as a result of rising demand for local phone services. $(D4.$)     Few Cracks in the Glass Ceiling   A study of America's 500 largest companies found that 10 percent of their officers were women, but only 2 percent of the companies' top five earners were women. $(D4.$)    American Woman for British Post   Marjorie M. Scardino, chief executive of the Economist Group, was named chief executive of Pearson, the media conglomerate. Ms. Scardino will be the first American to head Pearson and the only woman heading one of Britain's 100 largest publicly traded companies. $(D7.$)     Chrysler Penalized on Lemon Law   A California regulator ordered Chrysler to halt new car and truck shipments to the state for 45 days as punishment for selling 116 used vehicles without disclosing that they had been repurchased under the ''lemon law.'' $(D9.$)     New York Sues Tobacco Companies   New York City sued tobacco companies to recoup the cost of caring for people with illnesses caused by smoking. The suit angered Philip Morris, one of the city's largest and most influential corporations. $(B17.$)     McDonnell Profit Tops Forecasts   McDonnell Douglas reported a rise in earnings on improved performance by its military and commercial aircraft businesses. $(D2.$)    An Unpopular $1.7 Billion Deal   Analysts and investors did not think much of the $1.7 billion purchase of Ornda Healthcorp by Tenet Healthcare. Market Place. $(D8.$)     A Rare Look Back for MTV   MTV is taking a rare look back  in a retrospective of 15 years of its advertising and promotional efforts, including promotions for spring break beach parties and a ''Choose or Lose'' voter registration drive.Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D7.$)     What Dole Leaves Unsaid on Taxes   Bob Dole calls for a new tax system. But, knowing that any change would produce losers as well as winners, he has offered no specific alternative to the current system. $(D6.$)

headline: Novell Earnings Nearly Flat With Revenues 22% Lower
abstract: Novell Inc reports earnings for fourth quarter ended Oct 26 rose to $59 million, up from year-earlier $58.9 million; chief financial officer James R Tolonen says firm is not for sale; table (S)

headline: NCR Spreads Its Wings (Flight Insurance, Anyone?)
abstract: Lars A Nyberg, chairman of NCR Corp, talks of his plans to return company to financial health before it is spun off from AT&T later this year; NCR lost nearly $4 billion since 1993, two years after AT&T's hostile takeover; Nyberg has cut more than 8,00 jobs in effort to trim $600 million in annual expenses; he has exited the PC business and plans to refocus company on its traditional strengths in automatic teller machines, electronic cash registers and large-scale computers; he faces formidable competition; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Credit Card Company Halts Marketing Project for Now
abstract: Advanta Corp, giving way to legal attack by Mastercard and Visa, agrees to temporarily stop marketing its Rewards Accelerator credit card, which is linked to American Express's frequent-flyer program; in return, Visa and Mastercard agree to take no further action against Advanta until matter is brought before a judge (M)

headline: The Harder Struggle to Make and Market Black Films
abstract: Blacks still have difficulty getting financing to make culturally authentic films; black actors are getting leading roles in mainstream movies, and blacks buy 25 percent of all movie tickets, but black film makers feel that both the culture and the economics of film business pose serious hurdles to them; say studio heads will always opt for projects that appeal to white audience; another problem is difficulty of cracking lucrative international market, and even distribution within United States; one positive sign for black movie makers is move toward building movie theaters in predominantly black neighborhoods; photos (M)

headline: Desperately Seeking Surfers
abstract: Some World Wide Web developers go to great lengths to try to get their Web site to appear at top of list that is displayed after user submits search query; developers of search services race to stay one step ahead and foil attempts of creative software programmers to find new ways to move to head of line (M)

headline: Has Wealth Ruined Chile? Neighbors Think So
abstract: There is growing notion in Latin America that Chileans, long viewed as shy and reserved people, have become arrogant as their country's economy has boomed; Chile has experienced 12 straight years of record economic growth; while many Latins say they admire Chile's economic success and would like their countries to emulate it, others say prosperity is altering character of country of 13.5 million; for many Argentines, who had long been considered most self-regarding nationality in Latin America, being overtaken by their once-poorer neighbor has been particularly galling (M)

headline: Copper Surges as Stockpiles Show 21st Consecutive Drop
abstract: Futures Markets column; copper prices surge as 21st consecutive decline in stockpiles at London Metal Exchange mutes speculation that copper in unregistered Dutch warehouses would flood market; tables (M)

headline: TEREX TO SELL CLARK MATERIAL UNIT FOR $139.5 MILLION
abstract: Terex Corp says it will sell its Clark Material Handling Co unit for $139.5 million to company formed by unit's management and Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd (S)

headline: Two Hardware Co-ops Join To Form Giant Wholesaler
abstract: Hardware co-ops Cotter & Co, which is owned by Truevalue hardware dealers, and Servistar Coast to Coast Corp to merge to form Truserv Corp; Dan Cotter will be chairman and chief executive of merged firm and Paul Pentz president and chief operating officer; merger is aimed at helping members compete with home improvement store giants; firm expects to shed up to 1,000 workers over two years, many through attrition (M)

headline: Japan Stocks Are Lower
abstract: Stocks trade slightly lower in Tokyo on Dec 30; Nikkei index of 225 stocks is down 7.69 points, at 19,361.35 (S)

headline: Immigrants' Shortcuts To Essential Information
abstract: World Wide Web sites for immigrants include those dealing with various bureaucratic immigration processes and sites run by ethnic groups with leads on jobs, recreation, schooling, clubs and legal issues; table (M)

headline: Tide of Rwanda Refugees Flows Back to Tanzania Camps
