abstract: Tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees return to camps in western Tanzania, day after panicky flight into bush; Tanzanian military temporarily gives up trying to get them on road back to Rwanda; photo; map; Hutus fear retaliation for massacre of half-million Tutsis in 1994 (S)

headline: Neglect of the Mideast Is No Option for Clinton
abstract: News analysis of Pres Clinton's latest efforts to ameliorate Middle East conflict (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TOM BROWN INC.,  Lubbock, Tex., an oil producer, said it had won approval in bankruptcy court for its plan to purchase Presidio Oil Co. for $101 million in cash and $92 million in stock.    ELCOM INTERNATIONAL INC.,  Norwood, Mass., which develops software systems, signed a definitive agreement to acquire Prophet Group Ltd., a British reseller of portable PC's with annual revenue of about $38 million. A price was not disclosed.    STAR BANC CORP.,  Cincinnati, said it had increased its stock repurchase program to three million shares and would split its stock 3 for 1 to make its shares more affordable. The bank has about 29.1 million shares outstanding.

headline: Rift in NATO Over Control Is Delaying Restructuring
abstract: Disagreement over French demand that US cede control of major NATO command in Naples to Europeans reportedly forces allied foreign ministers to delay plans to approve major post-cold-war military reorganization; restructuring is part of plan backed by US to redesign alliance to insure stability and security of Europe and American economic and political interests in changed geopolitical environment of 21st century (M)

headline: U.S. AND EUROPE AGREE ON FREEING TECHNOLOGY TRADE
abstract: US and European Union reach agreement to liberalize trade in information technology, paving way for broader pact incorporating most of world's big trading nations; resolve host of differences at World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore about proposal to eliminate tariffs within three years on computers, software, telecommunications equipment and other technology products; removes last hurdle to extend pact to some fast-growing nations of Asia, where some governments still maintain objections, and to other countries worldwide; as many as 35 more countries are expected to join agreement, though some have continued to press for delays in tariff reductions to allow their industries time to prepare for open competition (M)

headline: Gehe Rejoins Battle To Buy Lloyds Chemists
abstract: Gehe AG rejoins bidding battle against Unichem PLC for Lloyds Chemists PLC, offering to buy British drugstore chain for same 650.6 million pounds ($1.06 billion) it bid in February (S)

headline: Does Keeping the Peace Spoil G.I.'s for War?
abstract: Senior US Army officers say that year of peacekeeping in Bosnia has cost American soldiers some of their ability to fight conventional war, because they use skills directly opposed to combat training; photo; officers propose to give 10,000 troops returning to bases in Germany up to half a year to rest, catch up on training and practice traditional warfare; many lower-ranking officers are considerably more concerned about readiness as Army confronts switch from cold-war combat force to peacekeeping (M)

headline: In Rare Move, Ex-President of Mexico Testifies on Assassination
abstract: Former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari denies that he was behind 1994 assassination of Presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio; prosecutors says Salinas testified as witness in case, not suspect (M)

headline: Journalism Is Still Columbia's Priority
abstract: Joan W Konner, outgoing dean of Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, takes pride in fact that school has stuck with its traditional curriculum and has at least maintained standards that she claims other journalism schools have let slide; she is scornful of journalism schools that have been subsumed under programs called 'mass communications skills,' in which news gathering is merged with programs teaching public relations and advertising; Tom Goldstein has been appointed new dean succeeding Konner; photo (M)

headline: Japan's Banks Report Profit After Red Ink
abstract: Japan's 10 largest banks report small profits for first half ended in Sept after losses of last fiscal year; operating profits are down over one-third from year earlier; banks collectively write off loan losses of only $9.7 billion, leaving some $104 billion in troubled and reworked loans (M)

headline: A Phenom's Strategy Hits a Bumpy Stretch
abstract: Twentieth Century Giftrust Investors fund hs hit rough stretch; phenomenal performer for more than a decade, small-company fund has lost 9.5 percent since end of September; fund is managed by Glenn Fogle; tables; photos (L)Ø

headline: Japanese Banks to Aid Customers of Hanwa
abstract: Japanese bankers association says members will provided loans and other services to 'healthy' customers of failed Hanwa Bank (S)

headline: Mafia and a Lost Caravaggio Stun Andreotti Trial
abstract: Marino Mannoia, Mafia turncoat, causes major stir at trial of former Italian Prime Min Giulio Andreotti in Rome by testifying that he stole missing painting by Caravaggio from Palermo church 27 years ago and that painting was badly damaged during theft; photo (M)

headline: McDonnell Douglas Reports Earnings Are Up by 1.6%
abstract: McDonnell Douglas Corp reports third-quarter earnings rose 1.6 percent; profit from operations increased 22 percent, to $204 million from $167 million a year earlier; revenue fell slightly to $3.31 billion from $3.35 billion; table (M)

headline: Refugee Trek in Zaire: Illness, Thirst and Death
abstract: Plight of Rwanda refugees in Zaire, on run from rebel forces, discussed; vast majority has abandoned UN camps, and Western officials fear many will begin to die in great numbers (M)

headline: Republican Senate Chief Questions the Fed
abstract: Sen Trent Lott, Republican majority leader, expresses nervousness about Federal Reserve's degree of independence and holds Fed should push interest rates lower to spur economy, television interview; stand is sharp departure from usual Republican support for Fed's tough anti-inflation policies under Chmn Alan Greenspan (M)

headline: France Says Key Arrest Uncovers Basque Plot
abstract: French police report uncovering plot by Basque terrorists, angered by recent crackdown on their activities in southern France, to launch reprisal attacks against French targets; say plot included assassination of Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre and his predecessor Charles Pasqua (S)

headline: Near Boston, Developer Takes the Plunge: An Office Building on Speculation
abstract: Boston Properties Inc, owner of 12 million square feet of real estate--mostly office buildings in New York, Boston and Washington--is involved in first speculative office project in seven years; begins construction on three-story, 102,000-square-foot building in historic suburban community of Lexington, Mass; location is at core of premier suburban office market in Boston area (About Real Estate)(M)

headline: Bosnia Foes Told to Make Peace in 2 Years or Lose Economic Aid
abstract: US aned European countries overseeing still-fragile peace in Bosnia formally warn leaders of three warring ethnic factions that economic aid will end in two years if peace has not taken hold by then (M)

headline: TCI and Lodgenet Enter Joint TV Venture
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc will invest $40 million in joint venture with Lodgenet Entertainment Corp to provide direct broadcast and interactive television services to apartment buildings (S)

headline: In Irish Jail, Jets and Sharks Rumble Again
abstract: Inmates at Mountjoy Prison, Dublin, Ireland, stage production of Leonard Bernstein musical West Side Story; show is attended by US Amb Jean Kennedy Smith and Justice Min Nora Owen, who has been under heavy attack from opposition politicians for her administration of nation's prison and judicial system (M)

headline: Competitive Spur Seen; British Telecom Brings Local Phone Experience
abstract: British Telecommunications and MCI Communications to merge their operations to create world's first trans-Atlantic telephone carrier; company to be called Concert; deal is structured as $22 billion acquisition of MCI by British Telecom; it will be largest foreign takeover ever of United States corporation; at home, MCI could become formidable competitor in $100 billion market for residential local service; overseas, British Telecom could become provider of choice for many business customers seeking global communications; AT&T, which has been biggest US telephone company, urges Clinton Administration to demand that British Government open its phone market before it approves the deal; but analysts expect American regulators to approve deal because it could accelerate opening of overseas markets; MCI's chairman, Bert C Roberts Jr, and British Telecom's head, Sir Iain Vallance, will serve as joint chairmen of combined company, which will be based in London and Washington; photo; chart (L)

headline: Boycotts Rarely Have Impact on Bottom Line
abstract: Rev Jesse Jackson is calling for boycott of Texaco Inc; he hopes to settle discrimination lawsuit brought by company's black employees, but his other goal is to shift emphasis for civil rights movement from elective politics and government policy to protests against private companies; historians and economists say boycotts have often been useful in publicizing a cause, or as an organizing tool; photo (M)

headline: Times Co. Posts 37% Rise in Operating Profit
abstract: New York Times reports third-quarter operating earnings rose 37 percent, to $37.4 million, up from $27.2 million in 1995 period; reports net loss of $47.7 million for quarter, compared with year-earlier profit of $32.2 million (M)

headline: Big Japanese Property Company Is Bankrupt
abstract: One of Japan's flashiest real estate companies, Sueno Kosan, is forced into bankruptcy, with more than $6 billion in bad debts; this heightens concerns about impact on financial institutions that are owed the money, and comes at time when Japan is trying to crawl out of banking crisis set off by collapse of proerpty prices that had soared in late 1980's; Sueno's bankruptcy hints at difficulties officials are having in trying to recover loans from Sueno (M)

headline: Samsung Says It Still Wants To Buy Dutch Plane Maker
abstract: Samsung Group to continue to seek to buy Fokker NV despite rejection by bankruptcy receivers, who say suppliers are refusing to provide parts (M)

headline: Ammirati Secures Labatt Business
abstract: Labatt USA says it has consolidated its account, with billiongs estimated at $7 million to $10 million, at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York (S)

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: Financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. The stock and bond markets and the commodity markets in Chicago will reopen tomorrow, but will end trading in the early afternoon; the commodity markets in New York will be  closed until Monday.

headline: Blind Users Add Access On the Web
abstract: American Foundation for the Blind, New York, estimates that of 12 million Americans with visual impairments of some sort, 900,000 use computers; Larry Scadden, who works on technology issues for disabled at National Science Foundation, and is blind, says Internet has changed forever lives of blind people; National Federation of Blind's International Braille and Technology Center, Baltimore, is world's largest proving ground for products for blind and has worked to test accessibility of computer hardware and software; use of computers by people who are visually impaired depends on two factors: fact that text can be read aloud by speech synthesizer or can be output in Braille format and the user's ability to navigate screen with keyboard; photo; list of some Web sites for visually impaired (L)

headline: Dollar Is Flat to Slightly Down As Traders See Pause in Rally
abstract: Dollar slips against German mark and is little changed versus the Japanese yen in Dec 20 trading; traders see pause in dollar's rally (M)

headline: Takeover in Lima Imperils the Campaign to Free American Woman
abstract: Tupac Amaru's seizure of Japanese diplomatic compound in Lima is major setback to efforts to free Lori Berenson, American woman serving life sentence in Peru for aiding terrorists; her photo (S)

headline: Stay Is Granted To Credit Unions
abstract: US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit grants temporary stay on an injunction that would have prevented credit unions from signing up new 'noncore' members; with the decision, credit unions can continue to recruit new members for the time being from groups that are already part of credit union; but they will be blocked from adding new groups (S)

headline: $505 Million St. Jude Deal For Maker of Defibrillators
abstract: St Jude Medical Inc says its Pacesetter subsidiary will acquire Ventritex Inc in stock swap valued at $505 million (M)

headline: An Odd Rift Develops Between an Author and Borders, a Chain Promoting His Book
abstract: Michael Moore charges Borders Group Inc has barred him from promoting his book Downsize This! in any of its 152 stores, cancelling readings and autograph sessions, article in The Nation magazine; says firm responds to his stand that bookstore employees should join union; firm denies charge; photo (M)

headline: National Breast Cancer Awareness Month has inspired extensive corporate advertising.
abstract: Advertising column: National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, observed during October, has inspired national advertising and promotional campaigns worth millions of dollars, some of it from companies not usually associated with women's issues; this is because of current popularity of cause-related marketing, and because breast cancer has become 'apple-pie issue' that companies are comfortable supporting because it is crucial and noncontroversial (M)

headline: How Clashes Erupted Into Pitched Battles
abstract: Reconstruction of Palestinian rioting that led to deadly clashes with Israeli soldiers; students who set off from West Bank to protest opening of new entrance to archeological tunnel in Jerusalem battered down Israeli checkpoint and were met with rubber bullets; Palestinian officers on hillside with mob then fired down automatic weapons and Israeli soldiers responded in kind; Yasir Arafat encouraged 'mass confrontations' over tunnel, and memorialized those who 'kill' for Allah,' but there is no evidence that he intended deadly havoc that followed (S)

headline: ZORAN AGREES TO ACQUIRE COMPCORE MULTIMEDIA
abstract: Zoran Corp to acquire Compcore Multimedia Inc for about $57 million in stock (S)

headline: CT FINANCIAL TO BUY CANADIAN INSURER MELOCHE
abstract: CT Financial Services unit of Imasco says it will buy Meloche Monnex Inc for $103.5 million; London Insurance Group owns 66 percent of Meloche, and Meloche's management owns the rest (S)

headline: Empty Seat Signals Turkey's Sensitivity Over Role in Europe
abstract: Turkey declines to attend dinner with European Union heads of state in Ireland because it has not been offered fuller role in summit; Government of Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan complains that European Union seems not to recognize Turkey's strategic importance and stabilizing role in turbulent region (M)

headline: RJR NABISCO EXPECTS 'BARN BURNER' OF A FOURTH QUARTER
abstract: Steven Goldstone, chief executive of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. says company's fourth quarter is going to be very good (S)y

headline: Ford Places Top Designer On the Leadership Track
abstract: Ford Motor Co names Jacques A Nasser to head its North American and European automotive operations, clearing the way for Nasser to become Ford's top operating officer someday; Nasser, who had been group vice president in charge of vehicle development, will take rank of executive vice president when his promotion takes effect on Nov 1; Ford also announces that it is separating its many auto parts businesses from core automotive operations that Nasser will oversee; executive vice president Edward E Hagenlocker is named vice chairman with responsibility for overseeing new auto parts division; photo (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Mystic Coast and Country, North Stonington, Conn., to the Hughes Agency, Norwalk, Conn., to handle tourism advertising for the group, which represents 32 towns in southeastern Connecticut and western Rhode Island. The account, with billings estimated at $1 million, had been at O'Neal & Prelle, Hartford.

headline: BAXTER IN STOCK SWAP FOR RESEARCH MEDICAL
abstract: Baxter International Inc says it has agreed to buy Research Medical Inc in stock swap valued at $236 million (S)

headline: Wheat Falls on Expectation Of Abundant World Crops
abstract: Wheat prices fall sharply on Chicago Board of Trade as concerns grow that larger worldwide crop will make competition stiff for American exporters; gasoline prices rise (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Higher On 2 Reports
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities move higher as weaker-than-expected manufacturing and retail sales reports ease concerns of investors that the economy may be headed toward inflation; 30-year bond gains 18/32, to 98 15/32, to yield 6.87 percent, down from 6.92 percent on Monday; chart; Treasury graph (Credit Markets column) (M)

headline: Mexican Output Rises 7.4%, Eclipsing Economic Forecasts
abstract: Mexican Finance Ministry reports that economy surged by 7.4% in third quarter, exceeding economists' expectations; increase in gross domestic product, biggest quarterly rise in more than five years, is another piece of evidence of nation's bounce-back from peso crisis of 1994 (S)

headline: Executive Shifts On the West Coast
abstract: Recent appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: The Survival of the Most Efficient
abstract: Viewpoint article by Alexei Bayer on emerging free-market for labor in which people must work harder and longer in order to survive; says new anti-utopian picture is of an over-worked, super-efficient population deprived of compassion and lacking cultural interests and free time for simple human pleasures(M)9

headline: A Political Fight Marks a Coming of Age for a Silicon Valley Titan
abstract: Silicon Valley's top executives launch campaign to defeat California's Proposition 211, which would lower barrier to class-action lawsuits in cases where stock fraud is charged and would leave corporate directors and officers personally liable when juries award damages; lawyers pushing the proposition see it as way to defend savings of retirees from those who would lure them into high-flying, hard-crashing world of technology stocks, often with misinformation or inadequate disclosure of risk; but opponents see it as threat that could cripple nation's technology heartland; leader of campaign to defeat Proposition 211 is L John Doerr, venture capitalist who has history of nurturing technology start-ups that developed into entire new industries; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Foster Wheeler Corp, Clinton, NJ, engineering concern, receives $174.4 million contract from Hebel Electric Power Corp to supply equipment for Chinese power plant (S)

headline: Are Managers Counting on a Rubber Stamp?
abstract: Questions are raised about relatively new high-finance niche in which banks advance loans to mutual fund companies against sales charges and fees they expect to collect from shareholders years in future; catch is that marketing fees, called 12b-1 fees, are not automatic but must be approved each year by fund's independent directors as being in shareholders' interest; fund companies that take out loan against these fees, before they are even approved, are banking on continued willingness of independent directors to approve them (M)

headline: In Algeria, Oil and Islam Make a Volatile Mixture
abstract: Special report, State of Fear, finds as war between Algeria's military-backed Government and Islamic militants turns increasingly violent, profits of multinational companies that still pump oil there are caught in balance; presented with choice between secretive Government and violent currents of political Islam, Western companies and governments have come down on side of army and repression in war that has taken tens of thousands of lives; deep in country's northern oil sector, dozens of Americans and other foreign oil executives live behind high walls of heavily fortified camps, where fear is never far from surface; country, in form perhaps more acute than anywhere else, poses increasingly widespread quandry of how to sift moderate political Islam from Islamic militancy and terrorism; task has proved almost impossible in nation where Islam first triumphed at ballot box, but was then forced underground by Government; roots of conflict, which date back to elections of 1992, discussed; photos; map (M)

headline: Dreyfus is planning to put new life in the old lion by urging investors to 'Rule your kingdom.'
abstract: Dreyfus Corp lion is coming back in assertive campaign that begins Nov 6; advertising campaign, by Citron Haligman Bedecarre, faces dauntingly steep uphill climb in convincing consumers that Dreyfus's mutual funds offer improved investment opportunities; Dreyfus Corp is owned by Mellon Bank Corp (L)

headline: 2 Israelis Outline New Risk To Electronic Data Security
abstract: Leading Israeli computer scientists Adi Shamir and Eli Biham publish on the Internet a paper warning of new way to more easily decode and counterfeit electronic cash 'smart cards' widely used in Europe and being tested in United States (M)

headline: MAZDA SUED BY 14 STATES OVER ADVERTISEMENTS
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp of America is being sued by 14 states that contend it used false and deceptive ads to lure consumers into expensive car lease agreements; suits contend ads led consumers to believe they could lease new car for nothing down (S)

headline: Calls Issued For Boycott Of Texaco
abstract: Array of civil rights leaders, led by Rev Jesse Jackson, step up pressure on Texaco Inc, with calls for national boycott to protest alleged racial problems there and with demands that the company make changes in its policies toward nonwhites; calls for boycott cause deep concern among investors; Texaco shares fall as much as $3 a share, or 3 percent, in late afternoon trading but stock recovers somewhat, closing at $95.375, down $1.875; Texaco's chairman Peter I Bijur announces that company wants to settle quickly two-year-old discrimination suit that has led to company's problems; Bijur shuttles among meetings with civil rights leaders, apologizing for words captured on tape and committing his company to becoming a model for equality in employment; while number of civil rights leaders say they are impressed with Bijur's words, they remain concerned not only about company's actions, but also about what they say is inadequate number of minority executives at Texaco (L)

headline: Chinese Muslims Recount Their Days of Terror
abstract: Local residents recall violent 1992-93 struggle in southern Ninxia Hui Autonomous Region, China, over leadership of area's Sufi Muslims, interviews; many suspect local Communist officials engineered downfall of popular religious leader by backing rival to be rid of potential source of rebellion; story of fighting has never been fully told in China, where foreign journalists are all but barred from remote minority areas; map; photo (M)

headline: Netanyahu Reported Ready to Make Gesture to Palestinians
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu returns to Israel from Mideast summit in Washington, reportedly ready to make some quick gestures to Palestinians; photo; actions might include withdrawing some of tanks ringing Palestinian areas in West Bank and Gaza; officials note that by placating hawkish wing, and showing he will not bow to violence, Netanyahu is in better position to restore political process with Palestinians; Netanyahu also goes on Arabic-language program to ask that listeners not lose hope (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: CNF Transportation, Palo Alto, Calif., formerly Consolidated Freightways, to Citigate Albert Frank, San Francisco, a unit of Citigate Communications Group Ltd., to handle the creative portion of its account, previously handled by Grey Advertising, San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $4

headline: Olin Plans A Broad Shake-Up
abstract: Olin Corp announces that it plans to spin off its aerospace and ordnance operations, sell its isocyanate chemical business and buy back as much as 10 percent of its stock; Olin will sell isocyanate business to ARCO Chemical Co for $565 million in cash; Olin expects spinoff of its ordnance and aerospace businesses to be completed by end of year; new, independent company will be called Primex Technologies Inc (L)

headline: Accord Near On Computer Secruity Codes
abstract: Pres Clinton will permit American computer companies to export more powerful data-scrambling software, but only if they establish system that will enable keys to code to be obtained by law enforcement officials with a court warrant; American computer and software executives have long argued that United States export controls on most sophisticated data-privacy technology put American industry at disadvantage; Pres Clinton, like former Presidents, fears that such powerful data-scrambling software could be used by foreign terrorists, drug cartels and other criminals to hide transactions and communications; Clinton has also decided to move authority for exporting encryption software from State Dept to Commerce Dept; some computer companies are expected to object to 'key' system, although IBM and several other big companies have reportedly agreed to it (M)

headline: German Inflation Rate Eased a Bit Last Month
abstract: Germany reports consumer prices rose at 1.4 percent annual rate, Nov, down from 1.5 percent in Oct (S)

headline: In Russia, Whistle-Blowing Can Still Be Treason
abstract: Aleksandr Nikitin, researcher for Norwegian environmental organization and former Russian naval officer, is charged with treason for helping to publicize radioactive contamination caused by Russian Northern Fleet; he has been in former KGB prison for nine months; his case has emerged as critical test of limits of political freedom in new Russia; it also raises serious questions about Russia's ability to overcome its long history of masking mistakes behind veil of official secrecy and to deal openly with decades of environmental abuse and neglect (M)

headline: H & R BLOCK NAMES ACTING LEADER ITS NEW CHIEF
abstract: H & R Block Inc names Frank Salizzoni president and chief executive of corporation and chairman of its Compuserve Corporation unit (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Show An Advance
abstract: Treasury prices bond prices rise; 30-year bond rises 14/32, to 100 25/32, to yield 6.43 percent; graph (M)

headline: Tiny Village In Germany Subdues A Goliath
abstract: 350 residents of Liebenberg, Germany, thwart efforts by Government's privatization agency to sell village; are being given change to devise plan under which they would buy or extend leases on homes and businesses, and take matters into own hands by preventing outsiders from coming in and driving prices beyond those they can afford (M)

headline: After a Year Of Law, Scant Competition
abstract: Telecommunications future is murkier than ever one year after Pres Clinton signed landmark bill that he said would allow laws to catch up to the future; cable television industry has largely abandoned its foray into telephone business, regional phone companies have shelved their efforts to get into television, and three big long-distance carriers have put through their steepest rate increases in several years; critics of Federal Communications Commission say agency's rules are primary reason so little competition has taken hold; but several experts in deregulation blame companies themselves, for failing to predict cost of their new ventures and overestimating capabilities of the technology; Reed E Hundt, chairman of FCC, is criticized by several industry executives for his aggressive approach to prying open local telephone monopolies; that has provoked backlash from companies, and they have successfully challenged commission's first set of competition rules in Federal courts (M)

headline: Swiss Acknowledge Profiting From Nazi Gold
abstract: Swiss National Bank acknowledges that it profited to amount of about 20 million Swiss francs from dealings with Nazi Germany's central bank during World War II; vice president Jean-Pierre Roth insists there is no evidence that gold from concentration camp victims was involved; also denies bank is still holding Reichsbank ingots, although such gold could have been melted down to hide origin; American Jewish groups charge Swiss have billions of dollars in assets of Holocaust victims (S)

headline: Sex, Lies and the Courts: A Fury Rises in Belgium
abstract: Various acts of rebellion around Belgium reflect widespread frustration with official handling of major case involving kidnapping, sexual abuse and deaths of children and young women; frustration boils over after country's highest court removes magistrate in charge of investigation, saying he compromised his impartiality by attending dinner held in support of families of missing and dead children; wildcat strikes and sit-ins and barricades on roads and train tracks followed; judge, Jean-Marc Connerotte, had achieved status of near-hero because of his recent breakthroughs in the case; photo (M)

headline: Britain's Big 'McLibel Trial' (It's McEndless, Too)
abstract: McDonald's Corp is suing vegetarians Dave Morris and Helen Steel in London; case reached its 292d day on Nov 1, and achieved dubious distinction of becoming longest trial in British history; photo (M)

headline: Malaysia Moves to Rein In Radical Islamic Fundamentalism
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Malaysia is acting to curb radical Islamic fundamentalism and strengthen the modern form of the religion advocated by the government of Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

headline: Prudential Policyholders' Deadline Nears
abstract: Last opportunity for 10.7 million Prudential Insurance policyholders to battle company on their own over whether they were cheated by agents is fast approaching; by midnight tomorrow night, policyholders must move to be excluded from class-action settlement that was announced in Sept or be automatically included (M)

headline: BOSNIA REPORTED TO BE SMUGGLING HEAVY ARTILLERY
abstract: European intelligence agencies uncover evidence that Bosnian Government is involved in covert smuggling of heavy artillery weapons through Adriatic port of Ploce, Croatia; say 40 155-millimeter howitzers were shipped into Bosnia in last week of August; NATO officials accuse Turkey and Malaysia of involvement in operation, noting Bosnian Government recently signed secret arms agreements with both; fear Muslims are trying to stockpile more weapons than allowed under Dayton peace agreement, giving them potential battlefield advantage if war resumes in Bosnia; map (M)

headline: Chinese and Indian Leaders Vow to End Border Tension
abstract: China and India agree in principle on mutual troop withdrawal from disputed areas along their 2,500-mile-frontier and pledge that 'neither side shall use its military capability against the other'; agreement comes nearly 35 years after border war that left China occupying sprawling region of Himalayan uplands claimed by India; pact is centerpiece of visit to New Delhi by Pres Jiang Zemin of China (M)

headline: U.S. Said to End Inquiry of Litton
abstract: Litton Industries says Justice Department has ended investigation of its Guidance and Control Systems unit's billing practices without taking action against company or its employees; probe involved accusations of false billings to Pentagon (S)

headline: Conrail Stock Shaken by Suitors' Conflicting Accounts of Talks
abstract: Conrail stock takes temporary steep dive because of conflicting accounts of discussions between Norfolk Southern Corp and CSX Corp over Conrail's fate; Norfolk Southern and CSX are in bitter struggle for control of Conrail, and their bidding war has sent Conrail stock soaring; talk that Norfolk would abandon its offer causes momentary drop in Conrail shares, but they recoup after Norfolk announces it is still pursuing Conrail (M)

headline: Wintery Night In Red Square, And Sadness About Lebed
abstract: Moscow's Red Square is wintry and calm following Pres Yeltsin's dismissal of Aleksandr Lebed as national security chief; Russians express weary acceptance of ouster of Lebed, whom many consider most trustworthy man in Russian politics (S)

headline: Not a Beagle in Sight
abstract: There'll be dalmatians everywhere next week, and not just in theaters. Here, dance students from Babylon, L.I., rehearse on the ''101 Dalmatians'' float that will bark its way through the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. (Associated Press)

headline: Now in the H.M.O.: Yoga Teachers and Naturopaths
abstract: Alternative medicine, long on the fringes of medical care, is slowly being offered by more health plans; for example, Oxford Health Plans, Norwalk, Conn, recently took alternative medicine beyond state mandates, announcing that it would become first large medical insurer to have network of alternative-care providers; although medical community has increasingly incorporated some forms of alternative medicine in traditional treatments, doctors caution that many forms of alternative care are still being tested and question whether Oxford's action is too much too soon; photo (M)

headline: BOEING OFFERING $13 BILLION TO BUY McDONNELL DOUGLAS, LAST U.S. COMMERCIAL RIVAL
abstract: Boeing Co will acquire McDonnell Douglas Corp in $13.3 billion deal, 10th-largest merger in American history and largest ever in aerospace industry; acquisition will make Boeing only manufacturer of commercial jets in US while catapulting it ahead of Lockheed Martin Corp as world's largest aerospace company and bolstering its status as nation's leading exporter; executives at Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, as well as industry experts, say deal makes sense since Boeing is predominantly commercial aircraft builder that hopes to continue expanding in military field, while bulk of McDonnell Douglas's business is already in military field; with rich history in commercial aircraft and substantial manufacturing capacity, McDonnell Douglas can also help Boeing meet increased worldwide demand for new planes; photos; charts (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Oct. 18   Oct. 11   Oct. 20          1996   1996   1995       Gasoline production, daily   7.3   7.6   7.5       Distillate production, daily   3.7   3.6   3.1       Gasoline stocks   189.8   195.8   198.4       Distillate stocks   114.3   114.3   130.6       Crude imports, daily   8.1   7.3   7.4       Product imports, daily   1.9   1.6   1.5       Crude stocks   304.9   299.2   301.0       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.7       Refinery utilization (%)   93.1   92.7   89.4          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Despite Concern Over Abuses, Albanian Local Vote Goes Smoothly
abstract: Voting in local Albanian elections, watched with unusual concern by international observers, proceeds relatively smoothly, though Government took number of actions before vote that Western diplomats say seemed intended to undermine voter confidence; Government refused to allow chief European election monitoring group to bring full team of observers, and waited until last minute to give accreditation to largest domestic monitoring group; has been heavily criticized by US since Parliamentary elections in May that were marred by fraud and violence (M)

headline: Terror in the Air, and Frantic Rescue From the Sea
abstract: Hijacked Ethiopian Airlines jet runs out of gas and crashes into sea just off Mitsamouli, Comoro Islands, narrowly missing hotel; 123 of 175 people aboard are believed dead; hotel quickly sends out its scuba boats, one of which carries eight French doctors, to rescue survivors; two of hijackers survive crash and are in custody; map; photos (M)

headline: Seagram Promotes A Gin on Radio
abstract: Aggressive efforts by Seagram Co to promote distilled spirits outside of media like print and outdoor advertising have been extended into radio (S)

headline: Ukraine Walks Shaky Tightrope Between NATO and Russia
abstract: Ukraine finds tiself at heart of strategic tug of war, caught between beckoning West and volatile Russia reluctant to let loose its former prized province; is particularly feeling squeeze because of NATO's plans to admit Poland as new member and thus extend security alliance to its borders; viewed by Washington as critical buffer between Russia and Europe, Ukraine has changed its policy on NATO expansion from neutrality to one of support, which has irked Moscow(M)

headline: No Private Offers For Banco di Napoli
abstract: Mediocredito Centrale SpA, which is owned by the Italian Treasury, is reportedly the only bank that has offered to buy the Treasury's 60 percent stake in Banco di Napoli SpA (S)û

headline: G.M. TO BUILD FEWER AUTOS THAN PLANNED IN NEXT QUARTER
abstract: General Motors Corp plans to build 1.41 million cars and trucks in North America in 1997 first quarter, 46,000 fewer than it planned to build in 1996 period before strike crippled output and 16 percent more than it actually produced (S)ü

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Privatization Program Is Canceled by Mexico   Abandoning a central pillar of its economic modernization program, the Mexican Government canceled its prolonged, troubled effort to sell portions of the state-owned petrochemical industry to private investors.    The scheduled privatization of 61 plants had prompted months of protests from oil workers and even many businessmen; the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party formally announced its opposition last month. Still, President Ernesto Zedillo had pledged repeatedly during his 23-month administration to go ahead with the selloff. $(Page D2.$)    Executive-Plan Bankruptcy Shield   Special tax-deferred savings and supplemental pension plans for corporate executives get favorable treatment under the law, in part because the money is supposedly at risk if the company gets into financial trouble. But even when companies file for bankruptcy, such plans often survive while the retirement funds of rank-and-file workers remain in jeopardy. $(A1.$)    Wooing Internet Gamers   No one has yet made a fortune marrying multiplayer games to the Internet. ''But over time there will be,'' an analyst says. Businesses trying to profit from Internet gaming must meet player expectations while overcoming the restrictions of slow modems and other technological obstacles. $(D5.$)    A More Competitive Medium   A coalition of 38 computer makers and software publishers led by Netscape Communications plans to announce a new audio and video data standard today that will permit companies using the Internet to compete more directly with traditional radio and television broadcasters. $(D4.$)    Aloha to a Party Line   When GTE Hawaiian Telephone told its customers in a rural section of Hawaii that they could only use party lines, their outrage led to a five-year battle that recently culminated in an order by the state's public utilities commission requiring GTE to turn over its networks to a small competitor. $(D5.$)    In Ireland, the British Are Coming   The Irish Times, the most prestigious and influential newspaper in Ireland, is advancing, as its circulation sets new highs and its ability to sway and infuriate politicians increases. But as fast as it grows, the Irish editions of British papers are growing faster. $(D7.$)    Europe Rate Gauge for Finland   Finland, the newest member of the European Union, has taken another decisive step westward, linking its currency to the European exchange rate mechanism and possibly qualifying for participation in the forthcoming single currency. $(D2.$)    Hollywood's Weekend Wars   Every Friday night, only hours after a new film has opened across the country, the faxes pile up in the offices of nervous studio executives and producers detailing the box-office grosses of the movie. Judgments are set by Sunday. A studio film, opening nationally, that takes in at least $10 million at the box office is considered successful. Any highly promoted film that doesn't is a disappointment. Bernard Weinraub: Entertainment. $(D7.$)     Cable Access as Urban Resource     Like many disputes that mix politics and commerce, the showdown between Time Warner and the Giuliani administration is ultimately about control of a precious resource: in this case, cable TV access. Just how precious can be measured by the other media companies wading into the dispute in hopes of turning the furor to their advantage. News analysis. $(B3.$)

headline: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bills and notes markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills. On Wednesday the Treasury will auction a new two-year note, and on Thursday it will auction a new five-year note.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.78 percent and a six-month bill was 4.97 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a rate to yield 5.74 percent, and a five-year note, 6.05 percent.

headline: S.E.C. Is Investigating Rebates From Firms
abstract: SEC is investigating rebates to mutual fund companies from securities firms trying to win their business (S)

headline: Holders Back Time Warner-Turner Merger
abstract: Shareholders of Time Warner Inc and Turner Broadcasting System Inc approve $7 billion merger of the two companies; Time Warner chairman Gerald M Levin faces difficult problem of cutting its debt of $17 billion (M)

headline: Hope for Hebron Turns U.S. Aide Around
abstract: US Middle East negotiator Dennis Ross makes last-minute decision to remain in Israel after learning that Israelis and Palestinians have made significant progress in talks on Hebron; envoys deny announcement of his departure was ruse to spur talks (M)

headline: DANAHER CONSIDERING ACQUISITION OF TYLAN GENERAL
abstract: Danaher Corp and Tylan General Inc have confidentiality agreement that will allow Danaher time to evaluate possible acquisition of Tylan (S)

headline: For G.I.'s, More Time Away From Home Fires
abstract: American Army troops are spending more time on missions like Bosnia than they were before the downsizing of the military, and the strains on their families are growing; Army weighs whether to shift its culture to be more like the Navy or the Marine Corps, in which families expect both long deployments and fuller range of services to help them; photos (M)

headline: New Editor Is Named at New York Magazine
abstract: K-III Communications Corp names Caroline Miller, Seventeen magazine editor in chief, to replace ousted Kurt Andersen as New York magazine editor; she comments on plans; photo (M)

headline: 3 Concerns Join Forces To Buy STN Atlas
abstract: Rheinmetall AG, utility Badenwerk AG and British Aerospace PLC say they will jointly pay 550 million marks ($367 million) to buy STN Atlas Elektronik (S)

headline: Fiber Optic Cable Demand Outstrips Supply
abstract: Worldwide shortage of optical fiber is slowing construction of new telecommunications networks and forcing even big buyers to renegotiate supply agreements; shortfall is proving bonanza for small group of fiber manufacturers; annual installation of optical fiber worldwide has doubled since 1993, driven by expanding market for Internet access and other high-speed communications links; global fiber market is about $6 billion, with one-third of sales in North America; photo; chart (M)

headline: 2 Fidelity Funds Invested in Company Involved in F.B.I. Sting
abstract: Two mutual funds managed by Fidelity Investment Company--Fidelity Convertible Securities Fund and Fidelity Equity-Income Fund--are among biggest investors in small Canadian company whose chmn has been charged with conspiracy to commit securities fraud in connection with Federal sting operation; case involving Cam-Net Communications Network Inc of Vancouver and its chmn, Daryl Buerge, discussed (M)

headline: Dying Zapatista Leader Is Focus of Only Accord So Far
abstract: Mexican Government and Zapatista rebels have averted collapse of peace negotiations by agreeing to allow Commander Ramona, terminally ill leader of guerrilla army, to travel to Mexico City to attend Indian conference; photo (M)

headline: Active Boards Aren't Always Wise
abstract: Ralph D Ward Viewpoint column discusses question of whether an active corporate board, taking a stronger voice in setting business strategy and overseeing management, is necessarily a good board (M)

headline: 3 Strategies to Help Families in the U.S.
abstract: Article on what would be needed to assure adequate, center-based care for children for all the families that want it; focuses on what can be done in public preschools, working with voucher system and providing regulatory reform (L)

headline: Union Sets Sunday Night Deadline for G.M.
abstract: UAW imposes deadline of Sunday night for settling contract talks with General Motors Corp, setting stage for strike if negotiators fail to reach agreement; negotiators appear to have hit snag over work force guarantees (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ARMCO INC., Pittsburgh, said its chief financial officer, David Harmer, would resign at the end of the month to become president of Jetway Systems in Ogden, Utah, a unit of FMC Corp.

headline: A Healthy Start To Key Season In Retail Sales
abstract: Retail executives and mall operators report shoppers hit malls over '96 Thanksgiving weekend with vigor not seen in last few years; report sales increased 11 percent over '95 period, and that value of checks written by shoppers increased 3.6 percent (M)

headline: Ending Dialogue, Ruling Mexican Party Dilutes Reforms
abstract: Political party that has long dominated Mexico breaks off two years of talks with opposition on broad electoral reforms and uses its legislative majority to impose its own limited reform; opposition legislators denounce this as setback to a transition to political pluralism; Pres Ernesto Zedillo promised when he took office in December 1994 to enact deep changes in political system, which has allowed one party to control country since 1920's; Zedillo's role in his party's reversal is unclear, but Zedillo tells business executives that he suports his party's actions and has party's support for his policies; photo (M)

headline: New Publisher Named for Times Books
abstract: Random House announces that Peter Bernstein will become new publisher of its Times Books unit replacing Peter Osnos, who resigned in September (S)

headline: Pope Appeals for Aid for African Refugees and Peace in Mideast
abstract: Pope John Paul II uses Christmas message to appeal for more aid to victims of violence in Central Africa and for a quickening of efforts to achieve lasting peace in Middle East (M)

headline: It May Have Been Flashy in 1952
abstract: Photos of Sands Hotel in Las Vegas before and during its demolition

headline: Egypt Irked, But Softly, At the U.S. On U.N. Veto
abstract: Egyptians mutter about arrogance of US power in blocking second term for UN Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali, but the Egyptian diplomat, a Coptic Christian, has always been something of an outsider in Cairo, barred from highest posts for fear of angering Islamic militants (S)

headline: Envirodyne Shares Soar on Lawsuit Victory
abstract: Shares of Envirodyne Industries rise 34 percent after company says it has won $102 million in damages in patent lawsuit over plastic films used for meat packaging; judgment was against American National Can Co (S)

headline: France Asks European Neighbors to Be Alert for Bombing Suspects
abstract: France asks its European neighbors to be alert for the terrorists who set off bomb in Paris commuter train that killed three people (S)

headline: AST INCREASES ITS CREDIT LINE TO $300 MILLION
abstract: AST Research Inc says it has completed negotiations to increase its credit line to $300 million and to sell group of personal-computer-related intellectual properties to Samsung Electronics Co for $10 million (S)

headline: TRW Announces Layoffs And $233 Million Charge
abstract: TRW Inc, in move to increase competitiveness in its automotive business, says it plans to eliminate about 2,300 jobs and close several plants; takes after-tax charge of $233.4 million in third quarter to pay for the moves; reports third-quarter earnings totaled $86.2 million, from $78.2 million in comparable period year ago; earnings chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Chart on key United States interest rates

headline: Credit Offerings for the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.99 percent and a six-month bill was 5.08 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ARVIN INDUSTRIES, Columbus, Ind., a multinational maker and distributor of auto parts, said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell four million preferred shares through a finance unit.     BANK OF BOSTON CORP., Boston, said its BancBoston Insurance Agency Inc. unit had been issued a license to act as an insurance agent in Massachusetts.     ROCK-TENN CO., Norcross, Ga., a packing company, said it had filed to list its class A common stock on the New York Stock Exchange.     THE BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, said it had completed its acquisition of the corporate and municipal trust businesses of Riggs National Corp., Washington. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Body Bizarrely Found in Mexico Is Telling No Tales
abstract: Mexican investigators have made no progress in identifying decomposed body unearthed over two weeks ago on ranch owned by Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of former Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari; Atty Gen Antonio Lozano Gracia had said body would prove Salinas ordered 1994 assassination of leading politician Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu; tests have failed to confirm that body is that of Manuel Munoz Rocha, who allegedly conspired with Salinas to organize and pay for killing, and indicate body may have been planted to incriminate Salinas; map; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Charges an Official Of Philadelphia Exchange
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges Richard B Feinberg, member of board of Philadelphia Stock Exchange, with cheating customers; SEC contends that Feinberg and his brother, Alan, are principals in Richardt-Alyn & Co, which made secret trading profits on trades, telling customers their shares were sold for lower amount, then pocketing the difference; Feinberg denies charge (M)

headline: Ready. Aim. Start Bonding! Corporate Lessons in Guns
abstract: Number of companies are sending executives and employees out to bond on shooting ranges; photos of employees and clients of Mecca Krull Corp at Remington Arms shooting school in Ilion, New York; Orvis also reports surge in corporate outings (S)

headline: VALUE HEALTH IS PLANNING SPINOFF OF BENEFIT UNIT
abstract: Value Health Inc to spin off its Valuerx unit, buy workers' compensation managed-care firm from Beverly Enterprises Inc for $87.5 million and repurchase up to $100 million of its common stock (S)

headline: The Villain Is Inflation
abstract: S Abraham Ravid letter says inflation is main culprit in distortions and unpredictability of tax law regarding home sales

headline: Russia Will Put Off Signing Agreement on Missile Systems
abstract: Russsia, without clear explanation to US, reportedly backs away from signing agreement on non-strategic missile defenses allowed under 1972 Antiballistic Misile Treaty (S)

headline: Treasury Report Will Oppose Federal Taxes on Internet Sales
abstract: Treasury Dept will publish draft report that outlines Clinton Administration's opposition to new Federal taxes on Internet but underscores its determination that global computer network not become a haven for tax evaders; report is intended to disclose Administration's general thinking on key issues affecting global electronic commerce and taxation, but it will not specifically address issues of state and local taxation on electronic transactions and on-line services, as is being considered by several states, including New York (M)

headline: On Eve of African Relief Talks, Aid Donors Argue Over Numbers
abstract: UN, relief agencies and donor countries dispute central question of just how many Rwandan refugees are still trapped in Zaire, on eve of meeting to plan international military mission; Rwandan Government insists all but 100,000 have walked home and rest are on their way; photo; map; UN refugee office says hundreds of thousands may be trapped by Hutu guerrillas, although it is not clear who among these people are from Rwanda, Burundi or Zaire itself; US Amb Robert E Gribbin 3d believes most of Rwandans who want to return home have done so; refugee advocates angrily disagree; US suspends aerial surveys after plane is apparently fired at; jockeying over numbers precedes meeting in Stuttgart over proposed mission to be led by Canada (M)

headline: Back to the Classroom, With a Wealth of Experience
abstract: Andrew Tokash article on his return to college as adult to advance his career; notes companies are allocating more funds for employee education and retraining (M)

headline: PHOENIX CANADA OIL OFFERS TO BUY BOX ENERGY
abstract: Phoenix Canada Oil Co to bid $239 million in cash or stock for Box Energy Corp (S)

headline: A 4.8% Rise For Morgan Stanley Profit
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group reports 4.8 percent rise in earnings for third quarter, to $219 million; net income for nine months ended Aug 31 was $793 million, compared with $422 million for comparable period year ago; separately, Morgan says its board acted on recommendation of chairman and chief executive, Richard B Fisher, and named John J Mack to take over as chief executive next June; Fisher will continue as chairman (S)

headline: Softbank Plans Stake In Software Maker
abstract: Softbank Corp to take 35 percent stake in Trendmicro for 3.5 million yen (about $31 million) (S)

headline: Insurer to Curb Sales Of Policies on Coasts
abstract: A large insurer plans to curtail sharply the sale of new homeowner policies in coastal areas in East Coast and Gulf of Mexico states. The decision by Nationwide Insurance would be the most extensive retrenchment by insurers reeling from losses caused by hurricanes, earthquakes and other huge disasters.     Business Day, page D1.

headline: USAir Will End Pacts With British Airways in March '97
abstract: USAir Group Inc says it will end code-sharing and frequent flier accords with British Airways PLC, effective Mar 29, 1997, because of British Air's proposed broad marketing accord with American Airlines; applies to Transportation Department to run own flights between London's Heathrow Airport and its gateways at Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Charlotte, NC (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Stora North America Corp., Stamford, Conn., to Anderson & Lembke, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first North American agency for the paper products company. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

headline: From Beer to Prozac, Perks Abound
abstract: List of fringe benefits offered by certain companies; Ben & Jerry's workers get three pints of ice cream a day, which are sometimes bartered around South Burlington for haircuts and baby-sitting; brewers give out free beer, Great American Backrub free massages and Eli Lilly workers free Lilly prescription drugs; photos (S)

headline: Face Lift at Apple
abstract: Analysis: critical question that confronts Gilbert F Amelio, new chairman of Apple Computer Inc, is whether computer marketplace will wait while he completes his planned three-year corporate 'transformation'; company is battling deepending industry perception that it is no longer an innovator; photo (M)

headline: U.S. AND NATO PLAN NEW BOSNIA FORCE
abstract: US and NATO begin preparations to field international peacekeeping force in Bosnia that would include at least 5,000 Americans at least through 1997; contingent would total 15,000 to 30,000 troops; Pres Clinton's aides say he will make no decision until after election, but US officials reportedly agree with other NATO countries that sizable ground force will be necessary to preserve tenuous stability (M)

headline: Nominees Raise Both Hope and Worry Abroad
abstract: Governments around the world formally welcome Pres Clinton's nominees for Secretary of State, Madeleine K Albright, and Secretary of Defense, William S Cohen; some hope that the new foreign policy and defense team may see things more their way, but many others fear they will not (M)

headline: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 issues climbs 77.46 points to close at 21,293.57 (S)

headline: MACERICH ACQUIRES THE VALLEY VIEW CENTER IN DALLAS
abstract: Macerich Co, real estate investment trust, has bought Valley View Center mall in Dallas, Tex, for $85.5 million; identity of seller is not disclosed (S)

headline: A Founder of Japan's Opposition Bolts Party
abstract: Japan's main opposition party crumbles a bit more as one of founding members, former Prime Min Tsutomu Hata, bolts to form new Sun Party (S)

headline: Judge Backs Extradition Of a Palestinian to Israel
abstract: Federal Judge Kimba Wood refuses to halt extradition of Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, political leader of militant Palestinian group Hamas, from US to Israel (S)

headline: Japanese Stocks Rise
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 399.19 points, or 1.94 percent, at 20,991.52 on Wednesday, Nov 6 (S)i

headline: New Chairman At Continental
abstract: Continental Airlines announces that David Bonderman has stepped aside as chairman, sign that the turnaround of the once-bankrupt carrier is complete; also says Bonderman will remain on the board and will head board's executive committee; succeeding Bonderman is carrier's president and chief executive, Gordon M Bethune (S)

headline: HOLLINGER BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN SOUTHAM OF CANADA
abstract: Hollinger International Inc completes acquisition of 8 million shares in Southam Inc for $160 million (Canadian), or $118 million (US), giving it majority stake in Canada's largest publisher of daily newspapers (S)

headline: Would-Be Briton Fights Government Inhospitality
abstract: Britain's highest appeals court rules that Mohamed al-Fayed, Egyptian-born owner of Harrod's department store, is being treated unfairly in his quest for British citizenship; Fayed has admitted bribing several legislators; photo (M)

headline: Guerrillas in Peru Release One of Six Hostage Envoys
abstract: Marxist guerrillas holding more than 100 hostages inside Japanese compound in Peru release one, Guatemalan Amb Jose Maria Argueta, hours after mysterious explosion rocks building in Lima; photo; authorities believe booby trap laid by guerrillas was set off; Argueta links his release to Guatemala's peace agreement to end its long guerrilla war; US is not directly involved in crisis now that all seven American hostages are out (S)

headline: Time Warner-Murdoch Feud Entangles MCI Satellite Plan
abstract: Time Warner Inc is taking its cable-television feud with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp to the skies; Time Warner pres Richard D Parsons, in letter to FCC, urges commission to withhold approval of MCI Communications' application for satellite license because MCI is being acquired by foreign company, British Telecommunications; letter contends FCC would open door to 'foreign ownership violation' if it grants license to MCI; execs familiar with situation say real target of Time Warner's request is not MCI but its partner, the News Corp (M)

headline: Former Ally of Mandela Plans To Form Rival Political Party
abstract: Bantu Holomisa, dismissed as deputy Cabinet minister in Government of South African Pres Nelson Mandela, says he will drop plans to regain standing in African National Congress and will begin exploring ways of creating rival political party; embarrassed Mandela Government by disclosing that Mandela accepted large campaign contribution in 1994 from casino operator currently under investigation for bribery (S)

headline: In a Lima Slum, No Support for Hostage Takers
abstract: Residents of Villa el Salvador, an impoverished shantytown not far from downtown Lima, express little support for the rebels holding hostages in the residence of the Japanese Ambassador to Peru, despite assertions by Tupac Amaru guerrillas that they are fighting for the poor; photos (M)

headline: Incumbent in Romania, a Leftist, Faces a Runoff
abstract: Romanian Pres Ion Iliescu faces runoff election on Nov 17 against Emil Constantinescu; with 50 percent of votes counted in Nov 3 Presidential election, Iliescu reportedly has 33 percent and Constantinescu 28 percent (M)

headline: I.B.M. and Toshiba Gain in Strong Global Market
abstract: Dataquest releases figures showing worldwide personal computer market grew by 16.3 percent in third quarter compared with year-earlier quarter; in global market, IBM and Toshiba showed sharpest increases and Apple Computer and Packard Bell the biggest losses in market share in US; US PC market grew 12.5 percent in quarter, with Intel and Intel-compatible segment of market up more than 20 percent (M)

headline: COMPUSERVE TO DISCARD AN ON-LINE SERVICE
abstract: Compuserve Corp says it is scrapping its eight-month-old Wow service, which was aimed at children and novice users of computer on-line services, because of its high costs (S)

headline: For Japan's Auto Makers, Windfall From Yen
abstract: Sharp fall in value of yen in last year has been providing earnings windfall to Japan's major automobile companies; owing largely to currency fluctuations, Toyota Motor Corp reports that net income for first half of year nearly quadrupled as autombile exports surge; Nissan Motor Co records first-half profit for first time in five years; Mitsubishi Motors Corp, however, reports 26.3% first-half decline in net income as its sale in its home market declined; earnings detailed (M)

headline: The Hard Part: Fixing the Errant Price Index
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on conclusion reached by special Congressional commission that tax bracket of every middle- and upper-income taxpayer has been overadjusted for inflation, and that tens of millions of Government beneficiaries have gotten larger monthly checks because Consumer Price Index has overstated changes in cost of living; flaws of Consumer Price Index as measure of cost of living are well understood, but no member of Congress is willing to support change in widespread practice of inflation indexing, fearing political outcry from constituents (M)

headline: Georges Duby, 77, a Scholar Of Medieval Societies, Is Dead
abstract: Georges Duby, one of world's greatest medieval scholars and member of Academie Francaise, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: Trade Deficit in Vietnam Climbs 80% to $4 Billion
abstract: Vietnam says its trade deficit has soared by more than 80 percent, to record $4 billion, in 1996; analysts note ballooning trade deficit occurred despite strong economic growth (S)

headline: Yeltsin Back in Kremlin
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin leaves intensive care hospital where he underwent heart bypass operation and returns to Kremlin hospital, making it easier for him to resume work (S)

headline: HOME HEALTH CARE COMPANY BOUGHT FOR $154.1 MILLION
abstract: Integrated Health Services Inc purchases First American Health Care of Georgia Inc for $154.1 million; under the accord, First American agrees to pay $255 million to settle charges that it defrauded Medicare; First American and two of its officers were convicted of Medicare fraud in Federal court in Savannah, Ga (S)

headline: Agency Switches By 2 Marketers
abstract: Great Brands of Europe shifts its North American account to Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG; ITT Hartford Group Inc names Arnold Communications to handle its account (S)

headline: S.E.C. to Ease Trading Rules
abstract: SEC is expected to adopt new rule on Wednesday to relax trading restrictions on stocks and bonds in days before companies sell new issues of securities to public (S)

headline: Motorola in Chinese Deal
abstract: Motorola Inc receives three contracts worth total of $108 million for equipment to expand cellular networks in Fujian province of China (S)

headline: Metromedia Says Its President Has Resigned
abstract: Metromedia International Group Inc announces resignation of John D Phillips, its president and chief executive; Phillips will be replaced by Stuart Subotnick, company's vice chairman (S)

headline: UPN Forms In-House Ad Unit
abstract: UPN, fledgling broadcast television network in Los Angeles, forms in-house advertising sales division (S)

headline: PHARMACIA TO SELL BIACORE TO INVESTORS
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc to sell Biacore AB to investors (S)

headline: Service Programs Are Promoted
abstract: Conde Nast Publications is joining with advertising agencies to promote Volunteers of America clothing drive for needy; Taco Bell Foundation is teaming with Boys and Girls Clubs of America to raise $15 million in five years for program to offer vocational, educational and recreational programs for teens; Saks Fifth Avenue retail chain is joining with Mercedes-Benz of North America to auction restored and new Mercedes-Benz cars to benefit Pediatric Aids Foundation (S)

headline: Serb Leader's Foes Persist, Hoping He Will Blink First
abstract: Serbian opposition, smarting from latest refusal by Government to overturn annulment of local elections, begins third week of protests; has been unable to organize strikes that would increase pressure on Government of Pres Slobodan Milosevic; protests, while continuing to draw large crowds in capital of Belgrade and other cities, appear to have peaked (M)

headline: Rite Aid to Buy Thrifty Payless for $1.3 Billion
abstract: Rite Aid Corp, second-largest druggist in the country, in an acceleration of the wave of consolidation sweeping the drugstore industry, says it will acquire Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc, 1,007-store West Coast chain, for $1.3 billion in stock and asssumption of debt; new entity will create national chain of 3,816 drugstores and annual revenue of more than $10 billion; map shows states with Rite Aid and Thrifty Payless stores (M)

headline: First Eagle Fund of America
abstract: Profile of Harold J Levy and David L Cohen, managers of First Eagle Fund of America; photo (S)

headline: MOBILE-HOME OPERATOR SWEETENS ITS BID
abstract: Manufactured Home Communities Inc offers to sweeten its bid for Chateau Properties Inc, which is the center of takeover battle; management of Chateau has already pledged to merge with ROC Communities Inc (S)

headline: Mickey Kantor, Gutsy Campaigner, Has Smoothed Clinton's Path
abstract: Mickey Kantor's tireless, enthusiastic campaigning for Pres Clinton, and strong advocacy of US trade positions, discussed; one day's appearances in Ohio related; photos; Kantor has been Commerce Secretary since death of Ron Brown last spring, although he relished more informal role as aggressive trade negotiator; some of his major achievements on behalf of US industries and Clinton Administration reviewed (M)

headline: Currency Talks Snag on German Demand
abstract: European Union finance ministers, meeting in Brussels, resolve most differences over pact to require low budget deficits after switch to a single currency, but important disagreement remains; disagreement is over German demands to severely limit circumstances in which country would be allowed to run excessive budget deficit; Germans want that to happen only if a severe recession occurs, defined as annual decline of 2% in gross domestic product; ministers agree to meet again in Dublin on Dec 12, in last-minute attempt to prepare agreement that could be ratified by European Union heads of Govt, who convene beginning the next day (M)

headline: Tokyo Suspect In Subway Raid Erupts in Court
abstract: Shoko Asahara, leader of Uam Shinrikyo religious cult who is accused of masterminding poison gas attack against Tokyo subways system in 1995, erupts in Tokyo court, taunting judge to execute him (S)

headline: NEC Is Selling Stock Holdings To Cover Losses
abstract: NEC Corp says it will take charge against earnings of $850 million to help bail out troubled subsidiary that makes consumer electronics equipment; NEC to sell $520 million of stocks it holds in other companies to help offset loss; NEC says it expects its net profit for year, which ends in March, to be roughly $520 million, same as was forecast in October; Mazda Motor Corp says it will invest additional $126 million to shore up its American importing and distribution arm, Mazda Motor of America; says this will raise its stake in its American distribution arm to 88 percent, up from 50 percent (M)

headline: The Bells Want F.C.C. to Make Providers Share Internet Costs
abstract: Regional telephone companies are asking FCC to require Internet service providers to pay network access charges, but the computer companies and Internet providers say changing the regulations would jeopardize the low monthly rates that have made the Internet accessible to millions of Americans; the Bells warns that Internet calls, which tend to last much longer than voice conversations, tie up network switches and cost them money because they must upgrade their systems to handle the demand; long-distance carriers and Internet providers accuse the Bells of exaggerating the threat of a network overload (M)

headline: Stocks Plunge Again as Dow Falls by 98.81
abstract: Stocks continue to plunge, with Dow Jones industrial average falling 98.81 points, or 1.5%, to 6,303.71; other indexes drop as well, with Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also off 1.5% and Nasdaq composite index down 0.8%; tables (M)

headline: 'The Big Man' Is a No-Show on the Non-Campaign Trail in Zambia
abstract: Kenneth D Kaunda ruled Zambia from independence in 1964 to his surpise defeat at polls in 1991 by Frederick Chiluba; now Kaunda is encouraging voters to boycott elections because he has been kicked off ballot by Chiluba's party, which amended Constitution to prevent Kaunda's inclusion as candidate; country is significantly poorer than it was when Chiluba took office, but Western diplomats blame Kaunda for this; they say he squandered country's prosperous copper-based economy with his pioneering exercise in African socialism, which was a flop (M)

headline: L'eggs Ends Ties With Cordiant Unit
abstract: L'eggs Products unit of Sara Lee Corp, Winston-Salem, NC, unexpectedly ends 25-year relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, by naming DDB Needham Chicago unit of Omnicom Group as agency of record for creative and media planning assignments (Advertising column) (S)

headline: AMRESCO BUYING MOST OF QUALITY MORTGAGE
abstract: Amresco Inc agrees to purchase most of assets of Quality Mortgage USA Inc for $65 million in cash (S)

headline: North Korea's Heir Seems in Charge, but a Grim Winter Looms
abstract: Diplomats and other analysts increasingly say North Korea's Kim Jong Il, who has not assumed titles of head of state or of ruling party since death of father Kim Il Sung more than two years ago, appears to be running country and consolidating his authority; say, for all of country's problems and despite speculation its is near collapse, it could stagger on indefinitely (M)

headline: Northeast Brazil to Get Korean Auto Plant
abstract: Asia Motors Co of South Korea plans to build $500 million assembly plant in northeastern Brazil; Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso says plan will lead to greater industrialization of region (S)

headline: Heating Oil Price Plunges On Report of Jump in Supply
abstract: Heating oil prices tumble on New York Mercantile Exchange after report that showed sharp gain in inventories; corn and soybeans fall, while copper rises (M)

headline: Financial Services Acquisition Talks
abstract: Fortis, Belgian-Dutch financial services company, says it is in talks with ABN Amro Holding NV about buying Mees Pierson NV; analysts estimate Mees Pierson would cost $1.2 billion (S)

headline: U.N. Shift on Rwandans A Bow to 'New Realities'
abstract: United Nations officials concede their support for recent expulsion of Rwandan refugees from Tanzanian camps is departure from longstanding opposition to forced refugee repatriation and bow to 'new realities'; cite financial pressure from United States to close camps, which cost some $2 million a day (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Casino America Inc says its Isle of Capri unit had laid off 112 employees at Bossier City, La, and another 9 workers at its Lake Charles riverboats after disappointing second-quarter earnings (S)

headline: CHUBB PLANNING TO SELL ITS LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: Chubb Corp to sell its Chubb Life Insurance Co of America unit (S)

headline: Charges Dismissed in Silicon Valley Trade Secrets Case
abstract: Santa Cruz County, Calif, District Attorney drops 1993 charges against Symantec Corp chairman Gordon E Eubanks and former Symantec aide Eugene Wang involving trade secrets of rival software firm Borland International Inc; cites job shifting between firms by witnesses, diminished value of secrets and changing legal standards; Borland had charged Wang disclosed secrets to Eubanks before leaving Borland post to join Symantec; continues civil suit (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Rise in Dow Jones industrial average noted in relation to US election cycles

headline: Humana to Trim Staff as Much as 5% as Health Care Profits Sag
abstract: Humana Inc will cut 700 to 900 jobs, or up to 5 percent of its work force, in 1997 as it struggles to reduce costs and stem decline in earnings; will take pre-tax charge of $15 million in fourth quarter to cover severance payments and other costs of the cuts (M)

headline: Sears of Britain Discusses Catalogue Sale
abstract: Sears P.L.C., a British department store and retail chain operator unrelated to Sears, Roebuck & Company, said yesterday that it was in ''advanced discussions'' to sell its catalogue shopping business, Freemans, to the Littlewoods Organization. Sears has sold several businesses and properties in the last two years to deal with falling profit, sluggish sales and battered margins.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Melville Corp names Thomas M Ryan to position of vice chairman and chief operating officer; Ryan will also continue as president and chief executive of Melville's CVS drugstore unit; Railcorp Holdings Inc names Joe R Micheletto chief executive and president in a move to reduce number of corporate officers; Micheletto will also continue as chief financial officer; he succeeds Richard A Pearce, who resigned as president and co-chief executive last month (S)

headline: Pope to Meet Castro as a Possible Prelude to Papal Trip to Cuba
abstract: Vatican announces that Pope John Paul II will meet with Fidel Castro, suggesting that trip to Cuba by Pope is under active discussion; meeting itself, requested by Castro after his arrival in Rome to attend World Food Summit, will mark important milepost in tentative dialogue between Roman Catholic Church and one of world's last Communist strongholds (M)

headline: Exchanges Discuss Revisions Of Rules on Market Plunges
abstract: Chicago Stock Exchange aide Allan A Bretzer says nation's stock exchanges discuss easing so-called circuit breakers that halt stock trading if share prices plunge to reflect rise in stock prices since rules were adopted after 1987 crash; says they weigh 30-minute trading halt after 350-point plunge in Dow Jones industrial average, up from current 250-point drop, and second halt of one hour if average drops 550 points for day, up from 400 points (S)

headline: Compaq Computer Enters Work Station Fray
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp introduces its first line of work stations, with five models priced from $4,300 to $10,200; Compaq says work stations are available immediately; Compaq's move into work stations could help company identify itself as a computer systems company (L)

headline: IRON MOUNTAIN BUYS 3 DATA-STORAGE COMPANIES
abstract: Iron Mountain Inc is buying three smaller data-management companies for total of $26.4 million as part of expansion strategy; Iron Mountain will purchase Mohawk Business Records Storage, International Records Storage and Retrieval Service Inc and Security Archives Corp (S)

headline: Virtues of the 403(b)
abstract: David R Blask letter on 403(b) plans at nonprofit organizations (S)

headline: Be prepared to pay a lot more, and pay in advance, to be in Hong Kong next summer.
abstract: Business travel news roundup; high cost of traveling to Hong Kong in period just before and after colony reverts to Chinese rule on July 1 discussed; airlines and hotels are demanding high, nonrefundable deposits; Sabena offers new passenger accommodations on daily flights between New York and Brussels (M)

headline: Dollar Off vs. Yen as Traders Doubt Commitment to Strength
abstract: Currency Markets column; dollar falls against yen, touching seven-week low, amid lingering doubts that Japan and United States are committed to stronger dollar (M)

headline: Lotus Development Plans New Software for Internet
abstract: Lotus Development Corp says it will strip out some crucial technolgy behind its popular Notes software and sell it as separate product to give people much greater ability to exchange data over Internet; Lotus calls this software the Weblicator; it has ability to retrieve information from World Wide Web, manipulate it on personal computer while not connected to network, and then synchronize those changes with originals the next time a network connection is made (M)

headline: E. W. BLANCH TO TAKE A CHARGE TO EARNINGS
abstract: E W Blanch Holdings will take fourth-quarter pretax charge of $22.75 million to reorganize its wholesale insurance brokerage operations in San Antonio (S)

headline: Canal Plus Revenue Rose 10.8% in 9 Months
abstract: Canal Plus SA, Europe's biggest pay television company, says that its sales rose 10.8% in first nine months of year as subscriptions maintained their strong growth, especially in France; sales put at 8.2 billion French francs ($1.6 billion) (S)

headline: Nine-Month Profit Rises By 24%, ING Reports
abstract: Dutch banking and insurance company ING Groep NV says that its nine-month profit rose by 24%, to 2.34 billion guilders ($1.4 billion) (S)

headline: With winter a whisper away, the question is how much vitamin C should a person take each day?
