abstract: Roc Ordman receives patent for vitamin C supplement of 500 milligrams taken twice a day; Ordman says his research showed that dosage was amount body can best absorb and retain; Neose Technologies Inc and Rockefeller University receive patent for method of producing enzymes used to string chains of carbohydrates together to add to food or administer as drugs and bolster immune system; Andrew Dibner receives patent for device that answers phone and diverts call to answering machine or fax before bell chimes (M)

headline: South Korea's Immovable Objects
abstract: Analysis of impasse between South Korean workers, who are striking to oppose new laws that make layoff easiers and prolong ban on labor unions, and Pres Kim Young Sam, who once championed workers; many workers say Kim has betrayed democratic movement; photos (M)

headline: Levi Strauss Hopes to Match Performance of Dockers
abstract: Levi Strauss & Co struggles to duplicate stunning success of its Dockers, casual pants line that became billion-dollar brand; has introduced new Slates men's dress pants after discontinuing Dress Dockers last May; backs new line with $20 million marketing budget in bid to establish line as market leader; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Bonds Drop Sharply; Yield Up to 6.62%
abstract: Treasury securities prices drop sharply; 30-year bond falls 1 15/32, to 98 13/32, to yield 6.62 percent (M)

headline: Do I Hear 400,000 Miles? For Frequent Fliers, New Ways to Splurge
abstract: Airlines offer growing variety of fantasy trips, other exotic awards in exchange for frequent-flier miles; seek to spice up programs for longtime frequent fliers weary of routine awards; photos (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Says 9-Month Profit Rose 9%
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG reports Jan-Sept earnings rose 9 percent, to 1.53 billion marks ($2.33 billion); expects fourth-quarter results in line with rest of year (S)

headline: WEAK SALES ANNOUNCEMENT SENDS UNIFY SHARES TUMBLING
abstract: Shares of Unify Corp fall 38 percent after company forecasts a second-quarter loss; Unify expects second-quarter revenues to come in at $7.2 million; it expects $1.8 million in losses for the period; shares close down $3.625, to $5.75 (S)

headline: U.S. Pushes Bigger NATO Despite Qualms on Russia
abstract: US pushes ahead with plan to bring several former Soviet allies into NATO in 1999, despite new uncertainties about possible Russian reaction and qualms of some NATO allies (M)

headline: MCI PLANS VENTURE WITH SYLVAN LEARNING
abstract: MCI Communications Corp will invest $10 million in 'distance learning' partnership with Sylvan Learning Systems Inc, which offers tutoring services to schoolchildren and administers standardized educational tests over computer networks (S)

headline: True North, back in the expansion mode, plans to buy and take public an interactive marketing unit.
abstract: True North Communications, world's seventh-largest advertising agency company, with billings estimated at $7.5 billion, says it will combine TN Technologies, a unit that specializes in interactive marketing communications, with Modem Media Advertising LP, a privately held shop in Westport, Conn, that creates marketing programs for media like CD-ROM's, the Internet and interactive television; True North says shares in combined operations, which will retain TN Technologies name, are to be sold in initial public offering (L)

headline: Speedo Maker Drops Line Of Skiwear
abstract: Authentic Fitness Corp, owner of Speedo sports apparel trademark in North America, says it is abandoning skiwear business, shuttering its outlet stores and restating its second- and third-quarter results to include additional reserves to cover potential losses on inventory and accounts receivable; charges will push fourth-quarter earnings into the red, with loss of $36.1 million after income tax benefit of $6.9 million; excluding charge and merger fees, company lost $13.2 million in quarter; this compares with profit of $6.98 million in year-earlier fourth quarter; many of company's problems relate to bankruptcy of Herman's Sporting Goods, a major buyer of Authentic products (M)

headline: Technology And Travails Of Dow Jones
abstract: Dow Jones & Co is hurt by troubles at its Telerate unit; Telerate faces increasing competition in its core business of supplying government bond prices to traders and lags behind both Reuters Holdings PLC and Bloomberg LP in making investments in new computer software that enables dealers to quickly convert market data into analytic programs used to spot trading opportunities; Telerate's troubles loom large at Dow Jones because it has become far more important to the company's performance than its flagship newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, whose earnings are rising now along with those of other newspapers (M)

headline: Marketing campaigns go digital to cultivate cyberfriendly personas for old-line products.
abstract: Advertising column notes new trend among marketers to adopt language and imagery of high technology for the brand names of products that have nothing to do with computers; goal is to create positive perceptions among consumers who prize any and all things digital; photo of ad for Revlon's Virtual Violet cosmetics (M)

headline: Filling the 'Politically Incorrect' Gap
abstract: Comedy Central, cable station with reputation for sharp-edged humor, seeks to keep its edgy image now that its most popular program, Politically Incorrect With Bill Maher, is moving to ABC; Comedy Central's new flagship is called The Daily Show, featuring former sports anchor Craig Kilborn, who reads satirical news stories based on day's events and conducts interviews with guests; photo (M)

headline: Games Wooing an Internet Audience
abstract: On-line games are offered by a number of companies, including Crossover Technologies, Interactive Imaginations, Sega, Maxis, Total Entertainment and Mpath Interactive; they struggle to meet players' expectations while contending with the restrictions of slow modems and connections littered with E-mail; drawings (M)

headline: Sony Mulls a Public Sale of Entertainment Assets
abstract: Sony Corp president Nobuyuki Idei, at news briefing on newly completed overhaul of troubled Sony Pictures Entertainment, confirms retaining CS First Boston to advise firm on future strategy, including possible public offering of entertainment assets; denies planning to sell any division; Sony Pictures head John Calley comments on plans (M)

headline: OM GROUP ACQUIRING U.S. INDUSTRIES' SCM SUBSIDIARY
abstract: OM Group to acquire SCM Metal Products Inc, Research Triangle Park, NC, unit of US Industries, for $122 milllion in cash (S)

headline: Year After Rabin Fell, Israel Is No Closer to Unity
abstract: Israelis observe first anniversary of Yitzhak Rabin's assassination according to Jewish lunar calender; they seem overwhelmed and troubled by deep division in their society exposed by slaying, which seems to have only deepened in past year; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Encourages Analysts To Cut Earnings Estimates
abstract: General Motors Corp, citing variety of marketing, sales and production costs, encourages analysts to reduce their estimates of the company's fourth-quarter earnings; says decline of Japanese yen and German mark in currency markets over last 18 months, along with introduction by foreign auto makers of cheaper new models, has narrowed premium in prices that Americans used to pay for foreign cars; most analyusts leave their estimates of 1997 earnings unchanged, saying that they had been fairly conservative (M)

headline: Report Calls for Recasting Corporate Boards
abstract: Market Place: tough new standards for corporate America's board rooms is suggested in sweeping report issued by panel of prominent executives and business experts assembled by National Assn of Corporate Directors; report suggests limiting number of boards an individual should serve on to six or less, and puts onus for deciding board's duties and culture on outside directors, rather than on chief executive who commonly controls board practices; disgruntled shareholders have clamored for better boards for years; panelists say directors will be swayed by report's sheer logic and weight of names who signed it, including Alan J Patricof, venture capitalist, and John J Phelan, former chairman of New York Stock Exchange; Ira M Millstein, lawyer, headed panel; photo (M)

headline: Perry Denies Pledging to Keep U.S. Troops in Bosnia in 1997
abstract: US Defense Sec William Perry denies committing American peacekeeping troops to Bosnia through 1997 (S)

headline: Boeing to Buy McDonnell Douglas
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Boeing Co., the world's largest commercial aircraft maker, said Sunday it would buy its long-time rival McDonnell Douglas Corp. for $13.3 billion in stock, creating the world's largest integrated aerospace company.

headline: DIARY
abstract: Week's financial and economic diary

headline: The Two Faces Of Texaco
abstract: Article reviews longstanding complaints of racial discrimination at Texaco, based on thousands of pages of sealed court records obtained by The New York Times from discrimination lawsuit; company officially has antidiscrimination and affirmative action policies in place, but principles can be impotent because midlevel or senior managers operate by their own rules, with almost no corporate oversight; employee accounts of bias quoted in detail; photos; graphs showing dearth of blacks in highest levels; American oil companies, which grew up selling largely to other white industries, have always been resistant to minorities, no company more so than Texaco; company, founded in 1901 by Joseph Cullinan, prided itself on being industry bad boy for decades; diversity consultant Lawrence Otis Graham says petroleum industry has done the least of any industries, and Texaco is most laggardly of all with regard to women and minorities; determination of new chairman, Peter I Bijur, to reverse course is acknowledged even by harshest critics (L)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN AGREES TO BUY BAY MEADOWS
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc agrees to buy California Jockey Club and Bay Meadows Operating Co for $195 million in cash or stock; shares in Bay Meadows and California Jockey are traded as single unit (S)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Income Is Down 4.4% in Quarter
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co reports earnings for its fourth quarter were down 4.4 percent, to $648 million, from year earlier; says revenues rose 11.8 percent, to $10.15 billion; says latest fourth-quarter results suffer partly from comparison with extremely strong period last year; notes order growth rebounded in quarter, after sluggish orders in third quarter (M)

headline: U.S. Chooses 2 to Develop New Rocket
abstract: Air Force selects Lockheed Martin Corp and McDonnell Douglas Corp to develop prototypes for its next family of rockets; goal is to produce new single-engine missiles to replace two-stage Titan, Atlas and Delta missiles (M)

headline: A book tells how the effective and often imitated ad campaign for Absolut vodka has fueled sales.
abstract: Advertising column describes Richard W Lewis's book devoted to advertising campaign for Absolut vodka; book is one of few ever devoted to creation and duration of campaign for single product; but Absolut's advertising is among most effective, most honored and most imitated in marketing; it was devised by TBWA Chiat/Day and a predecessor shop; book is called Absolut Book and it includes reprints of 500 ads for the vodka (M)

headline: 3 SENIOR EXECUTIVES OF HILTON HOTELS RESIGN
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp says that it accepted resignations of three senior executives whose conduct delayed gambling license for its Kansas City, Missouri, riverboat casino; Hilton is awarded preliminary license after company informs Missouri Gaming Commission that executives had resigned; they are Raymond Avansino, F Michael O'Brien and Mark Rousseau (S)

headline: Snapshot Without a Negative
abstract: Former Motorola Inc chief executive George M C Fisher, who left firm in late 1993 with big reputation for top job at Eastman Kodak, continues to win kudos for his tenure at Motorola and his work at Kodak despite Motorola's recent reverses; photo (M)ï

headline: BASF 3d-Quarter Profit Down Amid Revamping
abstract: BASF AG says its pretax profit fell 2.3 percent in third quarter, to $697 million, due to costs of its reorganization efforts (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Personal Income Nov.    TUESDAY  None    WEDNESDAY  None    THURSDAY  None.    FRIDAY  Durable-Goods Orders Nov.  Weekly Jobless Claims

headline: 5 Seated in Security Council After Intensive Manuevering
abstract: United Nations member countries, after unusually intense campaign for five rotating seats on Security Council, elect Costa Rica, Japan, Kenya, Portugal and Sweden; their two-year terms begin on Jan 1 (M)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks trade lower in Japan on Nov 11; Nikkei index of 225 issues is down 135.96 points, at 21,065.08 (S)

headline: RISCORP CONSIDERS A SALE OF THE COMPANY
abstract: Riscorp Inc says it will consider sale of company in light of recent plunge in its stock price and disappointing earnings (S)

headline: It's a time of uncertainty: just how much merger can the industry get away with?
abstract: Stocks of all independent radio companies have retreated since Justice Dept blocked American Radio Systems Corp's purchase of two radio stations; radio executives are upset about seeming inconsistency of recent decisions regarding radio acquisitions; Justice Dept says it will make market-by-market decisions, and will even look into existing joint sales agreements, arrangements in which one station agrees to sell advertising time for another station, to see if they give companies too much influence with advertisers; graph (M)

headline: Reader's Digest To Ogilvy & Mather
abstract: Reader's Digest Assn selects Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide to handle worldwide advertising (S)

headline: Taking a Shine to Rust-Oleum
abstract: Outlook for investing in RPM Inc, maker of industrial coatings, sealants and specialty chemicals, discussed; graphs (M)é

headline: Bonds Falter On Strong Housing Data
abstract: Credit Markets column; prices of Government securities drop following housing report that is stronger than expected, but bonds partly erase some early losses and manage to end above day's lows; graph shows Treasury yield curve (M)

headline: A Huge Insurance Merger: AXA and UAP in France
abstract: French insurance giant, AXA, says it is buying rival, UAP, in stock swap worth $9.02 billion that would create largest insurer in the world in terms of assets under management; combination would produce a company with $445 billion in assets under management, compared with $355 billion in managed assets by Nippon Life of Tokyo, now the world leader (L)

headline: Zaire's Leader Names General to Lead Armed Forces Out of Chaos
abstract: Zaire Pres Mobuto Sese Siko, returned from cancer treatment in Europe, announces changes in armed forces aimed at restoring Governmenet control over rebellious eastern regions (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The New Pentagon Reality Behind McDonnell's Loss   When the Pentagon dropped McDonnell Douglas and chose Boeing to compete with Lockheed Martin to build new multi-purpose combat aircraft, it was ushering out the age of the military-industrial complex.    With its decision on the Joint Strike Fighter, the Pentagon was trying to encourage companies that do not rely so heavily on military contracts. News analysis. $(Page D2.$)    Support for Texaco Station Owners   Despite calls for a boycott, black motorists continued to patronize Texaco stations, with many saying that station owners should not be punished because of the comments of some corporate executives while discussing a bias suit brought against the company. $(B10.$)    Sudden Departure at Apple   When the executive in charge of Apple Computer's troubled operating systems division resigned, he raised new questions about the company's ability to solve its problems and differentiate its operating software from Microsoft's Windows 95. $(D9.$)    Dueling Standards for Cellular   Primeco Personal Communications has made good on its pledge to introduce its new type of wireless telephone service, known as P.C.S., last week in 15 metropolitan markets including Chicago and Miami. The Primeco rollout was the first United States market test in a battle between an established AT&T technology and a newer format upon which Primeco, Sprint Spectrum and most other P.C.S. providers are staking their futures. $(D9.$)    Outsourcing and the Valujet Crash   Representatives of Valujet and its maintenance contractor, Sabretech, which blame each other for the crash of a Valujet airliner last May, will appear in National Transportation Safety Board hearings that are expected to be confrontational. $(A12.$)    Comdex Unleashes New Technology   Seven computer companies, including Casio, Compaq, Hewlett-Packard and Philips, are introducing paperback-sized computers that run on Microsoft's Windows CE operating software at Comdex, the trade show. $(D8.$)    The show floor at Comdex can be a madhouse, attracting people who want to see and be seen -- and party, gossip and collect freebies. $(D9.$)    U.S.-Britain Telecommunications   The United States and Britain are moving rapidly to relax the remaining restrictions on phone competition into and out of their countries. The changes are likely to further reduce prices for calls between the countries -- the most heavily used international communications pathway. $(D8.$)    Finding New Life in Enhanced CD's   Enhanced CD's record digital music, graphics and video on the same disk, but have not taken off. Now more creative material from an independent recording label may do the trick. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. $(D9.$)    Fading Sources of African News   For in-depth coverage of crises in Africa like the current troubles in Zaire and Rwanda, people have depended on smaller, African-focused publications. But three sources of African news -- Africa Report, Africa News Service and Africa Notes -- are defunct, or about to be. $(D10.$)    Measuring an Event's Worth   When Federal Express paid $2.5 million to sponsor the Orange Bowl, and wanted to know whether it was getting its money's worth, it turned to the Bonham Group, a firm that evaluates the amount of exposure a sponsor gets. Advertising. $(D13.$)    New Sheriff in Broadcast Town   The defeat of Senator Larry Pressler likely sets John McCain up as head of the Senate Commerce Committee. Broadcasters may find him less compatible than his predecessor. Mark Landler: Broadcasting. $(D10.$)

headline: Growth Pace Picks Up In German Economy
abstract: Economics Ministry reports gross domestic product in Germany expanded significantly in third quarter, after rising 1.5 percent in the second quarter (S)

headline: Investigation Under Way In British Takeover Bid
abstract: British regulators investigate big fee paid to brokerage firm, BZW, by Northern Electric PLC days before American company, Calenergy, won majority stake in hostile bid (S)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: Telex Communication Group hires Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to study options, including possible sale of company or public stock offering (S)

headline: U.S. READY TO KEEP A FORCE IN BOSNIA 18 MONTHS LONGER
abstract: Pres Clinton says United States is prepared to keep thousands of troops in Bosnia for additional 18 months, dropping his commitment to end deployment this year; says rebuilding Bosnia's economic and political life is taking longer than anticipated, and follow-on force is needed to protect fragile peace there; Congress is out of session, so reaction on Capitol Hill is muted; but critics of original Bosnia deployment had said Administration had no clear exit strategy and would be bogged down in Bosnia for longer than the year Pres Clinton had promised; photos (M)

headline: NETANYAHU HOLDS TALK WITH ARAFAT FOR THREE HOURS
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat meet face to face at White House and will meet again on Wednesday; White House calls meeting constructive, but officials refuse to provide details about private conversation, which does not involve American officials; Pres Clinton, after separate meetings with Israelis and Palestinians, pulls them all together before they head into lunch in White House Library; photos of Arafat, King Hussein of Jordan, Clinton and Netanyahu (M)

headline: Curb Your Briefcase
abstract: Readers asked to tell what they really keep in their briefcases; drawing (S)

headline: SBS TECHNOLOGIES TO ACQUIRE BIT 3 COMPUTER
abstract: SBS Technologies Inc to buy Bit 3 Computer Corp for $24 million (S)

headline: McCann-Erickson Hires Head of New Unit
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York says it will hire Stan Rapp, longtime direct marketing agency executive, to head new worldwide direct-marketing unit as chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: Stocks Set Record Again As the Dow Passes 6,200
abstract: Stocks set records for second day, helped by optimistic forecast for fourth-quarter sales from Intel Corp and better-than-expected sale of 30-year bonds; Dow Jones industrial average passes 6,200 for first time, rising 28.33 to 6,206.04; Standard & Poor's 500 Index rises 3.06 to 727.65 (M)

headline: Ontario Doctors Reach Agreement on Fees
abstract: Doctors in Ontario, Canada, reach tentative agreement on fees with provincial government that would end monthlong protest that interrupted medical care in country's largest province (S)

headline: Shift Planned In Network By Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp is set to reintroduce its revamped Microsoft Network on-line information service; MSN will look and feel more like television in bid to attract broader mass audience; is reining in initially ambitious plans to expand abroad, and is now focusing on North America, Japan, Australia and Europe (M)

headline: Prodigy Executive Takes Post at G.E.
abstract: General Electric Co says it has hired Prodigy Inc's chief operating officer, William J Lansing, as head of corporate business development (S)

headline: N.A.S.D. Panel Says Broker Manipulated Stock Trading
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers market surveillance committee charges Sterling Foster & Co, president Adam R Lieberman and other principals manipulated trading and used 'boiler room' sales practices to generate huge illicit profits from three small stock offerings; complaint is part of crackdown on brokerage firms NASD thinks abuse Nasdaq's small-cap market; complaint involves initial stock offerings of Advanced Voice Technologies Inc, Com/Tech Communications Technologies Inc and Embryo Development Corp; firm denies charges (M)

headline: 4 Marketers Change Agencies
abstract: Advertising agency changes by American Portable Telecom, Go-Jo Industries Inc, Princess Marcella Borghese Co and Aer Lingus noted (S)

headline: Log on, sign in, push key marked 'absurd.' Monty Python spoofs computer-speak.
abstract: Description of new CD-ROM game, Monty Python and the Holy Grail, which features Python-esque looniness; drawing (M)

headline: On Catwalks: Black, Male and Muscular
abstract: WASHINGTON—  It's too early, and perhaps too optimistic, to say that black men are defining this fashion moment's standard of masculine beauty. But black male models have risen in prominence on the runway and in advertising.

headline: Lower-priced co-ops sell again in once-troubled buildings in boroughs outside Manhattan.
abstract: Some developers who have taken over troubled buildings in boroughs outside Manhattan are selling apartments again; sales of affordably priced cooperatives are being nudged along because housing market in general and Manhattan's in particular are improving, while rents are rising and mortgage interest rates are stable (M)

headline: Shares of ENI Climb After Sale
abstract: Shares in Italy's state-controlled ENI SpA rise on Milan stock exchange after second stock sale; sale of 14 percent of ENI is Italy's largest privatization (S)

headline: Many Airlines Not Worried By Boeing-McDonnell Deal
abstract: Airline executives say they do not oppose merger of Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp, which would shrink number of commercial jet makers to two from three; American Airlines chairman Robert L Crandall and United Airlines aide Jake Brace comment (M)

headline: Italy Regains Place in Line For Europe's Currency Club
abstract: Italian lira inches closer to goal posts set for first currencies eligible for European monetary union in 1999; at two-day meeting in Brussels, Italy was forced to settle for exchange rate that pegged lira at level slightly stronger than many Italian business leaders wanted; valuation might hamper Italy's recent boom in exports, but Government headed by Prime Min Romano Prodi has set currency union as its top priority, and getting lira back into the fold was victory of sorts for Italy (M)

headline: Foreign Investment Surges in Russia
abstract: Russia reports foreign investments in 1996 exceeded $11 billion as of October (S)

headline: Softbank Profit Lifted By Software Sales
abstract: Softbank Corp says its profit rose 77.8 percent in six months ended Sept 30, to $75.32 million; sales rose 46.1 percent (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Checkfree Corp sells its securities certificate and accounting software subsidiary to Sungard Data Systems Inc for $20 million (S)

headline: Homestake Bids $2.3 Billion for Santa Fe Pacific Gold
abstract: Homestake Mining Co offers $2.3 billion for Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corp, outbidding Newmont Mining Corp by nearly $300 million; Newmont is expected to sweeten bid; graph (M)

headline: Rival Bid Disclosed in Standard Federal Sale
abstract: Standard Federal Bancorp reportedly spurned higher takeover offer from Charter One Financial Inc when it accepted ABN-Amro Holding NV's $59-a-share cash offer; Charter One's chairman, Charles John Koch, has sent letter to Standard Federal's board, urging it to reconsider and offering $60.47 for every Standard Federal share; disclosure of Charter One's letter could complicate transaction with ABN-Amro that was expected to gain easy approval; Standard Federal board is expected to discuss letter in meeting today (M)

headline: Blame Men, Not Allah, Islamic Feminists Say
abstract: Sisters In Islam, budding feminist movement, has sprung up in Malaysia, which is seeking to define itself as liberal role model in Islamic world; group is at center of debate over putting new domestic violence law into effect; is lobbying for universal enforcement, arguing that human beings, and not Islam, have failed to understand Allah's intentions and are to blame for nation's oppression of women; photo (M)

headline: AT&T's Romancing of Its New President
abstract: AT&T Corp retained two top seach firms in its hunt for new president, practice used only once before, with top job at IBM in 1993; AT&T's search started just as it ended: in secret, long before outside world even knew that it needed new No 2 executive; AT&T asked Dennis C Carey at Spencer Stuart and Paul C McCartney at Korn/Ferry International to each make list of candidates for job; John R Walter, chairman of R R Donnelley & Sons, was on both lists; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Obstruction Charge For Ex-Texaco Official  The former Texaco executive who recorded senior company officers belittling minority groups and planning the destruction of documents that were demanded in a discrimination lawsuit was charged with obstruction of justice. Those tapes set off a furor over the company's relations with minorities, and led to Texaco's record settlement of the bias suit last week.     Richard A. Lundwall, who until August was a senior finance executive at Texaco, had given the tapes to plaintiffs' lawyers in the suit. Mr. Lundwall was the first Texaco executive to be charged in the case. $(Page A1.$)    Housing Starts Drop 5.1%  Housing starts fell by 5.1 percent in October, the second consecutive month of diminished activity. The drop, which surprised analysts, raised questions about whether economic growth might be faltering. $(D2.$)    I.B.M. Up Again, Fueling Market  The Dow industrials surged 50.69 to 6,397.60, the ninth new high in 10 sessions, as money managers scurried to add I.B.M. shares to their portfolios. I.B.M. jumped 7 3/8, to 154 1/8, and other leading technology stocks also rose steeply. Broader measures gained, as well, with the Nasdaq composite rising 8.05, to 1,262.62. $(D6.$)    Treasury prices advanced, pushing the yield on the long bond down to 6.43 percent. $(D16.$)    G.M.'s New Models in Demand  General Motors has some popular new models this fall, but under its manufacturing schedule the new cars and mini-vans are arriving in dealerships in a trickle, not a flood, to the consternation of analysts and dealers. $(D3.$)    Investment Adviser in Guilty Plea  Teresa V. Fernandez, an investment adviser working from her home in Tenafly, N.J., pleaded guilty to fraud; prosecutors said she had stolen more than $65 million from clients. The S.E.C. also filed a complaint. $(D3.$)    Utility Turns to Power Marketer  Seeking big cost cuts, Oglethorpe Power, a big Georgia utility, is turning to an outside power-marketing company, LG & E Energy, to supply half its electricity needs. $(D2.$)    Intel and E.P.A. in Novel Plan  The Environmental Protection Agency granted a huge Intel chip-making plant in Arizona extraordinary operating flexibility; in exchange Intel pledged to do better than the law requires in controlling pollution. $(A18.$)    Three Retailers Exceed Forecasts  Dayton Hudson's third-quarter earnings more than doubled, and two other retail groups, Limited Inc. and Ann Taylor, also turned in better-than-expected earnings, on strong demand for new women's fashions. $(D16.$)    Plan for Crash Notification  Seven major airlines in the United States and the State Department signed an agreement to provide speedier notification for the families of those killed or injured in international air disasters. $(A1.$)    Robert Citron Is Sentenced  Robert Citron, the former treasurer of Orange County, Calif., was sentenced to one year in jail and fined $100,000 for his role in the county's bankruptcy. In addition, he must do 1,000 hours of community service and faces five years of probation once he leaves jail. $(D2.$)    Sumitomo Loses $1.9 Billion  Sumitomo announced a $1.9 billion loss for the first six months of its fiscal year, its first loss in its 77-year history, as $2.6 billion in losses from unauthorized copper trading more than offset gains elsewhere. $(D4.$)

headline: U.S. Negotiating With Ex-Official In Texaco Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors and lawyers for Richard A Lundwall, former Texaco executive, are negotiating to avoid trial on first criminal charges resulting from company scandal stemming from racial discrimination case; case reviewed (M)

headline: Women Pass Milestone in the Board Room
abstract: Catalyst reports women held over 10 percent of directors' seats at nation's 500 largest firms for first time ever in 1996; finds rate of increase of female directors has declined; says only 11 of 1,216 inside directors are women, five of them related to chief executive or controlling family; 83 percent of firms now have female director, up from 69 percent in 1993; graphs; table (M)

headline: GULFMARK TO SPIN OFF SOME ASSETS AND SELL THE REST
abstract: Gulfmark International Inc says it plans to spin off to its stockholders all assets of its marine energy transportation business, and after spinoff it will sell its remaining assets to Energy Ventures Inc for $107 million in stock (S)

headline: New Issues '96: Euphoria, Then Ennui
abstract: New-issues stock market, which earlier this year saw overenthusiastic buyers bidding prices up to astonishing heights, has faltered; some investors are turning up their noses and shopping elsewhere, while others, sharp-eyed, are rooting around for bargains; tables; photos (L)`

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Aura of Sham Transactions
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files administrative proceedings against Aura Systems and its chief, Zvi Kurtzman, and two former financial officials of company, accusing them of violating securities laws by failing to disclose real nature of certain transactions in its financial statements (S)

headline: Weighing Demand and Figuring Supply
abstract: Purveyors of new type of software, called supply chain management, say they can help business eliminate or limit some common human errors; their modus operandi is to load computers up with details about capacity, production scheduling, orders and transportation options, and let machines use that data to project where, when and how much product must be made; Monte Zweben, president of Red Pepper Software, leader in this emerging software field, says his software assesses demand and optimizes supply to meet that demand; such services are expensive, but corporate America sees it as bearable price for systems that can help slash inventories in half and reduce by two-thirds the time between taking an order and shipping a product; analysts say the $300 million supply chain managemet business has plenty of room to grow; photo (M)

headline: Finance Briefs
abstract: Debt     Citicorp, New York, is selling $200 million of subordinated notes due in 2011 through Bear, Stearns & Co. The notes are priced at 99.233 to yield 7.335 percent. The issue is rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc.  and A by the Standard & Poor's Corp.     Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $150 million of bonds due in 1997 through Sanwa Securities and HSBC Securities. The bonds are callable quarterly beginning on Feb. 4, carry an interest rate of 5.81 percent, and are priced at par.     Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $35 million of bonds due in 2001 through Vining Sparks. The bonds are callable quarterly beginning on Jan. 29, carry an interest rate of 7.183 percent and are priced at par.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PHYSICIAN SALES AND SERVICE INC., Jacksonville, Fla., a distributor of medical supplies, said it would acquire X-Ray Corp. of Georgia and Chesapeake X-Ray Corp. for $18 million in stock and the assumption of $6.8 million in debt.    BRIO INDUSTRIES, Vancouver, British Columbia, a bottler and distributor of juices, water and soft drinks, sold certain soft drink assets to the Cott Corp., Toronto, a maker of soft drinks, for about $27 million (Canadian), or $20 million.    ADAPTEC INC., Milpitas, Calif., a maker of computer-networking products, acquired Sigmax Technologies Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., a developer of CD-ROM components, for $14.4 million in cash.

headline: New Zealanders Invest In Australian Publisher
abstract: Brierley Investments Ltd, New Zealand, says it acquired 20 percent stake in John Fairfax Holdings Ltd, one of Australia's major newspaper publishing companies, from Hollinger International Inc; also says it agreed to buy another 5 percent of Fairfax from Hollinger; puts combined price of purchases at about $357.6 million (S)

headline: Norsk Hydro Profits Plunge 45% in Quarter
abstract: Norsk Hydro AS, Norway's largest industrial company, says that its profit fell 45 percent in third quarter to 909 million kroner ($141 million) from year earlier (S)

headline: Applied Graphics To Buy Spot Link
abstract: Applied Graphics Technologies agrees to acquire the assets of Spot Link Inc from Western International Media Corp (S)

headline: Alas, Poor Hamlet! He's Turning Rotten in Serbia
abstract: Article on newest production of Hamlet in Belgrade, Serbia, that is nationalistic allegory intended to convey message that usurping authority, even when illegitimate, only brings chaos and ruin; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: New York Economy Starts to Bounce Back   The economy of New York City, which has foundered since the recession of the early 1990's, has begun to crawl back toward prosperity, largely because of rising profits on Wall Street.

headline: Bond Prices Stabilize After Falling Initially
abstract: Treasury bond prices stabilize after falling initially; 30-year bond falls 2/32, to 99 29/32, to yield 6.51 percent (M)

headline: A New Language Is Adding Depth to the Flat Computer Screen
abstract: Technology and software for three-dimensional computer displays is bringing virtual reality to the World Wide Web; Apple Computer, Microsoft, Netscape Communications, IBM and dozens of small design firms and software companies vie to create 3-D Internet worlds; shift from two-dimension displays reflects greater power processing available on standard desktop computer and the industry agreement on Virtual Reality Modeling Language as the Internet standard; virtual-reality took off in recreational settings but is now being taken up by electronic shopping malls, real estate industry, businesses, political groups and even professional sports teams; drawings; photos (M)

headline: Diplomats Cautiously Welcome Ouster of Bosnian Serb General
abstract: Western officials laud ouster of Gen Ratko Mladic as leader of Bosnian Serb Army; foreign diplomats and Bosnian Serb officials say it is still unclear whether Pres Biljana Plavsic will succeed in bid to assert control over army (M)ü

headline: An On-Line Consultation With a Number Cruncher
abstract: Virginia Munger Kahn article assesses review of her own mutual fund portfolio performed on-line by Net Results (M)

headline: Gucci Reports 69% Rise In 3d-Quarter Revenue
abstract: Luxury goods maker Gucci Group says that its revenues jumped 69% in third quarter, helped by strong sales of leather goods and shoes (S)

headline: Salomon Reports Surprising Earnings Drop of Nearly 60%
abstract: Salomon Inc says earnings fell nearly 60 percent, to $112 million from $268 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue, after subtracting interest expense, declined by little less than 33 percent, to $816 million; graph; chart (L)

headline: TWO CANADIAN FERTILIZER COMPANIES TO MERGE
abstract: Agrium Inc to take over Viridian Inc for $1.2 billion Canadian ($887.4 million US) in deal that will create one of largest fertilizer companies in North America (S)

headline: Sometimes It's the Little Things
abstract: Maybe you took home a few pens from the office or wrote some letters on company stationery. Or maybe you were a little more daring, sending the company jet to pick up your spouse. Many workers have used company time or property for personal benefit. Have you? Or do you have any unusual stories about someone who has? Send your best story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: U.S. Discloses Pension Fund Rescue Plan
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, a Federal agency, announces plan to shore up Amalgamated Insurance Fund, in hope of rescuing pension fund covering 70,000 workers in men's suit industry; says plan would protect employers and taxpayers as well as union retirees; Amalgamated's estimated liabilities now exceed assets by $253 million, and employers have been withdrawing from the fund faster, increasing burden on those that remain; sales of tailored clothing for men have suffered in recent years (M)

headline: Tainted by Corruption, Colombian President Is Ceding Power
abstract: Presidency of Colombian Pres Ernesto Samper seems paralyzed, six months after Congress absolved him of charges that drug dealers pumped $6 million into his election campaign; still stigmatized by corruption charges, he appears to have surrendered much of mandate to sectors and politicians whose support he has had to rely on to stay in power (M)

headline: Judge in Bomb Inquiry Has Made a Career of Fighting Terrorism
abstract: Article profiles Jean-Louis Bruguiere, one of three French investigating magistrates named to lead inquiry into latest terrorist bombing of commuter train in Paris (M)

headline: European Rights Court to Hear Case of British Boy's Caning
abstract: European Court of Human Rights will hear case of 12-year-old British boy, who was caned by stepfather over period of days and argues that Britain's corporal punishment statute violates European law; case has turned into cause celebre in Britain, where use of corporal punishment to discipline children is deeply entrenched in national psyche (M)

headline: Pharmacia & Upjohn Seeks to Sell a Unit
abstract: Swedish-United States pharmaceutical company Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc may sell all or parts of its Pharmacia Biotech operations (S)

headline: Chi-Chi's Names Campbell Mithun
abstract: Chi-Chi's, chain of Mexican-style restaurants, in Louisville, Ky, and owned by Family Restaurants Inc, names Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, to handle the creative part of its account as well as efforts like in-store promotions (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch Names Investment Banking Chief as President
abstract: Merrill Lynch says that Herbert M Allison Jr will become president and chief operating officer on April 15, making him likely eventual successor to David H Komansky as head of biggest American securities company; Merrill Lynch recently said that Komansky, 57, current president, would become chief executive on Dec 28, and would succeed Daniel P Tully as chmn on April 15, when Tully is to retire (M)

headline: Desperately Seeking Deductions? Year-End Tips
abstract: Article on some year-end suggestions for reducing Federal income taxes; photo (L)

headline: Manhattan Is Chosen For Offices By Publisher
abstract: Addison-Wesley Longman Publishing Co has leased 58,206 square feet at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, office building between 46th and 47th Streets in Manhattan (M)

headline: RYDER GETS HELP IN EXAMINING UNIT'S FUTURE
abstract: Ryder System Inc says it has hired adviser to help it explore options for its Ryder Automotive Carrier Services unit (S)

headline: Wells Rich Picked By Citizens Telecom
abstract: Citizens Telecom unit of Citizens Utilities says it has names Wells Rich Greene BDDP as its first agency of record; billings estimated at $12 million to $17 million (S)

headline: Murdoch-MCI Efforts Under Growing Strain
abstract: MCI's two alliances with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp appear to be coming unraveled as MCA solidifies merger with British Telecommunications; MCI reportedly negotiates to limit its investment in News Corp to the $1.35 billion it has put up so far, which is less than $2-billion cash infusion promised in 1995; second alliance is supposed to be American Sky Broadcasting, consumer satellite service; both plans may have been swept to side by long complex negotiations with British Telecom (S)

headline: Vast Influx Jams Road Leading From Zaire
abstract: Rwandan troops, facing avalanche of ragged refugees, give up on holding Rwandan refugees in temporary camp near border, and instead direct them to march straight into Rwanda without any formalities; thousands of refugees begin to straggle into their home villages, as hundreds of thousands of others continue to pour out of Zaire, clogging roads and overwhelming aid workers; column of refugees stretches for at least 28 miles on both sides of border; photos; map (M)

headline: Acquisition Set By Schlumberger
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd says it will buy Solaic SA from Sligos SA; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Charging Trademark Violation, Visa Sues American Express
abstract: Visa sues American Express, accusing it of trademark infringement; at issue is new Visa card, issued by Advanta, big credit card company, that gives customers points in American Express Membership Rewards program, depending on size of their unpaid balances; American Express has been trying to persuade banks to issue cards using its brand, but Visa's rules have stopped any banks that issue Visa cards from also linking with Americn Express; Visa and American Express agree that Advanta program is intended to be American Express's foot in the banks' door; Carl Pascarella, president of Visa USA, notes that to get new Advanta card, customers are required to also have account with American Express; claims program blurs lines between two competing entities, confusing customers; Visa's suit seeks to stop the promotion; American Express discounts suit as unfounded (M)

headline: Big Australian Retailer Sells More Assets
abstract: Coles Myer Ltd says it has sold number of its retail property assets for $445 million, including two shopping centers to Westfield Property Trust (S)

headline: Big Swiss Brewery Cuts Jobs and Capacity
abstract: Feldschlosschen-Hurl imann Holding AG, Switzerland's largest brewer, will cut a fifth of its work force and reduce brewing capacity by a third in an effort to restore earnings growth; charge of 315 million Swiss francs ($249 million) will be taken against earnings for fiscal year; some 680 jobs will be cut (S)

headline: Banco Bilbao Buys Argentine Bank
abstract: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya SA, Spain, to buy 30 percent stake in Banco Frances del Rio de Plata, Argentina's third-largest bank, for $350 million (S)

headline: B. F. GOODRICH IS SELLING ITS SEALANTS AND COATINGS UNIT
abstract: B F Goodrich Co agrees to sell its Tremco Inc sealants and coatings unit to RPM Inc; terms of agreement undisclosed (S)

headline: GT INTERACTIVE STOCK DIVES ON EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Shares of GT Interactive Software Corp plunge 37.6 percent after company warns that delays in products tied to its Nintendo 64 will result in fourth-quarter sales of $115 million to $125 million--below analysts' expectations of $150 million (S)

headline: Young & Rubicam Dismisses Employees
abstract: Six junior-level employees in various departments at Young & Rubicam New York are dismissed for circulating electronic message that contained material deemed racially offensive (S)

headline: Japan Increases Its Surplus in U.S. Trade
abstract: Japan says its merchandise trade surplus with United States rose 31.3 percent, Oct, to 354.79 billion yen ($3.2 billion), first gain since Feb 1995; says its overall trade surplus fell 12.9 percent from Oct 1995, to 470.86 billion yen ($4.2 billion) (S)

headline: F.C.C. Chief's View On Liquor Ads
abstract: Chairman Reed E Hundt holds Federal Communications Commission has jurisdiction over television and radio advertising by liquor industry, which has decided to end its decades-long voluntary ban on such ads, speech; other FCC members have questioned agency's jurisdiction (S)

headline: Traditional Service Reigns at the Malls
abstract: Retailers rarely accept returned goods in Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Philippines, where stores traditionally provide high level of service; retail mores are changing with spread of shopping malls, where some department stores allow exchanges (S)

headline: Fox and Time Warner Square Off Over Ad
abstract: Fox Television, in latest episode of clash that began when Time Warner declined to add Fox's new all-news cable channel to its cable systems in New York, places ads in newspapers in several cities, including Milwaukee, Wis, and Austin, Texas, warning viewers that they may not be able to see this year's Super Bowl; ads inform viewers to be sure they have adequate broadcast antennas on their homes or else plan to schedule viewing Super Bowl at home of friend that has satellite antenna; Fox says reason is Time Warner's refusal to negotiate new agreement for retransmission rights to Fox's broadcast channels in those cities; Green Bay Packers and Dallas Cowboys are among football favorities to reach Super Bowl; both Fox and Time Warner executives exchange bitter charges, accusing each other of misrepresentations and outright lies (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Brunei Bank Buys 13% of Australian Bank
abstract: Brunei Investment agency's Brunei Investment & Commercial Bank buys 13.4 percent of Macquarie Bank Ltd for equivalent of $123 million from Lloyds TSB Group's Hill Samuel unit (S)

headline: Mexico's Closing of Five Ports Pushes Up Prices of Crude Oil
abstract: Crude oil prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange after Mexico closes five big ports because of bad weather, move that threatens to disrupt exports to United States (S)

headline: ARCHER DANIELS AGREES TO BIG FINE FOR PRICE FIXING
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co agrees to plea guilty to conspiring with competitors to fix prices of agricultural products and to pay $100 million in fines; plea bargain agreement will bring end to almost four years of investigation that began when former senior executive Mark E Whitcare agreed to act as Government informer and secretly tape hundreds of conversations at highest reaches of company; will push company and chairman Dwayne O Andreas into unusual new position; after decades of being run as virtual family fief under Andreas's control, company will be forced to provide evidence in continuing investigation of Andreas, his son and former heir apparent, and other executives; fine is by far largest ever obtained by Justice Department in criminal price-fixing case, eclipsing next highest by almost seven times; charges against company reviewed (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTEGRATED HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS INC.,Reston, Va., which develops and sells health-care management software, said it was in active negotiations with two companies for the sale or merger of its businesses.     FIBREBOARD CORP.,Dallas, a manufacturer of construction material, has entered an agreement to purchase the Florida-based assets of Gentek Building Product Inc., for about $14 million, which includes the assumption of its trade payable obligation.

headline: GULF SOUTH MEDICAL TO ACQUIRE GATEWAY HEALTHCARE
abstract: Gulf South Medical Supply Inc agrees to acquire Gateway Healthcare Corp for about $38.8 million in cash and warrants (S)

headline: Guatemalans Formally End 36-Year Civil War, Central America's Longest and Deadliest
abstract: Guatemala and leftist guerrillas sign final armistice ending 36-year civil war; poll by local paper finds 78 percent of people back peace, but only 38 percent believe accords will be respected (M)

headline: APRIA HEALTHCARE'S BID FOR VITAS IN JEOPARDY
abstract: Apria Healthcare Group Inc says its acquisition of Vitas Healthcare Corp might be called off because of decline in Apria's share price (S)

headline: Barneys Begets Loehmann's
abstract: Photo of Loehmann's store preparing to open at former site of Barneys, New York City

headline: Dollar and Foreign Economies Influence Earnings
abstract: Some forecasters believe corporate earnings in 1997 will support another good year for stocks; there are two factors critical to most of the earnings forecasts for 1997 that could disappoint investors: economic growth overseas and value of dollar; earnings forecasts could fall with lower-than-expected growth and a stronger dollar (M)

headline: Home Resales Surged a Surprising 1.8% in November
abstract: Figures compiled by National Assn of Realtors show that sales of existing homes rebounded in November after five-month decline, all but guaranteeing record four million home resales for all of 1996; unexpected 1.8 percent increase in November also suggests that housing might help propel economy to brisk expansion in early months of 1997; housing figures, which few analysts had predicted, are partly attributed to declining interest rates since late summer; regionally, Midwest showed 4.9 percent surge in sales in November, West was up 4.5 percent, and South was up 1 percent; in Northeast, they slumped 4.8 percent from October pace; Conference Board calculates that index of leading indicators edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in November, 10th month in row without decline; graph (M)

headline: Heating Oil Drops as Traders Think U.S. May Insure Supply
abstract: Heating oil prices fall on New York Mercantile Exchange amid speculation that Federal Government might intervene to insure adequate supplies in the Northeast, sparing consumers from soaring heating bills this winter (M)

headline: HFS in Accord That Extends Buying Spree
abstract: HFS Inc announces it will acquire PHH Corp, largest corporate relocation business in country, in stock deal worth $1.7 billion; HFS plans to pay for acquisition by issuing 23.4 million shares of stock in exchange for 34.8 million shares of PHH; PHH's chief executive, Robert D Kunisch, is expected to join HFS board of directors when merger is completed; analysts see synergies between HFS and PHH, which had net income of $86 million on revenues of $600 million for year ending July 31 (M)

headline: T&N Seeks to Limit Liability for Asbestos
abstract: T&N PLC sets 1 billion pound ($1.67 billion) plan to limit liabilities related to its former asbestos manufacturing operations; will take 373 million pound charge under plan (S)

headline: Blenheim and Reed Silent on Merger Report
abstract: Blenheim PLC, a British conference and exhibition organizer, and British-Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier, have no comment on Daily Mail report that Reed offered to buy Blenheim for 493 million pounds ($772 million) (S)

headline: Bill to Revise Securities Regulations Ready for Clinton
abstract: Senate approves bill, National Securities Markets Improvement Act of 1996, to help streamline regulation of mutual funds, investment advisers and stockbrokers; average American investors are not likely to notice many of bill's changes, most of which clarify whether states or Federal Government is responsible for overseeing different parts of securities business; main provision eliminates state review of mutual fund prospectuses and advertisements; Arthur Levitt Jr, chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission, hails bill; Pres Clinton is expected to sign it this week (M)

headline: Comments by Fed Governor Send Treasury Prices Lower
abstract: Treasury securities prices fall; 30-year bond falls 10/32, to 99 1/32, to yield 6.83 percent; graph (M)

headline: 2 Drug Companies Name Agencies
abstract: Roche Laboratories names Lowe & Partners/SMS, Lowe Direct and Lowe McAdams Health Care to introduce Xenical, anti-obesity drug; Merck & Co names Young & Rubicam Inc to introduce Propecia, hair restorative product (S)

headline: Japanese Bank Waits for Ruling
abstract: Asahi Bank, one of Japan's biggest banks, waits for regulators to rule on possible irregularities at bank's New York branch in June (S)

headline: In South Korea, the Strikers Take a Break for New Year's
abstract: South Korea hands over to North Korea remains of 24 infiltrators, killed after they slipped ashore from grounded North Korean submarine in September '96; photo (S)

headline: CSX Raises Its Offer To Purchase Conrail
abstract: CSX Corp sweetens cash portion of its bid for Conrail Inc, in attempt to knock out rival Norfolk Southern Corp and establish largest railroad in East; CSX increases cash offer by 19 percent for 40 percent of stock of Conrail; CSX would buy remaining 60 percent through stock swap after merger is approved by Federal regulators; total value of new bid comes to $8.5 billion; Norfolk Southern's all-cash bid totals $9.1 billion, and its officials hint that bid may be increased in light of CSX's new bid; but Conrail reaffirms its merger pact with CSX and rejects Norfolk Southern's offer (M)

headline: Piles of Storied Jewish Books Are Languishing in Lithuania
abstract: Tens of thousands of rare Hebrew and Yiddish texts lie forgotten in Roman Catholic church in Vilnius, Lithuania; many date from 17th and 18th centuries, when city became unrivaled center of Jewish intellectual and spiritual innovation; books, forming what experts regard as one of largest such collections in world, were hidden first from Nazis and then from Soviets; they are property of Lithuanian National Library; Larissa Lampert, who teaches at Vilnius University, and Fira Bramson, Holocaust survivor, are struggling to catalogue books; Jewish scholars say books, collected from most important yeshivas and libraries in Eastern Europe, no longer belong in Lithuania; map; photos (M)

headline: Shipping Tycoon, at Ease in U.S., To Govern Hong Kong for China
abstract: C H Tung, tough-talking shipping magnate, is confirmed as China's choice to administer Hong Kong when 150 years of British rule ends in July '97; will be first Chinese to administer one of Asia's most successful economies; he expresses confidence in future; says Hong Kong will finally be master of its own house; his successful career as businessman discussed; his education at University of Liverpool and 10-year sojourn in US, working for General Electric in Boston and later for family company in San Francisco, noted; photos (M)

headline: Croatia Chief Seeks to Muzzle A Radio That Aided His Rise
abstract: Pres Franjo Tudjman is seeking to silence Radio 101, last independent radio station in Croatia, which aided his rise to power when he was political dissident; new restrictive press laws have recently been passed despite requests by Croatia's European and American allies to end Government crackdown on press; demise of radio station, many say, would effectively end any hope for independent news media (M)

headline: Trading Scandal at Sumitomo Causes $1.9 Billion Loss, Its First
abstract: Sumitomo Corp posts $1.9 billion loss for fiscal first half, first loss ever, as result of huge losses from unauthorized copper trading; says profits from recurring businesses rose 77.8 percent in first half, to $300 million; expects net loss of $1.35 billion for year ending in Mar (S)

headline: Body Planted On His Ranch, Mexican Says
abstract: Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother the former President of Mexico who is being held on charges of plotting the 1994 assassination of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, a prominent politician, accuses prosecutors of planting a body on the grounds of a weekend retreat he owned; official autopsy shows that the body underwent an earlier autopsy; prosecutors are unshaken and contend the body is that of Manuel Munoz Rocha, a member of the assassination conspiracy (M)

headline: Soybeans Soar on Forecast; Oil Rises First Time in 4 Days
abstract: Futures Markets column; soybean prices soar; oil prices rise for first time in four days; tables (M)

headline: Mubarak Says Bitterly That Israel Is Obstinate
abstract: Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, showing bitterness that led him to shun Middle East summit, assails Israel for its 'obstinate acts' and 'discouraging' statements of Prime Min Netanyahu; says he urged Netanyahu three times last week to take steps to defuse Arab-Israeli tensions (S)

headline: Be thrifty and invest well, and then wait for the huge tax bill.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on troubling study by John Shoven and David Wise, suggesting that people who save the most in their tax deferred retirement plans will be taxed at alarmingly high rates once they retire; Shoven argues that tax shelters can easily become tax traps for middle-income Americans who are thrifty and invest well; says broader issue is whether it ever makes sense to tax assets at rates exceeding 90 percent; says this could act to undermine savings incentives of upper middle class; drawing (M)

headline: Russia Still Upset at NATO
abstract: Russian Defense Min Igor Rodionov tells NATO counterparts that plans for expansion to Eastern Europe are unaceptable, but allows it should be possible to negotiate Russian-NATO security agreement anyway (S)

headline: Shock Waves in Geneva From Chechnya Atrocity
abstract: Red Cross employees at headquarters in Geneva are deeply shocked by murder of six Red Cross workers at hospital in Chechnya (S)

headline: STRIKES CAUSE G.M. TO CUT 4TH-QUARTER PRODUCTION
abstract: General Motors Corp cuts its planned fourth-quarter production of cars and trucks 11 percent because of strikes in Canada and United States that temporarily shut down assembly plants, costing GM $666 million (S)

headline: Philips May Shed Its Cable TV Stake
abstract: Philips Electronics NV says it might sell or spin off its half of Europe's largest cable operator, in what could be another move in campaign to pare unprofitable units (S)

headline: SERVICE EXPERTS TO ACQUIRE 18 SERVICE CENTERS
abstract: Service Experts Inc says it is acquiring 18 heating, ventilating and air-conditioning service centers for about $57.2 million in stock and cash; companies being acquired are members of Service Experts' wholly owned subsidiary (S)

headline: North Korea Frees American, Prompting Optimism on Other Issues
abstract: North Korea releases Evan C Hunziker, American missionary whom it had detained on charges of spying; Rep Bill Richardson, who negotiated release, says North Korea seems willing to increase cooperation in other areas as well (M)

headline: Two Ways to Invest While Dancing to a Beat
abstract: Bruce Felton (Minding Your Business) column replies to reader's question on value averaging versus dollar-cost strategy for investing in mutual funds (M)

headline: POLAROID TO SELL UNIT AND TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE
abstract: Polaroid Corp says it will sell its medical diagnostic photography unit for undisclosed price to Sterling Diagnostic Imaging; Polaroid also says it will take fourth-quarter charge of as much as $20 million to cut jobs in its Helios Laser Imaging unit and write down inventory (S)

headline: British Air Delaying $1 Billion Jet Order
abstract: British Airways PLC will postpone $1 billion aircraft order until effectiveness of its cost-cutting program can be assessed (S)

headline: FEDERAL MOGUL SELLING A BALL BEARING PLANT
abstract: Federal Mogul Corp says it has sold its 900-employee ball bearing manufacturing operations to NTN Corp of Japan; purchase price is not announced (S)

headline: With Party Conference Near, Tories Suffer New Setbacks
abstract: Problems mount for Prime Min John Major's demoralized Conservative Party in Britain, with Labor Party widenening lead in new Gallup poll from 24 to 33 points as elections approach; setbacks center on growing civil war within party over integration with Europe, and new scandal involving members of Parliament (M)

headline: Volkswagen's History: The Darker Side Is Revisited
abstract: Hans Mommsen book, Volkswagen And Its Workers During The Third Reich, describes darker side of Europe's biggest automobile manufacturer; describes its founding as economically dubious pet project of Adolf Hitler, its munitions procurement during World War II and its use of slave labor during war (M)

headline: Chinese Court Finds Dissident Guilty and Gives 11-Year Sentence
abstract: Chinese court cinvicts dissident Wang Dan of plotting to overthrow Government and sentences him to 11 years in prison; sentence is among harshest meted out to student leaders of 1989 democracy movement in Tiananmen Square (M)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.42   5.97        3-MO. headline: Singapore Worries About Rival Next Door
abstract: Singapore leader Lee Kuan Yew is warning about economic competition from neighbors, particularly Malaysia; his surprise mention in June of possible reunification with Malaysia has put relations on edge; map (M)

headline: Caribbean Nations Find Little Profit in Aiding U.S. Drug War
abstract: English-speaking nations of eastern Caribbean, which have in recent years devoted larger portions of their meager budgets to aid America in fighting drug trafficking, feel short-changed by US, which they say is responding with policy of economic retrenchment (M)

headline: Stock Tipsters Praised, and Profited
abstract: SEC files complaint against SGA Goldstar, on-line tipsheet, for promoting investments in companies in which owners have secretly received stock; charged are Theodore R Melcher Jr and Shannon B Terry; list of companies (S)

headline: COMMERCE BANCORP EXPANDS INTO NORTHERN NEW JERSEY
abstract: Commerce Bancorp says it reached preliminary agreement to acquire Independence Bancorp for $76 million, in move to expand into northern New Jersey (S)

headline: Genetic Screening: An Unsettling Battle Is Joined
abstract: LONDON—  Five years ago, Jamie Stephenson, a New Hampshire writer and her husband, Jonathan, a dentist, got a nasty shock. Their new health insurer suddenly dropped them after re-examining their file.

headline: Buy Your Company's Stock Plan And Get a 'Captive Broker,' Too
abstract: As more and more companies offer stock plans to their workers, Wall Stree firms are vying for piece of booming business; led by Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney, brokerage firms are negotiating exclusive contracts--sometimes known as captive-broker arrangements--with companies to handle stockplan transactions for employees; in the process, they hope to become employees' broker of choice (L)3

headline: Penney Seeks to Purchase Drug Chain for $2.5 Billion
abstract: Latest consolidation in drugstore industry is announcement by J C Penney Co that it will acquire Eckerd Corp for $2.5 billion in cash and stock; deal includes assumption of $760 milion in debt, and is one in series of recent acquisitions Penney has made in its Thrift drugstore division; Penney and other drugstore operators are creating regional and national chains so they can cut costs and demand better prices from suppliers; Penney hopes to cut $100 million in that way; Penney and Eckerd say there will be no immediate job cuts but hint that they are possibility in future (M)

headline: Nippon Telegraph Says Profits Surged
abstract: Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corp reports profits rose 63.9 percent in six months ended Sept 30 to record 207.75 billion yen ($1.87 billion); company's share price jumps (S)

headline: Netcom to Seek Profitable Niche: Internet Access Just for Business
abstract: Netcom On-Line Communications Services Inc, leading Internet access provider, plans to phase out flat-rate pricing model and stress higher-quality, higher-priced services for business users (M)

headline: The Contrast Of Business And Celebrity
abstract: Michael Ovitz, with his resignation as president of Walt Disney Co, joins many high-powered Hollywood executives who have left top jobs in last two years, including Time Warner's Michael Fuchs, Viacom's Frank Biondi, MCA's Tom Pollock and even Disney's Jeffrey Katzenberg (M)

headline: British Utility Bid Wins Approval
abstract: Calenergy Inc says British regulators rejected Northern Electric PLC's last-ditch effort to block hostile $1.54 billion takeover bid by Calenergy and Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc (S)

headline: Japan Enlists the Big Powers In Seeking End to Peru Crisis
abstract: Japanese Government begins new effort to forge united front of industrialized nations to persuade Tupac Amaru guerrillas to free 103 hostages from Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru; Group of Seven nations, joined by Russia, condemns hostage-taking; expresses support for Peruvian Government's efforts to end crisis peacefully and reaffirms group's position that no concessions should be made to terrorists (M)

headline: It's Health Reference Data (Do Not Take as Medicine)
abstract: World Wide Web sites provide variety of medical information; doctors can be researched by name or specialty, and several sites offer versions of 'ask the doctor,' with information presented in question-and-answer format; chart (M)

headline: The H.M.O. Says the Doctor Is In. Is He Really?
abstract: Consumer advocates warn that HMO listings of participating doctors may be outdated, inaccurate or incomplete in omitting specific limitations; doctors and plans often part ways, leaving subscribers stuck at least until next year's enrollment period; photo of Dr Stephen Shochat, who removed rare kidney tumor and found that HMO refused to pay $50,000 hospital bill on grounds that he was not in same subgroup as child's family (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SAKS HOLDINGS INC.,  New York, the department store chain, said it would open 20 stores in the fiscal years 1997 and 1998, 9 more than originally planned, and expand 12 stores in a more ambitious schedule.    SHAW INDUSTRIES,  Dalton, Ga., which manufactures tufted carpet, announced plans to revamp its British operations and take a one-time pretax charge of about $35 million in the current quarter.     ELEKTA A.B.,  Stockholm, a medical device maker, agreed to buy Johnson & Johnson's Cordis Neuroscience business, based in the Sophia Antipolis region in southern France, for $8.87 million.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: HCIA falls off the growth curve and the reaction is brutal.
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Place) column profiles HCIA, Baltimore company that collects and sells data in the health care industry; notes company announcement that it would post earnings for quarter ended Monday of 10 to 15 cents share, compared with expected 29 cents, had brutal impact on its stock, which closed at $32.875, down $27.125 in Nasdaq trading; stock price graph (M)

headline: Ford Reports Vehicle Sales Dropped 2.2% in November
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports its sales fell 2.2 percent in November; final tally of monthly auto sales shows American companies lost ground to Japanese and European competitors; Big Three American auto makers built 72.1 percent of cars and trucks sold in United States in November, down three percentage points from year-ago figure; foreign auto makers, especially Honda and Toyota, gain market share given up by American companies; General Motors Corp's market share dips below 30 percent for third month this year; charts (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: Summary of major stories on inside pages of Business section

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Dynatech Corp, Burlington, Mass, to sell assets of its Unex Corp unit to GN Netcom for undisclosed terms; Italian Oven Inc, Latrobe, Pa, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; Alltel Corp, Little Rock, Ark, says it will buy back up to 3.5 million of its 190.5 million common shares outstanding; Mobilemedia Corp, Ridgfield, NJ, says it may not be able to make interest payments in Nov on its bonds (M)

headline: After an underdog agency gets the Acura account, heads turn on Madison Avenue.
abstract: Shock waves from stunning conclusion to review of American Honda Motor Co's Acura advertising account, will billings estimated at $125 million, continue to reverberate along Madison Avenue; Acura announced dismissal of its longtime agency, Fathom in Los Angeles, and hiring of darkest of the dark horse contenders in the review, Suissa Miller in Santa Monica, Calif (L)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Schedule of the coming week's economic reports (S)

headline: Bond Prices Slip on Fear Of Inflation
abstract: US Treasury bond prices end slightly lower; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 7/32, to 98 22/32; yield edges up to 6.85 percent from 6.84 percent (L)

headline: Advertisers Receive Lemon 'Awards'
abstract: Center for Science in the Public Interest presents its 12th Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards, which mock marketers for advertisements that are considered misleading; United Airlines, unit of UAL Corp, gets Lemon for newspaper ads this year (S)

headline: LARGEST SHAREHOLDER REDUCES ITS VOTING STAKE
abstract: Crown Cork & Seal Co says that its largest shareholder, Compagnie Generale d'Industrie et de Participations, had cut its voting stake in company to 10.1% (S)

headline: Heating Oil Supplies Climb As Eastern U.S. Stays Warm
abstract: American Petroleum Institute reports that after months of dwindling inventories and rising prices, supplies of heating oil and diesel fuel climbed sharply last week; heating oil futures drop following forecasts that mild weather in US East will continue, cooling demand (M)

headline: Germans Plan Combat Troops Outside NATO, A Postwar First
abstract: German parliament approves use of 4,000 peacekeeping soldiers in Bosnia, first deployment of German combat troops outside NATO borders since World War II; overwhelming vote, five years after refusal to join Persian Gulf War coalition, reflects Chancellor Helmut Kohl's effort to reverse decades of reluctance stemming from Nazi past; ground troops will join smaller US-led force that will replace NATO mission next year (S)

headline: AMENDED BID FILED FOR CAJUN ELECTRIC
abstract: Central and South West Corp and Entergy Inc say they filed amended $780 million offer for Cajun Electric Power Cooperative Inc that has support of Cajun's primary customers; companies are trying to defeat higher bid by partnership of Northern States Power Co, Ziegler Coal Holding Co and Southern Co (S)

headline: Hunt Adkins Wins Best of Show Award
abstract: For second consecutive year, Hunt Adkins in Minneapolis takes top honors, winning best of show award, at The Show, a competition for advertising created by Minnesota agencies that is sponsored by Advertising Federation of Minnesota and Art Directors/Copywriters Club of Minnesota (S)

headline: Retail Shares Decline Despite Earnings
abstract: J C Penney Co, Wal-Mart Stores Inc and Home Depot Inc each report strong third-quarter earnings increases, but they watch their shares fall; Wal-Mart says earnings rose 12 percent, to $684 million from $612 million in same period last year; J C Penney Co earned $257 million in operating profits, a 7.1 percent increase over similar period last year; Home Depot Inc reports 26 percent rise in earnings of $221.4 million over quarter last year, when it had earnings of $175.5 million; same-store sales rose 7 percent, down from 9 percent rise in second quarter (M)

headline: Unilever Profit Gains And Its Stock Soars
abstract: Unilever reports it had better-than-expected 4% gain in third-quarter earnings on increases in Latin America and Asia while North American profits were flat; third-quarter profit put at $781 million, on 7% sales increase (S)

headline: Pope Shows How Faith And Evolution Coexist
abstract: Pope John Paul II's statement acknowledging that evolution is 'more than just a theory' is unlikely to change significantly teaching of evolution in Roman Catholic schools, where it is already standard part of curriculum; teaching of evolution and creationism in public schools has re-emerged as increasingly contentious issue; Pope's statement is viewed as powerful support for idea that religious faith and teaching of evolution in country'schools can easily coexist (M)

headline: Wyser-Pratte Invests In 2 French Businesses
abstract: Wyser-Pratte & Co has taken a more than 5 percent stake in Cerus SA, Carlo de Benedetti's French holding company, and in insurer La France SA (S)

headline: To Control Cambodia, Rivals Are Stripping It Bare
abstract: King Norodom Sihanouk says illegal export of huge amounts of timber could turn Cambodia into desert in next century; environmentalists say both sides in country's long-running civil war, as well as high-ranking Government and military officials, appear to be involved in logging business; map; photo (M)

headline: Athens Re-enters the Olympic Beauty Contest
abstract: ATHENS—  Never mind the Acropolis. Tell us about the buses, the computers, how many hotel rooms have you got and what is everybody going to do during their spare time?
