headline: Electric appliances come alive to sell their G.M. sibling, the EV1.
abstract: Television commercial created by Hal Riney & Partners promotes EV1, the electric-powered two-seat coupe that General Motors Corp will make available by lease at some Saturn dealerships; photo (M)ï

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of business events for week ended Oct 20; graph; table; photos; drawing (M)

headline: An Economy of Happily Ever After?
abstract: As Washington bathes in post-election presumption that country need not worry about serious business downturn any time soon, some economists are suspicious of attitude that we have tamed once-ominous business cycle and that inflation is dead; while there are solid reasons for optimism, both political parties claim to have learned painful lessons of fiscal recklessness; current economic expansion, five years and eight months old, is already third-longest of century; should it last until, 2002, target date agreed on by both parties for eliminating deficit, it would be longest on record; recession on the other hand would wreak havoc on the effort to balance the budget; chart on performance of stock market for 12 trading days following election eve since 1900 (M)

headline: CYTOTHERAPEUTICS GETS BIG INVESTMENT FROM GENENTECH
abstract: Genentech Inc to invest up to $50 million in Cytotherapeutics Inc to help it develop treatments for three diseases; plans initial investment of $8.3 million (S)

headline: Excerpts From Tapes In Discrimination Lawsuit
abstract: Excerpts of tape recording of meeting of Texaco executives discussing request for information they received in lawsuit filed by company employees charging company with racial discrimination (M)

headline: FALCON BUILDING STOCK SURGES ON TALK OF SALE
abstract: Shares of Falcon Building Products Inc rise 13% afer company says it is exploring a sale (S)

headline: A new tombstone design can incorporate a person's life story -- including photographs.
abstract: Hali Weiss patents tombstone with rotating element that contains 500-word biography of deceased; inscription process allows use of photographs or genealogical trees alongside text; Pharmatarget is developing implantable defibrillator to counteract arrhythmia in heart's upper chambers; device is based on research by Dr Robert Arzbaecher, who recently patented technology; Alexandra McMullen-Richards patents self-heating eyelash curler (M)

headline: HADCO AGREES TO DEAL FOR RIVAL MAKER OF CIRCUIT BOARDS
abstract: Hadco Corp says it has agreed to acquire rival maker of printed circuit boards, the Zycon Corp, for $18 a share in cash, or $205 million (S)ø

headline: As Shares Slip, So Do Phone Deals' Worth
abstract: Market Place column: Wall Street bankers say weakness in shares of telephone companies could stanch flood of mergers that has transformed these industries in recent months; they cite Worldcom's takeover of MFS Communications, worth $14 billion when announced on Aug 26, but now worth $11.8 billion; also, US West and Continental Cablevision, which announced their merger in February, have now agreed to reduced price after 20 percent drop in US West unit shares that would be used to finance deal; graph (M)

headline: Progress Is Reported in G.M. Contract Talks
abstract: General Motors Corp and its main American and Canadian unions reportedly are making steady progress in talks to produce new national labor contracts and to resolve disputes over the company's planned sale of auto parts factories; sources say that while several issues may still produce strikes, United Automobile Workers and Canadian Automobile Workers have been discussing possible compromises in hope of reaching deals in next few days (M)

headline: LEON BLACK TEAM ACQUIRES PARKING LOT COMPANY
abstract: Leon Black, head of Apollo Advisors LP, teams with Aldrich Eastman Waltch to buy Allright Parking Corp; terms not disclosed; Allright is owned by Hang Lung Group; selling price is thought to be about $250 million in cash and debt (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Gillette Co's proposed purchase of Duracell International Inc for $7.82 billion in stock and debt is approved by shareholders of both companies (S)

headline: Dresdner Bank to Unite Foreign Funds Business
abstract: Dresdner Bank AG, Germany's second-largest commercial bank, says that it plans to merge its foreign institutional funds business under one roof (S)

headline: In Manila, Asians Pore Over Washington's Inner Truths
abstract: Pres Clinton arrives in Manila for Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting; Asian business executives have poured into city in days leading up to meeting; many of them are concerned about Washington's increasingly central role in setting--or vetoing--rules of global trade; after years of insisting that US is diminished world economic power, they have concluded that decisions made in Washington are more important to their prosperity than ever; photos (M)

headline: American Home Products Will Buy the Rest of Genetics Institute
abstract: American Home Products Corp, which bought majority stake in Genetics Institute Inc in 1992, moves to buy rest of company after new blood-clotting therapy being developed by Genetics Institute clears regulatory hurdle; American Home Products says it exercised its options to purchase 40 percent of Genetics Institute that it does not already own for about $1.25 billion, or $85 a share (M)

headline: Avoiding Stock Deals Too Good to Be True
abstract: Humorous comment on how investors can avoid being burned by 'hot tips' regarding stock market opportunities (M)

headline: The 'Oldest Old,' 80 and Over, Are on the Increase Globally
abstract: Joseph Chamie, director of Population Division of United Nations economic and social policy research department, recently brought together demographers, economists, social scientists and policy planners from around world to talk about new concept in population--emergence of distinct category of people 80 and older--and what this means in areas like health care, consumer marketing and voting behavior; UN conference was co-sponsored by US Census Bureau and American Association of Retired Persons (M)

headline: Sandinistas Are Shaken By Election
abstract: Political analysts in Managua, Nicaragua, say Sandinista National Liberation Front's ideological base has been weakened and its ranks divided by loss of Daniel Ortega Saavedra in presidential election (M)

headline: Nissan is changing the rules for car ads by rolling out entertaining spots using toy characters.
abstract: David Barboza, in Advertising column, discusses popular animated television commercial that Rob Siltanen of TBWA Chiat/Day created for Nissan Motor Corp (M)

headline: The Supreme Court steps into a gray zone to consider ''virtual'' infringement on a patent.
abstract: Ad pages are down at The New Yorker even as its circulation surges and awards roll in; advertisers are slow to pick up on the changes Tina Brown has wrought at the magazine, and the increasing specialization in the magazine field has diminished the appeal of general interest magazines like The New Yorker; the magazine's provocative content puts off some advertisers, but beckons to others; Brown and Thomas A Florio, president, are sharpening the sales pitch to advertisers; photos (M)

headline: GROWING OPTIMISM FOR PEACEFUL END TO CRISIS IN PERU
abstract: Optimism is growing in Peru that hostage crisis at Japanese Ambassador's residence can be resolved peacefully after Government aide and Tupac Amaru rebels meet face to face; both sides seem to soften their stands; Bishop Juan Luis Cipriani, friend of Pres Alberto Fujimori, served as 'witness' during meeting between Peruvian aide Domingo Palermo and rebel leader Nestor Cerpa Cartolini; photos (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Capstead Mtg  CRI Liquid Reit  Criimi Mae  Green Mtn Powr  Harnischfeger   JDN Rlty Corp  Spartech Corp  Summit Pptys   Total Sys Svcs  York Intl    TUESDAY   Enron Oil & Gas  Fluor  Montana Powr  Norrel  Oil Dri   United Dominion    WEDNESDAY   Alpharma  Flightsafety Intl  Fluke  General Re  Heilig-Meyers  Hubbel  Illinova  McNeal Schwndl  Nac Re  Spieker Pptys  SPX  Transatlantic  Trinet Corp Rlty  Unicom  Valspar  Vestaur Secs  Yank Enrgy Sys    THURSDAY   Ampco-Pittsburg  Atlantic Energy  Bedford Ppty   Delmarv Pwr & Lt  First Data  General Signal  Pier 1 Imports  Quanex Corp  Scotsman Inds  Tyco Intl  Wiley J. & Sons  Wolverine World    FRIDAY   Abbott Labs  Boise Cascade  Pioneer Hi-Bred

headline: Slaying Tells of Russia's Deadly Capitalism
abstract: Gangland-style killing of Paul E Tatum, American co-owner of Radisson-Slavyanskaya Hotel in Moscow, has sent chilling message to foreign business community; Tatum is first American businessman killed in Moscow in apparent contract murder in recent memory; threats and contract killings have become such a disturbingly common way for Russians to resolve business disputes that foreigners are no longer off-limits; photo (M)

headline: DeBakey Flies To Moscow To Discuss Yeltsin Surgery
abstract: Dr Michael E DeBakey arrives in Moscow to clear Pres Boris N Yeltsin for heart bypass surgery (M)

headline: How Belgium Blinked at Child Killer's Trail
abstract: Belgians are outraged at police slowness in apprehending Marc Dutroux, who allegedly kidnapped at least six young girls, held them prisoner and repeatedly raped them, despite succession of warnings from his mother, informers and others; bodies of four children have been found and two girls were freed after his arrest in Aug; over 300,00 people held protest in Brussels in Oct and protests have taken place every day in other cities; chronology of events; photos (L)

headline: Canada to Force A Vote at Airline
abstract: Labor Min Alfonso Gagliano of Canada says passenger-service staff of Canadian Airlines International Ltd would be forced to vote on company's proposed rescue plan, which is opposed by their union; airline will run out of money next month unless workers agree to wage cuts and other concessions (S)

headline: Stores Don't Expect Crush of Exchanges
abstract: French retailers, who were extremely busy this Christmas, say gifts are rarely returned; generally let customers exchange goods (S)

headline: Quaker Oats Shifts Two Cereal Brands
abstract: Quaker Oats Co shifts responsibilities for two cereal brands to Bayer Bess Vanderwarker advertising agency from Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor (S)ï

headline: Cable-Phone Concern Gets A Setback
abstract: RCN Corp, which is challenging Time Warner and Nynex in cable and telephone business, suffers setback when Federal Communications Commission denies request by RCN's sister company, MFS Communications, for permission to transmit video over its fiber optic networks in New York City and Boston; FCC said in its ruling that MFS might have misrepresented itself in its application as an open video system operator, when it was, in fact, running a conventional cable system (M)

headline: Investigation Finds No Evidence of Slur On Texaco Tapes
abstract: Outside investigators hired by Texaco Inc. have concluded from an analysis of a tape recording that a senior company executive did not use a highly charged racial epithet at a 1994 meeting, though a transcript of the recording, filed in court papers, said he did.    The new analysis of the recording, using a digitized copy of the tape enhanced by sound experts, has concluded that Robert Ulrich, the company's former treasurer, never referred on the tape to minority employees as ''niggers.'' In their report, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, the outside investigators conclude that the word used by Mr. Ulrich, who retired as treasurer last year, was ''Nicholas,'' rather than the racial slur.

headline: EMMIS BROADCASTING BUYS ST. LOUIS RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Emmmis Broadcasting Corp acquires three St Louis radio stations from closely-held Zimco Inc, for $42.5 million; stations are WKBQ-AM and FM and WKKX-FM (S)

headline: Disputes Slow Help for Rwandan Refugees
abstract: International relief operation meant to help hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees bogs down in disputes between United Nations and Rwandan authorities over how and where to deliver supplies; Rwanda has discouraged anything that would slow movement of refugees or that would give them reason to erect camp inside Rwanda; has reportedly commandeered UN's fleet of trucks, so it can control how many refugees are transported, where they are picked up and where they are taken; photos; maps (M)

headline: Britain Seeks Informers To Fight Welfare Fraud
abstract: British Government launches pilot program to fight welfare fraud; sets up toll-free telephone hot-line for people to report welfare cheats; estimates $4.5 billion is being lost to fraud annually out of $135 billion-a-year social security budget; photo (M)

headline: Rewriting History Is a Tricky Business
abstract: P F Collier's plans to publish first uncensored Russian-language encyclopedia since Russian Revolution; Encyclopaedia Britannica's earlier, failed effort recalled; photos (M)

headline: From Risk To Inflation: A Reader's Bull Market
abstract: Market Watch column by Floyd Norris on 1996's best books for investors: The Great Wave: Price Revolutions and the Rhythm of History by David Hackett Fischer, The Trouble With Prosperity: The Loss of Fear, the Rise of Speculation and the Risk to American Savings by James Grant and Against the Gods: The Remarkable Story of Risk by Peter L Bernstein (L)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: DONNA KARAN INTERNATIONAL INC., New York, named Dewey K. Shay, a Morgan Stanley & Co. executive, as senior executive vice president and chief administrative officer.    UNION PACIFIC CORP., Bethlehem, Pa., named the president and chief operating officer, Richard Davidson, to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive, replacing Drew Lewis, who is retiring on Jan. 1.    VIAD CORP., Phoenix, formerly Dial Corp.'s services division, named Robert H. Bohannon chairman, president and chief executive. Mr. Bohannon, who is also chief operating officer, replaces John W. Teets, who will retire on Jan. 1. Mr. Teets became chairman and chief executive of Dial, which spun off Viad in August, in 1981.

headline: Study Finds Few Women In 5 Highest Company Jobs
abstract: Study by Catalyst, nonprofit research and advocacy group for women, finds among 12,997 corporate officers of 500 companies, only 1,303--or 10 percent--are women; among 2,500 people who are listed as top five earners in these companies' 1995 proxy statements, only 50--or 2 percent--are women; among 2,430 people holding title of chairman, chief executive, vice chairman, president, chief operating officer or executive vice president, only 57--or 2.4 percent--are women; and among 978 women officers having title of executive vice president, senior vice president or vice president, only 271--or 28 percent, hold positions with responsibilities for sales and profit or loss of the business; chart shows companies among top 100 in Fortune magazine's annual list of 500 biggest companies that do not have a woman among their top officers (L)

headline: On, Dilbert! On, Dogbert! On, Dave!
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews several books of office humor, including The Dilbert Principle by Scott Adams and Dave Barry in Cyberspace; photo (M)

headline: Shares of Sanofi Fall on Drug Test
abstract: Shares of Sanofi SA fall sharply after study finds company's experimental blood thinner works little better than aspirin in warding off heart attacks and strokes in people with clogged arteries; Sanofi developed drug with Bristol-Myers Squibb Inc (S)

headline: Chase and First Data in Joint Venture
abstract: Chase Manhattan Bank and First Data Corp agree to form venture that will provide merchant-processing services; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: I.R.A.'s Political Wing Still Hopes to Join Talks
abstract: Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, pledges to continue working for peace in Northern Ireland, despite Britain's virtual rejection of party's latest proposal to gain seat at peace talks (M)

headline: A Surprise in Toyland: Mattel to Buy Tyco
abstract: Mattel Inc, largest toy company in US, will buy Tyco Toys Inc, third-largest toy company, for $737 million; deal will add Tyco's 3.2 percent share of $17.5 billion US toy market to Mattel's 15.6 percent share; analysts say it will give Mattel opportunity to increase global sales of well-known Tyco brands; Gary Baughman, Tyco's chief executive, says there will be as-yet-unspecified reduction of Tyco's 2,200 employees worldwide; analysts expect merger to be carefully scrutinized by Federal Trade Commission, which must give its approval for deal to proceed; photos; graphs (M)

headline: HORIZON CELLULAR TO SELL LICENSES TO PRICELLULAR
abstract: Horizon Cellular Group will sell cellular licenses in four Kentucky markets to Pricellular Corp for $116.5 milion in cash and stock; four areas have 23,000 subscribers and 756,000 potential customers (S)

headline: Archer in $430 Million Deal To Buy W. R. Grace Cocoa Unit
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co will buy cocoa business of W R Grace & Co for approximately $430 million in cash and debt (S)

headline: P.& G. Sues Colgate On TV Commercial
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co sues Colgate-Palmolive Co and its agency, Young & Rubicam Inc, contending that Colgate commercial by Y & R deliberately copies commercial for Crest that P & G has run since 1989 (S)

headline: TCI Strives To Ease Jitters Among Wary Cable Investors
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc president John C Malone meets with stock analysts in effort to calm shareholder fears in wake of firm's decision to suspend all shipments of new cable television equipment; shareholders have been nervous about heavy investments in new services at time when TCI faces fierce challenges to its core cable franchise; graph (M)

headline: Nestle Sales Up 5.7% In First 10 Months
abstract: Nestle SA says its sales rose 5.7 percent to $38.6 billion in first 10 months of year, and Helmut Maucher, company chairman, forecasts full-year profit of more than $2.4 billion (S)

headline: A Payout Ends A Family Feud But Could Be Costly To Investors
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Place) column says shares in Value Line Inc have turned weak, apparently due to realization that individual owners of stock are about to get hit with big tax burden about Dec 26 unless they sell shares; discusses sale, which is result of resolution of fight within founding family for control of company (M)

headline: Dow Corning Offers Plan To End Suits
abstract: Dow Corning Corp, year-and-half after it turned to bankruptcy court to avoid drowning in tidal wave of lawsuits over breast implants, proposes to set aside $3 billion to pay all creditors, including up to $2 billion for injury claims linked to silicone implants; but Dow Corning's plan includes provisions for a trial on whether there is any scientific basis for contentions that silicone leading from ruptured or defective breast implants causes disease; company says that if it won that trial, its payments for implant claims should be no more than $600 million; amount earmarked for commercial creditors is $1 billion (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Record Bull Market, Any Way You Slice It  With the latest rise in the Dow Jones industrial average of 29.07, to 5,933.97, the current bull market has become the biggest ever without a decline of at least 10 percent. Since the last such decline ended, almost six years ago, the Dow is up 150.9 percent. $(Page D8.$)      Prices of Treasury securities rose to a six-week high. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.84 percent, from 6.87 percent. $(D18.$)     When Trade Meets Politics   It took six years for American negotiators to bring to an end billions of dollars in government subsidies for shipbuilders. But the deal unraveled when Congress realized that the United States would also have to cut subsidies for American shipbuilders. $(A1.$)    Service Corp. Raises Loewen Bid   Service Corporation, its bid for the Loewen Group rejected, went to Loewen shareholders with a hostile $3.2 billion offer. $(D2.$)    The Fed as Risk-Taker   The Federal Reserve, after two decades of hard work to establish its credibility, is now showing a slight shift in its tolerance for inflation. Some view its decision not to push up rates as entailing a risk of a slight jump in prices to make sure that the economy keeps  cruising ahead. Market Place. $(D8.$)    Morgan Stanley Earnings Rise   Morgan Stanley Group reported a 4.8 percent rise in third-quarter earnings to $219 million, slightly less than expected. $(D4.$)    One Phone Call, $20 Million Tax   Household Finance mounted an intense lobbying campaign to be exempt from an industry tax, and was assured of success. One call from Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat, put the kibosh on that. $(D5.$)    Construction Spending Up in August   Construction spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, to $562.1 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. $(D4.$)    S.E.C. Appears to Drop Case   The S.E.C. appears to have decided against accusing the Denver International Airport and its underwriters of securities fraud, people familiar with the matter said. $(D2.$)    Toys 'R' Us to Buy  Baby Superstore   Toys ''R'' Us, the country's largest toy store, said that it would buy Baby Superstore, which sells everything from diapers to cribs to formula, for $376 million in stock, exemplifying the trend toward rapid super-store consolidations. Shares in both companies rose significantly. $(D4.$)    Eurotunnel Averts Bankruptcy   The operator of the tunnel under the English Channel, avoided bankruptcy with an agreement on the ''basic principles'' to revamp $12.5 billion in debt. $(D4.$)     Shake Up at WCBS-TV News   WCBS-TV/Channel 2, a perennial third place in the local ratings race, dismissed some of its best known news anchors and reporters. $(D6.$)

headline: Japanese Investment Abroad Up 27% in Half
abstract: Japan reports direct foreign investment by Japanese rose 27 percent in first half of fiscal year to 2.66 trillion yen ($23.46 billion), up from 2.10 trillion yen in year-earlier period (S)

headline: In One Poor African Nation, Democracy Thrives
abstract: Even though Mali has become one of Africa's most vibrant democracies in space of past four years, dramatic political transformation has only slowly begun to change harsh facts of life for country that is among continent's poorest; despite hardships, its leaders and people alike describe democracy as one of their principal assets, and situation is providing hope that country will be able to improve lot of its people; two-thirds of country consists either of desert or unusable wastelands, and most of its 10 million people eke out living as farmers or herders; 80 percent of women are illiterate, as are 70 percent of men; photo; map (M)

headline: Expected Papal Visit Could Be Pivotal for Cuba and Church
abstract: Planned visit of Pope John Paul II to Cuba could be pivotal not only for Roman Catholic Church, but for democratic change in country; could also be seen as papal blessing for Fidel Castro, who persecuted once-powerful church since taking power in 1959 (M)

headline: Supplies and Demand
abstract: Readers are asked to relate stories of outrageous liberties some people take at work with company property; cartoon (S)

headline: The World That Awaits U.N. Envoy
abstract: Interviews with current and former UN delegates, who comment on diplomatic world that faces Repr Bill Richardson, who will be new US envoy to world body (M)

headline: Singapore, Where Ruin Is Reward For Error
abstract: Interview with Chee Soon Juan, fastest-rising star in Singapore's fragmented and fumbling opposition, who must pay $18,000 fine for misstating statistic to Parliamentary committee and blaming it on typing error (M)

headline: Peso Strengthens and Mexican Stocks Rise
abstract: Mexican stocks rise for second day after peso strengthens and Bank of Mexico cuts borrowing costs, raising hopes that company earnings will benefit; Bolsa index rises 25.46 points, or 0.78 percent, to 3,288.47, after peso rebounds to 13 cents each from 12.7 cents on Oct 16 and central bank cuts cost of overnight loan to 29.54 percent from 31.69 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ovitz Leaving Disney To Start Own Business   Disney said Michael S. Ovitz, one of the top power brokers in Hollywood despite being only second in command at the company, would depart.    Mr. Ovitz was known to be unhappy at Disney and had been talking privately with Sony about possible top jobs. But after the announcement of his departure, he said he was not planning to move to another company but would seek to start his own business instead. $(Page A1.$)    In the bistros and bungalows of Hollywood, the announcement that Mr. Ovitz would leave Disney was big news. But his departure will have little effect on day-to-day business of Disney, analysts said. $(D5.$)     Mr. Ovitz joins a list of Hollywood executives who have left top jobs in the last two years, including Time Warner's Michael Fuchs, Viacom's Frank Biondi, MCA's Tom Pollock and Disney's Jeffrey Katzenberg. $(D5.$)    BankAmerica Plans Big Cuts   BankAmerica said that it would eliminate 3,700 of its 92,700 jobs and close 120 of its 1,017 branches in California. To pay for the cuts, the bank will take a $260 million pretax charge against earnings. $(D2.$)    Spending Is Down and Inflation Mild   Shoppers kept a wary eye on spending as this year's late holiday shopping season got under way; retail sales were down four-tenths of 1 percent in November. Inflation remained in check, with the Consumer Price Index rising only three-tenths of 1 percent. $(D5.$)    The Congressional Budget Office raised its projection of economic growth for next year, helping to narrow the differences between Congress and the White House over the size of the budget deficit. The projections are used to help set tax and spending proposals. $(A27.$)    A Vow to Fight Tougher TV Ratings   A spokesman for the television industry vowed that the networks would fight any effort to toughen a proposed system for rating programs. $(A1.$)    Pension Shortfalls Grow   The Federal pension insurance agency said that the shortfall last year between promised pension benefits and the money set aside to pay for them grew to $64 billion, more than doubling the gap in 1994. $(D6.$)     Siemens to Dismiss 6,000   Siemens of Germany, which has already made big cuts in its work force, said that it would dismiss 6,000 more employees in an effort to return to earnings growth. $(D4.$)     Utility in Pipeline Deal   Western Resources, the expansion-minded Kansas utility, said it would sell its natural gas pipelines and plants to Oneok for $660 million in stock, a deal that will give Western access to Oneok customers across Oklahoma. $(D2.$)    Trade Forum Addresses Labor Issue   As the end of the World Trade Organization's first meeting neared, representatives compromised over whether the group should  push for better standards for workers. $(D4.$)    Schwab Expands Availability   Charles Schwab said it would make a program that sells 600 mutual funds, at no fee, available to other financial institutions. Two banks, Keycorp and First Union, will offer the program, Mutual Fund Onesource. $(D2.$)    State Backs Owner  In Takeover Fight   A takeover battle for a New Hampshire company that makes devices that fold and seal cardboard boxes has taken on broad interest because of the state's response to the hostile bid for the company. Never before, experts say, has a state gone so far as to side with management in a corporate battle for control. $(D2.$)    Disclosure Sought in Fraud Suits   A group of judges and law professors is seeking to have major documents from all securities class-action lawsuits posted in at least one place on the Internet. That way they could be read by lawyers and reporters, regulators and legislators, academics and investors. Market Place. $(D6.$)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Big Dutch Insurer To Buy Providian Unit  In the biggest acquisition of an American life insurer, Aegon of the Netherlands said that it was buying the insurance business of Providian for $2.62 billion in stock. Life insurers have been rapidly consolidating, pressed by high costs and tough competition for consumers' savings from banks and mutual funds.    Aegon also said it would assume Providian debt worth $780 million and preferred stock worth $100 million. And Providian's banking subsidiary will be spun off. $(Page D2.$)    Tandy to Close Electronics Chain  Tandy said that it would close its Incredible Universe stores, which sell everything from computers to refrigerators to cassette tapes but have been losing money. The company will also close 19 of its Computer City stores and take a charge of $170 against earnings. $(D3.$)    NCR's Price: Too High, Even Now?  In one of the most disastrous corporate takeovers of recent years, AT&T acquired NCR for $7.48 billion in 1991. Today it is spinning off the computer maker for less than half that, based on the price of NCR's shares in ''when-issued'' trading. Still, some analysts think even that is too high a price. Market Place. $(D6.$)    Dow Falls 11.54 on Profit-Taking  A wave of late profit-taking snapped the market's eight-day advance. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.54 points, to 6,549.37, trimming its gain for the year to 28 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.63 points, closing at 1,287.75. The losers included some big technology stocks. $(D7.$)    Treasury prices were little changed in thin trading in the last full session of the year. The 30-year bond yield edged up to 6.54 percent from 6.53 percent on Friday. $(D13.$)    Humana to Cut Hundreds of Jobs  Humana, the operator of managed health care plans, said it would cut 700 to 900 jobs, or as much as 5 percent of its work force, next year as it reduces costs to stem a decline in earnings. $(D3.$)    Banc One to Grow in Oklahoma  Banc One said that it had agreed to buy the Liberty Bancorporation of Oklahoma City for $546 million in stock. Banc One operates in 12 states, and this acquisition would give it 29 branches and $2.9 billion in assets in Oklahoma, making it one of the top three banks in the state. $(D3.$)    Merger Could Squeeze Con Edison  The proposed merger of Brooklyn Union and Long Island Lighting would put new pressure on the New York area's largest electricity supplier, Con Edison, to lower rates and allow its customers to seek different energy options, analysts said. $(B1.$)    Executive Quits At HarperCollins  After less than a year as president and publisher of the HarperCollins trade publishing group, Jack McKeown has resigned, the company said. Mr. McKeown's responsibilities will be divided between David Steinberger, a management consultant at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, and Anthea Disney, the president and chief executive of HarperCollins Publishers. $(D4.$)    Chinese Growth and Inflation Slow  China's robust economy expanded at the slowest rate in five years during 1996. The gross domestic product rose 9.7 percent, down from 10.2 percent in 1995. The Government has been holding back growth in an attempt to curb inflation, which fell to a four-year low of 6 percent from 14.8 percent in 1995. $(D6.$)    Stake in Hong Kong Investor Sold  Executives of Citic Pacific, China's largest investment vehicle in Hong Kong, acquired 15.5 percent of the company from its state-owned parent, Citic Hong Kong, for $1.4 billion. Their goal is to increase its independence and growth prospects. The Chinese Government will still own 26.5 percent. $(D6.$)

headline: Japanese Form Chip Consortium
abstract: Japan's major electronics companies are forming consortium to develop alternative approach to microprocessors now used in personal computers; approach will be to combine relatively simple processors on same chip as the memory; new approach was developed by Kazuaki Murakami, college professor; members of new consortium include Fujitsu, Matsushita, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Sony and Toshiba (S)

headline: Two New Standards For Wireless in Duel
abstract: Primeco Personal Communications has begun first United States market test of technology for digital wireless phone service that rivals technology adopted by AT&T Wireless Services for new personal communications services; most other providers also plan to use less-proven code division multiple access technology Primeco tests; differences between technologies, which accomplish same goal in radically different ways, discussed; diagrams; photo (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Expected for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    3-D Geophysical Inc., Englewood, Colo., 4 million shares. Smith Barney.

headline: For the first time in recent years, the magazine industry is basking in a sunny outlook.
abstract: American Magazine Conference's 77th annual meeting attracts 720 publishers, editors, advertisers and suppliers; most see rosy future for magazine industry, after years of poor advertising sales and dire predictions about death of magazines; Publishers Information Bureau reports that total magazine advertising revenue through September was $7.8 billion, up 8.5 percent from comparable period last year (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.94   5.21   5.93        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.01   4.89   5.34        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.17   5.02   5.38        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.69   6.67   6.13        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.92   6.90   6.47        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.93   7.93   7.42        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.89   5.88   6.04          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: U.S. Expands Inquiry Into Alcohol Ads
abstract: Federal Trade Commission probes whether Stroh Brewing Co runs television beer ads aimed at underage viewers; also probes marketing and advertising practices of Seagram Co, Canadian distiller; Federal Communications Commission weighs banning liquor ads in response to end to distillers' self-imposed ban on television and radio ads; Chmn Reed E Hundt says he will work for ban if broadcasters accept liquor ads over holidays, interview (M)

headline: Since July Riot, Indonesia Cracks Down on Private Aid Groups
abstract: Indonesian Government, three months after worst rioting in capital of Jakarta in decades, is working to restore monopoly on political activity; private aid groups have become targets of Government concern because of their special role in country, where they function in many ways as kind of political opposition (M)

headline: U.S. Inquiring Into Texaco's Actions in Suit
abstract: Federal prosecutors reportedly open criminal investigation to determine if senior company executives illegally destroyed documents sought in discrimination lawsuit; subpoenas have been issued seeking evidence, including original audio tapes secretly recorded by former Texaco employee; in the tapes, senior executives are heard discussing plans to shred records and referring to company's minority employees as 'black jelly beans' and 'niggers'; in effort at damage control, Peter I Bijur, Texaco's chairman, tells employees that he deplores words quoted from the tapes, and that he has ordered immediate review of Texaco's programs for diversity and equal employment opportunity; Texaco stock drops 2.6 percent (M)

headline: Bid Is Dropped For Asian Utility
abstract: YTL Corp abandons plans to buy Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd from Hopewell Holdings Ltd after Gordon Wu, founder of Hopewell, would not guarantee his support (S)

headline: Marvel's bad quarter raises doubts about Perelman's plans.
abstract: Outlook for investing in Marvel Entertainment Group's junk bonds discussed in light of firm's expected loss for quarter ended Sept 30; at issue is whether investor Ronald O Perelman, who controls firm, will live up to terms of bonds (M)

headline: Compaq Shakes Up Its Top Management
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp, in latest of series of management shifts, says senior vice president Ross Cooley will retire and be succeeded by James Schraith; hires Alan Lutz to head new division devoted to networking and communications hardware (M)

headline: CALGON CARBON BUYS ADVANCED SEPARATION
abstract: Calgon Carbon Corp says it has agreed to purchase Advanced Separation Technologies Inc from Florida Progress Corp and Potomac Capital Investment Corp for $70 million (S)p

headline: U.S. Has System to Avert Air Collisions
abstract: Aviation industry officials say Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and Kazak Airlines Ilyushin jetliners, which collided over New Delhi, India, with loss of 351 lives, may not have been equipped with computerized collision-avoidance system in place on big passenger planes in US since 1993 (M)

headline: Japan's Forgotten People Try to Make Voices Heard
abstract: Effort to preserve Ainu language and culture are under way in Nibutani, village in Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, where the Ainu lived for centuries before the arrival of other Japanese in 19th century; some studies suggest that Ainu may be more closely related than today's Japanese to the Jomon people who founded Japan's first major civilization some 12,000 years ago; only 24,000 people across Japan now identify themselves as Ainu, and they are almost all of mixed race, a fact that reflects a good measure of acceptance in Japan toward the Ainu; map; photo (M)

headline: Holders of Savings Bonds Get That Sinking Feeling
abstract: On Oct 1, last of tens of thousands of people who bought Series EE bonds--they were sold between March 1983 and October 1986--saw 7.5 percent minimum interest rate vanish; investments lost their guarantee bond by bond, as each passed 10-year anniversary of purchase, which, because of 7.5 percent floor, meant they had reached face value; bonds will still earn higher of new minimum rate or an average market yield pegged to five-year Treasury rates; it gives investors choice between 4 percent floor and market yield of 4.06 precent; many holders of the bonds are not happy; photo (L)

headline: Poor Earnings Send Retail Stocks Lower
abstract: Most retail stocks drop for second day as several retailers report poor earnings; Dillard Department Stores Inc announces its third-quarter net income was $31.6 million, down from $51 million during same period last year; Federated Department Stores Inc says its earnings for quarter ended Nov 2 were $68.7 million, or $41.8 milion after expenses incurred in its acquisition of Broadway stores; sales for third quarter were $3.6 billion, down from $3.7 billion year earlier (M)

headline: UNISYS CORP. (UIS,N)
abstract: Unisys Corp says it earned $14.2 million in third quarter; company reported loss of $32.2 million year earlier (S)

headline: NATO TAKES STEPS TO EXPAND RANKS INTO EAST EUROPE
abstract: NATO takes first formal step to expand alliance to include formerly Communist nations of Eastern Europe and moves quickly to ease Russian apprehensions by offering to negotiate special charter with Russia and to increase military cooperation and contacts; foreign ministers also seek to reassure Russia by pledging that alliance has no intention, plan or reason to move nuclear weapons into territory of any new member; US Sec of State Warren Christopher will discuss issue with Russian Foreign Min Yevgeny Primakov; says NATO's door is open, and that Russia should walk through it (M)

headline: LVMH Buys Stake In Chateau d'Yquem
abstract: LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton buys about 55 percent stake in Chateau d'Yquem, French vineyard (S)

headline: In expanding its luxury appeal to a mass market, Tiffany tries television for the first time.
abstract: Advertising column describing Tiffany & Co's foray into television advertising for first time in company's history; aim is to expand its consumer appeal without compromising its prestigious image; commercials were created by McCann-Erickson (M)

headline: No Rights Mean No Incentive for China's Farmers
abstract: China's peasantry, while better off today than at any time in modern history, is in surly and uncooperative mood; is burdened by taxes and arbitrary local fees; failure of legal system to guarantee farmer's right to land and paltry returns on labor combine to discourage long-term investment needed to boost output and spur exodus to booming cities; map; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: American Express Co names John McDonnell chief financial officer of its travel related services unit (S)

headline: Norwegian Oil Concern to Buy Kuwaiti Unit for $1.23 Billion
abstract: Saga Petroleum AS says it agreed to acquire Santa Fe Exploration (UK) Ltd for $1.23 billion from Kuwait Petroleum Corp; purchase strenghtens Saga's position ahead of British Govt's planned issue of new licenses for oil exploration rights in North Sea (M)

headline: Sometimes, Election Euphoria Doesn't Last
abstract: Rarely has Wall Street celebrated election results as exuberantly as it did the re-election of Bill Clinton and the continuance of Republican domination of Congress.    In the 12 trading days since election eve, through Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 6.43 percent. That is the best election rally since 1928, when investors cheered Herbert Hoover's election by sending the Dow up 8.91 percent, according to figures compiled by James Bianco of Arbor Trading Group in Barrington, Ill.

headline: German Judge Rules G.M., in Discussing Suit, Didn't Slur VW
abstract: German judge throws out Volkswagen AG's defamation suit against General Motors Corp, giving GM its third courtroom victory in its industrial-espionage case against VW; judge rules that GM's Adam Opel unit was within its rights and did not defame VW when it announced plans to sue German car maker as a criminal organization under American racketeering laws; decision removes another potential obstacle in GM's path in its suit contending that GM's former executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, stole reams of company secrets when he was recruited by Volkswagen and joined company in 1993 (M)

headline: Shift at Top of Montgomery Ward Is Seen
abstract: Bernard F Brennan reportedly will soon be replaced as Montgomery Ward & Co chief executive (M)

headline: Natural Gas Drops on Forecast Of Warming Trend in Northeast
abstract: Natural gas futures prices fall on forecasts for warming temperatures next week in Northeast; gas for Jan delivery falls 29.7 cents, to $3.487 per thousand cubic feet (S)

headline: Cybersites for News And Entertainment
abstract: Mecklermedia Corp on Sept 14 will introduce Interactive Advertising Report on its Iworld magazine; American Cybercast, in which companies including Creative Artists Agency, Grey Advertising and Intel Corp hold stakes, on Sept 14 will start World Wide Web network that combines two episodic series with their own Web sites, the Spot and Eon-4, with two new offerings, the Pyramid and Quick Fix Theater (S)

headline: Safeway Offers $1.6 Billion for the Rest of Vons
abstract: Safeway Inc says it is offering to buy two-thirds of Vons Companies it does not already own in $1.6 billion stock deal; merger would create supermarket powerhouse on West Coast; combined operations would have sales of more than $22.5 billion and 1,375 stores operating in 16 states, Washington, DC, and Canada; it would cement Safeway's position as No 2 supermarket chain in country, behind Kroger Co; Steven Burd, chief executive of Safeway, says there is no overlap between Safeway and Vons stores, so no potential regulatory problems and no threat of job losses; notes Safeway has added 8,000 employees in last four years, while reducing number of stores to 1,050 from 1,121; anticipates similar increase in jobs at Vons stores; chart; graphs (M)

headline: Retailers Beat Expectations For October
abstract: Retailers beat analysts' expectations for October same-store sales with numbers that appear to be harbinger for decent holiday shopping season; figures prompt some retailers to raise their earnings estimates for fiscal third quarter; Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, which tracks same-store sales data, gains 3.3 percent in October, well above the five-tenths of 1 percent gain in October 1995; this October proved strong, in part because retailers were going up against easy comparison with last October, and for factors ranging from strong consumer confidence to fresh apparel buys in clothing stores to inexplicable urge that seized many shoppers to shop and buy; graph (M)

headline: People
abstract: William J. Ludwig, executive vice president and executive creative director at Campbell-Ewald Advertising, Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to vice chairman and chief creative officer, a new post.    Patrick Knisley was named president and chief operating officer of Bates Canada, Toronto, a unit of Bates Worldwide, owned by Cordiant P.L.C. He had been an executive vice president at Bates USA, New York, with account management responsibilities on the account of the Miller Brewing Co., part of the Philip Morris Cos. Mr. Knisley succeeds Malcolm Cullen; Bates Canada said Mr. Cullen was leaving ''to pursue other outside interests.''    Brian McMahon, vice president and associate group publisher for the Automotive Group of Hachette Filipacchi Magazines, Los Angeles, was promoted to senior vice president and group publisher. He succeeds William Jeanes, who was named editor in chief of Classic Automotive Register, Troy, Mich., a magazine scheduled to be introduced in April. Hachette Filipacchi is owned by the Lagardere Group.    Rick Lyke, partner and management supervisor at Eric Mower & Associates, Syracuse, was named to head a new full-service office in Albany.

headline: Stocks Fall As Investors Take Profits
abstract: Late wave of year-end profit-taking pulls stocks lower; Dow Jones industrial average falls 11.54 points, to 6,549.37, trimming its gain for the year to 28 percent and snapping eight-day advance; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 2.94 points, to 753.85 (M)

headline: Andreas Freund, Former Times Editor, 71
abstract: Andreas Freund, former New York Times editor and correspondent, dies at age 71 (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of week's events in business and financial world; photos (S)

headline: Agreement On Hebron Still Eludes Negotiators
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators fail to reach accord on Hebron; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat briefs Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Cairo and later meets with Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel in Gaza Strip in effort to resolve final differences; United States mediator, Dennis Ross, is set to return to Israel and renew mediating efforts; photo (M)

headline: 2d Day of Bosnia Fighting Is Worst Since '95 Pact
abstract: Worst fighting since signing of Dayton peace accord erupts between Bosnian Muslims trying to return to former homes near Gajevi, Bosnia, and Serbs who hope to keep them out; Russian troops from NATO-peacekeeping contingent are forced to take cover and withdraw; fighting occurred in so-called zone of separation between Bosnian Serb Republic and Muslim-Croat federation, two portions of country established under treaty; map; photo (M)

headline: Anybody Want a Comics Company?
abstract: Market Watch column on difficult financial position of Marvel Comics; Ron Perelman 'owns' 80 percent stake, but has not lost money because he put up his stock as collateral when he sold three issues of junk bonds in 1993 and 1994; bonds have collapsed and he is under no obligation to pay them off, since they are secured not by his credit but by vanishing value of Marvel shares (S)

headline: Ruling Issued On Milken Pact
abstract: Federal court denies challenge by TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc to 1992 global settlement that ended litigation against former junk bond financier Michael R Milken; says TLC Beatrice was three years too late in filing its challenge; 1992 settlement ended hundreds of civil suits against Milken from investors and regulators who said they were defrauded by Milken and his firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert (S)

headline: Hazardous Cargo
abstract: On-line responses solicited for story on embarrassing moments during business presentations

headline: PRESIDENT OF ENRON SAYS HE WILL RESIGN
abstract: Richard D Kinder to resign as Enron Corp president and chief operating officer; chairman Kenneth L Lay to assume duties of president (S)

headline: Michael Jackson's 'HIStory' shows the growing stature of global marketing.
abstract: Michael Jackson's HIStory album, a disappointment in the US in 1995, remains a top seller in dozens of European and Asian countries and may even realize Sony Music's goal of 20 million worldwide sales; other pop musicians are following Jackson in going after the global market; Asian and Eastern Europe are the world's fastest-growing markets for pop music and are No. 1 priorities for most major labels; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on Sept. 29 about the growth of the nanny business misstated the application of minimum-wage laws to nannies' pay. Under the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act, live-in nannies are entitled to the minimum wage for their time spent working; they are not covered by the law's overtime provisions, although some states do require overtime pay. Most nannies who do not live in their employers' households are covered by the Federal minimum wage and by the overtime provisions.    The article also misstated the minimum number of employees that a place of business must have before it is covered by New York State and New York City statutes on sexual harassment. It is four, not five.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.00   5.04   5.65        3-MO. headline: U.N. Fails to Authorize Peace Force for Zaire
abstract: United Nations Security Council fails to adopt resolution creating international military force to aid Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire, despite Sec Gen Boutros-Ghali's warnings of 'new genocide' by starvation; US strongly opposed resolution sponsored by Germany and France, expressing reservations about sending troops into volatile region without clear mission; US also hopes to broker cease-fire in ethnic fighting (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of week's events affecting financial world; photos

headline: Undercover Tactics By TV Magazines Fall Under Attack
abstract: Newsgathering tactics of television news magazines are coming under new form of legal attack, as targets find increasing success with argument that use of hidden cameras and other undercover techniques trample on their rights; network aides see jury verdicts against such tactics reflecting growing public skepticism about television (M)

headline: Slate Delays Fee for Readers
abstract: Slate, Microsoft Corp's on-line magazine of political commentary, will delay charging its readers a subscription fee for another three months; Slate announced move on its World Wide Web site in note to readers from editor, Michael Kinsley; Microsoft has been unable to develop workable on-line billing system (S)

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP CO. (CPB,N)
abstract: Campbell Soup Co reports first-quarter earnings were $88 million, compared with $219 million year ago, reflecting $160 million charge this quarter to cover costs of revamping that includes plant closings; sales rose 3 percent, to $2.05 billion (S)

headline: Retaliating, Mexico Increases 8 Tariffs on U.S.
abstract: Mexico raises import tariffs on eight American products, responding sharply to recent decision by Washington to punish Mexican straw-broom makers with higher duties; trade duel brings first tariff increases between two countries since North American Free Trade Agreement went into effect in January 1994 (M)

headline: Revised Data Show Layoff Rate Constant in 1990's
abstract: Revised figures released by Labor Dept show that despite economic recovery and substantial number of new jobs, rate of layoffs in middle of decade remained roughly constant compared with early 1990's; figures also show that number of people who identify themselves as having lost a job increased in middle of decade, providing further statistical underpinning for anxiety and job insecurity that have become staples of nation's economic and political discourse; Bob Dole's campaign says revised figures are evidence of why economic anxiety is 'spreading like a virus through America's work force'; Clinton Adm says figures are contradicted by other statistical evidence that suggests layoffs are down at time when unemployment is extremely low; graph (M)

headline: Artists are trying to enhance the image of the ho-hum enhanced CD.
abstract: Om's Records is producing enhanced CD's, for use in CD-ROM drives, that go beyond digital liner notes to provide context for music; packages CD along with audio-only CD, giving buyers two disks for about price of most audio CD's; drawing (M)

headline: Lowest Rate Since April On Long Bond
abstract: Yield on Treasury's 30-year bond falls to its lowest level since April 1 after fresh data suggests economy is continuing to slow, with no sign of inflation; price of 30-year bond increases 26/32 of point, to 101 14/32; graph (M)

headline: F.B.I. Trap Snares a Wall Street Recidivist
abstract: Unusual Federal Bureau of Investigation sting operation in which agents posing as brokers offered to put customers' money into stocks being promoted in return for payoffs has netted 46 arrest warrants; Joseph V Pignatiello, one of stock promoters charged, has been able to remain active in industry despite being barred from business since 1982; graph (M)

headline: Iraqis Look Ahead to Fattening Of Rations as Part of U.N. Deal
abstract: With limited amount of oil flowing to foreign buyers for first time since Persian Gulf War in 1991, ordinary Iraqis are eagerly waiting to witness alchemy that promises to turn oil into food; Iraqi Government has promised as part of deal with UN to fatten meager package that has become main source of sustenance for most of country's 20 million people; redemption of promise may have to wait until revenues from new contracts reach new UN account; photo; map (M)

headline: Dollar-Denominated Stocks an Elixir in China
abstract: China's long-moribund stock markets have suddenly come alive as local investors pour their money into dollar-denominated B shares instead of Chinese-currency-denominated A shares in face of lax enforcement of ban on such investments; B shares prices have soared since Nov 1 to correct price imbalance between A and B shares; graph (M)

headline: Another Senior Funds Executive Resigns From Fidelity
abstract: Fidelity Investments, which in last year has seen its market share stop growing and has faced investor unrest over lagging performance of some of its top mutual funds, loses another senior funds exec; Neal Litvack, who for last four years had charted rapid growth of retail mutual funds business of Fidelity Investments, resigns to pursue other interests (M)

headline: Italy's Marxist Party Still a Power
abstract: Italy's small Communist Refounding party æstill holds outsized influence on national policies at time when country, like much of Western Europe, is under heavy pressure to trim its social state; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BREED TECHNOLOGIES INC., Lakeland, Fla., which manufactures automotive crash sensors and airbag systems, acquired the steering wheel unit of United Technologies Corp., for an undisclosed amount.     GATX CORP., San Francisco, said its GATX Capital Corp. unit had acquired the remaining ownership interest in Centron DPL Co. of Eden Prairie, Minn., a provider of computer networks services and equipment. Previously, GATX had a 50 percent interest in Centron DPL.     ALLEGHENY TELEDYNE INC., Pittsburgh, a manufacturer of specialty metals, has sold commercial real estate in Northridge, Calif., for $25 million to Krausz Cos., a San Francisco commercial real estate firm.      UNISYS CORP., Blue Bell, Pa., said its Federal Systems division has been awarded a $200 million contract to provide computer networking equipment for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

headline: PLACER DOME OFFERS DEAL TO CANCEL STAKE IN HIGHLANDS
abstract: Canada's Placer Dome Inc offers to cancel its stake in takeover target Highlands Gold Ltd, Australia, in return for Highlands' 25 percent stake in Porgera gold mine in Papua New Guinea plus cash settlement; offer follows rejection by Highlands board of Placer Dome's takeover bid of 75 Australian cents a share (336 million US) (S)

headline: 60 Colombian Mothers Make Plea to Rebels for Abducted Sons
abstract: Group of Colombian mothers, organized by Vida Foundation, makes public plea for release of their sons who were abducted by leftist guerrillas of Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces who overran their military base at Las Delicias (M)

headline: As Thousands of Refugees Leave Camps in Zaire, U.S. Reassesses the Need for Military Force
abstract: United States is reassessing need for military force, led by Canada, to rescue Rwandan refugees in Zaire, now that hundreds of thousands of them have left refugee camps for home; Pres Clinton has reiterated American willingness to take part in the force, should one remain necessary, and says contingency planning is proceeding (M)

headline: GEMSTAR TO BUY STARSIGHT IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Gemstar International Group Ltd will buy Starsight Telecast Inc in stock swap valued at $273 million, or $10.23 a share (S)

headline: Yeltsin and Ukrainian Find Few Solutions on Fleet Issues
abstract: Yeltsin and Ukrainian Find Few Solutions on Fleet Issues**Ukrainian Pres Leonid Kuchma meets with Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin in effort to ease tension between their nations; they discuss fate of Russian bases and warships in Black Sea; map; photo (M)

headline: To Portuguese, an Artificial Quake Is Still a Quake
abstract: Portuguese Government suspends experiment by scientists who planned to detonate 22 tons of TNT at sea to simulate small earthquake (M)

headline: Elections Fail to Clarify Outlook for Japan
abstract: Liberal Democratic Party, which has ruled Japan for most of period since World War II and is considered pro-business, met with only partial success in national elections that were held on Oct 20; it strengthened its hand in lower house of Parliament, but not quite enough to completely avoid possibility of repeat of current unstable coalition Government (M)

headline: Computer Chip Sales Ratio Up
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association reports computer chip industry's book-to-bill ratio rose to 1.15, Nov, from revised 1.11 in Oct (S)

headline: As Settlements Grow, Palestinians Talk of Coming Explosion
abstract: Palestinian resentment has risen throughout West Bank in recent weeks as plans for new building in settlements have been announced, and some work has begun; latest steps have brought demand for clarification from Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, who calls renewed activity breach of Israeli-Palestinian accords (M)

headline: Modell's Looking For New Ideas
abstract: Modell's Sporting Goods in New York seeks creative ideas for its advertising campaign, with annual spending of $12 million; Modell's uses in-house agency for production (S)

headline: Big Jury Award In Injury Case Over Keyboards
abstract: Federal jury awards nearly $6 million to three women who sustained arm, wrist and hand injuries while using Digital Equipment Corp keyboards; case is first big victory against computer keyboard maker; Patricia Gerassy wins $5.3 million, Jill Jackson $306,000 and Jeanette Rotolo $278,000 (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/   Quaker Oats may soon report a $1 billion loss to come clean on its Snapple problems.  By Barnaby Feder.    INVESTING IT /Page 5/   Will control of Congress be split between the parties? Opinion is split not only on that, but also on how the markets would react.  By Jonathan Fuerbringer.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 7/   Elaine Garzarelli predicts the stock market will fall by 15 to 25 percent. So what's she doing? Starting a mutual fund. By Edward Wyatt.    EARNING IT /Page 10/   The ticklish decision of who's responsible when a worker loses money in a 401(k) or similar retirement plan will be decided by the courts. By Margaret Crane.

headline: Business Was a Big Winner, Too
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says that in 1996 elections, corporate America defeated host of state ballot initiatives that were intended to circumscribe ability of business to operate freely; says there was disappointment in certain business circles that Republicans did not put Bob Dole in White House and achieve kind of overwhelming majority in Congress that would let conservatives set agenda of sharply lower capital gains taxes and less Government regulation; says rise in stock market would indicate that Wall Street is pleased that status quo was left intact in Washington and that neither party will be able to impose liberal or conservative ideology without having to compromise with its opponents (M)

headline: Dead Language? Irish Soap Opera May Wake It Up
abstract: Ireland's first Gaelic-language television channel will begin operating in An Spideal, thriving town on shore of Galway Bay which is one of few areas where most people speak Gaelic; new channel, financed by $15 million in annual Government grants, has provoked growing national debate; virtually everyone, particularly 166 members of Parliament, of whom fewer than half are fluent in Gaelic, publicly supports channel and spread of ancestral language; privately many say it is waste of money and that English, as language of international commerce, will and should remain country's primary tongue; photo; map (M)

headline: Nextel Narrows Its Review
abstract: Nextel Communications names three finalists for its account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million; they are Houston Herstek Favat, Ketchum Advertising and Mullen Advertising (S)

headline: INTERLAKE SELLING ITS PACKAGING UNIT
abstract: The Interlake Corp agrees to sell its packaging businesses to Samuel Manu-Tech Inc; terms not disclsoed (S)

headline: Belarus Knight on a Charger Carries Hammer and Sickle
abstract: Thousands of Belarus demonstrators march through Minsk to protest Pres Aleksandr Lukashenko's plan to gain near-absolute power, demanding he abandon attempt to rewrite constitution; photo; map; Lukashenko portrays himself as model of flexibility, offering to delay, but not drop, referendum on expanding his powers; Belarus appears to be going back in time five years after gaining independence from old Soviet Union; privatization is halted, bank accounts of independent newspapers are frozen, leaders are hanging onto 18 Soviet nuclear missiles and Soviet hammer-and-sickle has replaced nationalist flag atop parliament building; Lukashenko, former director of collective farm, was elected on reform platform but is now trying to return to strong-man rule; he insists Belarus is free, even as he scribbles down names of reporters asking unfriendly questions (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization               Dec. 20   Dec. 13   Dec. 22          1996   1996   1995       Gasoline production, daily   7.6   7.7   7.6       Distillate production, daily   3.6   3.6   3.4       Gasoline stocks   192.0   191.5   196.4       Distillate stocks   121.3   123.2   128.0       Crude imports, daily   7.2   7.9   6.3       Product imports, daily   1.7   1.8   1.5       Crude stocks   292.9   298.0   314.7       Crude production, daily   6.5   6.5   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   93.3   93.5   91.4          (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: China Sentences Tibetan on a Fulbright to 18 Years for Spying
abstract: China sentences Tibetan music expert, Ngawang Choepel, to 18 years in prison, charging Fulbright scholar of returning to native land to conduct espionage under guise of filming traditional music and dance (M)

headline: Gangs Descend, to Pick Bosnia's Carcass Clean
abstract: Political chaos and poverty that continue to grip Bosnia 10 months after signing of peace accord have spawned thriving criminal underworld; well-organized gangs with plenty of money and roots in Milan, Hamburg and Frankfurt are building empires and taking advantage of country's division into Serbian, Croatian and Muslim entities; their size and reach threaten to overwhelm Bosnia's weak and divided law enforcement system; Western diplomats warn their swift rise presents one of gravest perils to post-war Bosnia; map; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Take A Wild Ride And Close Up
abstract: Stock market has volatile up-and-down day after eight-day surge, with Dow Jones industrial average leaping almost 65 points beofre closing 35.03 points higher, at 6,348.03 (M)

headline: Four Are Selected For Hall of Fame
abstract: American Advertising Federation to induct Jo Foxworth, late Morris L Hite, William E LaMothe and late Frank L Mingo into Advertising Hall of Fame (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    A Federal jury in North Carolina will decide whether to award Food Lion damages in its suit against ABC-TV.    The Conference Board reports on leading indicators for November.    The National Association of Realtors reports on home resales for November.    TUESDAY    Some financial markets close early for New Year's Eve.    The Commerce Department reports on new-home sales in November.    The Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for December.    THURSDAY    The Labor Department reports on initial claims for unemployment insurance.     FRIDAY    Kofi Annan of Ghana begins a five-year term as Secretary General of the United Nations.

headline: UAL's Profit Surged 30.8% In 3d Quarter
abstract: UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, says earnings rose 30.8 percent in third quarter; company earned $437 million, up from $334 million for year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 8.7 percent, to $4.49 billion from $4.13 billion; chart (M)

headline: TJX SELLING CATALOGUE UNIT TO BRYLANE
abstract: TJX Companies to sell its Chadwick's of Boston catalogue business to Brylane LP for $328 million in cash, notes and receivables (S)

headline: G.I. Charm Overcomes Anxieties In Hungary
abstract: Neither fantasies nor fears of residents of Taszar, Hungary, have materialized during year in which village served as base for US military operations in Bosnia; many had dreams of instant wealth from world's richest army, and others fears about dive in moral standards as free-wheeling GI's behaved as depicted in Hollywood movies; map (M)

headline: Digital Posts A Big Loss, And Stock Hits Two-Year Low
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp stuns Wall Street by reporting quarterly loss that is more than three times what most analysts had forecast; news sends Digital's stock plunging 23 percent to its lowest point in two years and raises serious question about management's ability to sustain turnaround that stalled earlier this year; Digital reports loss of $65.9 million in its first quarter, in contrast to earnings of $48 million in year-earlier quarter; total revenues tumbled 12 percent, to $2.9 billion from $3.3 billion a year earlier; Digital shares close at $29, down $5.375 (L)

headline: Stocks Set Another Record on Very Strong Earnings Reports
abstract: Stocks rise after Federal Reserve leaves benchmark lending rates unchanged; Dow Jones industrial average rises 8.20, to 6,274.24, its sixth consecutive record close (M)

headline: Turning Colombia's Drug Plots Over to Peasant Plowshares
abstract: Agrarian Reform Min Alba Ortilla Duenas is hoping new Colombian law authorizing seizure of drug dealers' assets will ease plight of landless peasants; says 3.7 million acres could be used to settle 120,000 families, speeding up national timetable for land redistribution; powerful Farmers Society of Colombia, which backs move, comlains drug dealers drive up land and labor prices and turn most fertile land into unproductive estates (M)

headline: Nokia and AT&T In Equipment Deal
abstract: Nokia says it has received $240 million three-year contract to provide mobile telephones to AT&T Corp's AT&T Wireless Service unit (S)

headline: At Volkswagen, the Past Isn't Pretty
abstract: Volkswagen AG publishes new book on company history, including Nazi associations and use of slave labor; photo (S)

headline: Breaking From the Gate, Slowly
abstract: Two years after first of three big Texas horse race tracks opened, two have filed for bankruptcy and the other, Lone Star Park outside of Dallas, has reorganized even before its first race; Lone Star has already opened Las Vegas-style pavilion for betting on races across the country; other tracks, Retama Park in Selma, Tex, and Sam Houston Race Park in Houston, Tex, are lobbying to add casino card games; stillbirth of Texas horse racing has several causes, but most of all, horsemen failed to understand that Texans want to gamble a lot more than they want to watch horses; and picking a lottery number, or playing slot machines at a casino across Louisiana border, is easier than analyzing performance charts; tables; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Is Nothing Sacred? Very Little on This TV Show
abstract: Interview with Ephraim Sidon, director of Hartzufim, popular and irreverent Israeli television puppet show that deals in political satire; photo (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Listing of Government and industry reports scheduled to be released this week (S)

headline: Soldiers Force Refugees Into Rwanda From Tanzania
abstract: Thousands of Rwandan refugees cross border into homeland from Tanzania after soldiers forced them to leave camps where they lived for more than two years; hundreds of thousands are forced from largest camp at Ngara in western Tanzania; mass movement appears to be another step toward end of refugee crisis that has undermined peace in central Africa for two years; map; photo (M)

headline: Craftsman of Corporate Culture
abstract: Biographical profile of John R Walter in view of his being named president and chief operating officer of AT&T Corp; discusses Walter's record as chairman and chief executive of R R Donnelley & Sons and challenges he will face at AT&T; notes that Walter was born on Jan 20, 1947; graphs; photo of Walter with AT&T chmn Robert E Allen (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: Table of United States petroleum data

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates (S)

headline: I.R.S. Considering Easier Rules on Some Mergers
abstract: Internal Revenue Service has proposed easing rules governing some tax-free mergers and acquisitions; tax specialists say that the change would not cause wave of new mergers, but that it would make it easier to arrange tax-free deals, which save public and private companies millions of dollars in taxes (M)

headline: Booksellers End 3-Year Lawsuit
abstract: American Booksellers Assn says it has settled antitrust lawsuit against Random House; publisher has agreed to offer same prices and promotional allowances to all bookstores, ranging from small independents to giant chains; Random House settlement comes three months after similar suits were settled with other publishing companies (S)

headline: Oil Prices Register Decline On Signs of Ample Supplies
abstract: Oil futures prices fall sharply; crude oil for Jan delivery drops $1.04, to $23.38 a barrel (S)

headline: Texas Instruments Takes Bids for Sale of Defense Unit
abstract: Analysts say Texas Instruments' reported plan to sell its defense electronics business and concentrate on making chips would bring higher but more volatile profits; Thomas J Engibous, new head of company, is known to be dissatisfied with company's recent performance, and has offered early retirement to more than 5,000 people, nearly 9 percent of his employees (M)

headline: Philip Morris Wins Bidding in Portugal
abstract: Philip Morris Companies wins bidding to take over Portuguese tobacco company Tabaqueira SA, as part of the nation's push toward privatization; Philip Morris's bid for 65 percent of company is valued at $212.1 million (US) (S)

headline: Bozell Worldwide Wins 2 Accounts
abstract: Bozell Worldwide, New York, is awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $98 million; accounts are Nobody Beats the Wiz and Lycos Inc (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Restoring The House of Rothschild
abstract: Profile of House of Rothschild, 253-year-old family banking dynasty, in light of reunion of English and French branches of family; Sir Evelyn Rothschild, head of N M Rothschild & Son, London bank, and French cousin, Baron David de Rothschild, founder of Rothschild & Cie Banque, say they will become partners to rebuild banking empire that has been fragmented for generations, interview; Sir Evelyn names cousin as his successor; chronology of events; photos; drawings; diagram (L)

headline: As Elf Aquitaine's image improves, so do its A.D.R.'s
abstract: Outlook for investing in Elf Aquitaine's American depository receipts discussed in light of recent price rise; French Government helped change negative perceptions of firm when it sold most of its remaining stake this month (M)8

headline: Boutros-Ghali Hails Man Who Will Succeed Him
abstract: UN Sec Gen Boutros-Ghali issues statement congratulating his successor, Kofi Annan of Ghana (S)

headline: At Coke, Less Fizz Than Met The Eye
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's cut in shipment of soft-drink concentrate to bottlers around world cut third-quarter earnings by $200 million; raises question of whether Coke forced bottlers to accept excessive inventories to make its growth appear steady; graph (M)

headline: Bank of America Picks Finalists
abstract: Bank of America names four advertising agency finalists to compete for its combined corporate image and retail accounts, which has been handled by Ketchum Advertising and Evans Group; Ketchum is among finalists (S)

headline: Indian and Kazak Officials Trade Accusations in Air Collision
abstract: Indian aviation officials are embroiled in finger-pointing battle with officials of Kazak Airlines, whose Ilyushin 76 collided with Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 over New Delhi, killing 349 people; several top officials of Indian aviation agency deny suggestions that country's air traffic control system is dangerously outdated; say most likely cause was pilot error, or equipment malfunction, on part of Kazak plane, which was descending to land at time of accident; Kazak officials angrily deny suggestions; criticisms of Indian air traffic control system in Indian news media noted (M)

headline: Bank of Scotland Posts 24% Rise in Profit
abstract: Bank of Scotland PLC says its pretax profit rose 24 percent in first half of year to $507.5 million (S)

headline: British Utility Lifts Payout in Face of Bid
abstract: Northern Electric PLC, seeking to fend off takeover bid by CE Electric UK, says it will raise dividend by 17 percent and develop its businesses through joint ventures (S)

headline: Conflicting Dreams of Arabs and Jews Stoke Rage in Hebron
abstract: Hebron, with its pale stone houses, crumbling archways and sacred monuments, chafes under Israeli-imposed curfew while Israeli and Palestinian officials meeting in Washington work to shape next phase of ancient city's existence; Hebron is last West Bank city still patrolled by Israeli troops; previous Israeli Govt agreed that most Israeli troops will be pulled out; map (M)

headline: Stocks Stagger a Bit, With Dow Off 19.75
abstract: Stocks stumble in volatile day of trading; Dow Jones industrial average and Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks drop for second consecutive day; Dow ends at 6,422.94, down 19.75 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PLAID CLOTHING GROUP, New York, a men's apparel company that has operated under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since July 1995, will sell all its assets to Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, for an undisclosed amount.    CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP., Philadelphia, said that it would buy back up to 22 million shares, or 10 percent of its common stock, by the end of next year. The company also increased its quarterly dividend to 47 cents a share from 42 cents, payable on Jan. 1 to shareholders of record on Dec. 9.    NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL CORP., Chicago, the truck maker, said it planned to spend $167 million to build a truck assembly plant in Mexico.    WESTERN PACIFIC AIRLINES INC., Colorado Springs, said it would buy six more Boeing 737-300 airplanes to supplement the 15 such planes it owns.

headline: Banana Republic Chooses Baron & Baron
abstract: Gap Inc's Banana Republic retail chain names Fabien Baron and his Baron & Baron agency to serve as lead creative resource for its advertising (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: TEXTRON TO BUY GERMAN PLASTIC TANK MAKER
abstract: Textron Inc says it will buy Kautex-Werke AG from Klockner-Werke AG for about $310 million (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about investing in stamp collecting misstated the period covered by a 14 percent annual rate of increase in the value of collectible United States stamps. The increase has occurred since last spring, not since November 1991.

headline: Sayonara to Mondale, the Custom-Made Envoy
abstract: Walter Mondale leaves Japan, where he has been US ambassador since 1993; 68-year-old former Vice President, who is much-revered in Japan, says he is returning to Minnesota, where people will laugh at his jokes and where his wife, Joan, will once again enter rooms ahead of him; photo of couple at farewell party, greeting sumo wrestler Daigoro Takamiyama (Tokyo Journal) (S)
