headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Growth Slowed To 2.2% in Third Quarter  In one of the last major economic indicators before the Presidential election, the Government reported a slowdown in the growth rate in the third quarter, to 2.2 percent from 4.7 percent in the second quarter. Economists -- and, not surprisingly, the opposing camps in the campaign -- differ on whether this is the beginning of a longer downturn or a brief slowing of an expansion that can be sustained well into 1997. $(Page A1.$)    Treasury bond prices rose initially on the news of weakening growth, but fell back after a report of stronger-than-expected housing sales. The 30-year bond's yield edged up to 6.70 percent from 6.68 percent on Tuesday. $(D17.$)    Technology shares regained some ground, sending the Nasdaq up 3.18 points, to 1,206.23. But most stocks slipped, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 13.79, to 5,993.23, as the mixed economic data heightened anxiety before tomorrow's employment report. $(D10.$)    Bay Networks Appoints New Chief  Bay Networks landed a new chief executive, naming a longtime Intel executive who was instrumental in persuading I.B.M. to adopt Intel's microprocessor for its PC's. $(D7.$)    An Offer for Carter-Wallace  Marvin Davis, the billionaire investor, announced an $835 million bid for Carter-Wallace, the maker of Trojan condoms and Arrid deodorant. $(D2.$)    Bethlehem Quitting Structural Steel  Bethlehem Steel, the last major steel producer to battle the minimills for the structural steel market, conceded defeat. It said that it would sell four unprofitable units, including its structural steel mill, and that it would close the operations if no buyer was found. $(D2.$)    Fed Lowers Banking Barriers  The Fed voted to knock down some of the walls that separate banks from securities affiliates, allowing companies like J. P. Morgan and Bankers Trust greater freedom to market and develop investment products. $(D2.$)    Medicare Patients Win in Court  A Federal judge in Tucson, Ariz., expanded the rights of Medicare patients in H.M.O.'s, saying they are entitled to immediate hearings when they are denied medical services. $(B15.$)     A Well-Promoted Public Offering  The difference between a small company selling for pennies a share and one selling for $9 a share seems to be promotion -- at least in the case of a hot initial public offering for Chem International, a small maker of vitamins. Floyd Norris: Market Place. $(D10.$)    An Expanding Luxury Empire  In airport duty-free shops and on fancy shopping boulevards, the products of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton are easy to find. Having acquired many of the most expensive, most luxurious brands of Champagnes, perfume, fashion and luggage, Bernard Arnault, who controls the company, is trying to gain additional outlets with his bid for DFS Group. $(D9.$)    Lotus to Offer Web Software  I.B.M.'s Lotus Development unit said it would strip key technology out of its Notes software and sell it as a separate product called Weblicator to enhance the ability of computer users to organize and exchange data over the Internet. $(D7.$)

headline: Stake in Chicago Board
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade says it is selling 49 percent stake in its brokering subsidiary to Liberty Brokerage Inc and Prebon Yamane USA with aim of creating new electronic market in over-the-counter products; venture is expected to start trading in the summer (S)

headline: Prices Plunge As Factory Output Climbs
abstract: Treasury prices drop sharply after stronger-than-expected manufacturing report; 30-year Treasury declines 22/32, to 98 13/32, to yield 6.62 percent, up from 6.57 percent on Friday; graph of 3-month Treasury bills (M)

headline: Manufactured Home Makes New Bid for Chateau Properties
abstract: Manufactured Home Communities Inc withdraws its hostile tender offer for rival Chateau Properties Inc and proposes revised bid aimed at winning over Chateau's largest shareholders; new deal offers Chateau investors $26 a share in cash, or sweetened package of convertible preferred securities, to appeal to those Chateau shareholders who want to defer taxes; J P Morgan, which is advising Manufactured, values convertible securities at $26 apiece; new offer has total value of $387 million; this is latest attempt by Manufactured to head off merger between Chateau and ROC Communities Inc (M)

headline: Stocks Climb in Tokyo
abstract: Japanese stocks close higher on Nov 19, with Nikkei index of 225 issues up 159.51 points, at 20,955.88 (S)

headline: Presenting the brew that wants to make Manchester famous.
abstract: Popular, award-winning advertising campaign for British brew called Boddingtons Pub Ale is being exported to America along with product it is pitching; advertising for the ale, christened 'the cream of Manchester' by Bartle Bogle Hegarty, ad agency in London that considered tag line a tactic to draw attention to brand's creamy head; Labatt USA imports and markets Boddingtons under agreement with Whitbread Beer Co division of Whitbread PLC; photo (L)

headline: Afghan Factions Still Fight It Out, but Talk of Peace Continues
abstract: Fighting 30 miles north of Kabul is current focal point of war in Afghanistan; goal is to clinch control of nearby military airfield, which served as nerve center for Soviet military occupation of country in 1980's; recent days have brought negotiations, but militant Taliban continue to balk at suggestions that they should share power in Kabul, where they have imposed harsh form of Muslim fundamentalist law; map (M)

headline: Treaty Banning Chemical Arms Worldwide Is Set for Spring
abstract: Treaty banning chemical weapons worldwide is set to go into force next spring, having attained needed 65 ratifications with approval by Hungary; treaty bars development, production, stockpiling or use of such arms and calls for destruction of existing stocks and factories that produce them; treaty applies to United States, Russia, China and other nations which have signed but not ratified it (M)7

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., said its Missiles and Space unit had more than 1,000 job openings and expected to hire about 3,000 people at its unit in Sunnyvale, Calif., during the next three years.    NATIONSCREDIT CORP., Dallas, the consumer finance subsidiary of Nationsbank Corp., said it planned to sell 29 branches in the Northeast and Northwest.    SUNRIVER CORP., Austin, Tex., a maker of computer network products, plans to cut 100 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring plan. The company will take a charge of $2.5 million in the fourth quarter.

headline: Freud in Russia: Return of the Repressed
abstract: Variety of Western methods of psychotherapy, banned by Soviet authorities for three generations, are flourishing in Russia, competing with more dubious methods of folk medicine, witchcraft and psychic healing; of all different methods and schools that have taken root since collapse of Communism, Freudian psychoanalysis is by far most challenging and controversial; in kind of cultural role reversal, Russian therapists are shaking free of 70 years of drug-based Soviet psychiatry to explore id and ego just as many of Western counterparts are turning away from such long-term talk therapies; rediscovery of Freud and psychoanalytic therapy has put Russia squarely on collision course with trends in West; photo (M)

headline: GTE (GTE, N)
abstract: GTE Corp reports 9 percent rise in third-quarter earnings; net income rose to $756 million from $695 million in 1995 period; revenues grew 7 percent, to $5.34 billion from $5 billion; table (S)û

headline: Nicaraguans Go to Polls Facing Stark Choice for President
abstract: Nicaraguans vote in national elections more than six years after casting ballot ending Sandinista Revolution; although 24 parties are competing, Presidential race has boiled down to contest between Arnoldo Aleman and former Pres Daniel Ortega Saavedra; public opinion survey show Aleman, former Mayor of Managua and leader of rightist Liberal Alliance, with narrow lead, making runoff likely; election will also choose 90 members of Parliament as well as mayors, city council members and delegates to region's Central American Parliament; map; photo (M)

headline: DRAVO EXPLORING POSSIBLE SALE OR JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Dravo Corp to explore options that include buying another firm, forming joint ventures or selling itself (S)

headline: Copper Continues to Gain; Coffee Prices Also Increase
abstract: Copper jumps for second day on futures market, reaching highest price in two weeks, following forecast for smaller surplus than traders expected; coffee prices rise (M)

headline: Japan Announces New Plan to Deregulate Financial Markets
abstract: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan announces plan for sweeping financial change that he says would create financial center to rival New York and London by 2001; plan could help eliminate some of regulation that makes it difficult and costly to do business in Japan; Hashimoto is hoping to emulate so-called Big Bang in London decade ago, when brokerage commissions were deregulated, freeing financial markets and setting stage for strong growth; move could bring about lucrative opportunities for foreign financial institutions accustomed to competing in open markets; but in Japan there is great political opposition, which could dilute and delay changes envisioned (M)

headline: Tories Slip Into Minority; Labor Silent on Forcing Election
abstract: Sir John Gorst defects from Conservative Party, depriving it of its majority in British Parliament, as Government of Prime Minister John Majors comes under attack from members of his fractious party over his insistence on staying engaged in discussions with Europe about a common currency; Tony Blair, Labor leader, expresses unrestrained delight but avoids calling for an imminent test of the Government, which can count on support of nine Ulster Unionist MP's to maintain control of Parliament; Kenneth Clarke, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is focus of dispute over his strong support of British integration into Europe; photos (M)

headline: VW Strives To Make Up With G.M.
abstract: Volkswagen AG's moves to settle dispute with General Motors Corp over its hiring of former GM aide Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua seem to have further irked GM; GM is angry that Lopez, who resigned from Volkswagen, still gets full pay and that VW gave some of his duties to aide who is codefendant in industrial espionage suit; is upset that VW chief executive Ferdinand Piech failed to acknowledge VW wrongdoing in expressing regrets (M)

headline: Citibank Plans Global Campaign
abstract: Citibank subsidiary of Citicorp begins seeking advertising agency to create what it describes as first Citibank worldwide brand campaign; Adweek estimates billings at more than $100 million (S)

headline: MARK IV INDUSTRIES IS SELLING ITS AUDIO BUSINESS
abstract: Mark IV Industries to sell its Mark IV Audio business to an affiliate of Greenwich Street Capital Partners Inc for $151.5 million in cash (S)

headline: While Lincoln-Mercury may not be trying for a new image, it's sure trying to sharpen the old one.
abstract: Robyn Meredith (Advertising) column discusses humorous advertising campaign developed by Young & Rubicam for Ford Motor Co's Lincoln-Mercury line; says ads poke fun at notion that line's vehicles carry a sofa-on-wheels image geared to the over-60 buyer (M)

headline: Mideast Talks Are Fruitless, Arafat Warns
abstract: Yasir Arafat tells Palestinian Legislative Council that four days of negotiations regarding Israeli pullout from Hebron have achieved nothing so far, and that Palestinians should be prepared 'to confront all possibilities'; Arafat does not elaborate on point in his somber speech, but after outbreak of violence last month and subsequent Israeli military blockade of Palestinian areas, it is evident that he is warning of further travails and perhaps violence (M)

headline: CS Holding to Take a Charge Of $3.8 Billion for Bad Loans
abstract: CS Holding will take a charge of $3.8 billion to cover bad loans, joining its major Swiss rivals in preparing for a floor of sour loans as the domestic economy flounders (S)

headline: 2 Settlers Die in Attack on West Bank Family
abstract: Palestinian militants attack family of Jewish settlers near West Bank village of Surda, fatally shooting boy and mother and wounding five others; map; photo (M)

headline: PETSMART AGREES TO ACQUIRE PET CITY HOLDINGS
abstract: Petsmart Inc says that it had agreed to acquire Pet City Holdings PLC in stock swap valued at $229.4 million, giving company a base for planned expansion in Europe (S)

headline: HUNTSMAN BUYING AMOCO'S POLYSTYRENE BUSINESS
abstract: Huntsman Chemical Corp says it is buying polystyrene business of Amoco Corp's chemical unit for undisclosed price; says it will retain all Amoco workers at two plants it is acquiring (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn, Kalamazoo, Mich., to Lally, McFarland & Pantello/Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising, to handle advertising for Camptosar, a cancer treatment. The account had been at the Ferguson Communications Group, Parsippany, N.J., a unit of WPP Group. Billings have not been determined.

headline: Recycler Purchase Studied
abstract: Schnitzer Steel Industries says Federal regulators asked for more data on its plan to buy Proler International Corp (S)

headline: Pitney Bowes Is Marketing A Digital Copier by Minolta
abstract: Pitney Bowes Inc will introduce line of digital copiers that are made by Minolta but carry the Pitney Bowes name; black-and-white versions will sell for $17,500, compared with as little as $4,000 for analog copiers; color copiers will go for about $70,000; unlike analog copiers, digital copiers put images into computer-readable language, process known as digitizing; copiers can then link to electronic networks and receive and transmit to and from other copiers and computers (M)

headline: An Internet newcomer is making money by selling moving ads as part of screen savers.
abstract: Advertising column explores advertising in cyberspace; Pointcast Inc, an Internet company, has begun what it calls 'Internet broadcasting,' delivering customized news, weather forecasts, stock quotes, sports scores and advertising, directly into computer using Internet connection; its site is already challenging Netscape Communications Corp and Yahoo Inc as one of biggest earners of advertising dollars on the Web (M)

headline: Economics is climbing into the trenches and the real world.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene article on continuing importance of economists despite failure of profession to live up to inflated expectations of 1960's and early 70's; cites examples of smart, relevant economic research; drawing (M)

headline: TA ASSOCIATES JOINS FIGHT FOR ALTAMIRA
abstract: TA Associates Inc says it may offer $582.8 million for Altamira Management Ltd, which would top bid by Manufacturers Life Insurance Co; Almiria Capital Corp, which owns 30.5 percent of Altamira, is seeking injunction to block Manufacturers Life deal (S)

headline: Waiting for the Cod, and Good Times, to Return
abstract: Newfoundland banned commercial fishing for cod in 1992 to give stocks chance to replenish; few cod are still caught to measure catch rates, and there are signs that stocks may be starting to come back; some fishermen from Petty Harbour comment; map; photo (M)

headline: Financial Advice Can Come With Many Different Price Tags
abstract: Various options for paying financial planners and investment advisers explained; consumer advocates, and most customers, prefer fee-only arrangements, to minimize conflict-of-interest issues that might arise in commission sales; more financial planners are shifting to that approach; profiles of planners Gregory D Sullivan, Madeline I Noveck, Arlene McCarthy and Wade M Wacker; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Exchanges Accepted But There's No Rush
abstract: Stores in Brazil do not grant refunds, even for defective products; exchange counters are not busy after Christmas because most exchanges are made well after holiday (S)

headline: U.S. and French Sniping Heats Up Over Paris's Links to Africa
abstract: French officials, continuing unusual diplomatic war of words between Washington and Paris over their relations with Africa, refuse to apologize for remarks by Foreign Assistance Minister Jacques Godfrain suggesting that Sec of State Warren Christopher recently visited Africa as part of electoral ploy (M)

headline: Westinghouse Special Meeting
abstract: Board of Westinghouse Electric Corp holds special meeting, and analysts speculate that directors and management are discussing long-anticipated plan to split company's media and industrial businesses (S)

headline: Investments in Stock Mutual Funds Declined 25% in October
abstract: Investment Company Institute reports that cash flows to equity mutual funds fell 25 percent in October, to $13 billion; cites uncertainty over strength of economy and over outcome of fall elections; independent analysts note that mutual fund companies received resurgent wave of fresh cash in first half of November (M)

headline: BMW Picks Agency For Midwest Ads
abstract: BMW of North America names McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown to handle advertising for its Midwest regional dealers (S)
